book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text:
Imam Al-Biqa'i: His Struggle and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Holy Qur'an
Prepared by: Mahmoud Tawfiq Muhammad Saad, Professor of Rhetoric and Criticism and Head of the Department at the Faculty of Arabic Language, Al-Azhar Al-Sharif University, Shebin El-Kom.
First Edition 1424 AH
All rights reserved to the author.
Important Note: This research was published in Cairo - Wahba Library. Address: Cairo, Al-Goumhouria Street - Abdeen - Phone number 3917470. I have placed it here for those who could not acquire the paper copy.
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
{All praise is due to Allah, Lord of the worlds * The Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful * Sovereign of the Day of Recompense}
O Allah, send prayers upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, as You sent prayers upon Abraham and upon the family of Abraham; indeed, You are Praiseworthy and Glorious. And bless Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, as You blessed Abraham and the family of Abraham; indeed, You are Praiseworthy and Glorious.
As for what follows,
It is the Sunnah (way) of Allah, the Almighty, regarding His creation that whenever a nation strayed far from obedience to Allah, glory be to Him, and His pleasure, and became reckless in sins and disobedience, He would raise a prophet among them or send a messenger {Indeed, We have sent you with the truth as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. And there was no nation but that there had passed within it a warner} (Fatir: 24). This continued until the final nation, the nation of the Arabs, who took polytheism as a religion, injustice as a method, and sins as a profession. So He sent among them the Seal of the Messengers and the most noble of them to Him, the Majestic, our Master Muhammad bin Abdullah, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace. He revealed to him the "Holy Qur'an" and made it the Book confirming what was before it, dominating over it, and abrogating the laws that preceded it:

book_title: Al-Imām al-Biqā‘ī and His Method in Interpreting the Eloquence of the Qur’an
text:
{“And We revealed to you the Book in truth, confirming what came before it of the Scripture and as a guardian over it. So judge between them by what Allah has revealed, and do not follow their desires away from what has come to you of the truth. For each [community] We have made a law and a method. Had Allah willed, He could have made you one community, but [He did so] to test you in what He has given you. So race toward good deeds. To Allah is your return altogether, and He will inform you regarding that in which you used to differ.”} (al-Mā’idah: 48)

Since the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) is the Seal of the Messengers and his ummah—the Ummah of Invitation—is the most widespread in lands and the longest-lasting in time, it is inevitable that some of this ummah, indeed most of it, will fall into great distance from what pleases the Lord of the Worlds, Exalted is He. And because no prophet will come after him, it is from the bounty of Allah upon this ummah that He sends at the head of every hundred years someone who renews for it its religion.

Abū Dāwūd—may Allah be pleased with him—reported in his Sunan, at the beginning of the Book of Malāḥim, with his chain from Abū Hurayrah—may Allah be pleased with them both—that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: “Indeed, Allah sends to this ummah at the head of every hundred years someone who renews for it its religion.”

Those who are sent are the imams of the scholars—the inheritors of the prophets. They renew for this ummah the understanding of its religion, so that its religiosity is renewed and its righteous commitment in conduct according to what came to it from Allah in His Book and from the Prophet (ﷺ) in his purified Sunnah, in the manner that pleases Allah, Exalted is He.

This renewal by the scholars—the inheritors of the prophets—is, in fact, a renewal of understanding of the Book and the Sunnah, an understanding that motivates people toward sound religious commitment to the Book and the Sunnah, and nothing else.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Among the subtleties and marvels of the Prophetic statement is that he called what the scholars who are sent at the beginning of every hundred years do of renewal "Deen" (Religion), meaning religiosity (Tadayyun). In this is a Prophetic indication that what comes from scholars in understanding the religion (the text/the divine and prophetic address to the Ummah) is part of the religion (religiosity) and not something external to the Book and the Sunnah; rather, it is something emerging from them. For the scholar's Ijtihad (independent reasoning) in understanding the Book and the Sunnah according to the principles of correct understanding of them is part of the Book and the Sunnah. Therefore, the Ummah should not feel reassured by an Ijtihad unless it is from a scholar of the Book and the Sunnah and the methods of understanding them. And its reassurance in what comes from the assemblies of the people of knowledge should be stronger than its reassurance in what comes of oddities and unique opinions from individual Ijtihads. We are today in the context of collective Ijtihad, upon which a group of sincere specialized scholars cooperate and collaborate. For in their gathering, consultation, and mutual advice is a safety from stumbling, and from the temptation of a devil or the audacity of a ruler. Also in this is a Prophetic guidance for the Ummah that what scholars produce of Ijtihad in understanding and comprehending the Book and the Sunnah according to the principles of Fiqh (jurisprudence) and understanding from Allah, the Lord of the worlds, and from His Messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, contains the goodness of this Ummah. And that it should accept this goodness and thank Allah, the Almighty, for raising among them those who renew for them their Fiqh and understanding of His Book and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him. Thus, from that renewal in Fiqh and understanding comes the renewal of religiosity through the Book and the Sunnah. In this is also a Prophetic guidance for the Ummah to observe the rights of the scholars of the Book and the Sunnah who act upon them, so their honors and biographies are not attacked, and no corrupt speech is listened to that casts falsehood into the ears of the common people, wounding the images of the Ummah's scholars in the hearts of its children, causing them to turn away from them towards others who earn worldly gains by speaking about the Book of Allah, the Almighty, and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him -

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And in the sending at the beginning of every hundred years is an indication that Allah, the Almighty, out of the abundance of His mercy and compassion, did not leave this Ummah to reside in indulgence in sin and recklessness in distancing from obedience for a long time. Rather, He places in every generation of its generations someone who renews its religion for it, so the darkness does not accumulate upon it, making its extraction from that darkness not difficult. Because one who resides in the darkness of sin for a long time, it becomes not easy for the one who rises to extract him from it to accomplish what he rose for. This is from the overflow of divine aid to the heirs of the Prophet, peace be upon him. The renewer sent at the beginning of every [hundred] years is not necessarily one; rather, the sending can be of more than one in several fields. Hence, I count some of the people of knowledge in a single century and fields of understanding in the Book and the Sunnah, whom Allah, the Almighty, sent to renew for this Ummah its religion: understanding His Book and the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace be upon him, in the ninth Hijri century, as renewers for this Ummah. Among them is "Burhan al-Din al-Biqa'i", the author of the exegesis "Nazm al-Durar" (The Arrangement of Pearls). He renewed for this Ummah the understanding of the Book of Allah, the Almighty. I desired to prepare this book about the life of his mind, the jihad of his pen, and the methodology of his interpretation of the rhetoric of the Holy Qur'an and publish it among the students of knowledge of the Book and the Sunnah. Hence, I made the book into two chapters: The first: His jihad in seeking knowledge and teaching it. The second chapter I dedicated to explaining his methodology in interpreting the rhetoric of the Holy Qur'an. I was keen to mention examples from his exegesis "Nazm al-Durar" because I see it as a landmark of his methodology in interpreting the Holy Qur'an, hoping that reading these examples would entice the reader to read in his exegesis itself, a reading of research and knowledge worthy of patience and perseverance.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In an age where a group proclaims that what sufficed the Companions in the era of Prophethood does not suffice them, and that we must reread the Holy Qur'an a modern reading that keeps pace with the movement of life in the age of (Globalization). So books multiplied with those readings whose primary concern is nothing but trivializing the interpretive heritage of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah and elevating the status of the philosophical interpretation of the Holy Qur'an, which was championed by a group of those attributed to scholars like "Ibn Arabi" and the interpretations of some of the Mu'tazila. Some of those engaged in knowledge strive to spread their rational methodology that elevates itself over the text and call for the text not being prioritized over reason; rather, reason stripped of subordination to the text has authority over the text, even if it is Mutawatir (mass-transmitted). Hence, we saw those who try unsuccessfully to apply foreign methodologies in literary criticism of texts to the Qur'anic discourse. And we saw those who proclaim among their students the necessity of studying the Holy Qur'an as a "literary study" and that any lesson of the Holy Qur'an that is not based on this literary study is a sterile lesson, and that literary study is based on stripping away the belief in the sanctity of the text during its study, so it becomes a subject of criticism like any text. Then, when the literary study of the text ends, one may return to establishing the sanctity of the Qur'anic text in his heart. Just like that, as if the sanctity of the Holy Qur'an and its establishment in the heart is a garment or less that the remover takes off when he wishes and puts on when he wishes. All this under the claim of scientific objectivity in scientific research, and much more than this with which the published newspapers among the people surge.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And perhaps I will soon publish, God willing, among students of knowledge, a book dedicated to clarifying the controls of understanding meaning from the Book and the Sunnah. I have finished, praise be to Allah, the Almighty, preparing its first draft, and I ask Allah, the Almighty, for help in revising and finalizing it. Perhaps there will be help in it for those searching for the truth to gain insight, and perhaps I will demolish some of what the corrupters are building of a mosque of harm (Masjid Dirar), so I would be striving to perform some of what is obligatory upon us of advice (Naseehah) towards the Book of Allah, the Majestic. Imam "Muslim", may Allah be pleased with him, narrated in his Sahih in the Book of Faith with his chain of transmission from "Tamim al-Dari", may Allah be pleased with him, that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, said: "The religion is advice (Naseehah). We said: To whom? He said: "To Allah, His Book, His Messenger, and to the leaders of the Muslims and their common folk." If every student of knowledge and those engaged in it placed that noble Hadith before their eyes, and remembered that the field of Jihad with the word of truth and standing guard (Ribat) in verifying scientific facts in the chapter of creed and Sharia is a vast door of Jihad in the path of Allah, the Almighty, they would find sweet whatever trials and tribulations they encounter in that path. And Allah, the Almighty, has said to us: {And We have made some of you as a trial for others - will you have patience? And your Lord is ever Seeing} (Al-Furqan: from verse 20)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Indeed, among the most severe trials that destroy not a few students of knowledge in our time is the trial of those in authority and power elevating the status of the people of debauchery and disobedience, bringing them close, appointing them to many of the affairs of the country and the people, and lavishing money and forms of honoring upon them, while distancing the people of knowledge and piety and neglecting to honor them if they do good. So, young students of knowledge thought that this justifies for them turning away from striving in the chapter of knowledge and standing guard at the frontiers of Da'wah and enlightening hearts with the meanings of guidance from the Book and the Sunnah. And [they thought] there is in this a justification for them to throw themselves into the embraces of the brothers of devils and increasing the numbers of those who loose and bind (decision-makers) in the affairs of the country. So they hastened to the doors of everyone with authority and turned away from the doors of inheriting from the Master of Messengers, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace. Indeed, what befits every caller to Allah, the Almighty, who strives with the word of truth, is the companionship of Surah "Al-Ankabut" (The Spider) in recitation, understanding, and adopting the character of the meanings of guidance to the Straight Path contained therein. It is a Surah dedicated to inciting striving in enjoining good and forbidding evil, and confronting the falsehood of the people of the world. For in their falsehood, even if they appear strong and fortified in apparent view, they are in reality protecting themselves with what is flimsier than a spider's web; none falls into it except he who is deceived by it. As for the people of insight, they are capable of uprooting it. {Alif, Lam, Meem * Do the people think that they will be left to say, "We believe" and they will not be tried? * But We have certainly tried those before them, and Allah will surely make evident those who are truthful, and He will surely make evident the liars} (Al-Ankabut: 1-3) {And those who strive for Us - We will surely guide them to Our ways. And indeed, Allah is with the doers of good} (Al-Ankabut: 69)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: So look wisely at the beginning of the recitation from that Surah and its end, for in it is what every caller to Allah, the Almighty – and every Muslim is a caller by the tongue of his state – needs to stand for a long time in understanding and comprehending the meanings of guidance to the Straight Path hidden within it. If you add to that the understanding and comprehension of the meanings of guidance in Surah (An-Nahl), you will have from that a generous provision that does not perish, and whose wonders and delights do not end. Indeed, what benefits the student of knowledge and helps him, by the permission of Allah, the Almighty, is the good reading of the lives of the Imams among the scholars of the Book and the Sunnah, especially in eras of tyranny and the abundance of worldly enjoyment. For in every era of those eras, there are Imams scholars who bit onto guidance with their molar teeth and held fast to guidance, and did not cast their foreheads under the shoes of those in authority, but rather spoke the word of truth and lit the lamps of guidance in the darkness of falsehood. Indeed, it is upon us to present the lives of those scholars standing tall in the face of tyranny, patient in supporting the truth and patient against the temptation of money, authority, and prestige scattered from under the feet of Satan. O Allah, I ask You by my bearing witness that there is no god but You, the One, the Eternal Refuge, who begets not nor was born, and there is none co-equal or comparable to Him, to send blessings, peace, and blessings upon Your servant, Prophet, and Messenger Muhammad bin Abdullah, and upon his family, wives, companions, and his heirs among the people of knowledge in every glance and breath, the number of Your creation, the satisfaction of Your Self, the weight of Your Throne, and the ink of Your words. And to make me, my parents, my offspring, and my household among the people of the Holy Qur'an outwardly and inwardly in both abodes. And to raise by the Holy Qur'an my mention among Your righteous servants in this world and the Hereafter. {Our Lord, give us in this world [that which is] good and in the Hereafter [that which is] good and protect us from the punishment of the Fire} (Al-Baqarah: from verse 201)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And reward Your servant "Burhan al-Din al-Biqa'i" for the Holy Qur'an with the best reward, for he was, as I reckon and I do not purify anyone before Allah, the Almighty, advising towards the Book of Allah, the Majestic, with what he presented to us of his exegesis: (Nazm al-Durar). And reward him on my behalf and on behalf of the students of knowledge of the Book of Allah, the Almighty, and the Arabic tongue with the best of what You rewarded a scholar for the students of his knowledge. And reward my parents on my behalf for raising me when I was small and enticing me to be among the people seeking knowledge of the Book of Allah, the Almighty, and the Sunnah of His Messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace. And reward on my behalf with the best reward, the most generous, and the most lasting, my Sheikh: "Muhammad Abu Musa", before whose generous hands I sat giving in the halls of knowledge at Al-Azhar Al-Sharif University. For he has a lasting, glorious, praiseworthy hand in my love for seclusion with the understanding of the Arabic tongue in high eloquence, poetry and prose, and the High Miraculous Eloquence: Qur'an and Sunnah, and in publishing that and teaching it to the servants. He taught me - may Allah honor him - that this is a major door among the doors of saving the Ummah from the clutches of ignorance and humiliation. He - may Allah elevate his mention with the Holy Qur'an in both abodes - had and still has a penetrating influence on many students of Arabic knowledge. He cast the light of his mind and heart on the path, so he paved and enticed. Scarcely anyone denies his virtue and hand except an ignorant or a resentful person. His effect will remain in us, God willing, as long as we have life on earth. And sufficient for him of the bliss of this world is that. And may Allah send blessings, peace, and blessings upon His servant, Prophet, and Messenger Muhammad bin Abdullah, and upon his family, wives, companions, and his heirs among the people of knowledge and those who align with him in every glance and breath to the number of everything known to Him. And praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds. Written by Mahmoud Tawfiq Muhammad Saad, Professor at Al-Azhar University, Cairo: Hadayek El-Zaitoun, Rabi' al-Awwal 1423

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Chapter One: His Jihad in Seeking Knowledge and Teaching It. His Jihad: Introduction. Indeed, when Allah, the Almighty, made His servant our Master Muhammad, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, the Seal of the Prophets and Messengers, and made his religion: Islam, the seal of religions, and for all people: {And We have not sent you except comprehensively to mankind as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. But most of the people do not know} (Saba: 28). And since people are in need of someone to take their hands to the Straight Path: {The path of Allah, to whom belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. Unquestionably, to Allah do [all] matters evolve} (Ash-Shura: 53), He made that the mission of the scholars after him, peace be upon him. So they were the stars of the Ummah as he, peace be upon him, informed in what "Ahmad", may Allah be pleased with them, narrated in his Musnad from "Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with them:" The Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, said: "The likeness of the scholars on earth is like the stars in the sky by which one is guided in the darkness of the land and sea. If the stars are obliterated, the guides are on the verge of going astray" (Musnad Ahmad vol. 3 p. 157). And He made them the heirs of the Prophets: "Ahmad", may Allah be pleased with them, narrated in his Musnad from "Abu Darda, may Allah be pleased with them" that he heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, say: "... Indeed, the scholars are the heirs of the Prophets. They did not inherit a Dinar nor a Dirham, but rather they inherited knowledge. So whoever takes it has taken an abundant share" (Musnad Ahmad: 5/196). According to the amount of a person's intellect is the amount of his striving to take from the inheritance of Prophethood in word and deed. So there were many in the Ummah in the past who strove to take from the inheritance of Prophethood; to undertake the clarification of the Straight Path in everything that arises from the renewed movement of life.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And indeed, what also entices one to be keen on being a person of knowledge is standing upon the glorious biography of scholars, especially those who approached seeking it seeking reward with an open heart. They did not adopt in seeking it the methodology of repeating what came from their predecessors, but rather adopted a critical methodology that invests in high and noble speech and adds to it; because of what came in the majestic Prophetic wisdom: "At-Tirmidhi", may Allah be pleased with them, narrated with his chain from Hudhayfah, may Allah be pleased with them, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, said: "Do not be a blind follower (Imma'ah), saying: If the people do good, we do good, and if they do injustice, we do injustice. But discipline yourselves: if the people do good, you do good, and if they do evil, you do not do injustice" (Sahih Al-Tirmidhi: Book: Righteousness - Hadith: 2007). Scholars are the most capable of the Ummah to discipline themselves with this tempting Prophetic wisdom towards a critical methodology for everything that the movement of life brings. It is a methodology that no one is capable of except one who has a good origin and pasture, a lofty goal, seeing the world as it is with its Creator, so he does not place it in his heart above its reality. Thus, he wonders at one who tempts a scholar with it, when his Lord, the Almighty, has made him an heir of Prophethood, not an heir of a kingdom that vanishes. And he wonders even more at one who affiliates himself with the people of knowledge and looks up to what the hand of the ruler waves of the scraps of the world. And "Burhan al-Din al-Biqa'i" is, as I reckon - and I do not purify anyone before Allah, the Almighty - one of those scholars striving in seeking knowledge, teaching it, and publishing his beneficial books in the Ummah. He presented to his Ummah many books of beneficial knowledge, so I desired to inform the students of knowledge about something of his struggle.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Chapter One: His Jihad in Seeking Knowledge and Teaching It. The Origin and Pasture.. At the beginning of the ninth Hijri century and in the land of Sham, there was the arrival of a man who would have, with the revolutionizing and pondering of the Holy Qur'an, a methodology that would raise his mention among his peers in his era, then in the successive eras after him, and make his mention prominent among those standing to ponder the generous Qur'anic statement. They are many before him and after him, their number hardly countable, but he will have the privilege of being a head in one of the methodologies of rhetorical pondering of the Holy Qur'an. Even if he was not the founder of that methodology, he is the one raising its bases, standing guard at its frontier defending it, and completing its structure. That one coming from the land of Beqaa, attributed to it, so he placed it on the tongues of many people of knowledge, thus being dutiful to its mention: "Ibrahim bin Umar bin Hasan al-Rubat bin Ali bin Abi Bakr" "Abu al-Hasan Burhan al-Din al-Biqa'i". His lineage ends - as he mentions - with our master "Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas al-Zuhri", may Allah be pleased with them (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: His birth was in the village of "Khirbat Roha" in the Beqaa al-Azizi in the land of Sham in the year eight hundred and nine of the Hijra. This date was transmitted from him by those who chronicled him (1). He remained alive in this world for seventy-six years, suffering from hardship and grief what he suffered, until he departed to his Lord, the Almighty, on the night of Saturday, the eighth of the month of Rajab in the year eight hundred and eighty-five (885) in Damascus and was buried on Saturday in the Hamidiyya cemetery towards the grave of "Atika" in Damascus (2). *** His Creed and Jurisprudential School: In the chapter of creed, "Al-Biqa'i" was on the methodology of the Ash'aris, and in the jurisprudence of Sharia on the methodology of Imam Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him. He did not suffice with that but studied the Maliki school under his Sheikh "Al-Mashdali" at Al-Azhar Al-Sharif, and studied "Al-Muwatta" under his Sheikh Muhammad bin Ali al-Safawi" in Cairo in the year eight hundred and thirty-seven (3). Combining two schools of jurisprudence in study after mastering one of them is an aid to broad intellectual vision and penetrating insight. The difference in schools of jurisprudence is based on a difference in the methodology of insight into the texts of the Book and Sunnah on one hand, and insight into the movement of life and the civilizational context in which the owner of the school and its student stand. A jurist is not one who devotes himself to memorizing the opinions of the people of knowledge and his chest contains what they wrote in their papers and books while isolating himself from the movement of his people's life and the context of their temporal and spatial existence. If the Sharia of Islam is valid for every time and place as is famous, it is also reforming for every time and place. There is no era or city where corruption prevailed and it surrendered its affair to the Sharia of Islam as a patient surrenders his affair to his doctor, except that it was healed and its glory, honor, and security returned to it. Indeed, upon the jurists of the Ummah in this era of ours and the eras following it is a necessary obligation that no individual among their group can perform alone:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: They must have profound awareness of the movement of life which is renewing feverishly, necessitating that it be accompanied by a movement of profound understanding of that movement in the light of the Book and the Sunnah, and striving towards what keeps people within the circle of obedience and distancing them from the embarrassment of restriction and strictness, and from obligating them to avoid what the evidences have not decisively prohibited if a need compels them to approach it. The good lies in leaving for the people - especially the common folk - a wide space of the permissible and of what the verified pious scholars' investigations have not unanimously agreed upon its prohibition. For the temptations of life are stronger than the pillars of faith in the hearts of not a few people. If words of prohibition not definitively indicated by texts pour into their ears regarding everything they ask about, the ways of escape are many. Let our jurists be Rabbani (godly), and such will not be realized if their sights and insights are confined to what the four schools of jurisprudence brought. In the heritage of our scholars before those four Imams, with them, and after them, are Ijtihads of Imams and scholars who are no less in status in their knowledge, Ijtihad, and advice to Allah, the Almighty, His Book, His Messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, and the Muslim leaders and their common folk, seeking the pleasure of their Lord, glory be to Him. It is worthy of us to revive the study of their heritage and benefit from the principles of consideration they had. *** His Scientific Journeys: The First Stage: (809 - 835). When Al-Biqa'i reached the age of discernment, he received several sciences in his village "Khirbat Roha". He read the Holy Qur'an to his uncle Al-Shihab Al-Biqa'i (770-820) and memorized it. He attended the Zawiya of Sheikh "Musa" to review his memorization of the Holy Qur'an, and led prayers with it (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This is a sign of his mastery of memorization and recitation, and this is a majestic methodology revealing the student's mastery of memorizing the Book of Allah, glory be to Him. Would that we adopt the like of it in teaching our students in the early stages of education at our noble Al-Azhar, granting our students the ability to recite the Holy Qur'an well after memorizing it; because praying with it in audible congregation is one of the factors stabilizing its memorization in the chest. Then a calamity befell his people in the twenty-first year of the ninth century (821), while the boy was in the twelfth year of his life. The calamity claimed a group of his family: his father, his two uncles, and six others. So he leaves his village with his mother and grandfather, moving through several villages: entering the villages of Wadi al-Taym and al-Arqub, remaining there until he entered Damascus" in the year (823). He becomes active in seeking knowledge: studying Al-Shatibiyyah up to Surah Al-Munafiqun under his Sheikh "Sharaf al-Din al-Masharati" (d. 825) (1). He reads grammar, morphology, jurisprudence, and rational sciences under his favorite Sheikh "Muhammad bin Bahadur" (d. 831) and sticks to him (2). He receives logic from Sheikh "Al-Badr Al-Hindi" (d. 833), student of Al-Sayyid Al-Sharif (d. 816). The Sheikh admires him and promises to teach him "the science of geometry," but "Al-Badr" left Damascus for "Hama" before he could fulfill his promise (3). In the year (828), he studies the ten readings under Al-Shams bin Al-Jazari (d. 833), memorizes "Al-Nashr fi al-Qira'at al-Ashr", and he grants him license (Ijazah) for everything permissible for the Sheikh (4). He travels to "Jerusalem" for the first time with his mother, studying there "the science of arithmetic" under his Sheikh "Al-Imad bin Sharaf" (d. 852). He memorizes the two poems of "Ibn Al-Ha'im" in algebra and the rules of inflection, presenting them to his Sheikh "Al-Imad", who admires him and entitles him Sheikh, Imam, and the Proficient Reciter (5).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In Ramadan of the same year, his mother died in Jerusalem. He remains there until the month of "Dhu al-Qi'dah", then travels to Damascus. There he memorizes the book "Al-Bahjah Nazm Al-Hawi" in Shafi'i jurisprudence, and reads "Al-Hawi" with "Ibn Qadi Shuhba" as a research reading. He completes the authorship of his book: "Kifayat al-Qari wa Ghunyat al-Muqri fi Riwayat Abi Amr" (1). He reads under "Taqi al-Din al-Hisni al-Shafi'i" (d. 828) his commentary on Al-Tanbih and Al-Minhaj. He remains attached to his Sheikh "Ibn Bahadur" until the Sheikh's death in the year (831). So "Al-Biqa'i" leaves Damascus again for "Jerusalem", adding to his poem: "Al-Baha fi 'Ilm al-Hisab wa al-Masaha" which he started in the year (827). He studies the book "Al-Wasilah fi al-Hisab wa al-Fiqh wa al-Fara'id" under his Sheikh "Zayn al-Din Mahir bin Abdullah", student of Ibn Al-Ha'im. He receives "grammar" from Al-Taj Al-Gharabili (d. 835) and studies the book "Al-Tuhfah" by Ibn Hajar under "Al-Imad bin Sharaf". He remains in Jerusalem looking forward to meeting "Ibn Hajar". When a need arose for him in "Hebron", he traveled there and from there to "Gaza", then came the journey to "Cairo". He entered it and stood before "Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani" in the month of Safar the Good in the year (834). He wrote a number of his Sheikh's works and read them to him, and he permitted him to teach (2). He heard in this trip from the scholars of Cairo. He does not stay in Cairo for long, returning to "Jerusalem" again in the same year, receiving "Sunan Abi Dawood" and others from some Sheikhs of "Jerusalem".

1. (1) - - 'Unwan al-Zaman: 1/32 
2. - 'Unwan al-Zaman: 1/162, Al-Dhayl 'ala Raf' al-Isr by Al-Sakhawi: 68, Al-Nujum al-Zahirah: 15/523, Shadharat al-Dhahab: 7/270

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He looks forward to residing in Cairo, so he returns to it in the year (835) to remain there for forty-five years. Thus ends one stage of his stages of receiving knowledge, to begin another stage where he combines receiving knowledge from its luminaries and teaching students of knowledge what he received, keen on being the learner-teacher. That is the way of the intelligent person among those affiliated with this Muhammadan nation in goal and method. For there is no good in a day in which a person does not learn beneficial knowledge, nor teach a Muslim what benefits him, whether by the tongue of his speech or pen, or by the tongue of his state, deeds, and morals. ***** The Second Stage: (835 - 880). In this stage, he took Cairo as a home and homeland, and undertook some travels inside the Egyptian lands and outside them. He used to reside in Cairo above a mosque in "Rahbat Bab al-Eid", which is a wide square that was in front of the eastern gate of the Great Fatimid Palace built by "Jawhar al-Siqilli" for Al-Mu'izz Al-Fatimi. It is now branching from Qasr al-Shawq Street in Al-Ghouriya at Al-Azhar, and "Rahbat Bab al-Eid" Street still exists and is populated. "Al-Biqa'i" assumed the function of "Mu'id" (Repetitor) in this mosque and in the "Al-Zahir" mosque. It is a function whose holder undertakes making some students understand what they could not understand from the Sheikh, repeating the lesson to them with some clarification as Al-Taj Al-Subki says in "Mu'id al-Ni'am".

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Would that this mosque: Al-Zahir Mosque, be cared for now regarding education and Da'wah in it, to be a scientific educational beacon in that area where it stands. For its neighbors are in dire need for the light of beneficial knowledge to shine upon them from it. It is not sufficient for it to be an Islamic monument viewed by non-Muslims while the sons of Islam do not benefit from it with anything other than performing the obligatory prayers, then the doors are closed in their faces. Mosques in Islam are not only for performing prayers, but they are likewise institutes of education, assemblies of consultation, and homes of mercy and connection. However, the people, fearing for the chairs of their emirates, trembled with fear that the youth would meet under the care of a scholar reciting the Book of Allah, glory be to Him, and studying it among themselves. So the mosques were closed outside the times of obligatory prayers, and brothels were opened at all times and for whoever desired. Al-Biqa'i remained attached to his Sheikh "Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani" in his residence and travels until the death of "Ibn Hajar" (d. 852). "Al-Biqa'i" was active in authorship during this stage. Among his travels with "Ibn Hajar" was his trip to Sham in the year (836) in the company of Sultan "Barsbay". There he reads with some Sheikhs of Sham like Al-Burhan Al-Tarabulsi, "Ibn Sheikh al-Souq al-Hanbali", "Ibn al-Adim", and Al-Shihab Al-Ramli". He sought to meet the poet "Ibn Hijjah al-Hamawi", but it was not facilitated for him (1). In the year (837), he returns with his Sheikh "Ibn Hajar" to Cairo, so he increases reading with its scholars: He reads with "Al-Maqrizi" the historian some of his works, and with "Al-Mashdali" exegesis and Maliki jurisprudence, learning from him the general rule for the proportionality of the verses and Surahs of the Holy Qur'an, and establishes on its basis his great exegesis: "Nazm al-Durar". He reads with "Al-Badr Al-Busiri", and with "Ibn al-Safawi". He reads grammar, rhetoric, Tafsir al-Kashshaf, logic, jurisprudence, and its principles with "Al-Qayati". He reads with "Al-Zayn Al-Mahalli", "Shihab al-Din al-Jawhari", and with "Sharaf al-Din al-Qalqashandi".

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He reads with some people of knowledge from the women of Cairo such as: Zaynab bint al-Zayn al-Iraqi, and Kulthum bint al-Zayn al-Babili (1). He strives in taking from scholars in various arts of knowledge. He chronicled his Sheikhs in his valuable book "'Unwan al-Zaman" which is in four manuscript volumes at the Egyptian National Library. He toured the towns of the (Delta) of Egypt reading with some people of knowledge there, recording biographies of some of them, and meeting some of its poets. He travels to the land of Hejaz for Hajj in the year (848) and stays for a year touring "Al-Jazirah" and taking from some of its scholars. Then he returns to Cairo in the year (849) resuming his reception and attachment to his Sheikh Ibn Hajar. He participates in Jihad and Ribat in Damietta in the years (851) and (852). He returns to Cairo residing there until the year (880). Numerous severe events and tribulations happened to him in Egypt due to his confronting what he saw as evil that is not permissible to remain silent about, so he leaves it for "Damascus" (2). What had an impact on his life and his status after his exegesis was his confrontation of tampering with the principles of Islamic creed, especially the purity of the doctrine of Tawheed. He saw in spreading the thought of atheism and saying unity of existence (Wahdat al-Wujud) and promoting the essays of "Ibn al-Farid" and "Ibn Arabi" an internal aggression on the Ummah. So he stood guard at this frontier whose danger is more severe than the frontiers attacked by the armies of the enemies of Islam. He drew his pen and tongue and confronted the brothers of falsehood. He had with atheistic thought represented in the heritage of "Ibn al-Farid" and "Ibn Arabi" battles recorded in history books: "Ibn Iyas al-Hanafi" says in the history of events of the year eight hundred and seventy-five:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "And in the beginning of this year, gossip increased among the scholars in Cairo regarding the matter of the Sheikh, the Knower of Allah the Exalted, my master "Umar bin al-Farid" may Allah benefit people with his blessing [!!! sic]. A group of scholars showed bias against him because of verses he said in his poem "Al-Ta'iyyah". They objected to him regarding that, and explicitly declared his debauchery, even his disbelief, and attributed him to those who say incarnation (Hulul) and union (Ittihad). Far be it from him to be attributed this meaning, but the understandings of a group of scholars of this age fell short, and they did not understand the meaning of Sheikh "Umar's" saying in what he intended by these verses. So they took them literally and did not direct a meaning for them. It was as Al-Mutanabbi said: 'How many fault a correct statement * And its bane is from the sickly understanding.' 'But minds take from it * According to the capacities and understandings.' The head of those who showed bias against Sheikh "Umar bin al-Farid" was: "Burhan al-Din al-Biqa'i", and the Chief Judge: "Muhibb al-Din bin al-Shihna", and a large group of students of knowledge followed them saying he was a debauchee. As for those who showed bias for Ibn al-Farid among the scholars, they were: Sheikh Muhyi al-Din al-Kafiyaji al-Hanafi, and Sheikh al-Qasim al-Hanafi.... When the agitation increased in this issue, fatwas were written regarding the matter of "Ibn al-Farid" whose appearance is departure from the rules of Sharia. So Sheikh Muhyi al-Din al-Kafiyaji wrote on this question what is the best expression and closest to justice 0. And Al-Jalal Al-Suyuti composed a book on that naming it: "Qam' al-Mu'arid fi al-Radd 'an Ibn al-Farid" (Suppressing the Opposer in Defending Ibn al-Farid). And "Al-Badri bin al-Fars" composed a healing book on this meaning clear in refuting those who objected to "Ibn al-Farid". And some scholars authored a book naming it: "Diryaq al-Afa'i fi al-Radd 'ala al-Biqa'i" (The Antidote of Snakes in Refuting Al-Biqa'i). Contentions occurred in this issue among the scholars which would take long to explain in this meaning. Then they satirized "Al-Biqa'i" and "Ibn al-Shihna" and others who showed bias against "Ibn al-Farid" and began writing papers satirizing the objectors to "Ibn al-Farid" and sticking those papers on his shrine....

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Then some Emirs showed bias for Ibn al-Farid, indeed the Sultan also showed bias for him.... As for "Al-Biqa'i", the common people almost killed him, and he received from the Emirs what had no good in it, so he fled and hid....." (1). "Al-Biqa'i" stood guard struggling against the aggression of the people of falsehood upon the purity of the doctrine of Tawheed. So there was nothing left but to migrate from Egypt to "Damascus". This which "Al-Biqa'i" undertook is an obligation upon the people of knowledge to undertake the like of in every age and city. For if the people of falsehood know that their proclaiming of falsehood will meet eloquent hardship from the people of truth, they will not proclaim their falsehood. Falsehood will not appear except from the weakness of the people of truth, their silence, and their leniency in repelling what arises of evidences of falsehood. For falsehood and its people are too weak to triumph by themselves; their victory is only from the weakness of their enemies, the people of truth. This stage of "Al-Biqa'i's" life is the richest stage of his life in learning, teaching, and authorship, and in acquiring many scientific and social skills. I think this stage is what resulted in him becoming one of those whose heritage a serious student of the sciences of the Holy Qur'an cannot dispense with. He is distinguished in this over his peers like Al-Sakhawi in that what he presented of scientific heritage cannot be replaced by others, especially his majestic exegesis: "Nazm al-Durar fi al-Ayat wa al-Suwar". As for Al-Sakhawi, although he presented what he is praised for, there is in what others presented what suffices from it.
foot_note: 1. (1) – Bada'i' al-Zuhur fi Waqa'i' al-Duhur by Ibn Iyas al-Hanafi: Vol 3 p. 47-51 – Ed: Muhammad Mustafa

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And Al-Biqa'i is distinguished from his student Al-Suyuti in that Al-Suyuti, although more famous and prolific, what he presented is dominated by compilation, arrangement, and classification, and he does not have much in it that is unique to him over others. Whoever analyzes many of "Al-Suyuti's" books can return what is in them to their owners from the scholars preceding or contemporary to Al-Suyuti, leaving him with nothing of them that can be pointed to. A person has nothing from his books except what his heart produced of the subtleties of knowledge, not what his memory contained of the sayings of others, especially in this time of ours where tools for preserving knowledge have become very numerous and easy 0. Al-Biqa'i has in his exegesis at least very much of what you hardly find with a predecessor or contemporary to him. For his scientific personality stands in his exegesis traversing it and cutting across it lengthwise and breadthwise, so his tone and breath hardly disappear from you. That is the affair of the glorious scholar. Hence, I claim that he and his Sheikh "Ibn Hajar" are among the renewers in the ninth Hijri century. ***** The Third Stage: From the year 880-885. This stage begins with his departure from Cairo to Damascus, and ends with his departure to his Lord, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. In Damascus, "Ibn Qadi Ajlun" (d. 928) and his students receive him and exaggerate in honoring and revering him for what reached him of his knowledge. He remains in the generosity of Ibn Qadi Ajlun until a fitnah erupts known as the fitnah of (There is nothing in possibility more wondrous than what was), which is a philosophical proposition said by "Al-Ghazali". "Al-Biqa'i" confronts it, refutes the opinions of those who say it, and writes about this. "Ibn Qadi Ajlun" does not approve of this from him, out of partisanship for Al-Ghazali.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i does not soften, for men are known by the truth and truth is not known by men. And Al-Ghazali or anyone else besides the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, is not infallible such that some of what he brings cannot be rejected. So "Ibn Qadi Ajlun" and his students turn away from "Al-Biqa'i"; indeed, some people attack Al-Biqa'i because of that (1). He is tested in Cairo with the fitnah of Ibn Arabi and Ibn al-Farid, and tested in Damascus with the fitnah of: "There is nothing in possibility more wondrous than what was". But he does not submit except to the truth he sees with evidence from the Book and the Sunnah and believes in. During his stay in Damascus, he authors some of his books and treatises, edits, and produces the fair copy of his final version of his exegesis "Nazm al-Durar". He finishes this editing in the afternoon of Sunday, the tenth of Sha'ban in the year eight hundred and eighty-two at his house adjacent to the "Badra'iyyah" School in Damascus, meaning three years before his death (2). Seventy-six years Al-Biqa'i lived struggling, not softening, nor slackening, nor tiring. He knew the value of life and the greatness of what he was coming to of meeting his Lord, glory be to Him, and His questioning him about his life and in what he spent it. So he strove to prepare for this majestic question an answer with which he would not regret nor be disgraced. If every one of us occupied himself with searching for a praiseworthy answer to this divine question to him on the Day of Resurrection, you would not find a Muslim reckless in killing his leisure times, nor consuming his life in what leaves him nothing praiseworthy and glorious upon departing to his destiny.

1. (1) - Al-Fatawa al-Hadithiyyah by Ibn Hajar al-Haythami al-Makki: p. 4 - Ed: 139 - Mustafa al-Halabi Cairo 
2. – Nazm al-Durar: Vol 22 p. 443, Tahdim al-Arkan min Laysa fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan by Al-Biqa'i – Plate 25 – Manuscript photographed in the Zakiyyah Treasury at the Egyptian National Library No./34, and Al-Badr al-Tali' by Al-Sakhawi: Vol 1/21, Shadharat al-Dhahab: 8/158

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: What remains for Al-Biqa'i – God willing, and I do not purify anyone before Allah, the Almighty – is his struggle in establishing a majestic methodology for interpreting the Qur'anic statement, an interpretation that guides to knowledge of some features of the Great Qur'anic Inimitability, and guides to knowledge of some subtleties of the truths of the meanings of guidance to the Straight Path. So one ascends with this knowledge in the stations of proximity to the Lord of the worlds, and moves in the teeth of obedience from the start of faith (those who believe) to its end (the believers), and from it to the start of piety (those who fear Allah) then to its end (the pious), to enter after that into the tooth of Ihsan (those who do good), worshipping Allah, the Almighty, certain that Allah, the Almighty, sees him so he does not turn to other than Him, then to the end of Ihsan (the doers of good), worshipping Allah, glory be to Him, as if he sees his Lord, the Almighty, tasting the sweetness of proximity and intimacy with obedience to the Lord of the worlds. ******* His Sheikhs and Students: It is not hidden that the working scholar is indeed an heir of the Prophet, peace be upon him, an inheritance of upbringing and education {Be Rabbaniyyin (pious scholars) because of what you have taught of the Scripture and because of what you have studied} (Al Imran: from verse 79). And every intelligent noble student of knowledge is but the fruit of a sincere effort of a Sheikh or Sheikhs sincere in their teaching and upbringing. This entices every parent to be keen on placing his child before a Sheikh who instills in the student's heart the love of beneficial knowledge and acting upon it, and its elevation over every enjoyment of the worldly life. That is more worthy of keenness to realize for his child than his keenness to realize for him fleeting enjoyment and false prestige. Our righteous predecessors did not throw their children before everyone who threw himself into the field of education. For how many an educator is in more need of being educated, and how many a teacher is in more need of someone to teach him, especially in this time of ours where not a few of those engaged in education are the great danger to the morals of the youth.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Many fathers have begun throwing their children under the hands of secular people who take what is known as private education for languages as a way to bring up the nation's children an upbringing not connected to the Book of Allah, the Almighty, and the Sunnah of His Messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace. They repeat to their hearing what contradicts the explicit Book and Sunnah without mentioning to them what came in the Book and Sunnah contradicting their teachings so that some of those children or parents do not feel embarrassed. So children grew up in the Ummah for whom the evil (Munkar) religiously is with them the good (Ma'ruf), and the good religiously is the evil from which they flee as they flee from everything hateful to them. If a nation reaches the point where evil transforms in it into good that is sought eagerly and boasted about, and the rulers, those affiliated with knowledge, its students, and the common people respect its people for it, and the general public believes that this is from the opening of Allah, glory be to Him, upon its owner and His honoring of him, then that nation has approached the edge of a crumbling cliff that may collapse with it into the fire of Hell, and Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people. Saving this nation at that time is very difficult, but it is not impossible, which imposes upon its scholars struggle and perseverance, and mutual advice with truth, patience, and mercy. Indeed, upon us – we fathers – is to choose well the places of our children's education and choose their Sheikhs, and to teach them that the message of the Sheikh is from the message of the Prophet: good advice seeking reward. There is no deed at all that is descended from the deed of Prophethood like the deed of teaching people good. Hence, its reward was great: Al-Tirmidhi narrated with his chain from "Abu Umamah Al-Bahili", may Allah be pleased with them, that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, said:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Indeed Allah, His angels, and the inhabitants of the heavens and the earths, even the ant in its hole, and even the whale, send blessings upon those who teach people good" (Sahih Al-Tirmidhi: Book of Knowledge, Chapter: What came regarding the virtue of Fiqh - Hadith: 2685) ... And the reader of the book of "Al-Qabisi": Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Muhammad bin Khalaf (324 - 403) titled: "Al-Mufassalah li-Ahwal al-Muta'allimin wa Ahkam al-Mu'allimin wa al-Muta'allimin" (The Detailed [Exposition] of the Conditions of Learners and the Rules of Teachers and Learners) sees what it contains of the status and effect of the Sheikh on his student, which necessitates every teacher to fear Allah, glory be to Him, regarding his students, for he is the role model. "Utbah bin Abi Sufyan" said to "Abd al-Samad bin Abd al-A'la al-Shaybani" when he came as a tutor for his son: "Let the first thing you begin with in reforming my sons be reforming yourself, for their eyes are tied to your eye. The good to them is what you deem good, and the ugly to them is what you deem ugly. Teach them the Book of Allah, the Almighty, and do not force them upon it lest they become bored of it, nor leave them from it lest they abandon it. Then narrate to them of poetry its most chaste, and of Hadith [i.e., speech] its most noble. Do not take them out of one knowledge to another until they master it, for the crowding of speech in the hearing is misleading to understanding. Teach them the biographies of the wise and the morals of the cultured. Keep them away from conversing with women. Threaten them with me, and discipline them without me [i.e., not in their father's presence]. Be for them like the doctor who does not hasten with medicine until he knows the disease. Do not rely on my excuse, for I have relied on your sufficiency. Increase in disciplining them, and I will increase in kindness to you, God willing" (1). His Sheikhs:
foot_note: 1. (1) – Al-Bayan wa al-Tabyin by Al-Jahiz: 2/73 – Ed: Harun – Ed: 1405 – Al-Khanji in Cairo

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i met in the stages of his receiving knowledge, which I summarized, many scholars and received from many of them in many of the countries he traveled to. The countries where he met scholars the most were Cairo then Damascus. He was not on an equal level in his reception from those scholars, nor was he attached to many of them with the attachment of studentship. Perhaps the most attached to him were his Sheikh Ibn Bahadur, and his Sheikh Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani. I am not here to classify them in terms of the sciences he received from them, for he used to receive a single science from more than one scholar in more than one country; indeed, he used to receive a single book from more than one Sheikh. The dictionary of his Sheikhs and peers overflows with the mention of his Sheikhs and what he received from them and his conditions with them, and with the mention of his peers. It is a vast dictionary that filled four manuscript volumes. I desired to suffice here with transferring Al-Biqa'i's biography of some of them from his manuscript dictionary to be a model of his methodology on one hand and biographies of his Sheikhs and students on the other, but I did not succeed in that. Transferring that from his manuscript dictionary completely was difficult for me due to lack of time and effort and numerous preoccupations, especially since many of his Sheikhs are luminaries whose biographies are presented in several references. I saw fit to arrange some of his Sheikhs according to the date of their death, and to summarize the biography by pointing to them and the sources of their biographies: Sharaf al-Din al-Masharati: Sadaqah bin Salamah bin Husayn bin Badran bin Ibrahim al-Jayduri (760-825). Al-Masharati with a Fatha on Meem, Sukun on Seen, and Fatha on Ha is attributed to the village of Mashara from the works of "Al-Jaydur" a stage away from Damascus. He had extreme care for readings, and the Sheikhdom of recitation in Damascus ended up with him. He taught readings in the Umayyad Mosque. Crowds in Damascus benefited from him, and most of its Sheikhs graduated through him. Al-Biqa'i read "Al-Shatibiyyah" with him and recited the Glorious Qur'an well with him up to Surah "Al-Munafiqun".

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Sharaf has works including: Al-Tatimmah fi al-Qira'at al-Thalathah al-A'immah (1). ***** Al-Taqi Al-Hisni: Abu Bakr bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Mu'min bin Hariz bin Mu'alla bin Musa al-Ja'fari al-Husayni al-Dimashqi al-Shafi'i, his lineage ends with our master Al-Husayn may Allah be pleased with him (742-829). A Muhaddith and Faqih, fanatical about the Ash'ari school, exaggerated in attacking "Ibn Taymiyyah" may Allah be pleased with them, and many fitnas arose because of that. An ascetic standing for enjoining good and forbidding evil as he believes in it. He has several works including: Exegesis of the Holy Qur'an up to Al-An'am, commentary on Al-Tanbih in five volumes, commentary on Sahih Muslim in three volumes, summarized the Takhrīj of "Ihya' 'Ulum al-Din" in a volume, commentary on Al-Arba'in in a volume, "Siyar Nisa' al-Salaf al-'Abidat" in a volume, "Qawa'id al-Fiqh" in two volumes, and "Sharh Asma' Allah al-Husna" in a volume. He was solid in religiosity and desirous of austerity and isolation. Despite that, his followers increased until he refrained from talking to people. He has stories in asceticism and minimizing [worldly needs] matching what was transmitted about the ancients. A world [of people] attended his funeral that only Allah, glory be to Him, can count (2). ***** Sibt Ibn al-Shahid: Taj al-Din Abu Hamid Muhammad bin Bahadur bin Abdullah known as Sibt Ibn al-Shahid (d. 831). A grammarian Faqih. Al-Biqa'i read grammar, morphology, jurisprudence, and rational sciences with him. He says about him: I did not obtain from anyone the benefit I obtained from him. He knew many sciences and would solve any book read to him. Eloquent in expression, good in presentation, sound in mind, religious, intensely withdrawn from people (3). ***** Al-Shams bin Al-Jazari: Abu al-Khayr Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Yusuf al-Jazari, attributed to Jazirat "Ibn Umar" (751-833 AH).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He read with "Ibn al-Sallar", "Ibrahim al-Hamawi", and "Ibn al-Labban". In Egypt with "Abu Bakr bin al-Jundi", "Abu Abdullah bin al-Sa'igh", "Ibn Umaylah", and "Ibn al-Sharji". His utmost care was for readings, and he has [knowledge] in Hadith, Fiqh, Usul, and Rhetoric. The Muhaddith historian "Ibn Kathir" and "Al-Bulqini" granted him license. He assumed teaching at the "Umayyad Mosque" and the judiciary of Sham. He descended to the lands of the Romans (Anatolia) and taught readings there. He toured many countries teaching the ten readings, so his students multiplied. Among his works is the book "Al-Nashr fi al-Qira'at al-Ashr", "Al-Durrah al-Mudiyyah fi al-Qira'at al-Thalath al-Mardiyyah", "Tahbir al-Taysir fi al-Qira'at al-Ashr", "Al-Ihtida' ila Ma'rifat al-Waqf wa al-Ibtida'", "Al-Zara'if fi Rasm al-Masahif", "Ghayat al-Nihayat fi Asma' Rijal al-Qira'at", and "Nihayat al-Dirayat fi Asma' Rijal al-Qira'at". He also has "Al-Hisn al-Hasin min Kalam Sayyid al-Mursalin", "Al-Hidayah fi Funun al-Hadith", "Al-Musnad al-Ahmad fima Yata'allaq bi-Musnad Ahmad", "Al-Qasd al-Ahmad fi Rijal Ahmad", "Al-Mas'ad al-Ahmad fi Khatm Masanid Ahmad", and "Asna al-Matalib fi Manaqib al-Imam Ali bin Abi Talib" (1). ***** Al-Jamal Al-Barmawi: Abdullah bin Muhibb al-Din Khalil bin Farah bin Sa'id al-Qudsi (760-833). He read with "Ibn al-Shurayshi", "Ibn al-Jabi", and others. He entered Egypt and resided in Mecca for a long time then came to Sham. "Ibn Hajar" says in "Inba' al-Ghumr": "He was severe in attacking the Hanbalis and incidents occurred between him and them" 0. Al-Biqa'i says about him in a footnote of his on a manuscript copy of his Sheikh Ibn Hajar's book: "Inba' al-Ghumr": "This is our Rabbani Sufi Knower Sheikh known as Al-Qal'i. He was a knowing Imam, a guide, an educator, a role model, with a firm foot in the inner science, participating in Fiqh and grammar a good participation, a professor in theology, with a strong memory, open to speech in preaching.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He has works including: Manar Subul al-Huda and 'Aqidat Ahl al-Tuqa". I discussed some of it with him, and stayed with him for a period at his Zawiya in Al-Aqabah Al-Sughra, and he died in Damascus (1). ***** Al-Badr Al-Hindi: Hasan bin Badr al-Hindi (833 AH). A student of Al-Sayyid Al-Sharif in rational sciences, and he was an Imam in them. Al-Biqa'i read Al-Shamsiyyah in logic with him 0. The Sheikh admired the student and promised to teach him the science of geometry and issues from it by which he would know who agrees with his temperament and who does not agree, so he would not mix with him [sic]. But the Sheikh left "Damascus" for "Hama" (2). ***** Al-Majd Al-Barmawi: Isma'il bin Abi al-Hasan Ali bin Abdullah al-Shafi'i (749-834). He read with "Al-Siraj Al-Bulqini" for he made him the destination of his journey and his specialization with him was great" as Al-Sakhawi says. He took from "Al-Isnawi". He mastered Shafi'i jurisprudence, undertook teaching, and preached at the Mosque of Amr bin al-Aas in Egypt. "He participated in several arts of jurisprudence, principles, grammar, and others. He was among the great virtuous ones and became a very learned scholar.. With his patience with poverty, he was ascetic in the world, certain that this is the best state, until it reached us that he used to ask Allah, glory be to Him, to make three-quarters of his provision knowledge. So he was delighted with his poverty and what Allah, the Almighty, gave him of knowledge, rather he would blame whoever frequents a rich man for his money or a person of prestige for his prestige" (3). And that is the affair of the scholar confident that Allah's favor upon him by making him among the people of knowledge is one of the greatest blessings after faith because it is a favor of inheriting Prophethood. So where are the levels of the people of the world from this, even if their wealth multiplies, their positions become numerous, and their authority and tyranny escalate? But most people do not reason.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The people of knowledge find the pleasure of knowledge and seeking it sweet, and see it as one of the greatest pleasures, until one of them said: We are in a pleasure that if kings knew of it, they would fight us for it with swords. Indeed, among Allah's favors upon the people of knowledge and its students is that kings and tyrants, their women and offspring, do not know that knowledge has a pleasure exclusive to scholars without them, and that they are deprived of it even though those enjoying it are under their authority. So wonder at a possessor of authority deprived of the most majestic blessing enjoyed by another under his authority, and he has no way, even if his soldiers, central and national security forces, and national and republican guards demonstrate, to deprive them of it!!! {Say, "Indeed, my Lord extends provision for whom He wills and restricts [it], but most of the people do not know."} (Saba: 36) {Say, "O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty, You give sovereignty to whom You will and You take sovereignty away from whom You will. You honor whom You will and You humble whom You will. In Your hand is [all] good. Indeed, You are over all things competent."} (Al Imran: 26) ***** Al-Shihab Al-Busiri: Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Abi Bakr bin Isma'il bin Salim bin Qaymaz al-Kinani al-Busiri al-Qahiri al-Shafi'i (762-840). He read with "Al-Nur Al-Adami", "Al-Badr Al-Qudsi", "Al-Izz bin Jama'ah", Yusuf Isma'il al-Anbabi", and "Al-Bulqini". He stuck to Al-Iraqi and "Ibn Hajar". He has many works including: "Zawa'id Ibn Majah", "Zawa'id al-Masanid al-Ashara", "Zawa'id al-Sunan al-Kubra" by Al-Bayhaqi, "Zawa'id Masanid al-Tayalisi", Zawa'id Musnad Ahmad, Musnad al-Humaydi, Al-Bazzar, Ibn Abi Shaybah, and Abu Ya'la, and Tuhfat al-Habib lil-Habib bi-Zawa'id fi al-Targhib wa al-Tarhib. Much silence, recitation, worship, isolation from people, and devotion to copying" (1). ***** Al-Burhan Al-Tarabulsi:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Khalil al-Shami al-Shafi'i known as Sibt Ibn al-Ajami (753-841). He read with "Ibn al-Ajami", "Al-Bulqini", "Ibn al-Mulaqqin", "Al-Fairuzabadi", and "Al-Zayn Al-Iraqi". He traveled to numerous countries: Egypt, Jerusalem, Gaza, Homs, and Hama. "Al-Najm bin Fahd" collected his Sheikhs in a volume 0. His status rose in the science of Hadith. He read Sahih Al-Bukhari more than sixty times, and Sahih Muslim about twenty times 0. Among his works are: Commentary on Sahih Al-Bukhari: "Al-Talqih li-Fahm Qari' al-Sahih", a commentary on Sunan Ibn Majah, "Al-Muqtada fi Dabt Alfaz al-Shifa", "Nihayat al-Sul fi Ruwat al-Sittah al-Usul", and "Al-Kashf al-Hathith 'amman Rumiya bi-Wad' al-Hadith". In summary, he was among those from whom the great ones took and benefited (1). ***** Ala' al-Din Al-Bukhari: Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad al-Bukhari (779-841). He grew up in Bukhara and studied Fiqh with his father and his uncle Al-Ala' Abdur Rahman. He took literature and rational sciences from Al-Sa'd Al-Taftazani (d. 792). He headed to India and settled there for a period, and his affair became great there due to his knowledge and asceticism. Likewise, his affair became great in Egypt. He was not desirous of frequenting those in authority. He was a scholar in the arts of rational, transmitted, and linguistic sciences. In the year (835), a fitnah arose between the Hanbalis and the Ash'aris in Damascus. Al-Ala' Al-Bukhari was biased against the Hanbalis and exaggerated in attacking "Ibn Taymiyyah" may Allah be pleased with them, explicitly declaring his disbelief. A group showed bias for Ibn Taymiyyah, and a collection of scholars in Egypt did not support Al-Ala' Al-Bukhari in unleashing his tongue against Ibn Taymiyyah. The Sultan issued a decree that no one should object to another's school, so the fitnah subsided (2). ***** Al-Shihab Al-Ramli: Abu al-Abbas Ahmad bin Husayn bin Arslan al-Maqdisi al-Shafi'i, known as: Ibn Arslan (773-844).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In the beginning of his affair, he was busy with language, grammar, evidences (Shawahid), and poetry. Then he busied himself with Fiqh, Hadith, and Usul. He read Al-Hawi Al-Saghir with Al-Qalqashandi, took inheritance and arithmetic from Ibn Al-Ha'im, read Al-Muwatta with Abu Hafs Al-Zaratiti, and with Al-Jamal bin Al-Zahirah and many Sheikhs indicated by Al-Sakhawi in "Al-Daw'". Among his writings: Pieces in Exegesis, "Sharh Al-Bukhari", "Sharh Sunan Abi Dawood" in eleven volumes, "Sharh Al-Arba'in Al-Nawawiyyah", a commentary on Al-Shifa by Qadi Iyad, a commentary on Jam' al-Jawami' in Usul al-Fiqh, and on Minhaj al-Baydawi, and Nazm al-Qira'at al-Thalath al-Zawa'id 'ala al-Sab' (Poem on the Three Readings Adding to the Seven) and the Three Adding to the Ten. And much more. He was known for righteousness, asceticism, and many acts of obedience. "His son-in-law "Al-Hafiz Al-Taj bin Al-Gharabili" recounted about him that he slept little at night, and that at the time of his waking he would rise standing like a lion; perhaps his standing preceded the completion of his waking up. He would stand as if terrified, perform ablution, and stand before his Lord, the Almighty, conversing with Him with His speech with contemplation and pondering. If the meaning of a verse confused him, he would hurry in those two Rak'ahs, look in the exegesis until he knew the meaning, then return to prayer." In summary, he is among those who became famous for knowledge and asceticism, so students of knowledge sought him and benefited from him (1). ***** Taqi al-Din Al-Maqrizi: Ahmad bin Ali bin Abd al-Qadir bin Muhammad al-Hanafi al-Shafi'i "Sibt Ibn al-Sa'igh" attributed to "Al-Maqarizah" which is a neighborhood in "Baalbek". Born in Cairo (766-845). Among his Sheikhs are his maternal grandfather "Al-Shams bin al-Sa'igh al-Hanafi", "Al-Burhan Al-Amidi", "Al-Bulqini", "Al-Iraqi", and "Ibn Khaldun", and he was influenced by him during "Ibn Khaldun's residence in Cairo". His Sheikhs reached six hundred as Al-Sakhawi says in "Al-Daw'". He was Hanafi then switched to the Shafi'i school. He worked as a Muhtasib in Cairo and a preacher at the Mosque of "Amr" and "Al-Hakim Mosque" "at Sultan Hasan School" 0. He resided in Mecca the Honored for five years 0. Among his works: "Al-Khitat lil-Qahirah" known as Khitat al-Maqrizi,

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Durar al-'Uqud al-Faridah fi Tarajim al-A'yan al-Mufidah", "Imta' al-Asma' bima lil-Rasul min al-Abna' wa al-Akhwal wa al-Hafadah wa al-Mata'", "'Iqd Jawahir al-Asfat fi Akhbar Madinat al-Fustat" in which he chronicled Egypt from the Arab conquest to the Fatimid conquest (21-358), "Itti'az al-Hunafa bi-Akhbar al-A'immah al-Fatimiyyin al-Khulafa" chronicling the Fatimid era. Then he authored his book: "Al-Suluk li-Ma'rifat Duwal al-Muluk" chronicling Egypt in the Ayyubid and Mamluk eras up to the year (845), "Al-Bayan wa al-I'rab 'amma fi Ard Misr min al-A'rab", "Al-Ilmam fiman Ta'akhkhar bi-Ard al-Habashah min Muluk al-Islam", "Al-Tarikh al-Kabir al-Muqaffa" in sixteen volumes, "Al-Takhasum bayn Bani Umayyah wa Bani Hashim", "Daw' al-Sari fi Ma'rifat Khabar Tamim al-Dari", "Ighathat al-Ummah bi-Kashf al-Ghummah", "Al-Awzan wa al-Akyal al-Shar'iyyah", "Shudhur al-'Uqud fi Dhikr al-Nuqud", "Izalat al-Ta'ab wa al-'Ana' fi Ma'rifat Hall al-Ghina'", and much more, exceedingly exceeding two hundred as Al-Sakhawi says in Al-Daw'. The predominant feature of him is authorship in the science of history. He had much recall of ancient events in Jahiliyyah and others. As for Islamic events, knowing men and their names, Jarh and Ta'dil (disparagement and endorsement), ranks, biographies, and other secrets and beauties of history, he was not skilled in it, as "Al-Sakhawi" says. He had little knowledge of Fiqh, Hadith, and Grammar, and acquaintance with the sayings of the Salaf, and familiarity with the doctrine of the People of the Book such that their virtuous ones used to frequent him to benefit from him" (1). ***** Al-Shams Al-Qayati: Muhammad bin Ali bin Ya'qub bin Muhammad al-Qayati attributed to "Qayat", near Faiyum in Egypt, Al-Shafi'i (785-850). Among his Sheikhs are "Al-Siraj Al-Bulqini", "Al-Shams Al-Qalyubi", "Al-Humam Al-Khwarizmi", "Al-Ala' Al-Bukhari", and "Al-Shams Al-Sunbati".
foot_note: 1. (1) – 'Unwan al-Zaman 1/84, Al-Daw' al-Lami': 2/21 – 25, Shadharat al-Dhahab: 7/254, Al-Badr al-Tali': 1/79

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He worked in teaching at "Al-Barquqiyyah", "Al-Ashrafiyyah", "Madrasat Ibn Ghurab", and was the Khatib (preacher) of Al-Azhar. He was, as "Al-Sakhawi" says, "A very learned Imam, utmost in verification, quality of thought, and success, removing problems with his high expressions and relieving fatigue with his clear indications and piercing thought, utmost in integrity.... He became the Sheikh of arts indisputably... No one stops at that except an envier or a fabricator." "Al-Kamal bin al-Humam was asked" about preference between him and "Al-Zayn Al-Tafahni" in Usul. He said: Al-Tafahni was knowledgeable in the Usul of his school, but this one in all Usul." He wrote separate pieces on Al-Minhaj by Al-Nawawi in which he took great care to repel the words of Al-Isnawi, and made a tail and points on "Al-Muhimmat" (1). ***** Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani: Abu al-Fadl Al-Shihab: Ahmad bin Ali bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Ahmad al-Asqalani al-Misri (773-852). Among his Sheikhs is "Al-Izz bin Jama'ah" "and upon him he took most of the instrumental and fundamental sciences like Al-Minhaj, Jam' al-Jawami', and the commentary of Al-Mukhtasar and Al-Mutawwal". Among his Sheikhs in language is "Al-Fairuzabadi" author of "Al-Qamus Al-Muhit". But he became enamored with the art of Hadith and sciences of Sunnah, so he turned to them and stuck to "Al-Zayn Al-Iraqi" and carried from him great beneficial knowledge in chain, text, defects, and terminology. So Ibn Hajar was the Sheikh pointed to in this. He traveled in search of knowledge like many students of his time, traveling to Mecca, Yemen, Hijaz, and Sham. He addressed authorship and publishing Hadith and its sciences. One of the greatest and most famous commentaries on Al-Bukhari is his commentary "Fath al-Bari". He began dictating it in the year eight hundred and seventeen, then continued writing by his hand and circulating it among students of knowledge bit by bit until he finished it in the beginning of the month of Rajab of the year eight hundred and twenty-four. In the last session of the commentary sessions, "Ibn Hajar" prepared a great feast that consumed five hundred dinars. People gathered, and it was a witnessed day. Poets spoke in it and said much, and gold was distributed among them. "Al-Biqa'i" was among those who recited a poem in this majestic gathering, the opening of which is:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Leave my infatuation and removal of my restraint If you do not yearn for the description of a virgin (or excuse). He assumed teaching in numerous places, most importantly the Shaykhuniyyah School where teaching was only by order of the Sultan to the great scholars of the era. Sultan Faraj bin Barquq entrusted it to him. He was the preacher of Al-Azhar and the Mosque of Amr, and the treasurer of the "Mahmudiyyah" library. He was concerned with it, creating two indexes for its books: one alphabetical by the names of the books and the other a subject index. His works are numerous, the most famous of which, as I said: "Commentary on Sahih Al-Bukhari", the book "Al-Imta' bi-l-Arba'in al-Mutabayinah bi-Shart al-Sama'", "Inba' al-Ghumr bi-Anba' al-'Umr", and Al-Qawl al-Musaddad fi al-Dhabb 'an al-Musnad lil-Imam Ahmad, which is one of the important books for the reader of Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal's Musnad 0. And "Al-Rahmah al-Ghaythiyyah fi al-Tarjamah al-Laythiyyah" which is on the biography of Imam "Al-Layth bin Sa'd", making it in eight chapters. It is a nice book. Imam Al-Layth bin Sa'd is the scholar whom his people neglected, so they did not take from him as they took from others. Al-Shafi'i said about him: "Al-Layth is more beneficial to the Athar (trace/tradition) than Malik", and he said about him: "Al-Layth is more knowledgeable in Fiqh than Malik except that his companions did not undertake him," and in a narration from him "his people neglected him". Al-Biqa'i elaborated in the biography of "Ibn Hajar" in his book "'Unwan al-Zaman", as did "Al-Sakhawi" in "Al-Daw' al-Lami'" and in Al-Dhayl 'ala Raf' al-Isr 'an Qudat Misr. Indeed, Al-Sakhawi devoted a biography to him naming it: "Al-Jawahir wa al-Durar fi Tarjamat Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Hajar" (1). ***** Al-Imad bin Sharaf: Abu al-Fida' Isma'il bin Ibrahim bin Sharaf bin Musharraf known as Ibn Sharaf (d. 852).
