book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He studied under Al-Shihab bin Al-Ha'im and benefited greatly from him, becoming Ibn Sharaf an Imam in arithmetic and inheritance. Al-Biqa'i learned the science of arithmetic from him. He had a hand in the science of grammar and rational sciences. He took from many scholars including Al-Shams Al-Qalqashandi, Al-Barmawi, and Al-Wali Al-Iraqi, sticking to him in Fiqh. He was not looking at worldly prestige but his gaze was towards knowledge 0. Among his works: Tawdih Bahjat al-Hawi in two volumes, and he started a lengthy explanation of Al-Bahjah reaching the Friday prayer, so the explanation was volumes. He explained the works of his Sheikh Ibn Al-Ha'im, and wrote a good useful clarification on the Alfiyyah of his Sheikh Al-Barmawi in Usul. He died in Jerusalem and was prayed upon after Asr on Tuesday the thirteenth of the month of Rabi' al-Thani in the year (852) at Al-Aqsa Mosque (1). ***** Al-Badr bin Al-Ayni: Abu al-Thana' Mahmud bin Ahmad bin Musa bin Ahmad bin Husayn bin Yusuf al-Ayntabi al-Hanafi (762-855). He grew up in Ayntab, as his father was its judge. Historian, Muhaddith. He assumed Hisbah, teaching, and several functions. His fame spread and he was the Chief Judge of the Hanafis in Egypt. He was eloquent in Arabic and Turkish. He excelled in Hanafi jurisprudence, history, Hadith, exegesis, language, grammar, morphology, and history. Among his many works: Umdat al-Qari Sharh Sahih al-Bukhari, Sharh al-Hidayah in Hanafi jurisprudence, Sharh Ma'ani al-Athar by Al-Tahawi in twelve volumes, Sharh Majma' al-Bahrain, Sharh al-Kalim al-Tayyib by Ibn Taymiyyah, explanation of a piece of Sunan Abi Dawood, a large piece of Sirat Ibn Hisham, Sharh al-Awamil al-Mi'ah in grammar by Abd al-Qahir al-Jurjani, Sharh al-Tashil by Ibn Malik in grammar, and explanation of the evidences of Alfiyyat Ibn Malik, a long and a short explanation. He has the Great History on the system of years in twenty volumes, and abbreviated it in three volumes. In summary, he was one of the vessels of knowledge in his era (2). ***** Al-Jalal Al-Mahalli: Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Mahalli al-Shafi'i (791-864).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Known as the Taftazani of the Arabs. He excelled in numerous arts: Fiqh, Kalam (Theology), Tafsir, Usul, and Grammar. He was utmost in intelligence and understanding, but weak in his memory. He was upon righteousness, piety, austerity, enjoining good and forbidding evil. The judiciary was offered to him but he refused. He was infrequent in teaching, boredom appearing on him. He authored books to which journeys are made, utmost in brevity, editing, refinement, and smoothness of expression. Among his works: Sharh Jam' al-Jawami' in Usul al-Fiqh, Sharh al-Minhaj in Shafi'i Fiqh, and Sharh al-Waraqat in Usul al-Fiqh. He has a concise exegesis that he did not complete, and Al-Suyuti completed it, known as Tafsir al-Jalalayn. Young students of knowledge today do not know its value due to its brevity 0. It is one of the exegeses that teach the student of knowledge good analysis and detailing of what is summarized, because it is like a text that entices training on detailing what is summarized. It is a faculty that the student of knowledge should practice. Hence, our ancestors cared for it in the curricula of education and preparation of the student of knowledge, so whomever of the moderns was ignorant or heedless of the goal faulted it 0 (1). ***** Abu al-Fadl Al-Mashdali: Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Abi al-Qasim bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Samad al-Mashdali al-Beja'i al-Maghribi (821-865). Al-Mashdali with Fatha on Meem and Shaddah on Dal attributed to a tribe from Zwawa 0. He received knowledge from his father famous in the Maghreb as Ibn Abi al-Qasim, and from "Ibn Marzuq" and Abu al-Qasim al-'Uqbani" 0. His Sheikh Ibn Marzuq said about him: "I did not know knowledge until this young man came to me 0. It was said to him: How? He said: Because I used to speak and my speech would be accepted, but when this one came, he began to dispute with me, so I began to be cautious, and doors of knowledge opened for me." Abu al-Fadl Al-Mashdali was the wonder of his time in memory and intelligence. He is the one who guided his student "Al-Biqa'i" to the general rule for the proportionality of the Holy Qur'an (2). *****

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Sharaf al-Din Al-Munawi: Abu Zakariya Yahya bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Makhluf al-Munawi al-Shafi'i (d. 871). He is attributed to "Munyat Bani al-Khasib" in Upper Egypt where his grandfather resided. He is the grandfather of "Abd al-Ra'uf Al-Munawi" commentator on "Al-Jami' Al-Saghir". Among his Sheikhs are "Al-Shams Al-Barmawi", "Al-Shams Al-Farraqi", his sister's husband "Al-Wali Al-Iraqi", and Al-Shams bin Al-Jazari". Al-Sakhawi says about him that he "set himself up to spread knowledge of Fiqh, Usul, Arabic, Hadith, and Tafsir, but the art for which his name flew is 'Fiqh' and most people did not mention him for anything else. A group graduated through him who became leaders in his life, although he did not occupy himself with authorship other than what I noted of his writing on 'Al-Mukhtasar': Mukhtasar al-Muzani in Shafi'i jurisprudence, and likewise through teaching 'Al-Salihiyyah Al-Najmiyyah' and he started an intermediate explanation on 'Al-Minhaj' and a footnote on the explanation of 'Al-Bahjah'." His times were charged with teaching, worship, and occupation keen on raising those belonging to him, and praising their mention.... And if the Hadith of the Prophet, peace be upon him, was read in his presence, he and his group would be in the utmost state of lowering heads and stillness of limbs, not speaking to anyone nor budging for a comer except rarely in both cases. He had endurance for reading such that he would often sit from after the Morning prayer until Noon" (1). ***** Al-Husam bin Hariz: Husam al-Din Muhammad bin Abi Bakr Muhammad bin Hariz al-Husayni al-Tahtawi al-Maliki (804-873). He has the long hand in knowing readings, Fiqh, and history.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Sakhawi says about him: "Judge Husam al-Din stuck to reading books of Fiqh, Tafsir, Hadith, History, and Literature until he could recall an abundant amount of all that, and he would discuss them well with speed of perception, eloquence, cheerfulness, modesty, magnanimity, giving to his askers and others, standing with whoever sought him for his needs, acquiring precious books, and being expansive in types of food and the like.... (1). ***** Izz al-Din Al-Hanbali: Abu al-Barakat Ahmad bin Ibrahim bin Nasrallah al-Kinani al-Asqalani al-Hanbali (800-876). Chief Judge of the Hanbalis in the Egyptian lands, son of the Chief Judge, and the scholar of the Hanbalis in his era as "Ibn al-Sayrafi" says. Among his Sheikhs are Al-Shams Al-Barmawi, Al-Badr Al-Damamini, Al-Izz bin Jama'ah, Al-Zayn Al-Iraqi, Al-Maqrizi, Al-Ayni, and Ibn Hajar. Ibn Hajar and Al-Shams Al-Busiri used to revere him. He traveled seeking knowledge to Hijaz, Sham, and Jerusalem 0. He assumed the Hanbali judiciary after Al-Badr Al-Baghdadi and assumed teaching in numerous schools and mosques like Al-Shaykhuniyyah, Al-Mu'ayyad, Qubbat al-Salih and Al-Hakim. He met the great ones, exchanged poetry with poets, and authored much such that few arts remained except he authored in them either in poetry or prose as "Al-Sakhawi" says. He has in Tafsir "Mukhtasar Zad al-Musafir" which he did not complete, and in Fiqh Mukhtasar al-Muharrar in Hanbali Fiqh by Al-Rafi'i. He summarized Alfiyyat Ibn Malik adding to it the science of calligraphy and a conclusion on what he missed, and Nazm al-Talkhis in Rhetoric, and much more (2). ***** Muhyi al-Din Al-Kafiyaji: Muhyi al-Din Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Sulayman bin Sa'd bin Mas'ud al-Rumi al-Hanafi (788-879).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: A fundamentalist jurist, exegete, and hadith scholar who paid great attention to linguistic sciences, especially the explanation of Al-Kafiyah in grammar, to which he was attributed due to his frequent engagement with it. He held a high status in rational sciences, principles of jurisprudence, Ma'ani, and Bayan. He says about his student Al-Biqa'i in the commendation of his interpretation "Nazm al-Durar": "The very learned scholar, the comprehensive ocean of understanding, superior to his peers... the teacher, the author, the Mufti Burhan al-Din... famous as Al-Biqa'i..." (1) Al-Biqa'i says about him: "He was like safety during the tribulation of 'Ibn al-Farid'." He has numerous summarized works, including: *Sharh Qawa'id al-I'rab* (Explanation of the Rules of Parsing), *Sharh Kalimatay al-Shahada* (Explanation of the Two Testimonies), and *Al-Taysir fi 'Ulum al-Tafsir* (Facilitation in the Sciences of Exegesis) (2). ***** Al-Muhibb ibn al-Shihna: Muhibb al-Din Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Mahmud ibn Ghazi al-Thaqafi al-Halabi, famous as Ibn al-Shihna (804-890 AH). He memorized *Umdat al-Nasafi* in the principles of religion early on, *Al-Tayyibah* in Qira'at (Recitations), *Al-Manar* in principles of jurisprudence, *Al-Mukhtar* and *Al-Wiqayah* in Hanafi jurisprudence, *Al-Mulhah*, *Alfiyyah of Ibn Malik*, and *Al-Shudhur* in grammar, as well as parts of *Tawdih* by Ibn Hisham and *Alfiyyah of Ibn Mu'ti*. In rhetoric, he memorized *Talkhis al-Miftah*. He accompanied "Al-Burhan al-Halabi" in the arts of Hadith, who used to divert him from engaging in logic. He read *Tajrid al-Shamsiyyah* in logic with "Ibn Salamah". He did not seek to have many sheikhs nor hear from many, as Al-Sakhawi says in *Al-Dhayl*. Among those he read to were "Al-Shihab al-Ajami", "Ibn Khatib al-Dahsha", "Al-Ala' al-Bukhari", and "Al-Taqi al-Maqrizi". Among his works is *Sharh al-Hidayah* in Hanafi jurisprudence, which—as Al-Sakhawi says—contains immense knowledge; he wrote five volumes or less of it up to the end of the chapter on Ghusl (washing), then his resolve to complete it waned. Among his writings are: *Al-Munjid al-Mughith fi 'Ilm al-Hadith*, *Tanwir al-Manar* (which is a summary of *Al-Manar* by Al-Nasafi in principles of jurisprudence), and *Ikhtisar al-Nashr fi al-Qira'at al-Ashr*.

2. Al-Daw' al-Lami': 7/259, Al-Badr al-Tali': 2/171, Husn al-Muhadarah: 1/317, Bada'i' al-Zuhur by Ibn Iyas: Vol 3, p 98, Shadharat al-Dhahab: 7/326

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: He held several positions, including the judgeship of Aleppo, its confidential secretaryship (Kitabat al-Sirr), supervision of its army, the confidential secretaryship in Egypt, the Hanafi judgeship there several times, and the sheikhdom of the Shaykhuniyyah Khanqah. He wrote a commendation for his student "Al-Biqa'i" on his interpretation (1). Indeed, the sheikhs of "Al-Biqa'i" are very numerous, and space does not allow for mentioning their names. His book *Unwan al-Zaman fi Tarajim al-Shuyukh wa al-Aqran* overflows with the biographies of many of them, Al-Biqa'i's relationship with them, the sciences he received from them, the books he read to them, the types of those readings, and the licenses (Ijazahs) they granted him and the types of those licenses. - - - His Students: If the sheikhs are among the most important sources that flow into the stream of "Al-Biqa'i", shaping his scientific personality from what he received from this multi-sourced spring, I argue that a brilliant student can be a tributary increasing the sea of his sheikh's knowledge. He draws his sheikh's attention to things his sheikh's care had not turned to. How often has a question from a brilliant student to his sheikh been the cause of a scientific work undertaken by the sheikh, thereby benefiting science and its people? Al-Biqa'i had students who sat with him, especially since his name became widespread in conjunction with his interpretation, unique in its methodology and goals. Among his students were those who took him as a primary sheikh, and those who took some of his knowledge. What I have found regarding his students is not equal to the amount of his sheikhs. It is clear that he held the position of repetitor (Mu'id) in the mosque of "Rahbat Bab al-Eid", and in the mosque of "Al-Zahir", known now as the neighborhood of "Al-Zahir" in Cairo. He undertook the teaching of the Holy Quran and Qira'at in the Mu'ayyad School. His sheikh "Ibn Hajar" appointed him as a reciter of Sahih al-Bukhari in the Citadel during the reign of Sultan "Jaqmaq", and he assumed the sheikhdom of reciters in the tomb of Umm al-Malik al-Salih. The important point is that he had students who became people of knowledge after him, teaching people what they had learned. "Ibn Hajar al-Haytami" (d. 974) says:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: "He had senior students who adopted his sayings and what he believed, and some of them are among my sheikhs (1). In his saying: 'and what he believed,' there is a reference to Al-Biqa'i's degradation of some of those affiliated with the Sufi sect, such as 'Ibn Arabi', 'Ibn al-Farid', 'Ibn Sab'in', and others to whom statements are attributed that are declared openly, which a Muslim safe from the fitna (trial) of detestable esoteric interpretation would not accept. Among his most famous students are: Al-Shihab al-Dimyati: Ahmad ibn Ali ibn Husayn ibn Ali al-Ashmuni (d. 840-890). He learned from Al-Shihab al-Bayjuri, Al-Alam al-Bulqini, and Al-Burhan al-Ajluni, and from Al-Biqa'i. His attachment to him increased to the extent that he used to send him some of his writings, as Al-Sakhawi says in *Al-Daw'* (2). *** Abu al-Mafakhir al-Nu'aymi: Abd al-Qadir ibn Muhammad ibn Umar ibn Muhammad ibn Yusuf ibn Abdullah ibn Nu'aym al-Nu'aymi al-Shafi'i al-Dimashqi (845-927). A historian, hadith scholar, and Sufi. He read to Al-Biqa'i, and he licensed him with what was permissible for him. Among his works are: *Al-Daris fi Tarikh al-Madaris*, *Tadhkirat al-Ikhwan fi Hawadith al-Zaman*, the book *Al-Tabyin fi Tarajim al-Ulama wa al-Salihin*, the book: *Al-Unwan fi Dabt Mawalid wa Wafiyat Ahl al-Zaman*, *Al-Qawl al-Mubin fi al-Muhkam fi Ihda' al-Qurb li al-Nabi salla Allahu alayhi wa sallam*, and *Tuhfat al-Bararah fi al-Ahadith al-Mu'tabarah* (3). *** Al-Badr al-Arbali: Hasan ibn Ali ibn Yusuf al-Haskafy al-Arbali al-Shafi'i, famous as Ibn al-Mustawfi (850-925). He cared for jurisprudence, principles, Hadith, and Arabic sciences, and was a poet. He learned from the scholars of his time, including Al-Biqa'i, who licensed him for issuing fatwas and teaching. Among his works are: *Hashiyah 'ala Sharh al-Minhaj* and *Hashiyah 'ala al-Kafiyah* (4). *** Ibn al-Hamlawi: Ahmad ibn Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Zuhayr al-Ramli al-Dimashqi al-Shafi'i, formerly known as Ibn al-Hamlawi (854-923).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: He cared for jurisprudence, Hadith, and Qira'at. He was zealous for his sheikh Al-Biqa'i, sticking to him and defending him. He took from him the Alfiyyah of Hadith and copied from his interpretation. He held the sheikhdom of recitation at the Umayyad Mosque, Dar al-Hadith al-Ashrafiyyah, the Ashrafiyyah Tomb, and the Tomb of Umm Salih after his sheikh Al-Biqa'i. He became the Sheikh of Reciters in Damascus after him (1). Al-Shams al-Dalaji: Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Dalaji al-Shafi'i (860-947). He cared for jurisprudence and Hadith. Among his works are: *Sharh 'ala al-Khazrajiyyah*, *Sharh 'ala al-Arba'in al-Nawawiyyah*, *Sharh 'ala al-Shifa* by Qadi Iyad. He summarized *Al-Minhaj* and *Al-Maqasid*, naming it *Maqasid al-Maqasid*, and explained this summary (2). Ibn Hajar al-Haytami says about him: "He was given, in Sharia and rational sciences, a robustness of composition and strength of phrasing that no one of his time was given." He also says about him: "He authored works in the art of jurisprudence that rival the works of Al-Sa'd al-Taftazani and others in rhetoric, beauty of phrasing, and quality of structures, but no one cared for them, nor turned to them; rather, people turned away from them with extreme avoidance." Ibn Hajar al-Haytami explains this by saying: "Because this Sheikh did not believe in 'Ibn Arabi', the author of *Al-Futuhat al-Makkiyyah*, like his sheikh 'Al-Biqa'i', so he was punished by the removal of blessing from his writings" (3). This is misguidance and misleading from Al-Haytami, as if belief in "Ibn Arabi" is the key to benefiting from him. This is not said by a fair person nor accepted by a rational one. The standard for benefiting from knowledge is sincerity to Allah, the Lord of the Worlds, in it. And what does "Al-Haytami" say about "Ibn Taymiyyah" and "Ibn al-Qayyim"? Is there no benefit in the knowledge they left behind? Or were they among those who believed in "Ibn Arabi", about whom I believe that he himself did not believe in himself, for he knew his own state better than others? No rational person reads anything from the book *Fusus al-Hikam* and retains in his chest a trace of belief that its writer is correct in what he blackened the pages of the book with, and his own pages as well. ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Jalal al-Suyuti: Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Bakr ibn Uthman ibn Muhammad al-Khudayri al-Suyuti (849-911). One of the most famous scholars of his time, he excelled in many sciences and arts. He wrote his own biography in his book *Husn al-Muhadarah*. He received knowledge from the scholars of his time, including Al-Biqa'i (1). There were criticisms between him and Al-Biqa'i that exceeded the limit of moral tolerance between people of knowledge and between a sheikh and his student. The students of every scholar are the carriers of his knowledge and the methodology of his life, and they are more dutiful to him than the child who came from his loins. The scholar who is worthy of having the ink of his pen be purer than the scent of musk on the Day of Resurrection is the one who is capable of transforming the lives of his students first, and his nation after them, from a level of the levels of proximity to what is higher than it, and to transform their lives into what establishes them in the station of enjoying the pursuit of knowledge, learning and teaching, and disciplining and adopting morals; so that they may one day be the heirs of prophecy. Formatting one student who carries the methodology of his life from the sheikh is equal to the world and what is in it. The true scholar is not keen on teaching his students how to memorize knowledge in their hearts like the memorization of books and papers; rather, the scholar is the one who teaches his students the methodology of thinking, analyzing, evaluating, selecting, and investing. If we taught our students in our universities - at least - how to think, analyze, evaluate, and select, we would have a different status. He makes his students stand before human knowledge, whatever its human source, with an open heart that does not take a stance of sanctification or desecration towards things before probing, analyzing, and evaluating. An open heart is the sign of its owner's life, and whoever closes his heart to human knowledge has closed the doors of life in his face, for knowledge is the lost property of the believer, and the value of the 'Other' to him is to the extent that the 'Other' does well.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: It is upon every scholar to raise his students to engage in cultural exchange with the 'Other' with an open, conscious heart, unimpressed by halos of sanctification and the noise of hollow propaganda; this is indeed a missionary duty. You cannot invite the 'Other' to the truth that is with you unless you have a deep knowledge of that 'Other's' mind, culture, and methodology of thinking, to know the reason for his turning away from the truth that is with you: Is the cause of that turning away in what you have, or in your method of inviting to it, or in circumstances surrounding that 'Other' preventing him from listening well to you, or in a matter existing in his heart blocking him from that truth? Even if you follow all paths of calling to the truth with wisdom and fair preaching, and even if you argue in the best manner? You will not discover all of that unless you master cultural exchange with the 'Other', and in that mastery is help in achieving what is required of you to truly be among the heirs of prophecy.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Chapter Two: Jihad of the Pen - His Scientific Works. A scholar is not beneficial to his people if he does not have his praiseworthy standing before his students in lecture halls, discussion, and dialogue, forming and shaping their scientific personalities, enticing them to enjoy seeking knowledge and adopting his noble morals and attributes. And if he does not have his praiseworthy standing as a caller to Allah Almighty through his good character and great asceticism regarding what is unbecoming for an heir of the Prophet, peace be upon him, to aspire to, for it is an inheritance of knowledge, character, and obedience to Allah, the Lord of the Worlds. He - meaning the scholar - does not limit his generosity and noble giving to students of knowledge in his time and city; rather, he is the one who is extremely keen that the table of his knowledge be set and full of hospitality for every student of knowledge in every era and city. If his body is absent from them, his mind, heart, and literature remain in his books which his right hand writes, for which his reward with Allah Almighty on the Day of Resurrection will be that their ink transforms to be purer than musk in scent. That is a reward of the same nature as the deed, for that ink was a cause for changing people's lives through the beneficial knowledge it spread to what is higher and purer, so the reward was its transformation into what is better than musk on the Day of Resurrection. The soul of the scholar finds the scent of ink more pleasant than others find the scent of musk in this world. Preparing research, writing books, and publishing them among students of knowledge is a majestic responsibility. It is not fitting for a scholar who possesses the ability to fulfill some of its rights to turn away from it or distract himself with a fleeting matter of worldly life. The darkness of ignorance and atheism will not envelop our lands as long as there remain among us scholars who teach, educate, research, and write, and students of knowledge who strive to acquire knowledge, understand it, and invest it to cultivate the land and the hearts of the servants. That was the case with "Al-Biqa'i". He presented to students of knowledge and the Islamic library more than sixty books and treatises. Some of his works reached several volumes, and some of his treatises were handwritten leaflets which, if their summary were detailed, would reach a huge volume. Eyes turned away from many of his works for a long time, and many people barely heard his name until less than three decades ago. Indeed, he was not known as an exegete except by a few of those occupied with the sciences of the Book, the Sunnah, and Arabic.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Today, some of his works have received attention from students of knowledge, especially his interpretation *Nazm al-Durar*, for not a few students of the sciences of the Noble Book today are keen to accompany this interpretation because they find in it what is not in others. Allah Almighty has facilitated for me the viewing of many of his books while they were manuscripts nearly a quarter of a century ago. I have divided the discussion here on his works into two sections according to my relationship with them: The First Section: For what I found and read, and this I have arranged according to its arts. The Second Section: For what I trusted in its attribution to him, but I was not successful in viewing, either because it is still a manuscript deposited in treasuries outside Egypt and I could not afford to go to them due to lack of funds, or because they are missing with no known location. This I arranged alphabetically according to its title, and I took care to document its attribution to Al-Biqa'i, and to clarify something of what I trusted regarding the subject in which it was written. Perhaps Allah Almighty will help me to work on publishing what benefits the servants from them, seeking His pleasure and drawing near to Him and showing love. The First Section: What I viewed of his works. First: Exegesis and Sciences of the Holy Quran: The requirement of what I adopted was to arrange the books of this art according to their title alphabetically, but I deviated here to start with his interpretation because of its high status in his soul and its majestic status regarding the arts of scientific research I am concerned with, and because it is the basis of "Al-Biqa'i's" fame among the Imams, for his interpretation is the main source for the high status Al-Biqa'i had in his time and subsequent eras. {Nazm al-Durar min Tanasub al-Ay wa al-Suwar} I was not able to view the author's copy, but I viewed a part of a manuscript copy written in his time in the year (871) which the author corrected himself, while the rest of the copy is fabricated and incomplete. It is copy number (285 - Tafsir - Egyptian National Library).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: It was written on the face of the first leaf of this part which the author corrected: (Nazm al-Durar min Tanasub al-Ay wa al-Suwar). Its title appeared as such in his book: (Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah fi Hukm al-Naql min al-Kutub al-Qadimah) on the third page, and page twenty-three of the manuscript number: (1269 - Tafsir - Egyptian National Library) (1). Likewise in his book: (Badhl al-Nush wa al-Shafaqah: f:61, Calligraphy No.: 117 - Tasawwuf - Egyptian National Library) and his book: (Masa'id al-Nazar li al-Ishraf 'ala Maqasid al-Suwar (Vol 1, p 118, 116, 114). Therefore, I preferred this title. Its title appeared as (Nazm al-Durar fi Tanasub al-Ay wa al-Suwar) in *Al-Itqan* by Al-Suyuti (3/322), *Mu'tarak al-Aqran* (1/55), *Kashf al-Zunun* (2/1961), *Hadiyat al-'Arifin* (1/21), and (*Al-Mawrid Iraqi Journal*: p 199, Issue 2, Vol 2). The title (Nazm al-Durar fi Tanasub al-Ayat wa al-Suwar) appeared in the manuscript copy number (155 - Tafsir Taymur - Egyptian National Library) and *Al-A'lam* by Al-Zirikli (1/50). Other names appeared for it with addition, subtraction, or alteration (*Nazm al-'Iqyan* by Al-Suyuti: p 24). It is known as "Al-Munasabat" (The Correlations), and he named it so in (*Masa'id al-Nazar*: p 10), (*Badhl al-Nush wa al-Shafaqah* f 61b), and (*Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah*: 2). It also appeared in (*Shadharat al-Dhahab*: 7/340) and (*Al-A'lam*: 1/50). He says in its beginning: "It is appropriate to name it: 'Fath al-Rahman fi Tanasub Ajza' al-Quran' and the most appropriate name for it is 'Tarjuman al-Quran wa Mubdi Munasabat al-Furqan'." He is concerned with the multiplicity of names for his books, as you also find in (*Masa'id al-Nazar*: Vol 1, p 98), indicating the multiplicity of aspects from which the Book can be viewed, believing that the name indicates the named, and that the multiplicity of names for a thing indicates its honor. *** Date of Authorship:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Biqa'i began writing his interpretation "Nazm al-Durar" in Sha'ban of the year eight hundred sixty-one (861) in Cairo, when he was fifty-two years old. He finished the draft on Tuesday, the seventh of the month of Sha'ban in the year eight hundred seventy-five (875) in his mosque at Rahbat Bab al-Eid branching from Qasr al-Shawq Street near the noble Al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo. Thus, the draft took fourteen years. He finished fair copying and refining it on Sunday, the tenth of Sha'ban in the year eight hundred eighty-two (882) in Damascus at his home adjacent to the Badraniyyah School, that is, three years before his death. So, its authorship and editing took twenty-two years, as he stated in the conclusion of his interpretation (1). Printed and Manuscript Copies of the Book: I was keen to mention a description of the printed copy of the book and some manuscript copies because I claim that the book is in need of re-verification due to matters occurring in the printed copy that are better removed. It is among the books in which a sentence may extend so long that it does not help the reader with good reading and understanding, and not a few of Al-Biqa'i's phrases and structures are convoluted. First: The Printed Copy: Despite the large number of books and treatises Al-Biqa'i wrote, only a few of them have been printed. Among those printed recently is his interpretation "Nazm al-Durar". This interpretation remained resistant to printing for many years. "Ibn Hajar al-Haytami" claims that Allah Almighty did not allow benefit from "Al-Biqa'i's" knowledge due to his hostility towards "Ibn Arabi". He says:
foot_note: 1. (1) Nazm al-Durar fi Tanasub al-Ayat wa al-Suwar by Al-Biqa'i: Vol 22, p 443 - Printed: Hyderabad, India

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: "Al-Biqa'i – may Allah forgive him – was among the senior people of knowledge, and he had many acts of worship, excessive intelligence, and brilliant memorization in all sciences, especially the science of Tafsir and Hadith. He authored many books; Allah Almighty refused that anyone should benefit from them at all [sic]. He has a book on 'Correlations of the Quran' in about ten volumes, known only to the elite by hearsay, while others do not know it at all. Had this book belonged to our Sheikh 'Zakariyya' [meaning Zakariyya al-Ansari] or others among those who believe [meaning believe in the sainthood of 'Ibn Arabi' and 'Ibn al-Farid', and hold their views], it would have been written in gold; because no like of it [i.e., the interpretation of Correlations] has been created. But {To each [category] We extend - to these and to those - from the gift of your Lord. And never has the gift of your Lord been restricted} (Al-Isra: 20) (1). This statement from "Ibn Hajar al-Haytami" is closer to absenting the monotheistic Muslim mind than to anything else, for the landmarks of misleading are very apparent in it. If this is the state of those who believe in "Ibn Arabi", then this is proof that believing in his sainthood is clear misguidance. Who possesses the right to claim that believing in someone like "Ibn Arabi" is an obligation and obedience, such that whoever does not adhere to it is punished and expelled? What ignorance and misleading is this?!! The Islamic nation has been afflicted in later ages, and continues to be so, by many of those responsible for numbing and hypnotizing the Muslim mind which draws its nourishment and healing from the Book and the authentic Prophetic Sunnah. Not a few of those affiliated with knowledge and taking the lead in Dawah and teaching servants base their knowledge on myths, stories, and comic superstitions imagined for them by devils of mankind and jinn. Such people have the false dominance in the media; thus, such a situation allows every tyrant to spread corruption among his people and find no one to deter him and expose his tyranny and misleading of his people.
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Fatawa al-Hadithiyyah by Ibn Hajar al-Haytami al-Makki: p 53

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Professor "Abd al-Qadir Atta" argues that the reluctance to print Al-Biqa'i's interpretation is a matter plotted by night, or due to ignorance. He says: "It is strange that the neglect of this aspect of important Quranic studies still exists and has not advanced a single step forward. Although government and private publishing institutions are diligent in publishing traditional books on interpretation, some of which suffice for the collection of them, they have closed their doors in the face of the first encyclopedic interpretation of its kind specialized in this type, which is 'Nazm al-Durar' by Al-Biqa'i. There is no excuse for these houses that they seek commercial popularity for books, for this book is in the first degree of popularity due to the lack of a peer for it among scholars, and due to its superior quality on the other hand. Nor is there an excuse for senior scholars in their ignorance of this book, for what we know is that it was permanently on the desk of Sheikh Al-Maraghi [meaning the Sheikh of Al-Azhar], and a senior scholar borrowed sentences from it to create an interpretation he attributed to himself. If withholding the book from printing was to make it a source for plagiarism, then what a miserable deed. And if withholding it with others was execution of a plan intended to keep Muslims in the clamor of boring repetition of the sciences of interpretation, then what a disappointing endeavor" (1). Perhaps among the reasons for turning away from printing this interpretation is the difficulty of reading it, for its phrasing is interlaced, reaching the point of complexity. Not a few readers can barely endure continuing to read it. I have seen this from some students of knowledge, and even its teachers and sheikhs; they can hardly endure it, making the excuse that they did not find what they sought in it!!! They have overlooked [the truth], for what they seek from it - and he told me so - is hidden in the interpretation "Nazm al-Durar" in a manner you may not find a tenth of in others. This interpretation remained trapped in manuscript treasuries until some people of knowledge in the Indian lands were destined for it, so they set about verifying, printing, and publishing it in the Islamic lands:
foot_note: 1. (1) Tanasuq al-Durar by Al-Suyuti: Introduction by Abd al-Qadir Atta: p 40

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: That was from "Da'irat al-Ma'arif al-Uthmaniyyah" in Hyderabad, Deccan, India, a house that has great credit for publishing books of Islamic sciences. This is among the wonders of the Arab lands: people of culture there devote themselves to publishing the book *Al-Futuhat al-Makkiyyah*, the dreams of Al-Wahrani, the epistles of Ibn Sab'in, *Al-Aghani* by Al-Isfahani, the epistles of Ikhwan al-Safa, and the interpretation of Al-Tha'alibi..., while they are stingy towards something like "Al-Biqa'i's" interpretation, leaving students of knowledge in the Indian lands to spend on its verification and publication despite what they suffer. The interpretation was produced in twenty-two volumes of medium size (17x24 cm). The first volume was published in India in the year one thousand three hundred eighty-nine (1389) and the last in the year one thousand four hundred four (1404). Sheikh "Muhammad ibn Abd al-Hamid", Sheikh of Nizamia University, undertook the verification of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth volume (end of Surat Al-Baqarah interpretation - Vol 4, p 194). The young Sheikh: Muhammad ibn Imran al-A'zami al-Ansari al-Umari undertook the verification of the remaining volumes – may Allah Almighty reward them well in the Abode for how they did well by us. The edition was compared with the Morocco "Rabat" copy, the Arif Hikmat copy in Medina, the Zahiriyyah Library copy in Damascus, and the Egyptian National Library copy. The verifier took the Rabat copy as the original without mentioning its number to us, without explaining the reason for choosing it as the original over other copies, and without describing the copies he relied upon nor their numbers in their treasuries, which makes the matter ambiguous. He also did not write an introduction to the verification, which is a very important matter, especially since the book is being verified for the first time, and such a thing would not have cost him much, and I think he is capable of such a thing. The verifier was keen to mention the comparisons of copies in the margin, but he did not explain his methodology in this to us: Does he place in the main text what was in the mother copy even if another is superior, or does he place the correct reading in the text and the rest in the margin?

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: He did not explain to us. Therefore, you find him placing the correct reading sometimes in the text and the other in the margin, and sometimes you find the correct reading in the margin and the error in the text, and it is not from the mother copy. The verification methodology is not straight, and many of his verifications were built on erroneous reading and understanding far from correctness (1). The verifier burdened the margin with quoting much from the interpretation *Tabsri al-Rahman* by Ali al-Mahatmi, which is printed, and from *Al-Bahr al-Muhit* by Abu Hayyan, which is printed and circulated. There is no requirement for this burdening, and what he quotes does not clarify what "Al-Biqa'i" said. Had he directed his attention to adjusting the text, especially some words wrapped in ambiguity or vagueness in Al-Biqa'i's speech, editing it, indicating the clarification of the ambiguity of some phrases, and connecting the speech together due to the distance of its parts in Al-Biqa'i's explanation, it would have been more appropriate. And had he cared for dividing the speech and distinguishing it to help with good reading, it would have been superior. For I suffered greatly in reading the manuscript copy I relied upon in preparing my PhD research {Quranic Correlation according to Burhan al-Din al-Biqa'i} (1399-1402) under the supervision of my Sheikh Muhammad Abd al-Rahman al-Kurdi, despite the clarity of its Naskh script; yet it has misspellings, distortions, and severe omissions. The important point is that the Indian edition became like a rarity in Arab lands, and you can hardly find it except with prohibitive difficulty and at a high price. I suffered from collecting its volumes from the libraries of Hijaz and Najd during five years I resided there (1408-1412). The interpretation is worthy of being re-verified on more and older manuscript copies and published in a well-printed and produced edition.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: If the Indian edition began (Year: 1389) and ended (1404), there is an edition like a stolen one from the Indian edition, committed in Beirut at Dar al-Kutub al-Ilmiyyah (1415). "Abd al-Raziq Ghalib al-Mahdi" undertook the extraction of verses and hadiths and placing footnotes. By comparing this Beirut edition, I became certain that it is the Indian edition transferred with all the errors in the Indian one. There was nothing but the deletion of the verification footnotes and placing hadith extractions in their place. As for the text of the interpretation, it is the same, distorted and misspelled even in the Quranic verses, as you see in the interpretation of the saying of Allah Almighty: {And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient} (Al-Baqarah: 155). Al-Biqa'i used as support in interpreting this verse the saying of Allah Almighty {Fighting has been enjoined upon you while it is hateful to you. But perhaps you hate a thing and it is good for you; and perhaps you love a thing and it is bad for you. And Allah knows, while you know not} (Al-Baqarah: 216). The verse came in the Indian edition as follows (O you who have believed, fighting has been enjoined upon you while it is hateful to you). Likewise in the Beirut edition. It is not hidden from you that the noble verse did not start with this call in the Book of Allah Almighty. Indeed, the matter reached the point that a part of a page from the interpretation was deleted from the Beirut edition: The last page of the first volume of the Indian (p. 357) (Beirut Vol 1, p 322, line 159). The one in charge of the Beirut edition did not notice the significant deletion in his edition which disrupted the text such that the speech does not make sense.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: The Beirut edition also did not make an introduction for its edition, completely imitating the Indian edition. Although Sheikh "Abd al-Raziq al-Mahdi" did well in what he did of extracting the hadiths in the interpretation, so may Allah Almighty reward him on our behalf with the best reward. Were it not for these extractions, the Beirut edition would have no scientific value... Second: Manuscript Copies: I said that the Indian verifier has great credit in bringing out this interpretation worthy of overflowing thanks, but the interpretation needs re-verification on other manuscript copies. The interpretation has very many manuscript copies in Egypt and abroad. I have before me texts listing dozens of manuscript copies and their locations, but I mention some of them, not all: - A copy at the Egyptian National Library under number (213 - Tafsir) in six volumes of large size. It is complete except for the amount of a leaf from the fourth volume (f. 373a - 374b). Its layout is (27 lines). It was written in the year (1270) by the hand of Muhammad Abu al-Fadl al-Safti. The total of its leaves is (2304 f). From it is a photocopy at the National Library number (1006 - Tafsir). I took the original as a source in preparing this PhD research of mine, as it is the clearest copy I could view in Egypt. I finished with it in the year (1402) and was not able to view any part of what was printed in India at that time. In this copy, there are misspellings, distortions, and omission of some words, as if the copyist was not among the careful people of knowledge. - - - - An incomplete copy of it, four volumes only, under number (285 - Tafsir at the Egyptian National Library). The existing volumes: First, Fourth, Sixth, and Eighth. Some of the first volume was written during the author's lifetime. - - - - A complete copy under number (590 / 12855 - Tafsir) at Al-Azhar Library in seven volumes written between the years (1325 - 1331). Its script is good and it is in (3731: f). From it is a transcribed copy under number (2308) at Al-Azhar Library written in the year (1370). - - -

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: - Copy number (229 - Tafsir – Al-Azhar – Turkish Riwaq) in three volumes, total leaves (1527 f) (no date). From it is a photocopied version (Microfilm - under number 650 - Egyptian National Library). - - - - Copy number (150 - Tafsir Taymur) at the Egyptian National Library, only the first volume exists, ending with verse (123 - Al Imran). - - - - Photocopied version (Microfilm) at the Institute of Manuscripts under number (237-279) from the library of (Madina) in Turkey, its number there is (151-154). book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: - Copy number (96-99) in four volumes in the library of "Asir Efendi in Turkey. Index of Asir Efendi p 96 – Egyptian National Library. - - - - A copy in Raghib Pasha Library in Turkey – See Vol 2 p 110 – Index of Rare Manuscripts by Al-Jaza'iri (MS) Egyptian National Library. - - - - A copy in the library of "Ali Pasha al-Corlulu in Turkey – See Index of Rare Manuscripts by Al-Jaza'iri p 57 *** - A copy in Beyazid Library in Turkey – See p 16 – Index of Beyazid Library – Egyptian National Library. - - - - A copy in Wali al-Din Library in Turkey – See p 38 Vol 2 – Index of Wali al-Din Library (MS) at Egyptian National Library. - - - - Four copies in Valide Sultan Library in Turkey number (160-164) – See Index of Valide Sultan Library p 34 (MS) Egyptian National Library. There are numerous other copies, and I only wished to mention this out of belief that this book needs re-verification due to its great importance, and because of the matters that befell the verification in the Indian edition, while other copies are superior to it, despite the favor it bestowed upon us whose light is not hidden from us. So may Allah Almighty reward those who undertook it with the best reward for His Noble Book. ***** The Value of the Book to its Author: A Muslim's joy at Allah Almighty's guidance of him to do a righteous deed is a praiseworthy matter in itself if his joy does not exceed the limit of highlighting Allah Almighty's favor upon him and does not approach the abode of vanity and arrogance. The best thing that pleases a Muslim is what contains general benefit for Muslims such as beneficial knowledge. Not a few people of knowledge used to speak in humility to Allah Almighty about Allah Almighty's favors upon them, as if they are announcing by this to people that if Allah Almighty has poured such favors upon them while they are who they are in the station of servitude to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, then how will He deal with one who is higher than them in that station?

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: In this, there is an urging for people to aspire to the stations of the Holy Effusion, and to establish themselves in stations of exposure to the breezes of Allah Almighty. Al-Biqa'i was one of those who frequently spoke about the favor of Allah Almighty upon him, especially the favor of His Majesty guiding him to author his interpretation "Nazm al-Durar". The phrases that followed in his interpretation expressing his joy with it are very many, including his saying: "This is a wondrous book of high status in an art in which I have not seen anyone precede me, nor has penetrating thought relied upon it" (1). His saying "in an art in which I have not seen anyone precede me" does not mean that he is the first to speak on the correlations (Munasabat) of the Holy Quran, for he has explicitly mentioned those who preceded him in that, but they did not undertake this in their contemplation of the entire Holy Quran, but rather in parts of it. Therefore, looking into his work and their work is requested, for he is the one who established his entire interpretation on the science of Quranic Correlation in all elements of Quranic eloquence. Truly, no one before him undertook this among those whose interpretations have reached us as he did in his interpretation. The origin of the science is undoubtedly preceded, but as for this comprehensive manner, he is truly unique in his age in it. Therefore, you see him mentioning the precedence of "Abu Ja'far ibn al-Zubayr" with his book (*Al-Burhan fi Tartib Suwar al-Quran*) and says: "It is for explaining the appropriateness of following a Surah with another Surah only; he does not address verses in it" (2). He mentioned "Al-Zarkashi's" book (*Al-Burhan fi 'Ulum al-Quran*) and said about it: "I saw that he mentioned in it what defines the value of this book of mine" (3). And he mentioned the interpretation of "Jamal al-Din ibn al-Naqib" (d. 698) named (*Al-Tahrir wa al-Tahbir li Aqwal A'immat al-Tafsir fi Ma'ani Kalam al-Sami' al-Basir*). His student "Al-Dhahabi" said about it in *Mu'jam al-Shuyukh* that it is in ninety-nine volumes covering Qira'at, causes of revelation, parsing, sayings of exegetes, and sayings of Sufis and their realities."

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Biqa'i said about the attention of this interpretation to the correlation of verses and Surahs: "There is much of it in the treasury of the Hakim Mosque. I requested a volume of it and saw the matter was so regarding verses, not their sentences, and regarding stories, not all their verses. Whoever looks into this book of mine along with others will know the ratio between them" (1). He said: "Some Persian scholars spoke to me, and I asked them about something of that, and he found it difficult. Then I established for him the aspect of its appropriateness, and asked him: Did it become clear to him? He said: 'O my master, this speech of yours races to the mind.' So do not think, O viewer of this book of mine, that the correlations were like that before the unveiling of their mask and the lifting of their curtains. Many a verse I spent months contemplating, among them: {And [remember] when you left your family in the morning to post the believers at their stations for the battle. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing} (Al-Imran: 121), and {And they request from you a [legal] ruling concerning women. Say, 'Allah gives you a ruling about them...'} (Al-Nisa: from verse 127), {They request from you a [legal] ruling. Say, 'Allah gives you a ruling concerning one having neither descendants nor ascendants...'} (Al-Nisa: from verse 176). Whoever wants to verify that, let him contemplate some of the verses before looking at what I said, then let him look at it; it will appear to him what I tired myself in, and what was achieved from Allah Almighty, and from the help, whether the face of that appeared upon his contemplation or not. Likewise, if he sees what others mentioned of correlations of some verses" (2). He also said: "These purposes are not revealed completely except to one who wades into the depth of this book, and becomes confident and correct from its beginning, end, and middle. None will remember except those of understanding. Al-Zarkashi mentioned about four leaves of correlations of some verses, and if you contemplate them, what is in this swelling sea of precious gems will become great in your estimation" (3).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: He said: "Divine support supplied me in it - and praise be to Allah - so I made it like a companion to the interpretation of Judge Nasir al-Din al-Baydawi. Perhaps its facilitation was by the blessing of a glad tiding from the traces of prophecy I saw in my boyhood, while I was around ten of my years in our village in the land of Bekaa..." (1). He said about it: (The interpretation which ages have not allowed the like of, nor has flowed upon them from interpretations, despite their large numbers, like the pouring of its rain) (2). He mentions at its end, praising it, a poem of Majzu' al-Rajaz meter, saying: (I said praising the mentioned book for what it revealed of the wonders of destiny and strange matters, explaining my state and their state, and the success of my hopes and the disappointment of their hopes, from Majzu' "Rajaz" and its beat is Maqtu' and the rhyme is Mutawatir, Mutlaq, Mujarrad, naming it "Kitab Lamma" (Book of When/Since) because most of its purpose is explaining the connection of sentences to one another such that every sentence holds the belt of what is before it, connected to it. That is the intended manifestation of speech, its secret and core which is to speech like the soul. And explaining the meanings of vocabulary and every sentence on its own is like the body. So the soul is the greatest intent, realized by one who tastes and understands, and whose mind travels in the fields of structures and knows. "Lamma" is an adverb intended for the establishment of the second of what it entered upon by the establishment of the first at the utmost possibility, meaning it is like the conditional requiring two sentences, necessary for that necessary implication. So the book was completed in this system with "Lamma" because I frequently used it in it for this purpose (3). Among what he said about his interpretation in his book *Masa'id al-Nazar*:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: "Allah bestowed - and to Him is praise - upon me my crafting of the book: 'Al-Munasabat bayn al-Suwar wa al-Ayat' (Correlations between Surahs and Verses), nay sentences and words, which ages have not truly allowed the like of without exaggeration, nor has a weaver woven on its pattern and shape, informing of the truth without pride and haughtiness. For it brought out from the Book of Allah Almighty hidden secrets no one had attained, and showed strange lights not a glimmer of which anyone had stumbled upon or found, and made flow thoughts of rivers whose sweet springs no one had issued from or arrived at. My heart was in it for long periods a captive of inspirations and a companion of fleeing hidden things. I clarified in it secrets of verses whose apparent interpretation no one had clarified, and I showed secrets of Surahs whose hidden conscience no one had revealed" (1). And what he mentioned about it in his book *Al-Fath al-Qudsi*: I said clarifying its virtue, the straightness of its method, and the honor of its paths: Have you seen, O people of Interpretation, one who crafted * An interpretation like Nazm al-Durar It is precise in meaning, majestic in casting its wording * In the faces of thought like white blazes And I said, and from truth I have not deviated: This is a book unique in Correlation * By Allah, none has woven on its pattern It baffled with its precision and tight construction * Whoever aimed to bring the people an example And I said - and the scholar "Burhan al-Din ibn al-Zahirah, Judge of the Shafi'is in Mecca had asked him to write it, as its position was great with him: I showed in the interpretation what baffled mankind * Its secrets, and the Quran glorified it What do the envious say when * "The Proof" (Al-Burhan) has come to spread its virtue among people (2). These are some texts of Al-Biqa'i's essays about his interpretation, in which speaking of Allah Almighty's favor upon him mixes with his joy that Allah Almighty made him the place of this effusion. He announces in these texts that he does not say them out of pride and haughtiness, but says them as a clarification of a truth and thanks for a favor the Benefactor, Majesty be to Him, bestowed upon him. *** Scholars' Stance on His Interpretation:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Biqa'i mentions that people divided regarding his interpretation into three sections: Praiser, Critic, and Silent who showed no face (1). ((The Praisers)) Al-Biqa'i cited in his books (*Masa'id al-Nazar*) and (*Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah*) endorsements (Taqriz) of the notables of his time for his book (*Nazm al-Durar*) such as "Al-Sharaf al-Munawi", "Al-Muhibb ibn al-Shihna", "Husam al-Din al-Tahtawi", "Al-Izz al-Hanbali", "Amin al-Din al-Aqsara'i", "Sayf al-Din al-Sirafi", "Muhyi al-Din al-Kafiyaji", "Taqi al-Din al-Shumni", and "Taqi al-Din al-Hisni". Among what came in those endorsements: What "Sharaf al-Din al-Munawi" said: "To proceed, I have viewed from this good, excellent composition what expressed that its author is a learned Imam in the arts of knowledge, for he has done well and excelled and showed from a good collection a good collection in the utmost correctness... So this composition deserves to be received with acceptance and no saying of an envier or blamer regarding it should be listened to. May Allah Almighty keep its author a spring for those coming to drink and perpetuate benefit by it and by his sciences for Muslims, on the nineteenth of Sha'ban year eight hundred sixty-eight) (2). Among what Muhibb al-Din ibn al-Shihna said: "To proceed: The poor, weak, insignificant servant has viewed this peerless compilation comprising from the pure spring the sweet water, and found its author has adorned in it, from the virgin daughters of his thoughts restricted in tents for the noble qualified ones of minds and understandings, every pearl difficult to attain... May Allah Almighty keep him to show benefits and reward him from His hidden kindnesses according to the most beautiful habits by His grace and generosity..." (3). Among what Husam al-Din al-Tahtawi said:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: "To proceed, I have viewed a part of the book marked as 'Nazm al-Durar min Tanasub al-Ay wa al-Suwar' compiled by the Sheikh, the Imam, the Very Learned, the Traveler, the Hafiz 'Burhan al-Din al-Biqa'i', may Allah honor the Bekaa [valley] by him. He spread from its benefits and unique pearls what minds delight in and ears are adorned with. I saw it in its chapter strange in its expression coming upon its Arabic and non-Arabic aspects. He has dived into the seas of sciences and extracted from them unique pearls, and probed their beauties and collected from them the best blazes, and tracked the anomalies of anecdotes and collected from them what scattered, and sent his horses in their racecourses so they won the betting rod, disposing in them how he wished. At that, the upper arm of his envier weakened, and in it he languished. May Allah Almighty return of his blessings and benefit us with his righteous prayers" (1). Among what Amin al-Din al-Aqsara'i said: "To proceed, I was honored by viewing places of the wondrous compilation crowned with 'Nazm al-Durar min Tanasub al-Ay wa al-Suwar' authored by our master and lord, the Imam, the Very Learned, the Ink, the Understanding, the Investigator, the Verifier, possessor of high compositions in the regions, openings from the Lord of Lords dispensed of prolixity in titles, the pure essence of the summary of the ancients and the elite of the later Imams, may Allah Almighty increase him in knowledge and action... Whoever looks into his composition with the eye of fairness and leaves arbitrariness knows the amount of betting rods he won in the track of verification and success..." (2). Among what "Muhyi al-Din al-Kafiyaji" said: "...This book 'Nazm al-Durar' is a book of great status, bright explanation, founded with good arrangement and quality system on the best jewels of rules, studded with types of unique benefits and returns. It is a sea whose wonders do not end, and whose strange things do not terminate. It is described by what you see as the focus of the circle of precision and clarification and a gift from the gifts of the Generous Merciful. A book in its secrets is joy * Speaking to it saves from sorrows How many a wondrous meaning under a word * There they paired in every coupling.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: The poor servant has contemplated it truly as should be in many places, and found it full of types of precious organized proportionate high pearls, crowned with types of shining expensive gems, its beginning fitting its end, and coupled with the subtleties of minute meanings and implication with observance of context and precedence. For this reason, it became a famous proverb in countries and horizons. None of the virtuous and scholars swam in its sea except the Very Learned Scholar... The Sheikh, the Magnanimous Imam, honor of the predecessors, best of successors, the teacher, the author, the Mufti Burhan al-Din Abu al-Hasan Ibrahim famous as Al-Biqa'i..." (1). Other endorsements than this he established in his book (*Masa'id al-Nazar*), and he decides that his purpose was not to present his interpretation to any of the Imams to endorse it, but when some envious people spoke against it, he was forced to present it to the Imams to testify to what is in it. It was not his habit in the beginning of his affair to be keen on taking the handwriting of his sheikhs with their endorsement on his writings. His companions used to blame him for that, so he used to say to them: "If I reach an age where knowledge is taken from the likes of me, if I am worthy in myself, I do not need the testimony of anyone, and if I am not worthy, the licenses of Sheikhs will not benefit me" (2). Those whose endorsements Al-Biqa'i mentioned are not all his supporters in some of his stances in which he fought, especially his stances on Ibn Arabi and Ibn al-Farid and proponents of Unity of Existence (Wahdat al-Wujud) and Union (Ittihad)... You see him saying in the introduction of mentioning the endorsement of "Amin al-Din al-Aqsara'i": "He inclined against the Sunnis in the fitna of 'Ibn al-Farid', and Allah - and to Him is praise - sufficed against him, and he harmed only himself." And he said in presenting the endorsement of "Adud al-Din al-Sirafi": "He was silent in the fitna of 'Ibn al-Farid'."

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: This which I mentioned is some praise of his contemporary people of knowledge. As for the praise of scholars after him for this interpretation, it is very much, space does not allow mentioning it. It suffices you to look at what "Ibn Hajar al-Haytami al-Makki" said, who is among the obstinate opponents of Al-Biqa'i in his stance on Ibn al-Farid and Ibn Arabi, and what Al-Shawkani said about Al-Biqa'i's interpretation despite the fact that Al-Shawkani does not adopt the school of correlation of verses and Surahs. Al-Shawkani says: "Whoever looks deeply into his book... in interpretation which he made regarding the correlations between verses and Surahs knows that he is among the vessels of knowledge, excessive in intelligence, combining the science of the rational and the transmitted. Often something in the Book confuses me, so I return to the long interpretations and their summaries and find nothing that heals, and I return to this book – Nazm al-Durar – and find in it what benefits mostly" (1). *** ((The Opponents)) At the head of Al-Biqa'i's opponents was his peer "Shams al-Din al-Sakhawi": Muhammad ibn Abd al-Rahman ibn Muhammad (d. 902). He held the view that Al-Biqa'i had been audacious against the Book of Allah Almighty with this interpretation of his and that he relied on quoting from the Torah and Gospel in his interpretation. So "Al-Sakhawi" authored his book: "Al-Asl al-Asil fi Tahrim al-Naql min al-Tawrah wa al-Injil" (2). "Al-Badr ibn al-Qattan" was among the fiercest opponents of Al-Biqa'i, and the dispute heated between them, so "Al-Biqa'i" satirized him with what repels a person from mentioning (3). The summary of what the opponents objected to in his interpretation: This is a book whose existence among people is not lawful because it is two parts: - Transfer from the distorted ancient books: Torah, Gospel, and Psalms, and this is not lawful. - Speech from his own self, so it is interpretation by opinion which is not lawful. That he plagiarized the essays of others and attributed them to himself. There is no need for such an interpretation, nor reliance upon it, and it does not fill a gap in others.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: His claim that some people of knowledge asked him to separate between his interpretation and the Quranic text with the word (i.e. / meaning) so his speech would not be confused with the Holy Quran. This is among what led to accusing him of disbelief, and attempting to establish the penalty for apostasy upon him (1). "Ibn Iyas" says in the events of the month of "Dhu al-Hijjah" of the year (877): "Among the incidents in this month is that 'Al-Burhan al-Biqa'i' and the Judge of the Community 'Abu Abdullah al-Qaljani al-Maghribi al-Maliki' had a discussion regarding some issues. An answer occurred from 'Al-Burhan al-Biqa'i' in that assembly which the Judge of the Community recorded against him, and declared his disbelief, and testified against him (2). He wanted the lawsuit to be established against him before the Maliki Chief Judge. When the Confidential Secretary 'Ibn Mizhar' knew of that, he requested 'Al-Biqa'i' to his presence, and some judges ruled for sparing his blood. Were it not for the Confidential Secretary, no good would have happened to 'Al-Biqa'i'. What happened to 'Al-Biqa'i' was because of the sin of 'Ibn al-Farid', for he was the head of those zealous against him (3). 'Al-Biqa'i' continued in reversal until he died." "Ibn Hajar al-Haytami" says: "It was recorded against him in his Correlations, so he was judged with disbelief and the shedding of his blood, and nothing remained of that except taking his soul, were it not that he sought help from some notables until he saved him from that predicament, and he was asked to repent in the Salihhiyah in Egypt and he renewed his Islam" (4).
foot_note:
1. (1) Nazm al-Durar: 22/244, Masa'id al-Nazar: 1/111-112, 136, 147, Al-Badr al-Tali': 1/20
2. It is not befitting for anyone, let alone a person of knowledge, let alone a Judge of the Community, to strive to make one of the Muslims fall into what does not please, nor to lie in wait for him counting his slips. Rather, the Muslim's nature is apologetic, accepting the excuses of his brothers, nay establishing excuses for them within himself increasing his approach to them even if they have no excuse within themselves.
3. This is misguidance and misleading which a rational Muslim cannot be silent about: How can confronting evil and commanding good in the chapter of Tawhid be a cause for punishment?
4. Al-Fatawa al-Hadithiyyah by Ibn Hajar al-Haytami al-Makki: p 53. And Bada'i' al-Zuhur by Ibn Iyas – Vol 3 p 89

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Biqa'i refuted those objections. ** Al-Biqa'i authored for refuting the saying of prohibition of transferring from distorted ancient books his book: "Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah fi Hukm al-Naql min al-Kutub al-Qadimah" in which he showed that he followed in this the trace of the Imams from the Salaf (1). ** The saying that it is interpretation by opinion has no basis; he refuted it as the saying of an ignorant person who does not know the difference between interpretation and speaking by opinion regarding the Holy Quran (2). ** The saying that he plagiarized the essays of others and attributed them to himself; he rejected it saying it is strange that he alone is the one aware of those sayings, so why did others not see them? The stranger thing – as he says – is that this renews for him at every question or whenever a difficulty appeared in the verse. He is the one who noted in this book of his quoting from a group whom the "Egyptians" did not know except from him, such as "Abu al-Hasan al-Haralli" and "Abu al-Fadl al-Mashdali al-Maghribi". Some Maghrebis asked him to drop the mention of "Al-Mashdali" from his interpretation so he would copy the book and send it to Morocco, for the Maghrebis do not acknowledge merit for "Al-Mashdali", so he refused that (3). ** The saying that the book does not fill a gap, there is no need for it, and no reliance upon it is refuted by the fact that his book stands such that were it not for it, most of them would be exposed if a debater stood against him regarding the Holy Quran, and conversed with him regarding many sentences from people of religions in a place where he is safe from injustice and does not fear the power of the sword. Then he mentions examples of those verses which, were it not for his interpretation of them, it would be possible for the obstinate disbeliever to attack many (4). ** The saying that he was asked to separate between his speech and the Quran but refused; I did not view a refutation by Al-Biqa'i on it.
