book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Perhaps it is among what was rumored about him falsely, or he saw it as an opinion too trivial to reply to, and he is clearly right in this. For that is a very strange accusation for a man who announces morning and evening the affirmation of the inimitability of the Holy Quran. Add to this that mixing the Holy Quran with the speech of the exegete such that it does not appear is a matter that never stands, and people of knowledge do not all separate in their interpretations with the word (i.e. / meaning), and we see Al-Biqa'i mentioning it in his interpretation in numerous places in the manuscript copies. The truth is that this interpretation of his is not dispensable by other books of interpretation in the chapter of interpreting the appropriateness of sentences, verses, ties, and Surahs. No one becomes certain of its high status among previous and subsequent books of interpretation except one who endured and persevered in reading it a reading of research and inspection. As for one who looked into it a hasty look, he is closer to turning away from it than accepting it. It is among the books that teach the student of knowledge looking into it the methodology of contemplation and pondering due to the hidden meanings in it. Struggling with difficult knowledge has a pleasure, and Al-Biqa'i's interpretation grants you an overflow of that pleasure. I do not find sweet the explanation that is exposed, for dominant on such is its lack of many minute meanings and their subtleties and many Ihsani meanings, because the nature of those Ihsani meanings is such that exposed human explanation is incapable of carrying them. *** {Dalalat al-Burhan al-Qawim 'ala Tanasub Ay al-Quran al-Azim} It is as if Al-Biqa'i felt that the expansion of speech in his interpretation and his addressing of matters that others might see as not part of interpretation at all, or that do not help the reader with good following and awareness, especially one who is impatient with the trouble of reception, so he intended to summarize his interpretation: Nazm al-Durar, and named it (Dalalat al-Burhan al-Qawim 'ala Tanasub Ay al-Quran al-Azim). This summary is still a manuscript. Of the first part of it, there is a manuscript copy in the Central Library of Imam Muhammad ibn Saud Islamic University number (4724), which is (464 f) photocopied from a copy in Turkey - Istanbul) number (853).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: The photocopy of this part contains not a little blotting and damage from which the reader may not discern the meaning. Hence, I claim that this copy alone might not help its verifier in good verification and editing of the text. Perhaps Allah Almighty will destine for it one who possesses the ability to bring other copies aiding people of knowledge in verifying, editing, and publishing it. The verifier of the book (*Masa'id al-Nazar*) had the credit of guiding me to it, so may Allah reward him with the best reward. I had no knowledge of it while I was preparing my PhD research in the year (1399). In my library, there is a copy of this manuscript part awaiting completion and finding another copy to verify and bring it out to students of knowledge if Allah Almighty wills. The part I was honored to acquire a copy of ends with the end of the summary of the interpretation of Surah "Al-Ma'idah": The Introduction took from (f: 2 / b – 7 / a), Al-Fatiha from 7 / a – 35 / b), Al-Baqarah from (35 / b - 261 / a), Al-Imran from (261 / a - 327 / a), Al-Nisa from (327 / a - 399 / b), and Al-Ma'idah from (399 / a - to the end of the manuscript part). In the beginning of this manuscript copy (f: 1-7), his saying after the Basmalah, Hamd, and Salah: "To proceed, I wanted in this Diwan of great status to summarize my book: Nazm al-Durar min Tanasub al-Ay wa al-Suwar min al-Furqan, because it became long by driving hadiths, turning over materials of language, and citing what witnesses from ancient books to the invalidity of religions opposing Islam... and I increase it - if Allah wills - replacing what I delete from it with what raises it over... Gemini and Libra. I adjust in it - as I did in its original - the Surah with a statement of its objective, for it is a guide to knowing its correlation. I indicate it by applying between it and the indication of its name whether that is one or more and whether it is a name of meaning or a letter of spelling; because the name of every Surah translates its objective; because for every thing, the appropriateness between it and its named is noticed, its title indicating in general the detail of what is in it.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: I interpret the Basmalah with what suits that objective without departing from the indications of words from the perspective of language. Then I start in the Surah after linking its beginning to the end of what is before it. I interpret the word, whether from the names of Allah Almighty or others, according to the preceding and following speech, while preserving the linguistic law, even if extracting that from the speech of linguists is difficult for one who has not practiced the language. I interpret the word with two words or more as clarification because a single word does not stand in place of a word from the Quran at all. Thereby appear the secrets of specification of some synonymous names like Sanah, 'Am, Hawl, and Hujjah (year) in some places, while another synonymous to it does not stand in another place, for the context looks at the origin of the meaning from which that word is derived, so another meaning from the origin of derivation joins the meaning for which that word was coined, so the synonym does not stand in its place due to missing what the derivation performed as called for by the context..." He expanded the discussion in the introduction of the (Summarized) book just as he expanded in the introduction of the original (*Nazm al-Durar*). He does not undertake summarization by deleting sentences from the original only; rather, he performs types of advancing and delaying, rephrasing, and adding things to the original: words, sentences, and paragraphs. Whoever compares his work in his interpretation of Al-Fatiha in the original (*Nazm al-Durar*) and his summary (*Dalalat al-Burhan*) realizes that his work in the Summary is straighter and more coordinated than his work in the Original. He does not care in the Summary to quote from the treatises of "Al-Haralli": Miftah al-Bab al-Muqfal, as his care for that was in the Original. Nor does he care - also - in the Summary to quote from the book of "Abu Ja'far ibn al-Zubayr": "Al-Burhan" as in the Original. In Surah Al-Fatiha (f: 7), he begins by explaining the reason for naming it Al-Fatiha, Umm al-Quran, Al-Asas, Al-Mathani, Al-Kanz, and Al-Shafiyah... and addresses the number of its verses and the scholars' stance on that when naming it the Seven Mathani and the reason for choosing the number seven.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: He mentions that the High Attributes are seven: Life, Knowledge, Power, Will, Speech, Hearing, and Sight, and to these attributes return all names we know. (f: 8/b). This is according to Ash'ari principles, and this limitation has no support from the Book and Sunnah or a trace from the tracks of the Companions, may Allah Almighty be pleased with them. He explains its objective and does not deviate from what is in the Original except with something of slight increase or decrease: He says in the Summary: "Its objective: Establishing Allah Almighty's entitlement to all praises, attributes of perfection, and sovereignty of the world and the Hereafter, and entitlement to worship and seeking help in bestowing by binding to the path of the successful and rescuing from the path of the destroyed, being exclusive in all that. The axis of this is the servants' observation (Muraqabah) of their Lord; to single Him out in worship because He encompasses all attributes of perfection and is exclusive in them. So He is its objective essentially and other than Him are means to Him. For it is necessary in that to establish His encompassing, Glory be to Him, of everything, and it will not be established until it is known that He is the exclusive one in being the Creator, the King, the Owner; because the purpose of sending Messengers and revealing Books is establishing laws, and the purpose of establishing laws is gathering creation upon the Truth, and the purpose of gathering them is introducing them to the King and what pleases Him. And what pleases Him is not known except through Messengers, and that will not happen except through what was mentioned of knowledge and action. Its names indicate observation: its objective; because everything that is not opened with the observation of Allah Almighty is not counted, and it is the mother of every good and the foundation of every kindness, and it is not counted unless it is doubled, so it was permanently repeating..." (1)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: After explaining the relationship of its names to its objective, he proceeds to the aspect of opening with the Basmalah and the relationship of this naming to its objective (f: 9/a) and how the ratio of Basmalah from Al-Fatiha is the ratio of Al-Fatiha from the Holy Quran, so Al-Fatiha was headed by Basmalah. And how advancing the preposition indicated Oneness and that He is the God, and His name Al-Rahman indicated the clarification of laws by revealing books and sending messengers, and His name Al-Rahim indicated the success of some of the invited and the abandonment of some of them. And that this is the summary of Surah Al-Fatiha which is the summary of the detail of the rest of the Quran. He explained the reason for legislating seeking refuge (Isti'adhah) at the opening of reading and the ruling of this seeking refuge according to scholars and the formula which is most appropriate, and what is in the formula of seeking refuge of indicative signs, and what is in starting the Basmalah and ending it with a labial letter. Afterward, he started analyzing the Basmalah, concerned with interpreting the Beautiful Names in it. Here (f: 11/a) he does not quote from "Al-Haralli" as he was doing in the Original: "Nazm al-Durar", just as he is here more organized regarding the overlapping of speech in the Original, while the Summary he did not mix his speech with Al-Haralli's speech, so it was straighter. He expands the discussion in interpreting the Basmalah more than he expanded in the Original. He confirms that "there is no repetition at all in anything of the Book of Allah Almighty, rather whatever you find in it repeated is for a meaning other than the preceding or for an increase in its meaning by emphasis for what the state required, so rhetoric is not complete except with repetition" (f: 14/a). He points to the indicative sign of the number of Basmalah letters in script and their number in pronunciation, saying: "The Basmalah being nineteen scriptural letters and eighteen pronounced ones is a sign that they are repellents of vengeance by the Fire whose keepers are nineteen, and bringers of mercy by the Rak'ahs of the five prayers and the Witr Rak'ah which are the greatest of worships" (1). This is among what he mentioned in the Original. He explains the aspect of bringing Al-Hamd after the Basmalah and that this is from observing the counterpart. Here he does not suffice with what he brought in the Original "Nazm al-Durar" but adds to it what clarifies it.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: He says: "Since the Basmalah is a type of praise, it suited every suitability to follow it to achieve doubling with the name of general Praise (Al-Hamd) gathering all its individuals, coupled with 'Lam of Definition' indicating in what it connected to its end and perfection, making known, Glory be to Him, to His servants how to praise Him due to His knowledge of their inability to bring what befits Him, Glory be to Him. For this, the Master of the first and the last, peace be upon him, said: 'I cannot enumerate praise upon You, You are as You praised Yourself.' As if it was said: Praise Him; because He is the one entitled to all praises, and specify this type of praise in opening your affairs, due to what was mentioned of sensing desire for Him and fear of Him leading to adhering to the path of guidance" (1). He cared in the Summary "Dalalat al-Burhan" to detail the saying on the indication of the material of Hamd (f: 16/b), which he did not do in the Original "Nazm al-Durar" in his interpretation of Surah Al-Fatiha. While in the Original: "Nazm al-Durar" he quoted the essay of "Al-Sa'd al-Taftazani" on the aspect of opening five Surahs of the Holy Quran with 'Al-Hamdu Lillah', in the Summary "Dalalat al-Burhan" he mentions that in general without reference to "Al-Sa'd's" essay (f: 16/a). He quotes a little from "Al-Haralli" from his interpretation while expanding the quote from him in his interpretation and his treatise "Al-Miftah" in the Original: "Nazm al-Durar". He clarifies for us the aspect of describing Allah Almighty with his saying: "Rabb al-Alamin" (Lord of the Worlds), and he poured forth in explaining the meaning of the Worlds. Then he decides: "That Mankind and Jinn are incapable of bringing the like of Basmalah and Hamdalah, nay even bringing a word parallel to a word of their words, and sufficing for it in all its indications. Likewise every verse of the verses of the Noble Quran, nay every word cannot have in its meaning in its style and the state which required it what stands in its place, even if counted as synonymous.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: This is known only to one who has dived deep into the science of literature, especially vocabulary of the language, and verified the stations for which the verses were driven, and what they require of brevity, detail, praise, blame, and others, the ranks of each of that, or understood what I mentioned in turning over the materials in the origin of this book" (1). We see him in his interpretation of the saying of Allah Almighty: {Guide us to the straight path} (Al-Fatiha: 6) saying what he did not say in the Original: "Nazm al-Durar" in this place, so I liked for you to hear. He says:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: "(Ihdina) [Guide us]: The origin of Huda (Guidance) is to become transitive to a first object by itself, and to a second by a preposition. It is either 'Ila' (to) which is the origin, like His saying, Glory be to Him: {Guide us to the straight path} (Al-Fatiha: 6) [Note: The verse cited here uses direct object, the example with 'Ila' is usually elsewhere, e.g., Yunus 25, possibly a slight confusion in text or referencing specific verse context] {And indeed, you guide to a straight path} (Al-Shura: from verse 52). Or 'Lam' (for) indicating that the Guide has great effect in guidance, and from it: {Indeed, this Quran guides to that which is most suitable} (Al-Isra: from verse 9). It may be expanded, so the preposition is deleted if a more eloquent effect is intended than what was intended by Lam, so it becomes transitive by itself, to indicate including the meaning of 'Ilzam' (bind/adhere), like His saying Almighty: {And guide you to a straight path} (Al-Fath: from verse 2). Like this letter, so the meaning is clearer to us by clarifying the road, and creating success in everything that pleases You, for me and all Your servants, that You guide us and lead us a very great guidance with kindness and support by adding the powers by which we are enabled to know the beneficial, and setting up proofs distinguishing between truth and falsehood, and illuminating our insights, and granting us success to adhere to (Al-Sirat), meaning the most perfect road as felt by the 'Lam' of perfection, and masculinity, the Wide Clear one which swallows [Yastrits - with un-dotted Sin] and swallows it due to what it has of width metonymized by its ease and clarity as indicated by the composition of its letters, and the difference of readers regarding them with contemplation of their attributes: The opening (Infitah) of its 'Sin' which is the origin in this material in the narration of 'Qunbul' from 'Ibn Kathir' and 'Ruways' from 'Ya'qub', and its 'Zay' generated from impregnating the 'Sad' in the reading of 'Hamza', and its 'Ra', and the whistling (Safir) of the first two, and the 'Sad' substituted from the 'Sin' according to the rest,

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: and the elevation (Itbaq) of its 'Sad' and 'Ta' and their rising (Isti'la), and the loudness (Jahr) of 'Zay', 'Ra', and 'Ta', and the strength (Shiddah) of 'Ta' and its Qalqalah (echoing), and what it has of Tafkhim (heaviness), and the repetition (Takrir) of 'Ra' which resembled with the heavy rising letters the softness (Rakhawah) of 'Sin', 'Sad', and 'Zay', and the whispering (Hams) of the first two, and the lowering (Istifal) of 'Sin', 'Zay', and 'Ra', and its standing between strength and softness. So there mixed for it, by what these letters described with these opposing attributes of softness and strength showed, a wondrous matter having a strange secret needing long explanation pointing [to] the Hadith: 'Religion is ease, and no one will contend with religion but it will overcome him' (1) and the Hadith: 'Indeed this religion is solid, so penetrate into it with gentleness' (2) and similar ones. I only said: These meanings are benefited from these letters intended for this specific composition; because the coiner of this wise language is Allah Almighty, and He Glory be to Him made by His wisdom between the indicative letters and the meanings understood from them a correlation understood by people of insights. The existence of strong attributes more than soft ones in the letters of this word indicates that it is befitting in the state of wayfaring that fear be more dominant on the wayfarer than hope... This is what the letters indicated essentially and branch-wise from the perspective of attributes. And the unity of their place of articulation, which is 'the tip of the tongue' which is the widest of outlets and the most hidden, and while being the middle of them is the nearest of the middle to the conclusion, [indicated] that it is the widest of religions, the easiest, and the nearest to the Hour, so there is no religion awaited after it, nor a prophet sent after its Prophet, and that it is one even if its branches multiplied, and that the many are only paths of misguidance..." (3)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: This which I quoted here, I do not find in the Original "Nazm al-Durar" in his interpretation of Surah "Al-Fatiha". It is as you see important, making you feel that while he summarizes his interpretation in "Dalalat al-Burhan", he was not undertaking deletion of some of what was in the Original, rather he is undertaking matters beyond deletion that are very majestic and important, making the Original not dispense with its summary. - - -.. {Masa'id al-Nazar li al-Ishraf 'ala Maqasid al-Suwar} That is its title in all manuscript copies I viewed or sources I mentioned. Al-Biqa'i himself mentions it by that name in several places of his writings. After mentioning its name in its opening, he says: ..."And it is fit to be named: Al-Maqsad al-Asma fi Mutabaqat Ism Kull Surah li al-Musamma" (1). He began authoring this book during his authoring of the book "Nazm al-Durar" in the year eight hundred seventy (870) in Cairo. He says: "My beginning in it was in the middle of Shawwal of the year seventy, and my finishing of its draft was on the night of Friday the fourteenth of Jumada al-Ula of the year eight hundred seventy-one (871). And my finishing of this copy [the author's copy deposited at the Institute of Manuscripts in Cairo] was the night of Tuesday the fourteenth of Sha'ban of the year. All of that in my home and mosque in Rahbat Bab al-Eid of Al-Mu'izziyah Cairo". Printed and Manuscript Copies of the Book: The book remained a manuscript until the year one thousand four hundred eight of the Hijra when Dr. Abdul Sami' Muhammad Ahmad Hasanyn, Assistant Professor at Imam Muhammad ibn Saud Islamic University in Riyadh, brought it out successfully to good, verified, annotated, and with its hadiths extracted in three volumes. He verified it on two copies: The author's copy, written in the year eight hundred seventy-one, deposited at the Institute of Manuscripts in Cairo in (146 f), and a copy at the Egyptian National Library under number (19691/b) in (149 f), turning away from another copy in the Egyptian National Library due to its poor quality and another copy in Rabat, Morocco. The truth is that the verifier has done well by the book and us, so may Allah Almighty reward him with the best reward.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: I had prepared my PhD study on a manuscript copy which is copy number (19691b) at the Egyptian National Library, which the book's verifier relied upon. There is another manuscript copy at the Egyptian National Library other than what the verifier mentioned, number (20323/b), copied from (19691/b) and its script is better, copied in the year (1356). And another copy in the library of Asir Efendi in Turkey = See Index of Rare Manuscripts by Al-Jaza'iri - Vol: 2 p 48, 69 - (MS) Egyptian National Library. Goal of the Book: Al-Biqa'i explains that his book stands to clarify the objectives of Surahs to realize the knowledge of the truth from the interpretation of every verse of those Surahs. It is as if his book completes his book: (Nazm al-Durar), for it is like an introduction to it. Therefore, he made its rank first in terms of being like a definition, so it is a general knowledge of the interpretation of Surahs, and his book (Nazm al-Durar) is a detailed knowledge of their interpretation. Thus, his book Al-Masa'id is among what is known as Quranic Sciences auxiliary to the science of Quran interpretation; it is among what speaks about the Great Quran and not among what speaks in it, so it is like what defines the philosophy of the science and not the science itself. His Methodology and Plan in it: "Al-Biqa'i" made for his book "Al-Masa'id" a long introduction in which he explained the name of the book, his invention of it, and the motive for authoring it due to what happened to him because of his book (Nazm al-Durar), mentioning scholars' stances on his interpretation, praise and objection. He quoted some endorsements of scholars for his interpretation, then spoke about the science of Correlation (Tanasub), defining it and explaining its status in the science of Rhetoric, its goal and benefit, and other things that occurred to him (1). Then he began dealing with Quranic Surahs as follows: - He explains the status of the Surah regarding Meccan and Medinan and scholars' opinions, determining the difference. In Surah "Al-Fatiha", he explains the rule of Meccan and Medinan saying: "Everything revealed before the Hijra is Meccan, and everything revealed after it is Medinan, even if the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family and companions, was in another town at the time of its revelation...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: And what was revealed in either of the two cities did not come arranged in one sequence; because the order of revelation was according to need and events. Then the order of the Uthmani Mushaf, transferred from the Mushafs which 'Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq', may Allah be pleased with them, copied, transferred from the parchments written before our Master the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family and companions, by his command, and according to how he was commanded to arrange it as Allah Almighty commanded him, abrogated it [the chronological order]. He used to say when a verse was revealed to him: Put it in Surah such-and-such between verse such-and-such and the verse before it" (1). He says in Surah "Al-Imran": "Medinan by consensus, thus they said. 'Al-Najm al-Nasafi' said in his Taysir: Meccan in the saying of 'Ikrimah' and 'Al-Hasan al-Basri', Medinan in the saying of the generality of exegetes. 'Al-Ja'bari' said in Sharh al-Shatibiyyah: Medinan except five verses which are Meccan" (2). He says in Surah Al-Nisa: "Medinan by consensus, thus some said. 'Al-Asbahani' said except one verse revealed in Mecca in the Year of Conquest regarding 'Uthman ibn Abi Talha', which is: {Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due and when you judge between people to judge with justice. Excellent is that which Allah instructs you. Indeed, Allah is ever Hearing and Seeing} (Al-Nisa: 58). It was said it was revealed upon the migration of the Prophet, peace be upon him. And it was said the Surah is Meccan. There is no disagreement that some of it was revealed in Medina. The apparent is the first, for in 'Al-Bukhari' from 'Aisha', may Allah be pleased with them: Surah 'Al-Nisa' was not revealed except while I was with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. And there is no disagreement that the Prophet, peace be upon him, consummated marriage with her in Medina" (3). In this methodology is an indication from him that verifying the knowledge of that aids in perceiving the features of the Surah's objective and meanings. - - -

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: - He explains what the Surah is named, even if its names are numerous. That is because he holds that "the name of every Surah translates its objective; because for every thing, the appropriateness between it and its named is noticed, its title indicating generally the detail of what is in it" (1). He explains to us the names of Surah Al-Fatiha saying: "So this Surah's name, along with Al-Fatiha, is Umm al-Quran, Umm al-Kitab, Al-Sab' al-Mathani, Al-Asas, Al-Mathani, Al-Kanz, Al-Shafiyah, Al-Kafiyah, Al-Waqiyah, Al-Shifa, Al-Ruqyah, Al-Hamd, Al-Shukr, Al-Du'a, and Al-Salah" (2). He says in Surah Al-Baqarah: "And it is named: Al-Sanam (The Hump), Al-Dhirwah (The Peak), Al-Zahra (The Radiant), and Al-Fustat (The Tent)." He says in Surah "Bara'ah": "Its name is also Al-Tawbah, Al-Fadhihah (The Exposer), Al-Bahuth (The Searcher), Al-Muba'thirah (The Scatterer), Al-Muthirah (The Excavator), Al-Hafirah (The Digger), Al-Mukhziyah (The Disgracer), Al-Musharridah (The Disperser), Al-Murshidah (The Guide), Al-Munakkilah (The Punisher), Al-Mudamdima (The Destroyer), Surah al-Bu'uth (Surah of Deployments), Surah al-Adhab (Surah of Punishment), and Al-Muqashqisha (The Curer)" (3). ... - - - - He mentions the number of verses of every Surah and the schools of scholars regarding that, mentioning the aspects of difference and its locations. He mentions in Surah "Al-Fatiha" that the people of counting are five: Medinan, Meccan, Kufan, Basran, and Levantine. He explains the narrators of every school of counting, and explains that the cause of difference is Tawqif (divine instruction) like Recitation. "Abu Amr said: These numbers, even if stopped (Mawquf) upon these Imams, they undoubtedly have a source they connect to, even if we do not know it, since every one of them met more than one of the Companions, witnessed him, and heard from him, or met those who met the Companions, while they were not people of opinion and invention, but people of adherence and following. And with Allah is success. Al-Sakhawi said meaning: 'If that were referable to opinion, the Kufans would have counted (Alif Lam Ra) as a verse, and would have counted (Alif Lam Mim Ra) as they counted (Alif Lam Mim Sad), and would have counted (Ta Sin) as they counted (Ya Sin), and would have counted (Kaf Ha Ya Ayn Sad) as two verses, as they did in (Ha Mim. Ayn Sin Qaf).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: And the Levantine would have counted {They said, 'We are but reformers'} (Al-Baqarah: from verse 11) just as he counted {and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment} (Al-Baqarah: from verse 7), and similar to that is much.'" (1). It is not hidden to the companion of the Quran that dividing Surahs into verses will never be referable to a linguistic, grammatical, or semantic standard, for not a few of its verses have the subject in a verse and the predicate in another, and the agent in a verse and what it relates to in another verse. This is often not hidden to one of heart. There is a narration from the Mother of Believers "Aisha", may Allah be pleased with them, that the number of Quran verses is according to the number of degrees of Paradise. It is as if the companion of the Quran in this world is in a moral spiritual paradise whose bliss is not felt except by one who has a heart safe from the disease of heedlessness and a satisfied soul reassured by obedience to Allah Almighty. Whenever he reads a verse, his soul ascends in the steps and ladders of the Holy Proximity. He arranges on this his stance on the saying of Saj' (rhyme) in the Holy Quran, saying: "From here we know for certain that there is no Saj' in the Book of Allah Almighty at all; for there is no doubt for one who has the slightest practice of that that 'Ta Sin' is more fitting for rhymers to 'Mubin' than 'Ya Sin' to 'Hakim'. Had Saj' been intended, consensus of counters would not have occurred that 'Ta Sin' is not a verse while some of them counted 'Ya Sin' a verse..." (2). He expanded the discussion of critiquing the saying of Saj' in the Holy Quran just as he expanded it in Nazm al-Durar = He - also - explains what is in the Surah resembling separators but not counted as a separator by consensus of scholars, defining that and defining the rhyme (Rawi) of the Surah and scholars' schools in this. He says in Surah "Al-Baqarah": "The number of its verses is two hundred eighty Kufan, seven Basran, and five in others. Their difference: Eleven verses.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: The Kufan was alone in counting 'Alif Lam Mim' (v:1), the Levantine in counting 'wa lahum 'adhabun 'azim' (v:7), the Basran in counting 'illa kha'ifin' (v:114) and 'qawlan ma'rufan' (v:235), the First Medinan in counting 'min al-zulumat ila al-nur' (v:257), the First Medinan and Meccan in counting 'yas'alunaka madha yunfiqun' (v:219), the Kufan, Levantine, and Last Medinan in counting 'la'allakum tatafakkarun' (v:219), and the Last Medinan, Basran, and Meccan in counting 'Al-Hayy Al-Qayyum' (v:255). The Levantine dropped 'muslihun' (v:11), the First Medinan 'wa ittaquni ya uli al-albab' (v:197), and the Last Medinan 'fi al-akhirati min khalaq' (v:200). In it is what resembles the separator: Twelve, of which eleven places no one counted by consensus, and the twelfth has a disagreement. Then he explains these places, then explains the rhyme of the Surah and that its rhyme is seven letters gathered by your saying: Qum linudabbir (Stand so we may plan) (1) - - - - He mentions the objective of the Surah, and in this he almost quotes what is in his interpretation, and rarely adds to it. He says regarding the objective of Surah Al-Fatiha: "Its objective: The servants' observation (Muraqabah) of their Lord. For adhering to His name Almighty alone, as indicated by advancing the preposition in every movement and stillness, calls for that, and its names indicated that." (2) - - - - He explains the relationship of its name or names to its objective, and in this too he mentions what is in his interpretation Al-Nazm and rarely adds to it. He says in Surah Al-Fatiha: "So this Surah's name, along with Al-Fatiha, is Umm al-Qura, Umm al-Kitab, and Al-Sab' al-Mathani... So the axis of these names – as you see – is on a hidden matter sufficient for every intent, and that is Observation. Everything that is not opened with it is not counted. It is the mother of every good and foundation of every kindness. It is not counted unless doubled, so it was permanently repeating. It is a treasure for every wish, healing for every disease, sufficient for every task, fulfilling every goal, protecting from every evil, curing every sickness, a Ruqyah for every Muslim.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: It is the affirmation of Praise (Hamd) which is encompassing attributes of perfection, and Gratitude (Shukr) which is magnifying the Benefactor. It is the essence of Supplication (Du'a) for it is turning to the One invoked, and Observation is the greatest turning, and its greatest gathering place is Prayer. According to the extent of the objective of every Surah is its greatness, and that is known from what was narrated regarding its virtues. Its names are taken from that, and its abundance indicates its merit. There is no Surah in the Quran greater than Al-Fatiha; because there is no objective greater than its objective. It gathers all meanings of the Quran, and that does not necessitate the unity of its objective with its [the Quran's] objective essentially, even if they agree in the outcome. For there is a difference between a thing and what gathered that thing. The objective of the Quran: Introducing the King to creation and what pleases Him. The objective of Al-Fatiha is the goal of that, being a goal for it, and that is the mentioned Observation benefited from adhering to His mention Almighty in every movement and stillness due to the belief that nothing happens except by Him. Upon the majesty of this intent came its virtues" (1). - - - - He cites Hadiths regarding the virtues of Surahs with their extraction. He explains his methodology in this saying: ... "Let it be known that I do not mention of that - if Allah wills - in virtues except what is Sahih (Authentic) or Hasan (Good), or permitted to be mentioned if it is weak, so long as it does not descend to the degree of Mawdu' (Fabricated). I did not mention anything of the Hadith fabricated upon 'Ubay' and 'Ibn Abbas', may Allah be pleased with them, regarding the virtues of all Surahs: Surah by Surah, as Al-Wahidi and Al-Zamakhshari and those who followed them mentioned; because the fabricated is not lawful to mention except by way of impugning it, and Allah is the Grantor of success" (2). He may mention some Hadiths regarding virtues of verses, as in the virtues of "Ayat al-Kursi" and "Endings of Surah Al-Baqarah". These are general matters existing in his speech regarding every Surah of the Holy Quran. He deposited in the beginning of his talk about Surah "Al-Fatiha" other very important matters in Quranic sciences other than what I mentioned before, including:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: = He addressed negating poetry from the Holy Quran, and the infallibility of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, from it, and went to the view that the Prophet, peace be upon him, could not straighten on his tongue the meter of a verse of poetry and that he used to quote it in this manner. = He spoke about the manner of revelation of the Quran and the revelation of heavenly books in Ramadan, and the revelation of the Holy Quran in stages... = He explained the superiority of the speech of Allah Almighty over all other speech, and the merit of the carrier of the Holy Quran. = He mentioned some legal rulings related to the Holy Quran such as: the meaning of revealing the Holy Quran on seven letters, its revelation in seven gates, that every verse has an exterior and interior, a limit and a point of ascent, the Quran's containment of all sciences, the virtue of Siwak (toothbrushing) when reading, the desirability of beautifying the voice with the Holy Quran, the meaning of beautiful voice, the prohibition of melodic chanting in reading the Holy Quran, the prohibition of traveling with the Mushaf to the land of the enemy, what is befitting for the carrier of the Holy Quran of high etiquette, stripping the Holy Quran of what is not of it, the dislike of minimizing the size of the Noble Mushaf, the obligation of writing it on something pure, and the prohibition of reading the Holy Quran inverted. Every topic of this allows for wide expansion for whoever wishes to sail in its encompassing ocean. = He spoke about lifting the Holy Quran from chests and Mushafs before the Day of Resurrection, and Allah Almighty's preservation of His Great Book from distortion. = He mentioned the reward of reading the Holy Quran explaining the intended meaning of the letter compensated by a good deed, and the reward of one who taught his child the Great Quran. ... = He mentioned I'rab of the Precious Book meaning clarifying it, and dotting the Mushaf and adjusting it with diacritics.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: = Mentioning the compilation of the Holy Qur'an during the era of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them all, their precision in compilation, the number of copies transcribed by Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, and other important issues in the sciences of the Glorious Qur'an. The book is unique in its field, distinguished in some of its aspects. May Allah Almighty treat its author, editor, and publisher with kindness... - - -. {Al-Fath al-Qudsi fi Ayat al-Kursi} (The Holy Opening regarding the Verse of the Throne). The book is attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (pp. 443, 444, 1233), Hadiyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Tarikh al-Adab al-Arabi by Omar Farroukh (Vol. 3, p. 872). He wrote it in the year eight hundred and seventy-nine (879 AH) in Cairo, a year before he left for Damascus. It states at the end of a manuscript copy deposited in the Chester Beatty Library in Ireland—a copy of which is in the Central Library at Imam University in Riyadh, and I have a copy of it—his saying: "I finished annotating this 'Al-Fath al-Qudsi fi Ayat al-Kursi' on the night of Tuesday, the tenth of the honored Sha'ban in the year eight hundred and seventy-nine, in my mosque at Rahbat Bab al-Eid in Al-Qahirah Al-Mu'izziyyah, while I am in the seventy-first year of my life, with many preoccupations and difficult days..." (1) Al-Biqa'i divided the book into two parts, making each part a chapter: First: In explaining the virtue of this verse, gathering many hadiths and numerous narrations. He titled this chapter: "The First Chapter on what is relied upon regarding the reward given to its reciter and what he obtains." Second: To explain the meanings of this verse, titling it: "The Second Chapter in highlighting the meanings from its vocabulary and repeated themes." After the opening praise and salutations, he indicates that he had previously composed his interpretation *Nazm al-Durar* and mentions some of its merits, and that he followed it with his book: *Masa'id al-Nazar lil-Ishraf 'ala Maqasid al-Suwar*. "I loved to single out the discussion from both of them regarding the Greatest Verse in a book I name: 'Al-Fath al-Qudsi fi Ayat al-Kursi', and I added to it what arouses desire and drives those of high aspirations towards it."
foot_note: 1. (1) – Al-Fath al-Qudsi fi Ayat al-Kursi by Al-Biqa'i: Folio: 19 - Manuscript

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In the first chapter, he amassed a collection of hadiths and narrations. He was concerned with mentioning the narrator of the hadith and the source of its narration, opening with the famous hadith of Ubayy bin Ka'b regarding the virtue of this Surah, which was narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, and Al-Qasim bin Salam in *Fada'il al-Qur'an*, and other books of Sunnah such as Musnad Ahmad, Al-Mustadrak, Shu'ab al-Iman, and Sharh al-Sunnah... In "Al-Fath", he mentions hadiths he did not mention regarding the virtue of the verse in his book "Masa'id al-Nazar", though he hardly concerns himself with commenting on these hadiths. The second chapter: "In highlighting the meanings from its vocabulary and repeated themes"—as he says—he explains the intent of the verse as "Exclusivity in Sovereignty which necessitates complete Knowledge and comprehensive Power, which necessitates Exclusivity in Divinity; thus it is the Verse of Knowledge and Sovereignty." Then he explains the relationship of its name to its intent and its inclusion of the mother-issues of theology, containing the rules of religious beliefs. Among what he explained is that Monotheism (Tawhid) has three degrees: First: Testifying with the word of Sincerity (Ikhlas) based on correct belief, which is the Clear Tawhid... Second: The Tawhid of the Elite, which issues from deduction using evidence and clear proofs not mixed with doubt in any way. Third: The Tawhid of the Elite of the Elite: This is the dropping of apparent causes and ascending above the disputes of intellects and attachment to evidence. It is to not witness a proof in Tawhid, nor a cause in reliance, nor a means in salvation. He becomes a witness to the precedence of the Truth by His ruling, His action, His placing of things in their places, His suspending them, and His hiding them in their forms, not verifying the knowledge of causes, and treading the path of dropping the created event....

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In these classifications of his, he does not rely on the Book of Allah Almighty, nor the Sunnah of His Messenger (peace be upon him), nor a narration from a Companion. Such a thing cannot be called Ijtihad (juristic reasoning), for there is no Ijtihad in theological inquiries except Ijtihad in understanding the text. The texts of the Book and Sunnah in the chapter of Creed (Aqidah) are definitive in implication; one does not need an interpretation that bears diverse or opposing facets. This is because difference in the chapter of Creed is a difference in the realm of Truth and Falsehood, Right and Wrong. The doctrinal truth has one face and one path. The sources of doctrinal understanding are two sources with absolutely no third: The Book and the Sunnah. There is no room for Consensus (Ijma') and Analogy (Qiyas), unlike the sources of Legal Jurisprudence (behavioral), which are four according to the majority: The Book, Sunnah, Consensus, and Analogy. The texts of the Book and Sunnah in the chapter of legislation have broad implications, and the scope of disagreement does not necessarily mean one is absolutely right and the other absolutely wrong, or absolutely lawful and absolutely forbidden; hence there was room for Ijtihad in interpretation. So, it was not for Al-Biqa'i to proceed to dividing Tawhid into those divisions without taking support from the Book and Sunnah. He addresses what came from Al-Hallaj, Ibn Arabi, and Ibn al-Farid, criticizing what came from them. His stance on them is not his stance on all Sufis, for he meets not a few of their seniors with reverence, especially their predecessors, and those who do not profess Unity of Existence (Wahdat al-Wujud) and Incarnation (Hulul) which appeared in the sayings of Ibn al-Farid and Ibn Arabi. He explains the meaning of "Jam' al-Jam'" (Union of the Union) among the Sufis and its relation to the degree of "Ihsan", the difference between "Taste" (Dhawq) and "Knowledge", and the wisdom of dispersing the proofs of Tawhid in the Holy Qur'an, and the verses of rulings and stories it contains. He is concerned with clarifying the location of the verse in its context and with interpreting and analyzing the vocabulary of the verse, especially the Beautiful Names it contains, and analyzing its sentences. He says in explaining its appropriateness to what precedes it:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "The facet of its arrangement (Nazm) with what precedes it is that when Allah Almighty began Al-Fatihah by mentioning the Essence with the specific Supreme Name gathering all attributes, then made Himself known through actions because they are witnessed, then ascended the address to definition by Attributes, then elevated it back to the Essence to qualify for knowledge, He began this Surah [Al-Baqarah] with the attribute of Speech; because it is the greatest of miracles, the clearest indication of the Unseen Essence, and the most impactful on souls, especially among the Arabs. Then He made Himself known through actions, increasing them. When no ambiguity remained, He established Oneness with its preceding verse [v. 254] wherein He urged spending before the attack of the Day of Meeting, the day of severing of lineages and connection by relations, a day when nothing saves at the reckoning except the causes legislated by Allah Almighty. Likewise [is the connection to] what is before that which resembles it, interspersing that with varieties of wisdom, beauties of rulings, and types of encouragement and intimidation in precise construction and arrangement. When matters were complete and those deterrents were terrifying, and souls yearned, and thoughts looked forward to knowing the cause of the severing of connection by the cutting of ties, and the negation of intercession on that Day... Allah Almighty explained the attribute of the Commander regarding His Majesty, Greatness, effectiveness of command, elevation above an opposite, and transcendence above an equal or peer, and His exclusivity in all perfections and the preventing awe after its revelation there with the most complete revelation; so that aspirations would not turn to other than Him, nor speak without His permission, and that nothing would be other than what He wants. This is to be more conducive to accepting His command and stopping at His prohibition and deterrent. For the sake of these purposes, the speech was driven as an answer to a question, as if it were said: 'This is what is unknown of the conditions of kings; so who is the King on that Day?' So He mentioned the Verse of the Throne (Ayat al-Kursi), the Mistress of the verses of the Qur'an...."

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This shows you that the Name of Majesty (Allah) at the beginning of Ayat al-Kursi, in Al-Biqa'i's interpretation, is a subject (Musnad Ilayh), and its predicate is omitted, indicated by the estimated question derived from the context in which Ayat al-Kursi was established. It is as if the meaning is: 'Allah is the King on that Day.' This construction [defining both terms] implies exclusivity (Qasr). It is as if it was said: 'There is no King on that Day except Allah,' so that the following sentence comes explicitly stating what the first alluded to and confirming its content, saying (There is no god but He). Al-Biqa'i says: "So He said (Allah), meaning the King who possesses all Beautiful Names, High Attributes, Majesty, and Honor, is the King on that Day. Then He explained what preceded by establishing for Himself attributes of perfection, purified from impurities of deficiency..." Al-Biqa'i points out that the consecutive sentences in the structure of Ayat al-Kursi stand as clarification and detailing for what was firmly established in the opening sentence of this verse, which is a sentence where the Name of Majesty was mentioned alone. In the conclusions of his interpretation of the verse, he says: "Every sentence that is started anew is a cause for what preceded it, arriving by way of clarification for what resulted from it. The clarification is united, as Al-Zamakhshari said, with the clarified; if a conjunction mediated between them, it would be, as the Arabs say: between the stick and its bark." That is more of what abounded in his interpretation of the Mistress of the Verses of the Holy Qur'an. There are numerous manuscript copies of this book in manuscript libraries. More than twenty years ago, I relied on the manuscript copy number 014-Tafsir Halim at the Egyptian National Library. There are other copies, including: ... = Copy at Chester Beatty Library No. (3666m4), and a photocopy of it is at the Central Library of Imam University in Riyadh, No. (3666 / F) in (19 folios), written in Sha'ban of the year eight hundred and seventy-nine (879) by the dictation of the author in Cairo. I have a copy of it in my library. = Copy at Chester Library in Dublin (Al-Mawrid Journal: p. 199, No. 2, Vol. 1). = Copy in Hagia Sophia Library (Nawadir al-Makhtutat – Vol. 2, p. 4).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: = Copy in Wali al-Din Library in Turkey (Previous source: 2/39)... = Copy in Bayezid Library in Turkey (Previous source). It was edited by Prof. Dr. Saud bin Abdullah Al-Funaysan, Professor at Imam Muhammad bin Saud Islamic University in Riyadh, and published by Maktabat Al-Rushd in Riyadh (1420-1999). Before seeing Dr. Al-Funaysan's edition, I had begun editing the book based on the Imam University copy and the Egyptian National Library copy, and perhaps I will complete that. - - - {Al-Ajwibah al-Sariyyah fi al-Alghaz al-Jazariyyah} (Secret Answers to Jazari Puzzles). In this book, he answered puzzles in the science of Qira'at (Readings) for his sheikh "Al-Shams bin al-Jazari Abu al-Khayr (751-833), author of Al-Nashr fi al-Qira'at al-Ashr. He finished his answers to those puzzles in the year 869 AH in Cairo. There is a manuscript copy of the book numbered (112-5950-Qira'at at Al-Azhar Library), and a photocopy of it at the Egyptian National Library (microfilm) which I viewed. ***** {Al-Istishhad bi Ayat al-Jihad} (Citing Verses of Jihad). This book is like a subject index for verses of Jihad, collecting them without arrangement or commentary by him. There is a manuscript copy numbered (1376-Tasawwuf) at the Egyptian National Library, which is the copy I read and relied upon. {Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah fi Hukm al-Naql min al-Kutub al-Qadimah} (The Upright Sayings regarding the Ruling of Quoting from Ancient Books). The author attributed the book to himself in his Tafsir (Nazm al-Durar - Vol. 1, p. 277, Vol. 6, p. 444) and it is attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p. 140, 837). He finished writing it in Cairo in the year eight hundred and seventy-three.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says about it: I classified regarding that "Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah fi Hukm al-Naql min al-Kutub al-Qadimah", in which I explained that this is a straight Sunnah for supporting the great Hanif religion, and I cited for that the text of Al-Shafi'i and the words of Al-Nawawi and Al-Rafi'i"... He says: He did not need to write this book except that some envious people defamed him because of his quoting from the Torah, the Gospel, and the Psalms in his interpretation. The one who took charge of this defamation was "Al-Badr bin Qattan", the son-in-law of "Al-Sakhawi", so Al-Biqa'i attacked him and satirized him (1). He established the book on eight chapters, an introduction, and a conclusion. In the introduction, he refuted those who defamed him and spoke at length on this. In the eight chapters, he spoke about the scholars' stance on his interpretation and cited eleven commendations by the seniors of his era for this interpretation (Al-Aqwal: 17-42). Then he clarified the ruling of quoting from the Torah, Gospel, and Psalms, the proofs for this ruling, the names of Imams of knowledge who preceded him and some who quoted, the sources of quoting and its locations. He spoke about the alteration of divine books before the Great Qur'an, and the effect of this on the ruling of looking into them... In the conclusion, he mentioned the merits of his interpretation (Nazm al-Durar) (2)... Then he cited "Ibn al-Naqib's" interpretation of Surah "Al-Kawthar" and his own interpretation of that Surah, asking the reader to compare the two interpretations. (3) "Al-Sakhawi" wrote a book refuting "Al-Biqa'i" which he named "Al-Asl al-Asil fi Tahrim al-Naql min al-Tawrat wa al-Injil" (The Fundamental Origin in Forbidding Quoting from the Torah and Gospel) (4). Dr. "Muhammad Morsi Al-Khouli" edited part of this book from the beginning of the second chapter to the end of the eighth in the journal of "Institute of Arabic Manuscripts" (pp. 37-96 - Vol. 26, Part 2, Issue: Muharram 1401). There is a manuscript copy of this book numbered (1269-Tafsir-at the Egyptian National Library), which is the one I took as a reference.
foot_note:
1. (1) - Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah fi Hukm al-Naql min al-Kutub al-Qadimah: by Al-Biqa'i: pp. 3-9 - Manuscript 
2. – Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah: 147-203 
3. – Previous source: 203-245 
4. – Al-Daw' al-Lami': 1/106

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And another copy numbered (49-Tafsir) at the Egyptian National Library. ***** {Al-Dawabit wa al-Isharat li-Ajza' Ilm al-Qira'at} (Controls and Signs for Parts of the Science of Readings). He attributed the book to himself in the margin of his book (Izhar al-Asr) (Vol. 1, p. 269 - Ed. Muhammad Salim Al-Awfi) and the book is attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p. 1090) and Hadiyat al-Arifin: Vol. 1, p. 229. This book or treatise is the text of an (Inaugural Lecture/Ijlas) he prepared to deliver before his professors when he was assigned the position of teaching Qira'at (Readings) at the Mu'ayyadiyyah School. It is a school located in the Mosque of (Al-Mu'ayyad) next to Bab Zuwailah in Cairo, established by King Al-Mu'ayyad Shaykh Al-Mahmudi Al-Zahiri in the year eight hundred and nineteen (1). This Ijlas, which serves as a scholarly lecture upon which eligibility for teaching at the school is decided, took place on Thursday, the seventh of Muharram of the year eight hundred and fifty-seven. On this day and the one before it, the illness of Sultan "Jaqmaq" intensified, and he suffered something resembling epilepsy, so it rumored among people that he had died. They were terrified and agitated, which caused many people to refrain from attending this Ijlas. Nevertheless, as Al-Biqa'i says, the notables and elites of the people attended: The four judges except the Maliki, Sheikh Amin al-Din Yahya bin al-Aqsara'i and his relative Muhibb al-Din the Imam of the Sultan, Sheikh Hamid al-Din son of the Judge of Baghdad the Hanafi Judge in Damascus, and his sheikh "Al-Mashdali". Of the students, virtuosos, deputy judges, and others, a large crowd attended, perhaps exceeding two hundred (2). Al-Biqa'i mentions in (Izhar al-Asr) the text of what he had intended to say (3), which he later made into a book he finished in the year eight hundred and sixty-six. It is a nice summary on Qira'at in which he mentioned after the introduction the definition of the science of Qira'at, its subject, and benefit. He explains that speech in it is confined to means and objectives. The means are confined to seven parts:
foot_note:
1. (1) - Al-Khitat al-Maqriziyyah: 2/328 
2. – Izhar al-Asr by Al-Biqa'i: 1/269 
3. – Previous source: 1/ 169 -282

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: First: Chains of Transmission (Asanid). Second: Science of Arabic, including articulation points and attributes of letters. Third: Stop and Start (Waqf and Ibtida'). Fourth: Separators (Fawasil), which is counting verses. Fifth: The Script (Rasm). Sixth: Seeking Refuge (Isti'adha). Seventh: Takbir. The objectives are confined to two parts: First: Principles (Usul). Second: Specific Variations (Farsh). The Principles are confined to about twenty chapters... The Specific Variations are confined to the Surahs. Then he explained the method of controlling the parts of the science of Qira'at. There is a manuscript copy at the Zahiriyyah Library in Damascus numbered (7422)... And another copy in the library of: "Shahid Ali" in Turkey (Catalogue of Shahid Ali Library – p. 256, Manuscript at Dar al-Kutub). I was not able to see a manuscript copy of it in Egypt. This book was edited and published in the journal (Al-Ihya), issue seven, series nineteen - Ramadan 1416, by Mr. Muhammad Rustum (pp. 177-195) based on a single copy, which is a copy in the library of the editor's sheikh: Sheikh Muhammad bin Al-Amin Abu Khubzah" within a collection on Qira'at, consisting of two manuscript folios... It reached me that "Muhammad Muti' Al-Hafiz" edited it and it was published by Dar Al-Fikr in Damascus in the year 1416 AH, but I was not able to acquire this edition. ***** ........Sciences of Hadith and Sunnah..... Although Al-Biqa'i was a student of an Imam of the sciences of Sunnah "Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani" (d. 852), he was not as concerned with writing in the sciences of Prophetic Sunnah as he was with writing in Tafsir and sciences of the Holy Qur'an, or even his concern with writing in History and Biographies. Among what reached me of his writing in this field which I read: {Al-I'lam bi-Sann al-Hijrah ila al-Sham} (Notification of Enacting Migration to the Levant). Al-Biqa'i was not the first to write on that subject, for book catalogs are teeming with such books. He wrote the book before leaving Cairo for the Levant, as he finished it on Tuesday, the fifth of Rabi' al-Akhir in the year eight hundred and eighty (880).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says: "This is a book I wrote when I intended to move from Egypt due to matters I denounced and tribulations I witnessed. They reminded me of what some historians narrated in the Prophetic Biography that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said when he showed grace to the sister of 'Adi bin Hatim', may Allah be pleased with them both: 'Have mercy on a noble of a people who has been humiliated, a rich man who has become poor, and a scholar lost among ignoramuses.' I named it: {Al-I'lam bi-Sann al-Hijrah ila al-Sham} for a matter that necessitated that." (1) The book was edited by: Muhammad Mujir Al-Husseini, and he published it in the year 1418. I had relied on a manuscript copy at the Egyptian National Library, so when I acquired the edited version, I checked what I had against it. He started the book by defining the geographical location of Sham (the Levant), relying on several diverse sources such as (Tahdhib al-Asma' wa al-Lughat) by Al-Nawawi, and (Al-Buldan) by Adh-Dhahabi. He elaborated on praising Sham and the virtues of its people, and mentioned several hadiths on the virtue of Sham, and on dispraising Egypt and its people. Among what he mentioned was a hadith combining the virtues of Sham and the vices of Egypt and its people. He says: "Al-Tabarani narrated in Al-Awsat in the biography of Muhammad bin Al-Rabi' bin Bilal with a good (Hasan) chain – God willing – if it is free from disconnection between the Companion and the narrator from him, Ya'qub bin Utbah Al-Thaqafi, although Ibn al-Jawzi mentioned it in Al-Mawdu'at (Fabrications) from Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Iblis entered Iraq and fulfilled his need, and entered Sham but they drove him away until he reached Mount Busaq, and he entered Egypt and laid eggs, hatched them, and set up his carpets.'" Al-Hafiz Abu Mahmud Al-Maqdisi said: "Its chain is strong." Ended. The editor "Muhammad Al-Husseini" explained the criticisms scholars have regarding this hadith.
foot_note: 1. (1) ? 1 – Al-I'lam bi-Sann al-Hijrah ila al-Sham: pp. 81-83 - Ed: Muhammad Al-Husseini – Dar Ibn Hazm – Beirut

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i also mentioned: "In the virtues of Imam Abu Al-Hasan Ali bin Muhammad Al-Raba'i from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' (1) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to me: 'Damascus will be the most populous city in the end times, a stronghold for its people, having the most Abdal (Substitutes/Saints), mosques, and men, and the least disbelief. And Egypt is the city with the most Pharaohs and disbelievers, the most injustice and immorality, and the most adultery and magic. When its outskirts are built up, the Dal [Dajjal/Antichrist?] will be sent, so woe to its people from his followers and partisans.'" The editor mentioned that "Al-Raba'i" narrated the hadith (p. 44) at length, and Ibn Asakir (2/54) briefly without mentioning Egypt. Both are from the path of "Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Ibrahim" with his chain to Wathilah. And Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Ibrahim, Ibn Asakir said about him: "An unknown man." So the hadith is not established (2). In a treatise by Al-Suyuti titled: "{Al-Khabar al-Dall 'ala Wujud al-Qutb wa al-Awtad wa al-Nujaba' wa al-Abdal}" from the hadith of "Wathilah", may Allah be pleased with them, there is no mention of Egypt and its people; it is restricted to mentioning "Damascus" and its people (3). Investigators hold that every hadith narrated from the Prophet regarding the number of Awliya, Abdal, Nuqaba, Nujaba, Awtad, and Aqtab... nothing of that is authentic from the Prophet (peace be upon him). The Salaf did not utter any of these terms except the term "Abdal". A hadith was narrated about them that they are forty men, and that they are in Sham; it is in Musnad Ahmad, may Allah be pleased with them, from the hadith of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, and it is a disconnected hadith, not established.
foot_note:
1. (1) ? 2 – Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' bin Abd al-Uzza (Abu Qirfasah). He embraced Islam while the Messenger (peace be upon him) was preparing for Tabuk. He was among the youngest of Ahl al-Suffah. He died in Sham in the year eighty-five (Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra by Ibn Sa'd (5/128) 
2. ? 1 – Al-I'lam bi-Sann al-Hijrah ila al-Sham: 101 
3. ? 2- Al-Hawi fi al-Fatawi by Al-Suyuti: 2/463-464

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is known that our master "Ali", may Allah be pleased with him, and those Companions with him were better than Muawiyah, may Allah be pleased with him, and those with him in Sham. So the best of people cannot be in the army of our master Muawiyah, may Allah be pleased with him, excluding the army of our master "Ali", may Allah be pleased with him. They narrated in the Two Sahihs from Abu Sa'id, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: "A renegade group will emerge at a time of division among Muslims; the party closer to the truth will kill them" (Muslim: Zakat: 2/745 - Hadith No. 150). These renegades are the Haruriyyah Khawarij who emerged when the division occurred among Muslims during the caliphate of "Ali bin Abi Talib", may Allah be pleased with him, so he killed them. The authentic hadith indicates that "Ali", may Allah be pleased with him, was closer to the truth than Muawiyah, may Allah be pleased with him. So how can the Abdal be in the inferior of the two armies excluding the superior one, in Sham with Muawiyah, may Allah be pleased with him?" (1) "Ibn al-Qayyim" says: The hadiths of Abdal, Aqtab, Aghwath, Nuqaba, Nujaba, and Awtad are all false (2). Philosophical Sufism, which took argumentation and theology as worship, had very bad effects on the progress of the Ummah. Many Muslims in past times inclined to those absurdities and delusions promoted by the masters of philosophical Sufism. As for behavioral devotional Sufism based on the guidance of the Book and the authentic Sunnah, which does not deviate, add, distort, or interpret [falsely], it is the Straight Path – if the Lord of the Worlds wills.
foot_note:
1. (1) ? 3 Majmu' Fatawa Ibn Taymiyyah: 11/167 - Comp. Ibn Qasim Al-Najdi 
2. ? 1- Al-Manar al-Munif by Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyyah: 189

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The people of this path hardly expose their chests to the public in gatherings, nor do they give people the illusion that they are people of arrival and acceptance, and that they veil themselves from people out of fear for them from their lights shining from their hearts onto their lights. They are closer to hiddenness in their states with Allah Almighty. They set before their eyes and in their hearts filled with fear of Allah Almighty the guidance of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) which "Muslim", may Allah be pleased with him, narrated with his chain from "Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas", may Allah be pleased with him, who said: "I heard the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) say: Verily Allah loves the servant who is God-fearing, rich [content], and hidden" (Muslim: Zuhd: Hadith No. 11/29). Every scholar of the Book and Sunnah who acts upon them is on this Straight Path, and whoever is other than them is the misguiding deviant. The summary is that Al-Biqa'i was concerned with amassing many hadiths indicating the virtue of Sham and encouraging living there, and he did not guard against fabricated and weak ones. It was more appropriate for him, being a Muhaddith, to limit himself to what has a strong chain, for therein is sufficiency for his goal. *** {Inarat al-Fikr bi-ma huwa al-Haqq min Kayfiyyat al-Dhikr} (Illuminating Thought with What is the Truth regarding the Method of Remembrance). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/170), Mu'jam al-Musannifin (2/278), and Hadiyat al-Arifin (1/22). The book was edited by "Sulayman Al-Harsh" in the year 1421 based on a copy (Ireland Chester Beatty) and published by Maktabat Al-Obeikan in Riyadh. "Al-Biqa'i" wrote the book in "Damascus" in the year (881), forbidding evil and enjoining good regarding the rulings and etiquettes of remembering Allah Almighty in mosques.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says: "When I returned from Egypt after a long absence to Damascus, hoping for a good return with few evils and many helpers against the oppressor... I found it had changed, its people had changed.... I found in its Great Mosque [Umayyad Mosque] people sitting in circles and chanting 'La ilaha illa Allah' in one voice from after the Friday prayer until Asr, a Dhikr they take out of its proper manner into the realm of disobedience with disturbing voices..." (1) He narrates to us some of what happened between him and them when he forbade them from evil. In this book, quoting from the book (Al-Madkhal) by Ibn al-Hajj dominates. "Al-Suyuti", Al-Biqa'i's student, wrote a treatise titled: "Natijat al-Fikr fi al-Jahr bi-al-Dhikr" (The Result of Thought regarding Loud Dhikr) in which he establishes that there is no dislike in what the Sufi masters are accustomed to of holding Dhikr circles and reciting it loudly in mosques and raising voices in Tahlil. It was published within his book (Al-Hawi lil-Fatawi - Part Two). This treatise is like a contradiction to Al-Biqa'i's treatise "Inarat al-Fikr". It seems "Al-Suyuti" did not distinguish between the ruling of a thing in itself, and its ruling in a specific manner. No one said that loud Dhikr absolutely or in mosques at times other than prayers is not permissible, but what happens of that at the hands of those affiliated with Sufism is a matter wherein the least that can be said is that it obstructs some of what mosques were built for, such as prayer and teaching Qur'an and beneficial knowledge. .......Principles of Religion: Creed (Aqidah)....... Al-Biqa'i has several writings in the sciences of Creed and Theology. Al-Biqa'i was on the school of the companions of Abu Al-Hasan Al-Ash'ari. He was severe in opposing those who profess Unity of Existence (Wahdat al-Wujud) and those professing Union (Ittihad). He used to frequently denounce them and proclaim their misguidance whenever an opportunity arose in any of his works, especially his Tafsir, and he dedicated treatises to this. Among his works in Creed are what is printed, manuscript, and lost. Among the non-lost: {Tahdhir al-Ibad min Ahl al-Inad bi-Bid'at al-Ittihad} (Warning Servants about the People of Obstinacy regarding the Innovation of Union).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He mentioned this book in his Tafsir Nazm al-Durar: Vol. 22, p. 245, and it is attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p. 355). There is a manuscript copy of this book in the Zakiyyah Collection at the Egyptian National Library and a copy in the Chester Beatty Library in Dublin (Iraqi Al-Mawrid Journal, p. 200, No. 2, Vol. 3). The book was edited and published with another book by Sheikh: Abdul Rahman Al-Wakil" under a title he invented, "Masra' al-Tasawwuf" (The Demise of Sufism) in the year: 1373 AH. Sheikh Al-Wakil, may Allah have mercy on him, should not have done that, for that title does not indicate Al-Biqa'i's stance on Sufism. The two books contain nothing but demolition of those who profess Unity of Existence, Union, and Incarnation. Most of those affiliated with Sufism do not say that, and do not see correctness in those who say it. Al-Biqa'i does not hold hostility towards all Sufis; rather, he takes a hostile stance against those who say what Ibn al-Farid and Ibn Arabi said regarding Unity of Existence, Union, and Incarnation. So the book exists to refute "Ibn al-Farid's" poem named: "Al-Ta'iyyah Al-Kubra" or "Nazm al-Suluk", which consists of seven hundred and sixty-one verses (761 verses) in the Tawil meter. Its beginning is: *The hand of my pupil gave me the wine of love to drink / And my cup was the face of the one who is exalted above beauty.* Many Sufi commentators collaborated to explain it, the first being "Sa'd al-Din al-Farghani" whose commentary is named: "Muntaha al-Madarik wa Mushtaha Lubb Kull Kamil wa Arif wa Salik", a manuscript at the Institute of Manuscripts in Cairo. "Al-Biqa'i" aimed at what this poem contains of contradiction to what the Book and Sunnah brought, and transgression of the truths of Shari'ah and the logic of a mind healthy from the disease of Shirk. He begins his speech by explaining that the path of the Jurists is the path of the great Sufis based on the Book and Sunnah, which is Behavioral Sufism. Whatever Ibn al-Farid and Ibn Arabi are upon is Philosophical Sufism. He states that the scholars judge the two men, Ibn Arabi and Ibn al-Farid, as disbelievers; he even goes so far as to say that whoever pauses in declaring them disbelievers is a disbeliever. He attacks the testimony of Ibn al-Farid's grandson for his grandfather, explaining what implies Sainthood (Wilayah) for a servant from the Book and Sunnah. *** {Tanbih al-Ghabi 'ala Takfir Ibn Arabi} (Alerting the Dimwit to the Takfir of Ibn Arabi)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He attributed the book to himself in his Tafsir "Nazm al-Durar" Vol. 22, p. 245. There is a manuscript copy of the book in the Zakiyyah Collection at the Egyptian National Library. It is printed with the book: "Tahdhir al-Ibad" mentioned previously in a book titled "Masra' al-Tasawwuf" edited by: Abdul Rahman Al-Wakil", referenced earlier. Al-Biqa'i says in its beginning: "I named these papers: 'Tanbih al-Ghabi 'ala Takfir Ibn Arabi', and if you wish, name it: 'Al-Nusus min Kufr al-Fusus' (The Texts regarding the Disbelief of the Fusus)." He finished writing it in Shawwal of the year eight hundred and sixty-four (864) in Cairo. If he made his book "Tahdhir al-Ibad" to refute "Ibn al-Farid's" poem "Al-Ta'iyyah Al-Kubra", he made his book "Tanbih al-Ghabi" to refute the book: "Fusus al-Hikam". He identifies the pivot of "Ibn Arabi's" speech in Al-Fusus as Absolute Unity, meaning that there is nothing other than this world, and that the God is a universal matter that has no existence except within its particulars. He asserts that whatever appears from "Ibn Arabi's" speech contrary to this is deception and obfuscation, rejecting the interpretation (Ta'wil) of his speech, for not every speech is interpreted and diverted from its apparent meaning. In this, he enters the chapter of precaution and repelling harm which every Muslim must hold fast to in the chapter of Creed, for the first thing that must be preserved pure and clear is Monotheism (Tawhid) stripped of every impurity of Shirk. It is upon scholars and rulers to compel people, with wisdom and good preaching and clarification of truth, to adopt that precaution, and not to leave people to what their devils from humans and jinn beautify for them. So everyone who persists in misguiding people and diverting them from what the Book and Sunnah brought should be taken to task. Al-Biqa'i tracks the sayings of "Ibn Arabi" in Al-Fusus, highlighting what is in them that contradicts the creed of Islam. He states that he relied only on a copy of Al-Fusus brought to him by one of those who believe in "Ibn Arabi" and are fanatical for him. This is from Al-Biqa'i's precision and precaution in scientific research and documenting his sources.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i's book "Tanbih al-Ghabi" met opposition from some scholars like his student "Al-Suyuti" (d. 911 AH), who wrote a book opposing it titled: "Tanbih al-Ghabi bi-Tabri'at Ibn Arabi" (Alerting the Dimwit to the Exoneration of Ibn Arabi). It was edited by "Muhammad Ibrahim Salim" in the year one thousand four hundred and fifteen (1415). Al-Suyuti did not explain the face of truth in Ibn Arabi's statements which Al-Biqa'i refuted. It was appropriate for him to refute Al-Biqa'i's arguments and show us the correct meaning of Ibn Arabi's speech and the proof for the correctness of what he says. But Al-Suyuti sufficed with mentioning the scholars who supported Ibn Arabi, as if a statement is proven to be true by who said it and who supported it, not by the truth contained in the speech. This indicates an inability to find what supports the speech from itself, which indicates that the speech itself does not contain what decisively proves its correctness. No one's speech is evidence for anything other than the Speech of Allah Almighty, then the speech of His Prophet (peace be upon him). If it is said: Allah, Majestic is His Majesty, said, or His Messenger (peace be upon him) said, and the attribution of the speech to them is authenticated, then the proof stands compellingly against one who believes in them. Otherwise, we need to establish proof for those who do not believe in them from the speech itself, not from the status of the speaker. Hence we heard the Truth Almighty calling to ponder His Speech and look into it so one may know it is the Speech of Allah Almighty: {Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an? If it had been from [any] other than Allah, they would have found within it much contradiction.} (Al-Nisa: 82) (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) ? 1 – His saying (they would have found within it much contradiction): The pronoun in (within it) refers to what is from other than Allah Almighty. As for what is from Him, Majestic is His Majesty, there is no contradiction in it at all. His saying (much) is a description of the contradiction that occurs in other than the Qur'an; as for the Qur'an, there is no contradiction in it at all to be described as little or much. "Abu Ja'far al-Tabari" says in the interpretation of the verse: (He, Majestic is His Praise, means by His saying {Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an}: Do not those who plot other than what you say to them, O Muhammad, reflect upon the Book of Allah Almighty, so they may know Allah's proof against them in obeying you and following your command, and that what you brought them of Revelation is from their Lord, Majestic is His Majesty; due to the consistency of its meanings, the harmony of its rulings, the support of some parts by others in verification, and the testimony of some parts to others in truth? For if that were from other than Allah Almighty, its rulings would differ and its meanings would contradict, and some parts would reveal the corruption of others) (4 / 200).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Then do they not reflect upon the Qur'an, or are there locks upon [their] hearts?} (Muhammad: 24) {[This is] a blessed Book which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], that they might reflect upon its verses and that those of understanding would be reminded.} (Sad: 29). Al-Suyuti's method in this book is far from the scientific method, while Al-Biqa'i's method is based on principles of scientific research and verifying scientific issues. Al-Suyuti should have addressed every text Al-Biqa'i mentioned from Fusus al-Hikam by Ibn Arabi proving his disbelief, and revealed to us the face of truth that was hidden from Al-Biqa'i if there was truth in it, and the facet of its indication of that truth, instead of mentioning the names of scholars who believe in the Sainthood of Ibn Arabi. It was the sophistry of the disbelievers to oppose the Truth by attacking the one who supported it and not the Truth itself: {So the eminent among those who disbelieved from his people said, "We do not see you but as a man like ourselves, and we do not see you followed except by those who are the lowest of us [and] at first suggestion. And we do not see in you over us any merit; rather, we think you are liars."} (Hud: 27). Al-Suyuti argues that the one undertaking the Takfir of "Ibn Arabi" did not fear a bad reckoning, and that it would be said to him: Is it proven to you in a text that he is a disbeliever? If he says: His books indicate his disbelief. Is he safe from being told: Is it proven to you by an accepted path in transmitting news that he said this specific word? And that he intended by it its customary meaning? The first is impossible due to lack of a document to rely on for that, and fame now is of no consequence. Even assuming the origin of the book is proven from him, every single word must be proven; due to the possibility that what is not his speech was inserted into the book by an enemy or an atheist... The second: That he intended [such and such] by this word is also impossible to prove. Whoever claims it has disbelieved; because it is of the matters of the heart which no one views except Allah Almighty -

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Some senior scholars asked some Sufis in his time: What made you agree on these terms whose apparent meaning is repugnant? He said: Jealousy for this path of ours, that one who does not master it claims it, and one who is not of its people enters it." (1) This argumentation from Al-Suyuti is laughable; it is closer to obstinacy than to debating in the best manner encouraged by the Great Qur'an. Al-Suyuti should not have thrown himself into such exposed defect. He knows that scholars judge people's sayings and actions, not what is in their hearts, for that matter belongs to Allah Almighty. You have nothing from your brother except his speech and action; as for his heart, it is for his Lord Almighty. Sayings and actions are the mirror of what is in the hearts and the translator for them. No one utters a word of disbelief and atheism without legal compulsion and then says to people: Did you tear open my heart to judge me by that? The thing that tore open his heart is his tongue and pen.
