So the one who announces that Pharaoh – curse be upon him – is a believer, is he not thereby explicitly denying the clear and definitive Qur'an? Whether Ibn Arabi said that or someone else, the important thing is that the sayer of this is undoubtedly stating a disbelief that bears a likely or unlikely interpretation; because one who is like that, his speech is not interpreted. So what drives him to that?!!! In Fusus al-Hikam: The bezel of Sublimity Wisdom in a Mosaic Word regarding the picking up of "Moses" from the ark and the saying of his wife [Pharaoh's wife], may she be pleased: "A coolness of eye for me and for you" (Al-Qasas: 9), explaining how Moses, peace be upon him, was a coolness of eye for Pharaoh.
foot_note: 1. (1) – Tanbih al-Ghabi bi-Tabri'at Ibn Arabi by Al-Suyuti: p. 45 – Ed: Muhammad Ibrahim Salim - 1415

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "And he was a coolness of eye for 'Pharaoh' through the faith Allah gave him at drowning, so He seized him pure and purified, having no malice in him; because He seized him at his belief before he acquired any sins. And Islam wipes out what came before it. He made him a sign of His care, Almighty, for whom He wills so that no one despairs of the mercy of Allah; for no one despairs of relief from Allah except the disbelieving people." Does not this statement tear open the chest of its speaker and reveal what is in his heart? Is this not explicit in denying what the Holy Qur'an and authentic Sunnah brought regarding Pharaoh's disbelief and that he is among the people of the Fire? {And We certainly sent Moses with Our signs and a clear authority * To Pharaoh and his establishment, but they followed the command of Pharaoh, and the command of Pharaoh was not right. * He will precede his people on the Day of Resurrection and lead them into the Fire; and wretched is the place to which they are led. * And they were followed in this [world] with a curse and on the Day of Resurrection. Wretched is the gift which is given.} (Hud: 96-99). Did the author of Fusus al-Hikam not read the saying of Allah Almighty (He will precede his people on the Day of Resurrection and lead them into the Fire)? Is this not definitive that Pharaoh leads his people to the fire of Hell? {But Pharaoh disobeyed the messenger, so We seized him with a ruinous seizure.} (Al-Muzzammil: 16). The author of Al-Fusus goes further than this when he views that criminals in this world reach in the Hereafter the very essence of nearness to Allah Almighty. This is when discussing the saying of Allah Almighty: {And We will drive the criminals to Hell as a watering place [thirsty].} (Maryam: 86)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says: "They are the ones who deserved the station to which He drove them by the westerly wind by which He destroyed them regarding their selves [sic]. So He takes them by their forelocks, and the wind drives them – which is the essence of the desires they were upon – to Hell, which is the distance they were imagining. When He drove them to that spot, they obtained the essence of nearness, so distance vanished, and the named 'Hell' vanished in their right. Thus they won the bliss of nearness by way of entitlement; because they are criminals. He did not give them this sweet taste-based station by way of favor, but they took it by what their realities deserved from their deeds they were upon. In striving in their deeds, they were on the straight path of the Lord [sic]; because their forelocks were in the hand of the One who has this attribute. So they did not walk by themselves, but walked by the ruling of compulsion until they reached the essence of nearness" (1). What does Al-Suyuti say about this? Can a sane person interpret this in a way that someone might calculate as circling around a meaning of the Holy Qur'an?!! What distortion of words from their places is greater and more criminal than this? From this atheism and distortion of words from their places and speaking about Allah Almighty without knowledge and speaking about the Holy Qur'an with corrupt, misleading, misguiding opinion which signals to people what rampages in the chest of this deviant, distortionist renegade is what he said regarding the saying of Allah Almighty about the people of 'Ad: {And when they saw it as a cloud approaching their valleys, they said, "This is a cloud bringing us rain." Rather, it is that for which you were impatient: a wind, within it a painful punishment.} (Al-Ahqaf: 24).
foot_note: 1. (1) – Fusus al-Hikam by Ibn Arabi the Sufi: p. 201

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says: "Do you not see 'Ad, the people of Hud, how they said: 'This is a cloud bringing us rain,' so they thought good of Allah Almighty, and He is as His servant thinks of Him [sic]. So the Truth turned away from this saying to them, and informed them of what is more complete and higher in nearness. for if He rained on them, that would be the luck of the earth and watering the grain, so they would reach the result of that rain only after a distance. So He said to them: 'Rather, it is that for which you were impatient: a wind, within it a painful punishment.' He made the wind a sign for what is in it of comfort (Rahah) [sic]. For by this wind, He relieved them of these dark structures and rugged paths and dark gloom. In this wind is a punishment ('adhab), meaning a matter they find sweet ('adhb) if they taste it [sic], except that it pains them because of separating from the familiar" (1). No sane person advising himself and his Ummah can claim that these statements of the "Author of Fusus al-Hikam" are not manifest misguidance, and do not proclaim explicit disbelief for their speaker. "Al-Suyuti's" argument that there is no proof that "Ibn Arabi" said this is closer to deception. Whether he said it or it was attributed to him, this statement is a statement of explicit disbelief. So whoever originated it, narrated it believing its correctness, or is pleased with it, has fallen into disbelief; because it is a repulsion, rejection, and destruction of what stands in the Book of Allah Almighty, a standing that bears not the slightest interpretation contrary to its explicit appearance. "Ibrahim bin Muhammad Al-Halabi" (d. 952) has a treatise: "Tasfih al-Ghabi fi Takfir Ibn Arabi" (Fooling the Dimwit regarding the Takfir of Ibn Arabi) in which he replies to Al-Suyuti. I was not able to see it. I expanded the discussion here for reasons: - The relationship of this to interpreting the Quranic Bayan (clarification) contrary to the correct face and method.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: - That many of the agitators of Fitnah in the Ummah among the secularists controlling the reins of culture and media in our lands struggle to publish the works of atheists, renegades, and distorters of words from their places, such as: "Ibn Arabi", "Ibn Sab'in", and "Ikhwan al-Safa". The cultural institutions in the Ministries of "Culture" and "Information" collaborated to facilitate the entry of this destructive atheistic heritage into the libraries of the youth and the common people, many of whom do not master understanding a journalistic article, let alone understand the delusions in the works of those saboteurs. If you asked the Minister of Culture himself and the Minister of Information himself about the meaning of anything published by the ministry of those falsehoods, silence would be his refuge. So how about one who does not master reading a book from the Ministry of Education books despite their shallowness and cultural and scientific poverty?!!! I would not have raised dust in the face of Ibn Arabi and his followers if his heritage were buried in libraries and manuscript repositories, looked into only by people of knowledge capable of distinguishing truth from falsehood. But for government institutions to work on publishing their heritage while leaving the heritage of investigative scholars like Al-Shafi'i, Al-Biqa'i, Al-Khattabi, Abu Bakr ibn al-Arabi the Maliki Jurist, Al-Shatibi, Al-Bayhaqi, Ibn Taymiyyah, Ibn al-Qayyim, Al-Shawkani, and those who supported them in protecting the creed of Monotheism from those delusions inserted by many atheists, the matter requires struggle and combat pleasing to the Lord of the Worlds. Silence about confronting their falsehood is pleasing to Satan and angering to the Most Merciful. *** {Tahdim al-Arkan min Laysa fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan} (Demolishing the Pillars of 'There is nothing in possibility more wondrous than what is'). He attributed it to himself in Nazm al-Durar (Vol. 20, p. 177, Vol. 22, p. 141) and it is attributed to him in (Kashf al-Zunun: p. 513). He finished it in the year eight hundred and eighty-three (883 AH) in Damascus. In it, he discusses the statement: "It is not in Allah's possibility Almighty to invent a world more wondrous than this world." "Al-Ghazali" had mentioned that in some of his works, so it stirred controversy.

category_en: Quranic Sciences and Principles of Tafsir
book_title_en: Al-Biqai and His Method in Interpreting the Eloquence of the Quran
text_en: Al-Biqai says in his interpretation of the words of Allah Almighty: {He created the heavens and the earth in truth and formed you and perfected your forms; to Him is the final destination} [At-Taghabun: 3]. The creation of humans in the best form does not negate that among a species, some individuals may be better than others, and there is no limit to the perfection among them. One observes the variety of individuals in their own species; Allah's power is limitless. Beware of accepting what is mentioned in Imam Al-Ghazali's books that nothing could possibly be better than what exists. Even though he responded to objections in his book, that response is not decisive because it would imply that Allah cannot create a world better than this one, which no one claims. This does not diminish the value of Al-Ghazali; everyone’s statements can be examined and critiqued, as Imam Malik said. Al-Ghazali himself attributed his knowledge to Ibn ‘Abbas. Imam Al-Shafi‘i said: 'I have written these books and exerted my utmost effort, yet I know they contain errors; for Allah says: {And if it had been from other than Allah, they would have found therein much discrepancy} [An-Nisa: 82].' Al-Biqai also explains the verse: {It is Allah who created seven heavens and of the earth the like of them. His command descends among them so that you may know that Allah is over all things competent and that Allah has encompassed all things in knowledge} [At-Talaq: 12]. Whoever can create a single atom from nothing can create anything less, equal, or greater without limit; there is no difference between few or many, great or small.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: {… You do not see in the creation of the Most Merciful any inconsistency …} (Al-Mulk: from Verse 3). And beware of turning to the one who said: 'It is not possible to create [something] more wondrous than this world'; for this is a wicked philosophical doctrine, and the verse is a text in its invalidation. Even if some atheists attributed it to 'Al-Ghazali', I do not doubt that it was fabricated against him!!! For it is a wicked philosophical doctrine by the testimony of 'Al-Ghazali' as I clarified in my book: 'Tahdim al-Arkan min Laysa fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan' (Demolishing the Pillars of 'Nothing in Possibility is More Wondrous than What Was'), and my book: 'Dalalat al-Burhan 'ala anna fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan' (Evidence of the Proof that in Possibility is Something More Wondrous than What Was), and my book: 'Itbaq al-Aghlal fi A'naq al-Dalal' (Locking the Shackles on the Necks of Error). Despite being a doctrine of philosophers, the most disbelieving of renegades, 'Ibn Arabi', adopted it and placed it in his 'Fusus' and other books of his, relying in it in some of them on 'Al-Ghazali' to perfect his plotting – may Allah protect us from his evil – and 'Al-Ghazali' is innocent of it by the testimony of what was found of his beliefs in 'Al-Ihya' and others" (1). And his saying when interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty {We have certainly created man in the best of stature} (At-Tin: 4): "And the form 'af'al' (superlative/elative) does not indicate what the heretics said, even if that was attributed to some of the great ones, from their saying: 'Nothing in possibility is more wondrous than what was'; because a single degree varies to what cannot be counted, like the variation of humans in their forms and colors and other aspects of their existences and wondrous affairs. I have clarified that in a separate composition for this phrase which I named: 'Tahdim al-Arkan min Laysa fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan', and I clarified it with the utmost clarification and explanation. Trials occurred in it that deafen the ears, and Allah Almighty supported the truth by the agreement of notables, and vanquished the people of tyranny. Then I followed it with the book 'Dalalat al-Burhan 'ala anna fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan', then I cured the ailments, refuted the opponents, and repelled the illusions with 'Al-Qawl al-Fariq bayna al-Sadiq wa al-Munafiq' (The Distinguishing Word between the Truthful and the Hypocrite), which is about two pages of utmost creativity in cutting off the dispute.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: It is possible that the form 'af'al' is restricted relative to something Allah Almighty willed such that we realize it, because it is agreed upon among Ahl al-Sunnah, and stated by 'Al-Ash'ari' and others in more than one place in their books, that Allah Almighty's capabilities are infinite. Among those who stated what 'Al-Ash'ari' stated and elaborated on it is the Imam, Hujjat al-Islam 'Al-Ghazali' in his books 'Al-Ihya' and others, especially: 'Tahafut al-Falasifah' (Incoherence of the Philosophers), where he clarified that this [i.e., 'nothing in possibility is more wondrous than what was'] is one of their rules for negating the attribute of Will, and their saying that His action is by essence, and he clarified the corruption of that" (1). This issue is related to the fundamentals of creed (Aqidah) which we should strive to keep pure and cleansed from every impurity. I believe that the greatest mission, most worthy of care, attention, and struggle by scholars, is the protection of the creed of Monotheism (Tawhid) – first and foremost – from the misleading of people of intellectual immorality, doctrinal error, and corruption in the hearts of servants hovering around its sanctuary. And that the ruler – if he wants good for his nation – must assist the scholars in that and empower them in the land, and lie in wait for those who infiltrate the hearts of servants with their doctrinal errors from atheist philosophers who distort words from their [proper] places. This is the most important and takes precedence over others, even if others are very important, for falling into drinking a glass of wine is not like falling into the trap of Shirk (polytheism). Allah Almighty has decreed, saying emphatically in the Surah of establishing the Muslim family upon His guidance, Mighty and Exalted, Surah 'Al-Nisa': {Indeed, Allah does not forgive that you associate partners with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills. And he who associates others with Allah has certainly fabricated a tremendous sin} (Al-Nisa: 48) {Indeed, Allah does not forgive that partners be associated with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills. And he who associates others with Allah has certainly gone far astray} (Al-Nisa: 116).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Allah Almighty emphasized that truth in Surah (Al-Nisa), the Surah of establishing society upon the Book and Sunnah to be a united and merciful society that knows the great right of kinship ties, even if they extend and prolong until they reach the father of humanity, peace be upon him; because Shirk is the most conducive to the collapse of society, its mutual enmity, and severance. Therefore, Allah Almighty described those who believe by His saying, Majesty be to Him: {Merciful among themselves} (Al-Fath: from Verse 29). "Al-Suyuti" wrote a book refuting the book of his sheikh "Al-Biqa'i" which he named: "Tashyid al-Arkan min Laysa fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan" (Reinforcing the Pillars of 'Nothing in Possibility is More Wondrous than What Was'). It is still a manuscript with handwritten copies in Al-Azhar Library: a copy under number (2728-Halim 33329-Ilm al-Kalam), copied in the year one thousand one hundred seventy in seventeen folios (17f), a copy under number (777) Majami' Halim (34824), and a copy under number (1362-Bakhit-44857-Tasawwuf), written in the year one thousand two hundred ninety-nine (1299). Al-Samhudi: Nur al-Din Ali bin Abdullah al-Shafi'i (d. 873) has a book: "Idah al-Bayan lima Aradahu al-Hujjah min Laysa fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan, wa ma Anahu mimma Qalahu 'ala Dhalika min al-Burhan" (Clarification of the Statement of What the Proof [Al-Ghazali] Intended by 'Nothing in Possibility is More Wondrous than What Was', and What He Meant by the Proof He Said Regarding That), in which he explains "Al-Ghazali's" intent from this doctrine of his. The book is still a manuscript with handwritten copies: a copy in Al-Azhar Library under number (752) Majami' Halim (34799) written in the year one thousand one hundred seventy-three (1173), and a copy in the Qadiriyya School in Baghdad under number (624) within a collection. Among what is attributed to Al-Ghazali as his book (Al-Imla' fi Ishkalat al-Ihya'), the text of a question is: "What is the meaning of 'nothing in possibility is more wondrous than the form of this world, nor better in arrangement, nor more perfect in craftsmanship', for if it existed and He withheld it while capable of it, that would be miserliness contradicting Generosity, and if He was not capable of it, that would be incapacity contradicting Divine Power?" (1) It was responded to with what does not heal, so whoever wants can find Al-Ihya' available. ***
foot_note: 1. (1) – Al-Imla' fi Ishkalat al-Ihya' by Al-Ghazali: Vol 5, p 14 – (Tail of Kitab al-Ihya' – Ed: Al-Ma'rifah – Beirut)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: {Dalalat al-Burhan 'ala anna fi al-Imkan Abda' mimma Kan} (Evidence of the Proof that in Possibility is Something More Wondrous than What Was). The location where he attributed the book to himself in his Tafsir has been mentioned previously. The book is attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/494) and Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22). Dr. "Muhammad Ahmad Al-Qasim" surmised that the book "Tahdim al-Arkan" and the book "Dalalat al-Burhan" are one book and not two, and that what appeared in Hadyat al-Arifin contains an omission like (Ibtal or similar). What the professor mentioned is inaccurate; rather, they are two books, the first refutes the saying and the other establishes its opposite. The first was written in the year (883) and the other was written a year after it. The book was established to affirm the proofs that Allah Almighty is capable of creating whatever He wills and bringing a world other than the one we see, which would be more wondrous and greater, for His capability is not limited to what is witnessed. The book is still a manuscript, of which there is a handwritten copy under number (180-Aqa'id Taymur in the Egyptian National Library), which is the one I used as a reference. ***** {Sirr al-Ruh} (The Secret of the Spirit). He attributed the book to himself in his Tafsir: Nazm al-Durar and in (Kashf al-Zunun: 2/278) (Nazm al-Aqyan p. 24). It is printed from a handwritten copy bearing Al-Biqa'i's handwriting preserved in the Turkish riwaq (gallery) at Al-Azhar Library. He wrote it after the plague that occurred in the year eight hundred fifty-three, which claimed the lives of some of his family in Cairo, as he states at the end of the book saying: "This is the last of what I wanted from the book 'Al-Ruh' by the scholar Shams al-Din ibn al-Qayyim, completed, and praise be to Allah. The motive for me to refine, summarize, and arrange it was those of the deceased who were martyred for me in the plague of the year eight hundred fifty-three in Al-Mu'izziyah Cairo.." He clarified his work on the book (Al-Ruh) by Ibn al-Qayyim: Refinement, summarization, and arrangement. This is what you see if you compare a chapter from the book Al-Ruh by Ibn al-Qayyim and the same chapter from the book Sirr al-Ruh.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Biqa'i proceeded to clarify or detail what was summarized, added to the book what was not there, and reorganized it. He says in its opening: (And perhaps I added something, so I distinguished it with 'I said, and Allah knows best'. I arranged it better than his arrangement, and exerted my effort in refining it. I had thought it would be, after the addition, about a third of it, and a third is much, so it came to half of it, superior in its composition and description. I did not omit anything of his chosen material, nor did I delete any authentic hadith from his hadiths and reports." He arranged the book and summarized it into ten issues: On the reality of the spirit and the soul and whether they are one or two things... Is it eternal or created... Does it die or is death for the body alone... Its return to the dead person and when it is returned... The abode of souls after death... Their perception after death... What distinguishes souls... The trial of the grave... The benefit of the soul from the endeavor of the living... The punishment of the grave and its bliss. The introduction published with the book 'Al-Ruh' by Ibn al-Qayyim is the introduction of Al-Biqa'i's book 'Sirr al-Ruh'; the publisher transferred it there when he did not find an introduction for "Ibn al-Qayyim's" book. Al-Biqa'i added to the original some news that Al-Biqa'i experienced himself, such as hearing voices from some graves and other things. ***** {Al-Nukat wa al-Fawa'id 'ala Sharh al-Aqa'id} (Subtle Points and Benefits on the Explanation of the Creeds). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p. 1148), Nazm al-Aqyan by Al-Suyuti (p. 24), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Idah al-Maknun (4/678). He recorded these Nasafi creeds while studying "Al-Sa'd al-Taftazani's" explanation of the book Al-Aqa'id al-Nasafiyyah with his Sheikh Al-Qayati in the year eight hundred forty (840). Preparing the draft of "Al-Nukat" took six years as he finished it in the year eight hundred forty-six, and completed its fair copy in the year eight hundred fifty-seven (857). The book Al-Aqa'id al-Nasafiyyah by Najm al-Din Umar bin Muhammad al-Nasafi (d. 537) is a text on creeds according to the school of the companions of Abu al-Hasan al-Ash'ari. Scholars paid attention to it through explanation and commentary. Among its most famous explanations is the explanation of Al-Sa'd al-Taftazani (d. 791). There are several marginalia on Al-Sa'd's explanation, including Al-Biqa'i's marginalia. There are several handwritten copies of "Al-Nukat": A copy number (23448 B) Egyptian National Library, which I used as a reference.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Copy number (2643-Al-Saqa-28612 – Al-Azhar Library), written in the year one thousand and six within a collection (134-228f), and it has a gap. A copy in the Hamidiya Library in Turkey - refer to the Hamidiya Library catalog - p: 47 *** ..........Jurisprudence and its Principles....... {Al-Idhan bi Fath Asrar al-Tashahhud wa al-Adhan} (Notification of Opening the Secrets of Tashahhud and Adhan). He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (Nazm al-Durar). His student "Al-Nu'aimi" attributed it to him in (Al-Unwan: p 14-MS), and in Idah al-Maknun (3/152), and in Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and "Subul al-Huda wa al-Rashad fi Sirat Khayr al-Ibad by Al-Salihi Vol: 3 p 354- Dar al-Kutub al-Ilmiyyah Beirut – 1414). There is a handwritten copy of it under number (174-Majami'-M) in the Egyptian National Library which I used as a reference. It has reached me that the book was verified by "Majdi Al-Sayyid" and published by Maktabat al-Rushd in Riyadh in the year 1416 - I was not able to see it. He established the book on two principles, making each principle two chapters: The First Principle on citing Prophetic Hadiths: The first chapter of it on Hadiths narrated regarding Adhan, and the second chapter on Hadiths narrated regarding Tashahhud. The Second Principle: On Secrets. The first chapter on the secrets of Adhan and the second chapter on the secrets of Tashahhud. ***** {Al-Sayf al-Masnun al-Lam'a 'ala al-Mufti al-Maftun bi al-Ibtida'} (The Shining Drawn Sword against the Mufti Fascinated by Innovation). With this book, he refuted a fatwa necessitating the recitation of Al-Fatiha after prayer, a fatwa attributed to "Al-Suyuti". Al-Biqa'i had no choice but to confront the claim that such a thing is obligatory or that it is Sunnah, for he struggles so that nothing is attributed to the Sharia that is not from it. This does not mean that he forbids reciting Al-Fatiha after prayer, but rather forbids saying that it is obligatory or that it is from the Sunnah or that it is a recommended act (Nafilah). We must distinguish between saying something is forbidden to do and saying that doing that thing is Sunnah when it is not proven to be Sunnah. Whoever performs an act of obedience that is not timed with a time, then times it or restricts it and claims that the timing and restriction are Sunnah, has lied against the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family and companions.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Biqa'i concluded the book with a poem of twenty-nine verses rebuking the one who issued that fatwa, beginning with his saying: You neglected what was of meaning and went to * A dispute of wording upon which rulings are not built. There are handwritten copies of the book: = The author's copy under number (738-Fiqh Taymur) Egyptian National Library - which I used as a reference. It is in twenty-three folios (23f). He finished its draft in the forenoon of Friday, the first of Rabi' al-Awwal year eight hundred eighty-two (882) in Damascus, and finished its fair copy on the fifth day of the same month. = Copy number (624) within a collection in the General Qadiriyya School Library in Baghdad. A photocopied version of it is in the library of the Iraqi Scientific Academy under number (10-Aqa'id), and it is in twenty-six folios - Catalog of Manuscripts of the Iraqi Scientific Academy Vol 1 p 86-87). = A copy in the library of "Chester Beatty in Dublin - Al-Mawrid Iraqi Journal p 199 No. 2 Vol 2. ..... Arabic Sciences ... Al-Biqa'i had glorious attention to the science of the Arabic tongue as it is the main tool for good understanding of the Quranic rhetoric. Whoever accompanies his Tafsir (Nazm al-Durar) realizes his great care and knowledge of that tongue: vocabulary, structures, and methods of clarification, expression, and communication. Of what he left us, I only saw some whose location could be reached in the treasuries of manuscripts, and a remainder remains; perhaps Allah Almighty will grant success, guidance, and facilitation to properly view it. What I saw are two books: {Aswaq al-Ashwaq min Masari' al-Ushaq} (Markets of Desires from the Fallen Lovers). The book is attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 1703) and Al-A'lam (1/50). It is a summary of the book (Masari' al-Ushaq) by Al-Sarraj al-Qari: Abu Muhammad Ja'far bin Ahmad (d. 500). Al-Biqa'i arranged it and added to it some rare news in this regard, and incorporated into it the book of Hafiz Ala' al-Din Mughlatay (d. 762) named: "Al-Wadih al-Mubin fi man Mata min al-Muhibbin" (The Clear Clarification regarding Who Died of Lovers). Al-Biqa'i made the book: "Aswaq al-Ashwaq" into an introduction and ten chapters. He finished authoring it in the year eight hundred seventy-three in Cairo. There are handwritten copies of the book:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: = Copy of Bashir Agha in Turkey, and a photocopy (microfilm) of it is in the Institute of Manuscripts in Cairo under number (37-Adab) in (285l) which I used as a reference. = A copy in Rabat under number (3324) copied during the author's lifetime by the pen of "Ali al-Manzarawi" in the year eight hundred seventy-six. It is in two hundred and eighty folios (280f). King Saud University has a copy of this manuscript (No: 320/1). = A copy in the Escorial Library and another in the Paris Library as mentioned by Jurji Zaydan in History of Arabic Literature: Vol 3 p 183). ***** {Ma La Yastaghni 'anhu al-Insan min Mulah al-Lisan} (What Man Cannot Do Without of the Graces of the Tongue). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 1575), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/380). A treatise in six folios of small size, containing nothing new, based on mentioning definitions and examples in grammar chapters, as if it were written for young students. He finished authoring it in the year eight hundred thirty-six (836) in Cairo, i.e., at the beginning of his arrival in Cairo, and perhaps he was working teaching young students. There are handwritten copies of it: O Copy of the Egyptian National Library under number (1593-Nahw) which I used as a reference. O Copy of Shahid Ali in Turkey under number (204) within a collection. This book is not indicative of "Al-Biqa'i's" standing in the science of Arabic grammar; rather, his standing in it you see clearly and highly in his Tafsir Nazm al-Durar, for he has in it contemplation of Quranic grammar issues that indicates to you his mastery in this science, and he often digresses in explaining a grammatical issue and what grammarians said about it, and what he approves of that because of its relation to the science of Quranic correlation. *** .....History and Biographies...... Al-Biqa'i had great attention to history and biographies of notables, as if he was influenced by his sheikh Al-Maqrizi and Ibn Hajar al-Asqalani. He left us a distinct heritage in the art of history and biographies. I have not seen printed of it except one part of one of his historical books, which is "Izhar al-Asr", and the dictionary of his sheikhs and peers is worthy of being verified and published: {Akhbar al-Jallad fi Futuh al-Bilad} (News of the Struggle in the Conquests of Countries).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Attributed to him in "Al-A'lam" by Al-Zirikli (1/50), History of Arabic Literature by Zaydan (Vol 3/183), and Mu'jam al-Mu'allifin by Umar Farrukh (3/272). In it, he spoke about the conquests until the end of the caliphate of our master "Uthman", may Allah be pleased with them. As for the caliphate of our master "Ali", may Allah be pleased with them, it was not an era of conquests but an era of internal disputes over the caliphate (f: 523-524). In its opening, he mentioned his sources of books and scholars, the value of each scholar and book, and the degree of his truthfulness and investigation (f: 3). Then he listed the verses of Jihad and what he himself said in urging Jihad (f: 4-15). He spoke about what was before the mission and the kings and rulers in it (f: 15-33). Then he reviewed the Islamic conquests (f: 33-523) and singled out the conquest of his town: "Al-Biqa' al-Azizi" for discussion (f: 150). He finished authoring it in the year eight hundred eighty-four (884 AH). There are handwritten copies of it: = Copy of the Egyptian National Library under number (2220-Tarikh Taymur- in three photocopied volumes – I used it as a reference. = A copy in Laleli Library in Turkey (No. 1994-Tarikh). = A copy in Damad Ibrahim Library in Turkey under number (886). = A copy in the Paris Library - Catalog of Rare Manuscripts by Al-Jaza'iri - Vol 2 p 142 (MS). *** {Izhar al-Asr li Asrar Ahl al-Asr} (Revealing the Age regarding the Secrets of the People of the Age). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/118, 171), Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/278), and Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22). He made it a sequel to the history of his sheikh Ibn Hajar called (Inba' al-Ghumr bi Akhbar al-Umr), which began with the news of the year seven hundred seventy-three (773). He stopped in it at the news of the year eight hundred fifty (850), which was also like a sequel to the history of Ibn Kathir which ended with the news of the year seven hundred seventy-three. In his history, he begins with Muharram of the year eight hundred fifty-five (855) and ends with Dhu al-Hijjah of the year eight hundred fifty-seven (857). The book was verified by Dr. Muhammad Salim Al-Awfi, Associate Professor at Imam University in Riyadh. He questioned: Is what is between (850-855) missing or did Al-Biqa'i not write it? (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) – Izhar al-Asr li Asrar Ahl al-Asr by Al-Biqa'i: Vol 1 p 45 - Ed: Muhammad Al-Awfi

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: The verifier, doing well, cared to explain Al-Biqa'i's methodology and the importance of his book. Among what he said was: "Al-Biqa'i presented in detail the events of his time... and described what was happening in his era of political situations, military events, social manifestations, and natural events. He described the struggle for power and competition for positions of leadership and pioneering in society... and presented the customs and traditions that prevailed in his society... He described the Mamluks, the imported slaves (Ajlab), and soldiers in their revolutions... and the epidemics and famines that afflicted society... He also paid attention to currency, its increase and decrease. Likewise, he chronicled the deaths of the most important notables of his time and also cared about the Mamluk state's relationship with neighboring kingdoms in peace or war... His interest in Egypt did not divert him from following the news of the Levant. The importance of Al-Biqa'i's history increases if we know that he was at odds with the Mamluk authority, looking at it with indignation and resentment, as he suffered harm from it... unlike the most important contemporary historians to him: Ibn Taghri Bardi and Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Iyas, who were of Mamluk origin, imported, and indeed close to the Mamluk state and possessors of wealth and feudal estates in it..." (1) ***** {Badhl al-Nush wa al-Shafaqah li Suhbat al-Sayyid Waraqah} (Exerting Advice and Compassion regarding the Companionship of Master Waraqah). Attributed to him in Khizanat al-Adab by Al-Baghdadi (3/391). He authored it to repel the denial of some students of knowledge that "Waraqah bin Nawfal" was a Companion. So Al-Biqa'i provided evidence for his Islam and Monotheism before the Mission (f: 2) and his resolve to support the Prophet, peace be upon him. He cited news indicating his Islam and that he is in Paradise (f: 49). He spoke about Zaid bin Amr (f: 12) and the difference between him and Waraqah (f: 18) and between him and Abu Talib (f: 43). He spoke about the definition of the Sabian (f: 46) and about the disbelief of Al-Muqawqis (f: 48). Then he elaborated on the biography of "Waraqah" (54-68). There are handwritten copies of the book: * Copy of the Egyptian National Library under number (177-Tasawwuf Halim – sixty-one folios (61f). I used it as a reference. * Copy of the Zahiriyya Library in Damascus under number (3733) in sixty-eight folios (68f), copied during the author's lifetime in the year (884).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: I read a research authored by Dr. "Uwayd Al-Matrafi" on the faith of "Waraqah" named (Waraqah bin Nawfal fi Batnan al-Jannah), published by the Muslim World League in Makkah Al-Mukarramah. It is an extensive, good research; may Allah Almighty be good to its author in both abodes. He addressed Al-Biqa'i's opinion and his book and mentioned that he sought to obtain the copy of the Zahiriyya Library to verify it. Perhaps Allah Almighty will facilitate that for him and help him publish it. ***** {Jawahir al-Bihar fi Nazm Sirat al-Mukhtar} (Jewels of the Seas in Versifying the Biography of the Chosen One). He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (Nazm al-Durar: 7/63) and in Kashf al-Zunun (p 612), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/2), and Al-A'lam (1/50). A poem of six hundred seventy-six verses (676) on a single rhyme, beginning with: What is wrong with your eyelid, shedding tears pouring * And the sea of your thought, full of worry, abundant Do not grieve over a wish that has passed * For Allah, before creating creation, divided it. He finished composing it in the city of Rosetta in Egypt, while he was stationed there in the year eight hundred forty-eight. When he went to Hijaz for Hajj, he recited it in front of the Prophetic Rawdah. It is still a manuscript. I used as my reference the copy of the Egyptian National Library under number (2143) Tarikh Tal'at - in thirty-eight plates (38p). ***** {Unwan al-Zaman fi Tarajim al-Shuyukh wa al-Aqran} (Title of the Time in Biographies of Sheikhs and Peers). He mentioned it as his own in "Masa'id al-Nazar" (1/135) and it is attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1174), Tanwir al-Hawalik by Al-Suyuti (1/104), Shadharat al-Dhahab (7/9) - the author of Shadharat used it as a reference - Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Al-A'lam (Vol 1/50, Vol 10/8). A dictionary in which he chronicled his sheikhs and peers in seeking knowledge. He arranged the names of the biographees alphabetically, starting with the name (Ahmad) for blessing. Among what is noted about it are matters: He committed to mentioning lineage, titles, kunyas, birth, and death if it had occurred when recording the biography. He relies on meeting, oral transmission, and writing for whom he chronicles, and repeats the meeting and compares and confronts with the discrepancy if it occurs (Vol: 2 p 168, Vol 3 p 135).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: He specifies the place and time of meeting with the biographee, what took place in it, and what he read to him or wrote of his poetry and speech, while recording the biographee's sheikhs, reading, license, morals, and livelihoods (Vol: 1 p 17, 26, 48, 53). He adheres to moderation in the biography except rarely as he did in the biography of his sheikh "Ibn Hajar" (Vol: 1 p 90-174). Repetition of biographies of some notables occurred, perhaps from the copyists or an oversight from him (Vol: 2 p 29, 68, 71, 101). Disturbance occurred in the arrangement of some biographies, so he advanced and delayed (Vol: 2 p 75, 99, Vol 3 p 411, Vol 4 p 21, 22, 40, 43, 88). He transgressed in some biographies, and he should not have done so. There are handwritten copies of the book: Copy under number (2255-Tarikh Taymur-Egyptian National Library) in four volumes. I used it as a reference. Copy number 1001 – Tarikh – Egyptian National Library. Copy number 4911 – Tarikh – Egyptian National Library. Copy of Arif Hikmat in Medina – Number (43-Tarikh). The author's copy – incomplete. Copy of Tunis number (5034-Tarajim – Al-Ahmadiyya Library – Catalog of Taymur Selections p: 73). Copy of Mehmed Pasha Koprulu Library in Turkey (Al-Mawrid Journal: p 221- No. 4 Vol 5). ***** {Unwan al-Unwan Tajrid Asma' al-Shuyukh wa Ba'd al-Talamidha wa al-Aqran} (Title of the Title: Stripping the Names of Sheikhs and Some Students and Peers). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 1175-1176), Hadyat al-Arifin (Vol 6 p 22), and Al-A'lam (Vol 1 p 50). He authored it in the year eight hundred eighty-four (884) in Damascus. The book is an abbreviation of his previous book "Unwan al-Zaman". He suffices in it with mentioning the biographee's name, birth, and death if it occurred. He did not provide biographies as he did in the original "Unwan al-Zaman". He included a biography of his father in both, and mentioned a group he did not mention in the original (1). *****
foot_note: 1. (1) Correction: After finishing preparing this work for publication, I learned that the book (Unwan al-Unwan) was published by (Dar al-Kitab al-Arabi) Beirut in one volume, 231 pages, and I was not able to view it.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: That is what Allah, Majesty be to Him, facilitated viewing of the scientific works of "Al-Biqa'i". They are, as you see, diverse, and despite their diversity, are characterized by depth in addressing their issues. As for the rest of his scientific production, I was not successful in finding much of it in our lands. Perhaps Allah Almighty will help with good access... Section Two: His works which I have not viewed. What passed was a quick glance at what Allah Almighty facilitated my viewing of. He has other books which I was not able to view due to the great distance between me and their hiding places in manuscript treasuries. Perhaps Allah Almighty will grant facilitation, success, and guidance. I am not classifying those books here by subject, but arranging them according to the order of their names: {Ibahat al-Bahah fi Ilm al-Hisab wa al-Masahah} (Permitting the Courtyard in the Science of Arithmetic and Surveying). He attributed it to himself in Unwan al-Zaman (2/304) and it was attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 1, p 216). This book was present in the Egyptian National Library, and I requested it often during four years I was stationed in the manuscripts section at the Egyptian National Library preparing my Master's thesis, but the specialist in the manuscript treasury decided every time that the book was not present, despite it being recorded in the manuscript catalogs of the Library under number (3) Arithmetic and Mathematics. Dr. "King" mentioned it in the Catalog of Scientific Manuscripts Part One and described it in a way indicating that he had viewed it. It is an explanation of his poem (Al-Bahah) which he composed in the year eight hundred twenty-seven (827) in Jerusalem, and whose mention is coming if Allah Almighty wills. ***** {Ahsan al-Kalam al-Muntaqa min Dhamm al-Kalam} (The Best Speech Selected from the Condemnation of Theology). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p: 828), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/21), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: This book he selected from the book (Dhamm al-Kalam wa Ahlih) by Al-Harawi: Abu Isma'il Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ali Al-Harawi Al-Ansari (d. 481), author of the book Manazil al-Sa'irin. There is a manuscript copy of the book (Dhamm al-Kalam wa Ahlih) at the Institute of Arabic Manuscripts number (97), and in the Zahiriyya Library in Damascus another copy under number (337). Al-Suyuti has a book (Sawn al-Mantiq wa al-Kalam) which he utilized. "Al-Biqa'i" received the book (Dhamm al-Kalam wa Ahlih) from his sheikh "Ibn Hajar" in the year eight hundred forty-six (846). ***** {Al-Idrak li Fann al-Ihtibak} (Realization of the Art of Reciprocal Omission). He mentioned it as his own in his Tafsir (1/225) and in the summary of his Tafsir as well (f: 3-a) and in Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah (p 198). His student Al-Suyuti attributed it to him in Al-Itqan (3/182) and Sharh Uqud al-Juman (p 133). Al-Biqa'i said about it: "It is a rare, precious art, and I have collected a good book on it in which I mentioned its definition, its source from the language, and what examples of it were present to me from the Dear Book and the speech of jurists, and I named it: Al-Idrak li Fann al-Ihtibak." He says in the summary of his Tafsir: Dalalat al-Burhan al-Qawim: "I also deleted from it the explicit statement explaining Ihtibak, dispensing with my book 'Al-Idrak', for I mentioned in it about three hundred verses of this creative art and formidable style" (f: 3-a). ***** {Asad al-Biqa' al-Nahisah fi Muta'addi al-Maqadisah} (The Biting Lions of Bekaa against the Transgressors of the Jerusalemites). He attributed it to himself in Unwan al-Zaman (1/346, Vol 2/353). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 81), Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/278), and Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22). It is a poem censuring some Jerusalemites which he presented to his sheikh Shams al-Din al-Sa'di, so he wrote for him on it: "Accepted Poem". ***** {Al-Isfar 'an Ashraf al-Asfar} (Unveiling the Noblest of Travels). He attributed it to himself in Unwan al-Zaman (4/175). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/86), mentioning it as "Al-Isfar 'an Ashridat al-Asfar", but the correct is "Ashraf al-Asfar". He authored it in the year eight hundred forty-four (844) when he returned from his journey raiding with the Muslim army "Cyprus" and "Rhodes". They had raids on "Rhodes" during the time of Al-Ashraf "Barsbay", but they did not succeed in conquering it. *****

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: {Isharat al-Muttaqi ila A'lam al-Bayhaqi} (The God-fearing's Sign to Al-Bayhaqi's Signs). He attributed it to himself in Unwan al-Zaman (2/355). A'lam al-Bayhaqi is a book on the signs of Prophethood, and it is a famous circulated book. ***** {Ish'ar al-Wa'i bi Ash'ar al-Biqa'i} (Informing the Aware of Al-Biqa'i's Poems). He attributed it to himself in Unwan al-Zaman (2/365, 372) and it was attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/104), Nazm al-Aqyan (p 25), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/278). It is his collection of poetry (Diwan). "Haji Khalifa" says: "He has many poems, and the good of his poetry is average." What I have seen of his poetry is closer to rhymed prose (Nazm); the enchanting spirit of poetry is not in it. In his book: "Unwan al-Zaman" are many of his poems. If there were time, I would have collected his poems, though I see their artistic value is not high. At the end of the thirteenth part of the explanation of Sahih al-Bukhari by his sheikh "Ibn Hajar": "Fath al-Bari" is his poem which he recited at the celebration of completing the explanation of Sahih al-Bukhari. In "Masa'id al-Nazar" he says: "And among what is suitable to cite in this racetrack of what follows of poems is what I said in the year eight hundred fifty, while I was stationed at the frontier of 'Damietta'. I contemplated one day my conditions and the conditions of the enviers, and I found them extremely far from the objects of their envy, for my pursuit is different from what they pursue, so we did not crowd over a single goal. My wonder at their affair intensified, so I said from the third Tawil meter and the rhyme is Mutawatir, Musmat, Mutlaq, Muradif: Lo! Many a person has become envious of me * Hoping for my death while he is mortal like me Oh, would that I knew if I die what he attains * And what is it to him if my time is prolonged My enemy is far from his injustice, safe * From oppression, close to benefit where he hoped for me Do I have an inheritance other than a bow I prepare * For fighting those of disbelief and other than Yemeni And what do the enviers seek of me while I * Am occupied away from them by my greatest affair I write it in this manner to indicate that it is closer to prose or rhymed prose than to poetry which is enchanting hymns... {Ashla' al-Baz 'ala Ibn al-Khabbaz}

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/105), Al-Daw' al-Lami' (1/109), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/278). A part he collected censuring "Nasir al-Din al-Zaftawi", but Al-Biqa'i regretted that and expiated for his deed by reading to "Al-Zaftawi", making him his sheikh and preserving his right over him. This is praiseworthy of Al-Biqa'i, indicating that he returns to the truth when it becomes clear to him. This is of praiseworthy character produced by courage and dignity that refuse for a person to be a slave to the defect of arrogance, for he will not enter Paradise who has in his heart a mustard seed of pride, as the purified Sunnah guided to that. If we, especially those in authority among us, adopted the character of returning to the truth and supporting it when it becomes clear to us, this nation would have a status in this time other than what it has fallen into. Those in authority have tried among us all systems and philosophies imported to us from capitalism, Marxism, socialism, dictatorship, fake democracy, Freemasonry, secularism, Machiavellianism... etc., and nothing remains but the path of Islam. So will those return to the truth and take the Book and Sunnah alone as a methodology of life and rule? ***** {Itbaq al-Aghlal fi A'naq al-Dalal} (Locking the Shackles on the Necks of Error). He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (20/177). It is among the books he prepared on the issue "Nothing in possibility is more wondrous than what was", which has been previously referenced. ***** {Al-Ittila' 'ala Hajjat al-Wada'} (Viewing the Farewell Pilgrimage). He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (2/264, Vol 22/321). He says when interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty: "Indeed, As-Safa and Al-Marwah..." (Al-Baqarah: 158), explaining the relationship of this verse to what preceded it: "And among the best of it also: That when He mentioned afflictions by loss of wealth due to sins (And whatever strikes you of disaster - it is for what your hands have earned; but He pardons much) (Al-Shura: 30), He followed it with the medicine repairing that loss religiously and worldly, for 'Hajj and Umrah eliminate poverty and sins as the bellows eliminate the dross of gold and silver'.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Narrated by Imam Ahmad, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Khuzaimah, and Ibn Hibban in their Sahihs from Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with them, from the Prophet, peace be upon him. It was also narrated from a number of Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, as I clarified in my book: 'Al-Ittila' 'ala Hajjat al-Wada'.'" He referred to it during his speech in Surah "Al-Nasr" and that he mentioned the Farewell Sermon in his book: "Al-Ittila' 'ala Hajjat al-Wada'" (Masa'id al-Nazar: 3/272). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/117). ***** {Al-Intisar min al-Muta'addi bi al-Absar} (Victory over the Transgressor with Eyes). He mentioned it as his own in Masa'id al-Nazar (1/135). His sheikh "Al-Kamal Muhammad bin Al-Humam Al-Hanafi (d. 861), author of the book "Al-Hidayah" in Hanafi jurisprudence and the book "Al-Tahrir fi Usul al-Fiqh", wrote a commendation for him on it. Among what he said in his commendation: "I stood on the shore of a swelling sea when I stood to look into this dazzling composition, standing over its opponent like a sharp sword. By my life, he has trodden in his view – after the path of the righteous – what incapacitates the stallions of established theorists regarding the subtleties of the cream of thoughts. It deserved to be said about it over the heads of witnesses until the Day of Calling: No wonder his Lord showed wonders * And in his robe is righteousness and in his heart is a sea. Perhaps the book concerns what the travels brought of his dispute with the people of a neighbor of his who were looking upon his family from above, so he disputed with them and there was conflict and fighting (1). ***** {Al-Bahah fi Ilmay al-Hisab wa al-Masahah} (The Courtyard in the Two Sciences of Arithmetic and Surveying). He mentioned it as his own in Unwan al-Zaman (2/354). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/216), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/277), and Al-A'lam (1/50). It is a poem in the science of arithmetic and the science of surveying which he began in the year eight hundred twenty-seven when he was eighteen years old, and completed in the year eight hundred thirty-two in Jerusalem. He used to call it first: Mushtarak al-Malahah fi Ilmay al-Hisab wa al-Masahah" (Shared Beauty in the Two Sciences of Arithmetic and Surveying). It is in seven hundred verses, and he explained it in the book (Al-Bahah) previously mentioned. ***** {Bayan al-Ijma'
foot_note: 1. (1) - See: Inba' al-Hasr by Ibn al-Sayrafi p 509 – Ed: Hasan Habashi – General Egyptian Book Organization.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: 'ala Man' al-Ijtima' fi Bid'at al-Ghina' wa al-Sama'} (Clarification of the Consensus on Preventing Gathering for the Innovation of Singing and Listening). He attributed it to himself in "Tahdim al-Arkan" (f: 11). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/260), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279). Its subject is clear from its title. It is a book worthy of verification and publication in this time of ours if it were available. How much we need such a thing, as we have fallen into the "swamp" of that detestable sin until people became certain that there is no harm in this, while it is very serious in Islam. We are now in a time where the matter is confused, so many of the common people and some of the elite intellectuals undertake the evil thinking it is not evil. If the matter were explained to them nicely and the explanation repeated by major scholars in lecture halls, mosques, forums, and media, the difference between the Known (Ma'ruf) and the Denied (Munkar) legally would be established in their hearts. Indeed, it is a great obligation on the scholars of Islam to explain to people what is Ma'ruf and what is Munkar in the Book and Sunnah with wisdom and fair preaching, for that is a great principle of Commanding the Good and Forbidding the Evil. ***** {Tatmim Isaghuji} (Completion of Isagoge). There is a handwritten copy of it in "Shahid Ali Library in Turkey" within a collection containing books by Al-Biqa'i under number (2804). The word "Isagoge" is Greek meaning "The Five Universals" which are: Genus, Species, Difference, Property, and General Accident. The Five Universals are one of the nine chapters of Greek Logic. Among the most famous who wrote on it are "Abd al-Latif al-Baghdadi", author of "Khizanat al-Adab", and "Athir al-Din al-Abhari". "Al-Biqa'i" studied "Logic" with his sheikh "Al-Badr al-Hindi", student of "Al-Sayyid al-Sharif" (d. 816) in "Damascus" and with his sheikh "Al-Qayati" in Cairo. ***** {Tadmir al-Mu'arid fi Takfir Ibn al-Farid} (Destruction of the Opponent regarding the Excommunication of Ibn al-Farid). He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (Vol 20 p 434, Vol 22 p 445) and in Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah (p 18). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (382), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279). It is one of the books he set up to refute the sayings of "Ibn al-Farid" tending towards the doctrine of Incarnation and Union.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Increasing the authoring and publishing of books refuting the errors that strike at the doctrinal foundations of the Muslim Ummah is a great matter that a scholar should not tire of, nor say 'I have already written a book on this', especially in an era where various sects flock and collaborate to entrench error, like this era of ours. Many a word written by a scholar is not heard by many, and another word penetrates everywhere and revives in every land. People of knowledge have said: What is repeated is established. Whoever wants to establish something in the hearts calls it out morning and evening in the ears of the servants, for it will inevitably penetrate their hearts. This is what the media in our countries pursues, not ashamed of mentioning, publishing, repeating, and varying the call to what they want to establish in the hearts of servants of low morals and bad lifestyles far from the Book and Sunnah. ***** {Tahdhib Jumal al-Khawnaji} (Refinement of Al-Khawnaji's Sentences). There is a handwritten copy of it in "Shahid Ali" library in Turkey under number (2804). See the catalog of the mentioned library p: 256 (MS). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/602) and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279). He authored it in the year eight hundred sixty-one (861). The book is an explanation and refinement of the book (Al-Jumal) in the summary of "Nihayat al-Amal" in Logic, by Ibn Marzuq al-Tilmisani. His student "Afdal al-Din Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Namur al-Khawnaji (d. 649) summarized it and named his summary "Al-Jumal", and "Al-Biqa'i" came and refined the summary: "Al-Jumal". ***** {Jami' al-Fatawi li Idah Bahjat al-Hawi} (Collector of Fatwas to Clarify the Joy of Al-Hawi). He attributed it to himself in "Unwan al-Zaman (1/361) and in Masa'id al-Nazar (1/132). The book "Al-Hawi" in the branches of Shafi'i jurisprudence by Najm al-Din Abd al-Ghaffar bin Abd al-Karim al-Qazwini (d. 665) was cared for by scholars through explanation and versification. Among that is the versification of "Zain al-Din Umar bin Muzaffar al-Wardi" (d. 749) in five thousand verses, and he named the poem "Al-Bahjah". "Al-Biqa'i" memorized the poem "Al-Bahjah" in Damascus, and read the book "Al-Hawi" to his sheikh "Ibn Qadi Shuhba" as a research reading (Unwan al-Zaman: 1/352-353).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: "Al-Biqa'i" says about his book "Jami' al-Fatawi": "A strange book in which I mixed the words of 'Al-Bahjah' as a poem with the words of the explanation, a mixing such that the two speeches became thought to be an independent text, like the book 'Al-Anwar' by Al-Ardabili, and it is my greatest reliance in this explanation" (1). "Al-Kamal Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Al-Barizi" (d. 875) wrote a commendation for him on it in which he said: "I paused contemplating the beauties of this 'Jami'', thinking about the eloquence of its speaker, and what he created in it of admiration for the viewer and delight for the listener. I found it containing every argument, encompassing 'Al-Anwar' and 'Al-Bahjah', and I knew the distinction of its author over his peers, and his alertness over the people of his time. May Allah extend him with sufficiency and make his end with goodness and increase" (2). ***** {Al-Jami' al-Mubin lima Qila fi "Wa Ka'ayyin"} (The Clear Collector of What Was Said Regarding "Wa Ka'ayyin"). He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (5/86) saying at the saying of Allah Almighty: {And how many a prophet} (Al-Imran: 146): "There is much discussion regarding its dialects, meaning, Tawatur and Shadh readings in connection and pause, its drawing in the Mushaf of Imam 'Uthman bin Affan' may Allah be pleased with him upon which the consensus of the Companions occurred to be the reference in case of disagreement, whether it is simple or compound, derived or rigid, and how to dispose in its dialects. I covered it comprehensively in my book: 'Al-Jami' al-Mubin lima Qila fi Wa Ka'ayyin'." ***** {Khayr al-Zad min Kitab al-I'tiqad} (The Best Provision from the Book of Belief). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 727, p 1393), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/280). "Al-Biqa'i" selected his book from the book "Al-I'tiqad wa al-Hidayah ila Sabil al-Rashad" by Imam Hafiz: Abu Bakr Ahmad bin Al-Husayn Al-Bayhaqi (d. 584). He is on the methodology of the Salaf: Ahl al-Sunnah wa al-Jama'ah in the fundamentals of creed. "Al-Bayhaqi" says in his introduction after praise and prayer:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: "By the success of Allah Almighty, I have authored regarding what those accountable need to know in the fundamentals of knowledge and its branches, what has spread in mention in some lands, and benefited those of the servants who were guided to hear and acquire it. However, the sentences of what is needed to be known of that for belief upon correctness are scattered in those books, and it hardly happens for their group to come upon collecting them and encompassing all of them. So I wanted, and the Will belongs to Allah Almighty, to collect a book comprising the clarification of what is obligatory upon the accountable person to believe and confess, with reference to the edges of its proofs by way of abbreviation, and what should be its slogan by way of brevity." Al-Biqa'i had read the book "Al-I'tiqad" to his sheikh "Ibn Hajar". He finished authoring "Khayr al-Zad" in Dhu al-Qa'dah year (861). ***** Dala'il al-Burhan li Munsifi al-Ikhwan 'ala Tariq al-Iman (Proofs of Demonstration for the Fair Brothers on the Path of Faith). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p: 759) and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279). He authored it in the year eight hundred seventy-seven (877). I have no knowledge now of its subject. ***** {Raf' al-Litham 'an Ara'is al-Nizam} (Lifting the Veil from the Brides of Poetry). There is a handwritten copy of it in "Shahid Ali" library in Turkey under number (3804). See catalog of the library (p 256) (MS) and Catalog of Taymur Selections (p: 55). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 910), Hadyat al-Arifin (1:22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279-280). A book on Prosody and Rhyme. He finished it in Rabi' al-Awwal year eight hundred forty-eight (848) in Cairo. ***** {Sharh Jam' al-Jawami'} (Explanation of the Collection of Collections). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p 596), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279). A book on Principles of Jurisprudence. "Jam' al-Jawami'" is one of the most famous books of Principles of Jurisprudence authored by "Al-Taj al-Subki". There are numerous explanations and marginalia on Jam' al-Jawami', the most famous of which is the explanation of Al-Jalal Al-Mahalli (d. 864), Al-Biqa'i's sheikh. ***** {Sharh Jawahir al-Bihar fi Nazm Sirat al-Mukhtar} (Explanation of Jewels of the Seas in Versifying the Biography of the Chosen One). He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (7/63). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p: 612), Hadyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279). An explanation of his poem "Jawahir al-Bihar" previously mentioned. It is in two volumes as Haji Khalifa says (p: 612). *****

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Sawab al-Jawab li as-Sa'il al-Murtab} He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (Vol 20, p. 434; Vol 22, p. 445). The book is refuting the doctrine of Incarnation (Hulul) and Unionism (Ittihad) espoused by some Sufi philosophers like "Ibn Arabi" and "Ibn al-Farid". The book is mentioned in Kashf al-Zunun (p. 267, p. 1083), Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/279), and Hadiyat al-Arifin (1/22) under the title (Sawab al-Jawab li as-Sa'il al-Murtab al-Mujadil al-Mu'arid fi Kufr Ibn al-Farid). Al-Biqa'i says: "I authored several works on that in which their disgraces became evident and the hidden things appeared, among them: 'Sawab al-Jawab li as-Sa'il al-Murtab', and 'Al-Farid li Takfir Ibn al-Farid', and 'Tadmir al-Ma'arid fi Takfir Ibn al-Farid', and 'Tanbih al-Ghabi ala Takfir Ibn Arabi', and 'Tahdhir al-Ibad min Ahl al-Inad bi Bid'at al-Ittihad'. I spent a long life on them, and they wasted my times—may Allah waste them utterly and threaten their pillars and supporters severely. I struck them with the inability to provide an answer that reveals doubt, morning and evening, repeatedly and initially. The rebuke, scolding, and censure compelled them to write an answer that was not free of confusion, disturbance, doubt, and suspicion. I demonstrated that its compiler erred in all of it, and committed explicit disbelief in four places, and lied in eight, thus becoming wounded, nay, a fallen dead man. So I prolonged the rebuke, scolding, and vilification thereby, so their necks were humbled, their dissent weakened, and their hypocrisy became hidden..." (1) ***** {Al-'Uddah fi Akhbar ar-Riddah} He mentioned it as his own in his Tafsir (20/128), and in his book "Akhbar al-Jallad" he mentioned it under the title (Zawal ash-Shiddah bi Qital Ahl ar-Riddah) (Folio: 4). The book investigates the news of the Wars of Apostasy during the time of Caliph Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with them. ***** {Azm Wasilat al-Isabah fi San'at al-Kitabah} Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1142) and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/280); a poem on calligraphy, diacritics, and punctuation. ***** {Al-Farid li Takfir Ibn al-Farid} He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (Vol 20, p. 434; Vol 22, p. 445) and in Tahdhir al-Ibad: 257 = Masra' at-Tasawwuf).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It was attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1215) and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/280). He selected in this book – as he says – in Tahdhir al-Ibad (p. 257) from the Ta'iyyah of Ibn al-Farid nearly four hundred and fifty verses about which "the righteous and the disbelievers testified that his intent by them was explicit Unionism." From this, it is verified that the title of the book is (Al-Farid) with a single-dotted 'Fa', the sister of 'Qaf', which is an active participle from (Farada - to impose/cut), for the book mentions texts that impose upon every fair person to judge "Ibn al-Farid" with disbelief. So what you see in "Nazm al-Durar" Indian edition (Vol 20/434, Vol 22/445) and the Beirut edition (8/621) that it is (Al-Qarid) with a 'Qaf' is not correct, and perhaps it is a distortion by a copyist or printer. Al-Shihab Al-Matbuli (Abu Al-Fath Ahmad bin Musa bin Ahmad Al-Shafi'i) has a book: "Al-Madad al-Fa'id fi adh-Dhab 'an Ibn al-Farid" (1). And Al-Suyuti has a book refuting his teacher "Al-Biqa'i" which he named "Qam' al-Ma'arid fi Nusrat Ibn al-Farid". ***** {Qadh az-Zand fi Saqt az-Zand li Abi al-Ala' al-Ma'arri} He attributed it to himself in his dictionary "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/363). It is clear from its title that it is an explanation of that Diwan. ***** {Qadh al-Fikr wa Tanwir al-Basar bi Ajwibat al-Shihab Ibn Hajar} He mentioned it as his own in his dictionary "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/174). He collected in it the answers of his teacher "Al-Shihab Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani" in jurisprudence. ***** {Al-Qawl al-Fariq bayna as-Sadiq wa al-Munafiq} He mentioned it as his own in his Tafsir (22/141). It is also regarding the issue of Incarnation and Unionism, in refuting which he elaborated and persisted, so may Allah Almighty reward him with the best reward. ***** {Al-Qawl al-Ma'ruf fi ar-Radd ala Munkir al-Ma'ruf} He attributed it to himself in his Tafsir (22/444). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1365) and Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/2870). The author of "Mu'jam al-Mu'allifin" (1/71) named it: "Al-Qawl al-Ma'luf".

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: That is inaccurate; for "Al-Qawl al-Ma'luf" belongs to his peer "Al-Sakhawi" refuting "Al-Biqa'i". "Al-Sakhawi" says: "I have refuted him on more than one issue in several works, among them: 'Al-Asl al-Asil fi Tahrim an-Naql min at-Tawrah wa al-Injil' and 'Al-Qawl al-Ma'luf fi ar-Radd ala Munkir al-Ma'ruf'" (1). And Al-Shihab Al-Matbuli has a book refuting Al-Biqa'i regarding the denial of the saying "Ya Da'im al-Ma'ruf" (2). ***** {Al-Qawl al-Mufid fi Usul at-Tajweed} He mentioned it as his own in his dictionary "Unwan al-Zaman" (2/335). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p. 1365), Hadiyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Al-A'lam (10/8). There is a manuscript copy of it in Al-Zahiriyah in Damascus under number (7423-Quranic Sciences) in sixteen folios (16f) written in the year eight hundred sixty-six, and a copy in the General Library in Rabat, Morocco, under number (1755/B). ***** {Kifayat al-Qari wa Ghunyat al-Muqri fi Riwayat Abi Amr} He attributed it to himself in "Masa'id al-Nazar" (1/131). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (p. 1500), Hadiyat al-Arifin (1/22), and Mu'jam al-Mu'allifin (3/381). He authored it in the year eight hundred twenty-seven in Damascus when he was eighteen years old. When he came to Cairo the first time in the year eight hundred thirty-four, he showed it to his teacher "Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani", who wrote a praise (Taqriz) for him on it, saying (3): "Thus are pearls organized, and to here ends the rank of those of high status. Indeed, when you see the crescent growing * You become certain it will become a full moon. I wish I knew who has this beginning, what is awaited by his joining of the star." Sa'd al-Din bin al-Dayri (d. 867) also wrote a praise on it for him, saying: "I stood upon this work marked as Al-Kifayah (The Sufficiency), combining authentic narration and rare knowledge, bearing witness for its author of reaching the rank of the end at the age of the beginning" (4). ***** {Mukhtasar as-Sirah an-Nabawiyyah wa Thalathah min al-Khulafa' ar-Rashidin}

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The book is a summary of his book (Jawahir al-Bihar) mentioned previously. It is attributed to Al-Biqa'i in "Al-A'lam" (1/50, 10/7). There is a copy of it in the "Ubayd" library in Damascus. In the newsletter of Islamic Heritage News (p. 25 - Issue 20 - Year 1409) by the Center for Manuscripts, Heritage, and Documents in Kuwait, the book was mentioned with the previous title attributed to "Al-Biqa'i", and that there is a manuscript copy of it in "Ra'is al-Kuttab" under number (704), and that this is mentioned in the journal "Alam al-Kutub" (p. 34 - Issue 34 Vol 3 = October 1982). ***** {Al-Maqsad al-Ali fi Tarjamat al-Imam al-Ghazali} Mentioned by "Al-Zabidi" in his book (Ithaf al-Sadah al-Muttaqin), and he said that Al-Biqa'i praised "Al-Ghazali" at the beginning of the book and prolonged his praise, then he moved to refute him regarding the issue: "There is nothing in possibility more wondrous than what was." Al-Zabidi stated that he possesses the book. ****** {Al-Multaqat min Mu'jam at-Tabarani al-Awsat} He attributed it to himself in his dictionary "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/363). ***** {Muntaqa al-Gharib al-Ani min at-Targhib lil-Asfahani} He mentioned it as his own in his dictionary "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/363). ***** {An-Nukat al-Wafiyyah bima fi Sharh al-Alfiyyah lil-Iraqi} A marginalia of his on Iraqi's Alfiyyah which he commented during his study of the explanation of the Alfiyyah by Iraqi with his teacher "Ibn Hajar", but he did not complete the marginalia; he reached half of the poem and showed his marginalia to his teacher "Ibn Hajar", who wrote a praise for him. "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/372) and "Masa'id al-Nazar" (1/135). He mentioned it as his own in his Tafsir (1/277), in "Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah" (143), in his dictionary "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/362), and in "Masa'id al-Nazar" (1/135). Attributed to him in Kashf al-Zunun (1/156), Mu'jam al-Musannifin (3/278), Nazm al-Aqyan (24), and Hadiyat al-Arifin (6/22). There is a copy of "An-Nukat" in the "Zahiriyah" library in Damascus read to the author

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: (Iraqi Journal Al-Mawrid: p. 299 Issue 2 Vol 6), a copy in Feyzullah Efendi in the National Library in Istanbul under number (252) in three hundred seventy-five folios (Ibid: p. 332 - Issue 2 - Vol 7), another in the Iraqi Museum in Baghdad (Ibid: p. 184 - Issue 1 - Vol 4), another in "Atif Efendi" library in Turkey (Nawadir al-Makhtutat by Al-Jaza'iri: Vol 2 p. 58), and another in "Qadi al-Askar" library in Turkey (Ibid: 2/85) (1). ***** {Washi al-Harir fi Ikhtisar "Ibn Jarir"} He authored it in the year eight hundred thirty-five (835). He mentioned it as his own in his dictionary "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/354). Works by others wrongly attributed to him... Some books were attributed to "Al-Biqa'i" which, upon verification, are not his, among them: The book "Al-Asl al-Asil fi Tahrim an-Naql min at-Tawrah wa al-Injil": The author of "Mu'jam al-Mu'allifin" (1/71) attributed it to him, and this is incorrect, for "Al-Biqa'i" is one who believes in the permissibility of such quotation, practiced it, and did it extensively in his Tafsir. He authored a book establishing the permissibility of this quotation named "Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah". We have previously clarified this book and the book "Al-Asl al-Asil" by his peer "Al-Sakhawi", who contradicts Al-Biqa'i's book: "Al-Aqwal al-Qawimah". "Al-Sakhawi" himself stated that in: "Al-Daw' al-Lami'" (1/106). 00000 Al-Qawl al-Ma'luf fi ar-Radd ala Munkir al-Ma'ruf.
