book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The author of "Mu'jam al-Mu'allifin" (1/71) attributed it to Al-Biqa'i. The book belongs to Al-Sakhawi as well, refuting Al-Biqa'i's book "Al-Qawl al-Ma'ruf" mentioned previously. "Al-Sakhawi" attributed the book "Al-Qawl al-Ma'luf" to himself in his dictionary "Al-Daw'" (1/106). It is attributed to Al-Sakhawi in Kashf al-Zunun (1/107) and "Shadharat al-Dhahab" (8/16). *** Book "Safwat as-Safwah" attributed to him by Dr. "Muhammad Buhairi" in his doctoral dissertation (PhD) in Holy Quran Sciences deposited in the library of "Faculty of Theology - Al-Azhar Al-Sharif University in Cairo", stating that the book is mentioned for Al-Biqa'i in his Tafsir Nazm al-Durar (Vol 3 Folio 325) from the manuscript copy number (213 - Tafsir - Egyptian National Library), which is the same copy I used as a source in preparing my doctoral dissertation. What Dr. "Buhairi" mentioned is inaccurate; what is mentioned is a discussion about the conversion of our master "Umar bin Al-Khattab" three days after our master "Hamzah", may Allah be pleased with them both. Al-Biqa'i says: "As I clarified in the footnote of Al-Aqa'id from Fawa'id al-Razi and Safwat as-Safwah 'by Ibn al-Jawzi'." This is decisive that what belongs to Al-Biqa'i is his footnote on "Al-Sa'd's" explanation of Al-Aqa'id Al-Nasafiyyah. We have previously discussed this footnote. As for the book "Al-Fawa'id" and the book "Safwat as-Safwah", they are not his; the first is by Al-Razi, and the other by Ibn al-Jawzi, and he explicitly stated that. **** Arrangement of letters of the book "Al-Ayn" by Al-Khalil, Arrangement of letters of "Al-Muhkam" by Ibn Sidah, Arrangement of letters of "Al-Tahdhib" by Al-Azhari, Arrangement of "Mawad Abi al-Baha'". These four were attributed by Dr. "Buhairi" to Al-Biqa'i, saying they are mentioned for him in "Unwan al-Zaman" (1/154), manuscript number (1001) Egyptian National Library. This is also inaccurate; these are not books by Al-Biqa'i, but rather poetic verses in which he arranged the chapters and sections of each book to facilitate memorization. He arranged the book "Al-Ayn" in two lines of poetry. Such a thing is neither a book nor a treatise. ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: That is a summary of what Al-Biqa'i left of scientific works. They are, as you see, diverse and numerous works signaling the breadth of his horizons of knowledge, and that he lived the life of his era, interacting with the events of his time and being active in them, undertaking the call (Da'wah), enjoining good and forbidding evil, and confronting those who strive in the land with what does not please Allah, Mighty and Exalted. If we look at the heritage he left us, we find that it exceeded sixty books, and that several sciences dominated his authorship: First: Tafsir and Sciences of the Holy Qur'an. Second: Hadith and Sciences of the Sunnah. Third: Creed, Theology, and Logic. Fourth: Science of History and Biographies. Fifth: Science of Jurisprudence and its Principles. Sixth: Language and its Sciences. These sciences and fields of knowledge formed his scientific personality, but the interpretation of the Holy Qur'an was the science that raised his mention among the scholars of the Ummah, and kept him in our ears, minds, and hearts.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Chapter Two: His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Holy Qur'an. Introduction to the Methodology. Al-Biqa'i established his contemplation of the Holy Qur'anic statement on the basis that all its words, sentences, verses, passages, and surahs are linked to one another with a semantic and rhetorical connection. Every element of it - if the expression is permitted, and I fear it may not be - holds the belt of what is in front of it. And that every Surah has a great universal objective dominating all its parts; it is to it like the spirit to the body in the world of creation, while the Holy Qur'an is from the world of command. This is but an approximation of what is from the world of command using something from the world of creation, called for by my rhetorical inability to fulfill the saying regarding the Holy Qur'an as befits it. Otherwise, most of our rhetorical terms that we chew in tasting our human statement hardly befit the speech regarding contemplating the Holy Qur'anic statement. This implies with a dazzling, compelling implication - about which one who advises himself and submits to the principles of healthy rational observation free from sterile argumentation would not hesitate - that the miraculous rhetoric of the Holy Qur'an silencing all worlds is not in some of what was revealed but in all of what was revealed. There is not the slightest hesitation in this for one in whose heart it is established that the Holy Qur'an is from Allah, Glory be to Him and Exalted, alone. If this is correct - and it will only be correct and eloquent - then what was revealed is not the Qur'anic meaning alone, nor the order of the sentence or verse alone, but all of this was revealed, and the position of every word in its sentence, every sentence in its verse, every verse in its passage, every passage in its Surah, and every Surah within the total context of the Holy Qur'an. Thus, the position where the word stands and what is above it up to the Surah is from what was revealed. So there must be, in the position where the word, sentence, verse, passage, and Surah were placed, a miraculous rhetoric which is the sign of the Muhammadan Prophethood, immortal as long as life remains on this earth.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This necessitates with an urgent, binding requirement that the contemplation of the Holy Qur'an, which is an obligation, be based on the rhetoric of all that was revealed, including the location of words, sentences, verses, passages, and Surahs. Therefore, Al-Biqa'i believes that it is obligatory to contemplate what can be called in human expression the Rhetorical Unity of the text built upon the Unity of its Universal Objective and the Unity of the Significance (Maghza) it aims for. The word "Significance" (Maghza) is one of the glorious words in this context, revealing the great effort of the human clarifier in high expression in his striving to reach his goal, standing like a ghazi (conqueror) with the armies of his words, structure, and tone, captivating the hearts of the receivers, capturing them with the ammunition of enchanting words he possesses, and establishing in the tent of hearts the hidden meanings which are his immortal rhetorical existence, as his physical existence perishes after a while and he remains as a rhetorical existence as long as life remains. The important thing is that the Holy Qur'an as a whole comes to a great end; its words, verses, passages, and Surahs came proportionate and brotherly to reach that end and that significance, and to convey to the heart free from arrogance the meanings of guidance to the Straight Path leading to the pleasure of the Speaker of this Noble Book - Majestic is His Glory. Al-Biqa'i, in his contemplation of the Holy Qur'anic statement, made the pivot of his contemplation its miraculousness existing in every sentence of its sentences, verse of its verses, passage of its passages, and Surah of its Surahs. That is the proportion (Tanasub) of the meanings of its statement and structures. That miraculousness is the spirit flowing in all the numerous, extensive faces of Qur'anic inimitability which are endless and encompassed by none, for it is one of the blessings of Allah Almighty that cannot be counted. This tempts us to seek to briefly explain the concept of Qur'anic Proportion in meaning and structure according to Al-Biqa'i, and its levels and fields, then we clarify the features of his methodology in contemplating the traits of this miraculous proportion.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Qur'anic Proportion according to Al-Biqa'i. The Concept. From what Al-Biqa'i named his interpretation: "Nazm al-Durar fi Tanasub al-Ayat wa al-Suwar" (Stringing of Pearls in the Proportion of Verses and Surahs). It is a naming he intended deliberately, for one of his principles that he adopts is the relationship of the name to the named. He considered naming as part of the brilliant opening indicating what is hidden in the named. We will look into this principle of his in its appropriate place, God willing. You see he made his work a "Stringing of Pearls" on the subject of "Proportion of Verses and Surahs". Perhaps he is looking at the relationships of agreement and divergence between Order (Nazm) and Proportion (Tanasub), for every proportion is an order, but not every order is a proportion. In Proportion - as will come God willing - there is what is not in Order: "Proportion" (Tanasub) comes from three roots: "N / S / B" revolving around the meaning: "connection of a thing to a thing" as "Ibn Faris" says in "Maqayis al-Lughah". This connection is an essential connection; it is based on internal relationships running in the essence of the proportioned items, and regulating their external aspects. This is what you see in the human world: the relationship of lineage among them is an essential relationship running in their joints, shaping their moral and physical traits, and they are eternal relationships. The world of rhetoric is from the world of humanity; the word in it is like the individual in the world of humanity. These two worlds: the Rhetorical and the Human, proceed on a similar path in many of their conditions. This term: "Proportion" (Tanasub) has an indication of its meaning different from the indication of "Order" (Nazm) of its meaning adopted by "Abd al-Qahir al-Jurjani" for his theory. The indication of the term Nazm on its meaning requires explanation with a precaution against including what is not intended. Hence, you find Imam "Abd al-Qahir" saying: "Among what must be mastered... is the difference between our saying: ordered letters and ordered words. For the 'ordering of letters' is their succession in pronunciation, and their ordering is not due to a meaning, nor does their orderer follow in that a drawing from the mind to pursue in his ordering of them what he pursued. If the establisher of language had said 'Rabad' instead of 'Darab' (he struck), there would be nothing in that leading to corruption.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: As for 'ordering of words', the matter is not so; because you follow in ordering them the traces of meanings in the soul. So it is an order in which the condition of the ordered parts with each other is considered, and it is not the 'Order' whose meaning is joining a thing however it came and happened..." (1). "Proportion" (Tanasub) does not need its speaker to take precaution likewise unless he places the word out of its place, and does not notice the germ of its derivative meaning signaling that it is an internal relationship running in things like the spirit in the body, possessing external effects accompanying it, subject to its authority. So between the verses of the Holy Qur'an, its rhetorical sentences, passages, and Surahs, there are spiritual relationships, with a deep lineage between them. It is as if in its appearance and perception, it is like the relationships of the sons of Adam to each other: "All of you are from Adam," as the purified Prophetic word guided, even if that lineage in its attachment and effects is greater and more majestic than what is between the sons of Adam. "Al-Biqa'i" makes Qur'anic Proportion a science among the sciences of the Holy Qur'an, revealing its concept by saying: "A science through which the reasons for the arrangement of the parts of the Qur'an are known, and it is the secret of rhetoric because it leads to achieving the conformity of speech to what the situation requires" (2). When using the term "Science", he proceeds from its concept in Arabic terminology, indicating "realizing principles and rules based on evidence, and the possibility of recalling them whenever desired." Through this, the student stands in a position of understanding and knowledge of the causes requiring the placement of every word and what is more than it in the appropriate location, and in the suitable form. You notice that "Al-Biqa'i" has defined this science by its effect, not its reality and essence, so he said: A science through which is known. By this, he reveals to us the effect of this science on one who encompasses or realizes it. By realizing its principles, we stand upon what required the parts of the Holy Qur'an - the word and what is above it - to be placed in their rank in which they were placed.
foot_note:
1. (1) – Dala'il al-I'jaz by Abd al-Qahir: p. 49 – Ed. Shakir – Printed: Al-Madani – Publisher: Al-Khanji 
2. – Nazm al-Durar: 1/6, and Masa'id al-Nazar: 1/124

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This also achieves: "Insight into the rank that the part deserves due to its connection to what is behind it and in front of it, which is like the bond of lineage" (1). Insight into Rank is above Insight into Order: In "Arrangement" (Tartib), the ranks of things and their measures are observed, so nothing is placed except in the rank it deserves. As for Order (Nazm), its origin is joining things to one another without restriction by observing the ranks of these things and their stations. Looking at the saying of "Abd al-Qahir" increases your insight into this: "And I found the reliance to be that there is here (Order and Arrangement / Compilation and Composition) and (Drafting and Portrayal / Weaving and Adornment)" (2). The Imam arranged these eight in this place in a wondrous sequence indicating their escalation. The beginning of the stages of "Building" is "Order", and its end is "Composition". The beginning of the stages of Form (Portrayal) is "Drafting", and its end is "Adornment". The context is not for elaborating on the statement of "Abd al-Qahir", but I wanted to indicate that Arrangement is a stage higher than the stage of "Order" in building meanings, and Order is the foundation of them all. Perhaps that is what made "Abd al-Qahir" apply it to all stations of relationships between words, for there is no stage except that Order exists in it. If "Al-Biqa'i's" expression here indicates that he sees the science of Proportion restricted to explaining the Rank between parts of speech, and Rank is one of the conditions of speech, implying a shortcoming in his stance, then the matter becomes more liberated by his saying about his work in explaining the Proportion between sentences and verses: That he "prepares for every sentence a cradle indicating the condition that required its placement, and necessitated its arrangement on what preceded it of its form or what necessitated its emphasis or stripping and restriction, and the like of the arts of speech and styles of the system" (3).

2. – Dala'il al-I'jaz by Abd al-Qahir: p 34 
3. – Masa'id al-Nazar by Al-Biqa'i: Vol 1 p 102

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It shows that the science of Proportion covers all compositional and ordinal rhetorical states of the parts and elements of speech regarding their varying sizes. Perhaps when he limited himself to the aspect of Arrangement in his definition of "Science of Proportion", he was looking at his saying afterwards: "It is the secret of rhetoric; because it leads to the conformity of speech to what the situation requires." Since the customary practice in achieving conformity is looking at the composition of sentences more than looking at the arrangement between passages and sections. Perhaps he wanted by what he did to draw insights to the status of "Arrangement" between passages and sections in the "Science of Qur'anic Proportion" and that it is not less in status in the rhetorical miraculousness of the Holy Qur'an than Composition in the field of the sentence. Perhaps he also indicates by restricting to the declaration of Arrangement in the definition to the higher level, because the "Proportion" which is the secret of the Qur'anic miracle depends on two types of systems for him, the second of which has what the first does not. *** Levels of Proportion. Qur'anic Proportion according to him consists of two types of systems, one higher than the other: {First: Compositional Order (Nazm Tarkibi)}: It is for him: "The ordering of every sentence independently according to composition" (2). This system covers every rhetorical aspect within the framework of the Qur'anic sentence, whether related to its two pillars or the attachments, even if numerous, and whether the sentence is minor or major extended comprising a collection of sentences and verses; indeed, the Qur'anic Surah might be one sentence.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Among those aspects is the arrangement between the locations of elements of a single sentence. For him, it is not considered arrangement but enters into Compositional Order. Arrangement for him does not occur in the construction of the sentence, even if the vocabulary extends. For him, vocabulary is not arranged but composed, to form a single sentence which is then arranged upon another. So everything that deals with the order of the sentence, even if extended, is for him composition. When you look at {Ayat al-Kursi}: the master of verses of the Holy Qur'an, you see that its order is a compositional order, not an ordinal one, because it is almost one rhetorical sentence, even if composed of ten consecutive grammatical sentences as follows: {Allah} - {there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence} - {Neither drowsiness overtakes Him nor sleep} - {To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth} - {Who is it that can intercede with Him except by His permission} - {He knows what is [presently] before them and what will be after them} - {and they encompass not a thing of His knowledge except for what He wills} - {His Kursi extends over the heavens and the earth} - {and their preservation tires Him not} - {And He is the Most High, the Most Great} (Al-Baqarah: 255). The name of Majesty for him is a subject whose predicate is deleted, understood from the question extracted from the previous verses, which he estimated as: "To whom does sovereignty belong today?", so the answer comes (Allah). The sentences coming after are explanation and detail, so the connections between them are compositional relationships, not ordinal relationships between rhetorical sentences. Most of what the "Science of Meanings" (Ma'ani) deals with regarding the conditions of the subject and predicate and their attachments, and what the "Science of Clarification" (Bayan) and "Science of Embellishment" (Badi') deal with, most of this is from the Compositional Order according to "Al-Biqa'i". Status of Compositional Order: .

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is for him a system "easy to access, easy to taste, for everyone who hears the Qur'an, whether intelligent or unintelligent [sic!!], shakes for its meanings, and acquires upon hearing it an awe with vigor, and a fear with expansion that does not occur when hearing other than it. And every time he looks closely at the meaning, the location of the miracle becomes greater for him." Many people, in the company of recalling the rules of the science of Arabic rhetoric which rhetoricians cared for in editing and application, feel within themselves the ability to speak about Compositional Order in sentence construction, so they think they have sailed into the dictionary of the rhetorical miraculousness of the Holy Qur'an, while they have not yet dipped the sole of their foot in the shore of the ocean with crashing waves. It can be said that "Al-Biqa'i" leaving the declaration of this Compositional Order in the definition of "Science of Proportion" - despite its importance to him - is a type of indicating the value of this system compared to the value of Ordinal Order for him, and this is a type of his method in evaluation and expressing it. {The Other: Ordinal Order (Nazm Tartibi)}: It is for him: "The ordering of every sentence with its sister with regard to arrangement." It is a system that does not deal with rhetorical characteristics except the relationships of sentences to one another, and among that is what rhetoricians call "Disjunction and Conjunction" (Fasl and Wasl), and relationships of passages and Surahs to one another. These are relationships that look at the stations of sentences, passages, and Surahs relative to each other. From the relationships of stations, the escalation of the statement embracing the escalation of meanings is achieved. This system is the main pillar of Proportion for "Al-Biqa'i", and its task is building the product of Compositional Order into an integrated, brotherly, harmonious structure so that every element of this integrated structure holds the belt of some of it. Holding the belt is not of the type of partial linking between elements of the statement, but of the type of essential attachment between sentences, passages, and Surahs in the entire Holy Qur'an. *** He holds that the Holy Qur'an is miraculous in all its rhetorical components:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is miraculous in the selection of its vocabulary, in the construction of its sentences, in the construction of its verses, passages, and Surahs, with no difference in that between one thing and another, and in all its semantic contents: it is miraculous in meaning and structure. He says: "As for the side of vocabulary, it is due to them being the ultimate in majesty of words, elegance of letters, and gathering of meanings, which benefits that no other word can take the place of a word from it at all. As for the side of composition, it is due to every word of it being more rightful in its place such that if anything of it were advanced or delayed, the intended meaning in that context would be disturbed according to that station. As for the side of arrangement in sentences, verses, and stories in beginnings and ends, it is because the likeness of the composition of words: every sentence is organized with what precedes it like the organization of a unique pearl in a tightly strung necklace; because it is either a cause for what followed it, or a proof, or complementary in a face of the faces superior in a manner forbidden to approach, majestic in veil; to be sweeter in his mouth, and clearer after his taste in his ordering and all his knowledge" (1). So his school does not stop him at the building of a sentence from words, nor the building of a verse from sentences, even if the verse reaches a great length, but goes beyond it to the building of the passage from verses, the building of the Surah from passages, and the building of the entire Holy Qur'an from Surahs. The smallest unit of Ordinal Order which is the spirit of the statement for him is the complete sentence, and the largest unit is the Qur'anic Surah. The units in the Productive Compositional Order, the sentence, transform in their relationship to each other, like the units of building the word which are letters and vowels in building each other. It is clear that any change occurring to any unit (letter or vowel) in the building of the word affects the indication of the word, and its semantic capacity, a clear effect for some people, and hidden for others, but it is an existing effect differing in appearance and concealment relatively due to matters returning to the faculties of the receivers.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The same applies to the construction of the sentence: any change occurring to any unit of it (the word) affects the indication of the sentence, and its semantic capacity, a clear or hidden effect, according to the capabilities of the receivers. The matter is similar in the units forming the construction of the verse, the passage, and the Surah, for what affects the small affects what is larger than it. In every unit formed from smaller units, there is a spirit dominating it. This spirit emanates from the relationships of the components to each other, and in the receiver's possession of awareness of this dominating spirit is what helps him to perfect understanding and improve contemplation. From here "Al-Biqa'i" goes to say that in every Surah there is a spirit dominating its statement, called: (The Greatest Objective). He says: "Every Surah has one objective around which its beginning and end revolve, and it is evidenced within it" (1). This universal Greatest Objective, knowing it benefits knowing the objective of all parts of the Surah (2). The science of "Qur'anic Proportion" for him "proficiency in it depends on knowing the objective of the Surah sought in it (3)". And due to the difference of objectives of Surahs, the orders of stories and their words change according to the style useful for indicating that objective (4). He also says: "Through it, the secrets of repeated stories become clear, and that every Surah in which a story is repeated, is for a meaning claimed in that Surah evidenced by that story other than the meaning for which it was driven in the previous Surah. From here the words differed according to those purposes, and the orders changed by delaying, advancing, brevity, and elongation, while nothing of that contradicts the original meaning by which the story was formed" (5). And he says: "Whoever realizes the objective of it knows the proportion of its verses, stories, and all its parts" (6).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: I have elaborated in quoting him, firstly for its importance, and to let you stand on the reality of his school and its pillar in his own language, and we will have a pause of analysis and evaluation for some of that. The important thing is that defining this universal Greatest Objective does not come haphazardly, nor does a person possess it from hasty readings of the Qur'anic Surah, but he does not possess its major features except after living with the Surah, and a profound striving to reside in it with his mind, heart, and spirit until it transforms into part of his internal existence or until it stands within him. The contemplator remains moving between contemplating the part and contemplating the whole, living in a circular oscillating movement, trying to interpret the Surah and contemplate it. "Al-Biqa'i" used to rotate in his contemplation analyzing words, sentences, verses, and passages in light of the major features of the Surah's Greatest Objective, until he ends up defining the precise features of that objective, then returns to contemplating the sentences, verses, and passages deeper than before in light of this precise definition of the precise features of the objective. We see "Al-Biqa'i" for example modifying his method and plan in contemplation when he advances in it. When he reaches Surah "Saba", he returns to what he previously did from the beginning of Surah "Al-Fatihah" until Surah "Saba" and re-examines it. Thus he establishes himself in a circular oscillating movement between the universal objective and the elements within the framework of the Qur'anic Surah, then in the entire Holy Qur'an, due to the vastness of the field of Proportion. If the two pillars of "Proportion" for him are "Compositional Order" and "Ordinal Order", and each of them depends on the other as you see in his saying: "The intended by Arrangement are meanings majestic in description, wondrous in construction, high in matter, great in value, distant from the meanings of speech although they are taken from it." If this is so, then "Al-Biqa'i" goes to say that "Ordinal Order" requires its contemplator to possess rhetorical insight (Firasah) in his contemplation, because it is extremely hidden.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "So if the contemplator wants to cross from 'Compositional Order' to contemplating the connection of sentences or verses... with what came after, the face of that is hidden from him, and he sees that the sentences have divergent purposes and distant objectives, so he thinks they are dissonant. Thus he gets from constriction and distress multiples of what he got from hearing of shaking and expansion. Perhaps that makes him doubt and shakes his faith, and displaces his certainty, and perhaps that stops many of the opponents from entering this religion" (1). Let us overlook somewhat Al-Biqa'i's exaggeration regarding the effect of ignorance of some stations of "Ordinal Order" to conclude that "Ordinal Order" which represents the spirit of speech for him derives its high effect and difficulty of contemplation and perception from its concealment, comprehensiveness, and dominance over every element such that the contemplator requires a breadth of horizon, depth of understanding, insight, ability for faithful storage of rhetorical subtleties, and precise tracking of every partial movement, monitoring it with penetrating insight; to obtain the spirit holding every small, large, and stray matter after it surrendered its leadership to him. That is a difficult matter to practice, and hence it was exciting for pleasure and enjoyment in us. ***** He adopts a methodology in his contemplation of the miraculous Qur'anic proportion. This methodology has universal features; I see a need to explain some of them, and my explanation of some of these features will not fulfill the right of revealing and explaining much of what exists in Al-Biqa'i's interpretation. *** If what passed was an explanation of the concept of Proportion for Al-Biqa'i, its levels, and fields in which it is realized, then Al-Biqa'i adopts this as a basis for the methodology of interpreting the rhetoric of the miraculous Qur'anic statement with its hidden contents and components: meaning and structure. This methodology has numerous traits and features; I preferred to summarize the speech on the most important of them, and to follow every feature with some of his interpretation so that what my explanation could not clarify becomes clear from it. These features are of two types: {The First Type}:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Features of his methodology in interpreting the proportion of the arrangement of Qur'anic Surahs as they are in the recitation sequence, and as the Ummah has it established between the two covers of the Mushaf. For every Surah is revealed in its wise position which has no other due to what its greatest objective required and what universal and partial meanings of guidance descended from it, realizing for the Surah its escalation in its arrangement and the generation of its objectives and meanings. This type is seen in the first four features, and I made them the First Chapter of this section. The attention of many exegetes to this type is little compared to its status in the rhetorical miraculousness of the Holy Qur'an, and its status in jurisprudence and understanding. Al-Biqa'i's attention to this type is distinct from the attention of his peers and teachers, which gives his interpretation (Nazm al-Durar) a place where you can be certain that no other rivals him. His methodology in contemplating this type is distinct from the methodology of his predecessors and successors who spoke about the occasions of Surahs. The coming papers will reveal to you - God willing - some of the features of this distinction in Al-Biqa'i's methodology in his interpreting the rhetoric of the Holy Qur'an in the proportion of its Surahs. {The Other Type}: Features of interpreting the construction of the Qur'anic Surah, the escalation of its universal and partial meanings, and their generation from a universal greatest objective. This you see in the rest of the features I summarized the speech on, and I made it the Second Chapter of this section. This type is the combiner of the two types of Order for Al-Biqa'i: Compositional Order and Ordinal Order. If the paths of Compositional Order are numerous and hardly encompassed as you see in Arabic rhetoric sciences, then the paths of Ordinal Order are more burdensome on the traveler in understanding and contemplation, and simpler in field and further in range, which necessitates upon the one undertaking to understand them to take provision, and the best provision is piety (Taqwa) and perfecting the work.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Chapter One: Methodology of Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'anic Text (Proportion of Surahs). The First Feature: Clarifying the Great Objective and Main Significance of the Holy Qur'an. Every book of value in human expression has a goal to which the statement is driven and a greatest objective aimed at. The most deserving of books for that is what is a statement from Allah Almighty to His servants; rather, its favor in this over servants' books is like the favor of Allah Almighty over His servants. The most deserving of Allah's books entirely for this is His Noble Book revealed to His servant, Prophet, and Messenger Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. It is the Seal Book revealed to the Seal Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, to the best nation brought out for people. It is the Book whose statement He made a miracle of the One who revealed it, while no book before it had its statement made a miracle of the One who revealed it. So it was worthy that everything in it be of the miraculousness that silences all worlds. "Al-Biqa'i" explains in his interpretation of Surah "Al-Fatihah" and his clarification of its greatest objective: "That the purpose of sending Messengers and revealing Books is establishing laws, and the purpose of establishing laws is gathering creation on the Truth, and the purpose of gathering them is introducing them to the King and what pleases Him. This is the objective of the Qur'an, which 'Al-Fatihah' organized by the Primary Intent, and that will only be by what was mentioned in knowledge and action" (1). He affirms something like this in numerous places of his interpretation where he explains the Greatest Objective of revealing the Holy Qur'an.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The truth is that the Holy Qur'an itself did not leave us to strive in defining its Greatest Objective through deduction, so we would vary in defining it. Rather, it decided that for us in many verses. For the Holy Qur'an has a speech about itself unlike the speech of anyone in the worlds. Whoever wants to know the reality of the Holy Qur'an, its message, status, and virtue, has only to gather in his hearing, sight, and heart the verses that speak about the Holy Qur'an, and arrange them recalling their contexts in which they stand in their Surahs. For in this is a revelation. The best speech about the Holy Qur'an is the speech of the Glorious Qur'an itself, then after it the speech of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace. It is beautiful for someone to intend to gather the two speeches: the speech of the Holy Qur'an and the Sunnah about the Great Qur'an in a vessel of analytical interpretive research. From the mercy of Allah, Majestic is His Glory, or His Rahmaniyyah (attribute of being All-Merciful), is that if He opens the Surah (Mother of the Book: Al-Fatihah) by speaking about Himself announcing His deserving of Praise, and teaching His servants how to praise Him, highlighting for them five of His Beautiful Names: the Name of the Essence and four attributes of His High Perfection: Allah - Lord of the Worlds, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, Master of the Day of Judgment; then He, Majestic is His Glory, opens the first detailing of {The Mother of the Book} with Surah {Al-Baqarah} initiating His statement by speaking about the Holy Qur'an: {That is the Book, no doubt in it, a guidance for the pious} (Al-Baqarah: 1-2). And if He, Majestic is His Glory, arranged His Name and Beautiful Attributes in a sequence indicating the greatness of their link and attachment, dispensing with a linguistic connector (conjunction), so they came consecutive without conjunction (Allah Lord of the Worlds the Most Gracious the Most Merciful Master of the Day of Judgment), then He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, also arranged His speech about the Great Qur'an in a sequence where descriptions followed one another in a manner having no place for a conjunction. They are descriptions where the second descends from the first, and the third from the second.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The Truth, Mighty and Majestic, announced in the opening of the detailed statement summarized in Surah Al-Fatihah that the Qur'an is the Book of far-reaching status and high destiny which no one can aspire to catch up with. It is the Standing Witness that does not absent itself, indicated by choosing the demonstrative for the distant (That - Dhalika). As if in this is an indication to the Straight Path requested to be guided to in Surah Al-Fatihah {Guide us to the Straight Path}, so He said that Straight Path you request guidance to is (The Book). And by what the definition with Lam (Al-Kitab) indicated and choosing the word (Kitab) indicating Collection on one hand and Decree, Inevitability, and Documentation on the other. It is the Comprehensive, Documented, Inevitable Statement whose settled matters no servant can undo. These are meanings hidden in choosing the word (Kitab) without mentioning Dhikr or Qur'an in this context, so He did not say 'That Dhikr' or 'That Qur'an'. He announced that that Book of far status and high destiny is also far removed from being a place for doubt or deserving that a doubter doubts in it whose doubt stems from something in what he doubts. As for those who doubt in what has nothing tempting to doubt, but rather project the doubt fermenting in their chests onto what is the High One transcending such things, no attention is paid to the likes of them. As if in this is guidance and instruction to the Ummah not to pay attention to all that tongues throw about of sayings, but upon it is to verify and validate. This which His saying (No doubt) conveyed implies and alludes to what the statement came explicitly in the saying of Allah Almighty: {O you who have believed, if there comes to you a disobedient one with information, investigate, lest you harm a people out of ignorance and become, over what you have done, regretful} (Al-Hujurat: 6).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: So His saying (No doubt in it) is not a negation of doubt [existence], but a negation of what a calculator might calculate to be something rightful to doubt. This is the utmost in negation. In this is glad tidings for everyone who wanted to take an objective scientific stance in his search for truth that he has only to adhere to the established scientific principles in searching for truth and researching it. Let him look at what he sees? And what does he end up with? He will not end up except at the reality of realities: that this [Book] revealed to the servant of Allah and His Messenger Muhammad, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, is nothing but the Book of High Destiny like which there is no book, and that it is transcendant above having in it what is valid to be a place for doubt. In this is also instruction to the Ummah not to fear from a striver striving towards what they call in human cultures "Critical Studies" based on the methodology of doubting all heritage and Salafi postulates. For such studies, if they adhered to scientific objectivity and adhered to principles of observation and scientific verification, the matter would not end except in submission and announcement that the Holy Qur'an is indeed the Perfect Book that none says except the Lord of the Worlds, Glory be to Him and Exalted. All there is to it is that those striving for such studies commit to being characterized by the morals of objective scholars. The Truth, Mighty and Majestic, announced after this that that Book, High, Transcendant above being a place for a doubter's doubt that anyone pays attention to, is indeed a book sent down to be a guidance for the pious. Everything that others were afflicted with - mentioned at the head of the meaning of Surah Al-Fatihah: the Maghdub 'alayhim (those who earned anger) and the Dallin (the astray) - the methodology of these two groups in searching for the Straight Path is the methodology worthy of being avoided (Taqwa), turning away from, and fleeing from. So whoever takes himself to not follow their path in searching for it, he is by this piety finding in the Holy Qur'an his guidance to what he strives for and searches for.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: By this, the Truth, the Majestic, makes clear to us that the Greatest Objective of the Holy Qur'an is guiding servants to the Straight Path to knowing their Lord and Creator and what He is pleased with from them, so they adopt it, and what He is not pleased with from them, so they avoid it. The important thing is that in clarifying this objective, achieving it, defining it, and designating it is a standard for everyone who strived to interpret a word, sentence, verse, passage, or Surah from the Holy Qur'an: that in this interpretation of his, there should be what manifests the methodology of the Holy Qur'an in guiding to the Straight Path. Whatever interpretation does not achieve that is not from the Ijtihad in deducing the Holy Qur'anic meaning a scientific deduction free from impurities of negligence, falsehood, error, and deception. If the Glorious Qur'an has a Greatest Objective from which meanings generate, then Allah Almighty, from the overflow of His mercy, has made the Great Qur'an into Surahs varying in the number of their verses and length, and made every Surah from verses, and made the verses sentences. So He, Majestic is His Glory, perfected it then detailed it. That is a face of the faces of the Qur'anic meaning in His saying, Glory be to Him and Exalted, in the opening of the recitation of Surah "Hud": {Alif, Lam, Ra. A Book whose verses are perfected, then detailed from One who is Wise, Acquainted} (Hud: 1). Hence, we see the Qur'anic statement detailed into Surahs, Surahs into passages (chapters), passages into verses, and verses - mostly - into sentences. The relationships between these are relationships of Proportion and Procreation (Generation) with all that these two words carry: proportion and procreation of precise and majestic meaning.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The human race in the world of creation is composed of tribes and peoples. The tribe is composed of bellies (clans), bellies of families, and families of individuals. The individual is composed of coherent organs. This is what Allah Almighty decreed for the human race to be in their proportion and procreation, even if many of them in the movement of their behavior are unlike what Allah Almighty wanted from them by assignment (Taklif). Our view is to what Allah Almighty wanted for them: (His Decree/Qadar) since they are all His slaves ('Abid), not what He wanted from them (His Assignment/Taklif) since few of them are His servants ('Ibad): like the single body, if an organ complains, the rest of the body collapses in sleeplessness and fever. If this is so, can we say as an approximation, not a depiction: That the Surah in the Qur'anic statement is like the Tribe, and every Surah composed of passages is like the Bellies for the Tribe, and every passage composed of verses is like the Families for the Belly, and every verse of sentences is like the Individuals for the Family, and every sentence of words is like the Organs for the Individual in building his body: the station of the word in the sentence is the station of the organ in the individual, the station of the sentence in the verse is the station of the individual in the family, the station of the verse in the passage is the station of the family in the belly, the station of the passage in the Surah is the station of the belly in the tribe, and the station of the Surah in the Qur'an is the station of the tribe in the human race. This is from the world of creation, and the Holy Qur'an is from the world of command {Unquestionably, His is the creation and the command; blessed is Allah, Lord of the worlds} (Al-A'raf: from Verse 54). The human race has a father from whom it procreates and to whom it relates, and the Holy Qur'anic statement has a Greatest Objective from which Qur'anic meanings procreate and to which they relate. It is but an approximation, not a depiction, for how can what is from the world of command be depicted by what is from the world of creation? The Greatest Objective of the Great Qur'an is the basis upon which the norm (Sunnah) of choosing the word in the order of the sentence, the norm of ordering the sentence from chosen words, the norm of ordering the verse from this sentence, the norm of ordering the passage from these verses, and the norm of ordering the Surah from these passages was established.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Then the norm of the system of Surahs and their arrangement. Hence, Al-Biqa'i's care for contemplating the rhetoric of the proportion of the Holy Qur'anic statement was from several faces, the most general being the rhetoric of the arrangement of Surahs and the proportion of their location. It is a great matter upon which the methodology of contemplation and interpretation in Al-Biqa'i's Tafsir stands, and he does not abandon it in any place. We will point to other features descended from this universal feature, all aiming to establish the truth of the proportion of the Holy Qur'an in the arrangement of building its sentences, verses, passages, and Surahs. "Al-Biqa'i" states at the end of his introduction to his Tafsir "that there is no full stop in the Book of Allah, nor at the end of Surah (Say, I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind), rather it is connected, despite being the last of the Qur'an, to Al-Fatihah which is its beginning, like its connection to what is before it, or even stronger" (1). He states when interpreting the saying of Allah, Majestic is His Glory: {And they said, "Our hearts are wrapped." Rather, Allah has cursed them for their disbelief, so little is it that they believe} (Al-Baqarah: 88) following "Al-Haralli" that: "The beginning of this Surah organized the manifestation of the two Satanisms of Jinn and Mankind which the Qur'an concluded with in His saying: 'from the jinn and mankind' (An-Nas: 6) so its two ends connect, making it a seal with no beginning and no end, and Al-Fatihah encompasses it. It is not said: It is its beginning or its end. Therefore, some reciters deemed it necessary to connect so that no end becomes clear for it, as the Arab woman said when asked about her sons: 'They are like the continuous ring; it is not known where its two ends are' (2). This which he takes as a basis for his interpretation decrees that every face of interpretation for the Glorious Qur'anic statement in which the realization of the Greatest Objective of the Glorious Qur'an is not present, and does not proportionate with it, that face of interpretation is not from correctness in anything. This is an objective standard from the interpreted statement itself acting as a resort and reference for what might be disputed in interpretation among groups of scholars. The Second Feature ... Clarifying the Escalation of Objectives of Surahs and their Meanings.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: If Al-Biqa'i holds that the Glorious Qur'anic statement has a Greatest Objective, he is concerned with clarifying the relationships of the objectives of Surahs to each other and the escalation of their meanings descended from that Greatest Objective of the Great Qur'an. So he was concerned with explaining the arrangement of the objective of a Surah upon the objective of the one before it, which means that the connection existing between the Surahs of the Holy Qur'an is not a connection restricted to the proportion of the beginning of the Surah with the conclusion of what is before it; rather, the matter is greater than that. In his explanation of the objective of Surah "Al-Baqarah", he focuses on the meaning which is the basis of meanings descended from the meaning of Al-Fatihah, which is the summary of the meaning of the Great Qur'an: the meaning of Belief in the Unseen. He says: "Its objective is establishing the evidence that the Book is guidance; to be followed in every condition, and the greatest thing it guides to is Belief in the Unseen, and its gathering point is Belief in the Hereafter, and its pivot is Belief in the Resurrection which the story of the Cow expressed, whose pivot is Belief in the Unseen. That is why the Surah was named by it" (1). All verses of Surah "Al-Baqarah" look towards establishing the meaning of Belief in the Unseen in the hearts (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: 1/55 
2. - Its verses vary in the mode of indication to this meaning, in disclosure, understanding, declaration, and allusion. This is a fertile field for rhetorical study using the methodology of "Science of Bayan". If we intended some of this, i.e., clarifying the modes of indication of the verses of Surah Al-Baqarah to this meaning, we would have a majestic overflow of knowledge of the methods of expressing the single meaning with different images in modes of indication to it. Therefore, I claim that sufficiency in studying the science of Bayan in the Holy Qur'an by studying the style of simile, metaphor, synecdoche, and metonymy is a severe shortcoming.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Hence, the first description of the pious in it is the description of Belief in the Unseen (guidance for the pious who believe in the Unseen...). This Belief in the Unseen is the foundation of every righteous, reforming deed, for there is no meaning at all for any righteous deed or belief in a religion if that is not established on the settlement of the meaning of Belief in the Unseen. There is no religion among religions that stands only on what all eyes see, all ears hear, and hands touch... Rather, the foundation of every religion embraced by anyone of the servants, whether that religion is false or true revealed by Divine Revelation from the sky, is Belief in the Unseen; because the foundation of religion is Belief in the existence and oneness of the Worshipped God. The Worshipped God is not fit to be witnessed and tangible, but must be Absolute Unseen, whose existence, oneness, perfection of majesty, beauty, dominance, mercy, etc., are witnessed by eyes [of insight] and insights. Hence, the objective of the first Surah of the detailing of the Mother of the Book (Al-Fatihah): Surah Al-Baqarah, was Guidance to Belief in the Unseen. This you see clearly in naming the Surah the Hump (Sanam), the Peak (Dhirwah), and the Tent (Fustat), for the Tent is a gatherer of what relates to it. If "Al-Biqa'i" comes to explain the Greatest Objective of Surah (Al-Imran), he elaborates the speech in this: he clarifies to us what appeared to him first in its interpretation, then when he reviewed and exaggerated contemplation, the definition of its objective became clear to him in another way. He elaborates the speech, explaining the relationship of the objective of Surah (Al-Imran) to the objective of Surah (Al-Baqarah) and their objective together to the objective of Surah (Al-Fatihah), rather he extends the view further to the objective of Surah (An-Nisa).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says: "The objectives for which this Surah was driven are establishing Oneness (Tawhid) for Allah, Glory be to Him and Exalted, and informing that worldly leadership through wealth and children and other things which the disbelievers preferred over Islam does not avail them anything in this world nor in the Hereafter, and that what is prepared for the pious of Paradise and Good Pleasure is what should be approached and hastened to. And in describing the pious with faith, supplication, patience, truthfulness, devotion, spending, and seeking forgiveness is what many arts of the styles of this Surah incline towards. This is what appeared to me first. Better than it is that we single out the First Intent, which is Tawhid, as the intent in it, for the last two matters return to it. That is because the description of Qayyumiyyah (Self-subsisting/Sustaining) necessitates standing with uprightness (Istiqamah). Standing is over every soul, and uprightness is justice... This aspect is more consistent with the arrangement, because Al-Fatihah, since it was comprehensive of religion in general, what details it came parallel to that. So it started with the Surah of the Book [Al-Baqarah] encompassing the matter of religion, then with the Surah of Tawhid [Al-Imran] which is the secret of the letter 'Al-Hamd', and the first letters of Al-Fatihah, because Tawhid is the matter upon which no building stands except on it. When the path was correct, and the foundation was firm, came the one after it [An-Nisa] calling for the gathering on that. Also, when the matter of the Book was established in Al-Baqarah that it is guidance, and the five pillars of Islam were established by it, this one [Al-Imran] came to establish the Comprehensive Call in His saying, Glory be to Him, (O Mankind, worship your Lord) (Al-Baqarah: 21). So it established Oneness for Allah Almighty by refuting the divinity of other than Him by proving that 'Jesus', peace be upon him, who used to revive the dead, is His servant, so other than him [is servant] by priority. When it was established that all are His servants, Surah 'An-Nisa' called for their turning to Him and gathering upon Him.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Among what indicates that the intent of it [i.e., Al-Imran] is Tawhid is its naming as "Al-Imran", for nothing expressed it in this Surah like what He, Glory be to Him, drove in it of their news containing evidences of the Perfect Power necessitating Tawhid, than which there is no higher degree in faith. It is the Crown which is the tangible property of the King, just as Tawhid is His intellectual property. And Tawhid necessitates the radiance (Zahrah) of the one adorned with it, that is why it was named Az-Zahra' (The Radiant)" (1). This Oneness is the second brick in the foundation of Faith; because if it is established that the God must be Unseen, not viewed or touched, then He must also be One, nothing is like Him. Just as it contradicts the meaning of Divinity for the God to be witnessed, viewed, and tangible, it also contradicts the meaning of Divinity for the God to be not one; because this results in the corruption of the universe and life, a corruption decided by the logic of the sound mind free from error. The connection between Surah "Al-Baqarah" and Surah "Al-Imran" is a great connection; because they stand on one matter which is establishing what is essential in the meaning of Divinity and what must be a great foundation of the foundations of the attributes of the God worshipped by right: to be Unseen not perceived by eyes, and to be One, there is nothing like Him. This is like coupling the specific to the general. This connection is seen clearly in what the Noble Prophetic Sunnah brought regarding the virtue of these two Surahs. "Muslim" narrated in his Sahih in the Book: Prayer of Travelers: Chapter: Virtue of Reading the Qur'an and Surah Al-Baqarah, with his chain from Abu Umamah Al-Bahili, may Allah be pleased with him, that he heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, say: "Read the Qur'an, for it comes on the Day of Resurrection as an intercessor for its companions.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Read the Two Radiant Ones (Az-Zahrawayn): Al-Baqarah and Surah Al-Imran, for they come on the Day of Resurrection as if they are two clouds or two shades or two flocks of birds in ranks, arguing on behalf of their companion. Read Surah Al-Baqarah, for taking it is a blessing, leaving it is regret, and the sorcerers cannot withstand it" (Hadith No: 252/804). This indicates a majestic indication of the proportion, brotherhood, procreation, and harmony between these two Surahs. Al-Biqa'i, as you heard, did not suffice with explaining the connection of the objective of Surah (Al-Imran) to the objective of Surah (Al-Baqarah), but he extends the view to the relationship of the objective of Surah (An-Nisa) to what is before it. In the opening of his interpretation of Surah "An-Nisa", he clarifies what establishes knowledge and confirms that its objective is built upon the objective of "Al-Imran" built upon the objective of Surah "Al-Baqarah", saying: "Its objective: Gathering on the Tawhid to which 'Al-Imran' guided, and the Book to which 'Al-Baqarah' urged; for the sake of the religion which 'Al-Fatihah' gathered, warning against what 'Shas bin Qais' and his peers intended of division" (1). When you look at the rulings and etiquettes that Surah "An-Nisa" established, you see they are rulings and etiquettes realizing for the society adopting them its unity on the basis of religion: "Tawhid". This basis, if the relationships of any society are established upon it such that its movement is linked to the certainty that there is no god for this universe except One God, One Creator, One Owner, One Bestower, One Withholder... you will not see in this society what you see in other societies that do not base their religion on pure Tawhid. Al-Biqa'i's interpretation and clarification of the Greatest Objective of Surah "Al-Ma'idah" comes, and it does not depart from that methodology. He says: "Its objective is fulfilling what the Book guided to, and what the covenant of reason indicated of the Oneness of the Creator and mercy for creation, in gratitude for His blessings and seeking removal of His vengeance" (2). He says in Surah "Al-An'am":

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Its objective: Providing evidence for what the Book called for in the past Surah regarding Tawhid, that He encompasses all perfections of creating, annihilating, power of resurrection, and others." He also says after interpreting the beginning of the Surah: ... "It appeared that the objective of the Surah is providing evidence for what the Book called for - which was clarified to be the Guidance - of Tawhid of Allah Almighty, gathering upon it, and fulfilling His covenants that He Almighty alone is the Creator possessing all perfections of the power of resurrection and others" (1). He thus shows you the existence of the objective of "An-Nisa", "Al-Imran", and "Al-Baqarah" in the objective of Surah "Al-Ma'idah" and the existence of the objective of all those in the objective of Surah "Al-An'am". And when you look at Al-Biqa'i's statement at the beginning of Surah "Al-A'raf", you see him explaining its objective establishing its structure on what the Surahs preceding it established, starting from Surah "Al-Baqarah" and what it stood upon of the call of the Book whose statement opened by pointing to its great value: {That is the Book, no doubt in it, guidance for the pious}, and what Surah "Al-Imran" stood upon of establishing the meaning of Tawhid, and what Surah "An-Nisa" stood upon of establishing the call to gathering on Good, and what Surah "Al-Ma'idah" stood upon of the call to fulfilling contracts, and what Surah "Al-An'am" stood upon of providing evidence for what preceded the establishment of previous Surahs (2). Thus the objectives of Surahs generate from one another, a generation standing on two majestic matters: First: Founding a meaning that was not founded in the one before it. And Second: Confirming what was previously founded. In every confirmation there is a founding from another aspect. Confirmation is not by repetition but by rhetorical variation in portraying meanings. That is because the Holy Qur'an does not proceed on the method of sterile repetition whose result is restating the statement in component and content. It is impossible for an important element of the statement which has a majestic effect in portraying the meaning to repeat.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: That element is the Context in which the repeated recited component stands. If the location of the repeated recited component changes, the tasted content changes. What establishes the hidden meaning in the statement is not only what the tongue recites, but there are other matters no less in status than it, among them the Propositional Context in which that statement stands. That context is protected from copying; it is like the surge of a wave in the context of the water of the teeming ocean, never repeating. Al-Biqa'i looks at the Total Context of the Qur'anic Meaning, seeing that it consists of stations and stages with numerous faces. Among those faces is looking at the statement of Allah Almighty about the Holy Qur'an, its status, and its objective. "Al-Biqa'i" looked into this statement and saw that the detailing of the Mother of the Book started with Al-Baqarah initiating its statement about the Holy Qur'an {That is the Book, no doubt in it, a guidance for the pious}. The one following the opening of this stage was Surah "Al-Imran" and He proved in it that the Holy Qur'an is Truth: {He has sent down upon you the Book in truth, confirming what was before it} (Al-Imran: 3). And that the context extended until the end of Surah "At-Tawbah" which is the last of the (Long Ones) and revealed regarding the Expedition of Hardship: Tabuk, which is about the invasion of the Romans. The recitation ended in it {O you who have believed, fight those adjacent to you of the disbelievers and let them find in you harshness. And know that Allah is with the righteous} until His saying: {But if they turn away, then say, "Sufficient for me is Allah; there is no deity except Him. On Him I have relied, and He is the Lord of the Great Throne"} (At-Tawbah: 123-129). The statement began after this stage with Surah (Yunus) which is the first of the (Hundreds) and initiating its statement also about the Holy Qur'an

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Alif, Lam, Ra. These are the verses of the Wise Book. * Was it a wonder to the people that We revealed to a man from among them, "Warn the people and give good tidings to those who believe that they have a [sure] footing of truth with their Lord"? The disbelievers said, "Indeed, this is an obvious magician."} (Yunus: 1-2). Its Greatest Objective was "Describing the Book as being from Allah Majestic is His Glory due to what it contains of Wisdom..." The one following it was Surah "Hud", its objective "Describing the Book with perfection and detailing in the states of glad tidings and warning"... {Alif, Lam, Ra. A Book whose verses are perfected, then detailed from One who is Wise, Acquainted} (Hud: 1). And that the context extended until the end of Surah "Ar-Rum" revealed regarding the Romans and the victory of the Persians over them and the promise of Allah Almighty of the Romans' victory over them so the believers would rejoice. The recitation ended in this stage with the saying of Allah, Majestic is His Glory: {And We have certainly presented for the people in this Qur'an from every example. But if you bring them a sign, those who disbelieved will surely say, "You are but falsifiers." * Thus does Allah seal the hearts of those who do not know. * So be patient. Indeed, the promise of Allah is truth. And let them not disquiet you who are not certain} (Ar-Rum: 58-60). The statement began after this stage with Surah "Luqman" initiating its statement also about the Holy Qur'an {Alif, Lam, Mim * These are verses of the Wise Book * As guidance and mercy for the doers of good * Who establish prayer and give zakah, and of the Hereafter they are certain * Those are on guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful} (Luqman: 1-5). The one following it was Surah "As-Sajdah" establishing the negation of doubt from the Holy Qur'an and establishing that it is a revelation from the Lord of the Worlds.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Alif, Lam, Mim * The revelation of the Book is no doubt from the Lord of the worlds} (As-Sajdah: 1-2). This stage ends with the end of Surah "Al-Fath" which is the last of the (Hundreds). So the beginning of every stage is a talk about the Holy Qur'an, and the end of every stage is a Surah of Jihad and victory of Truth (At-Tawbah - Ar-Rum - Al-Fath). The Surahs of (Al-Mufassal) come starting with Surah "Al-Hujurat" - according to Al-Biqa'i's school (1) - and the Mufassal's status is the status of the summary of the Qur'an, so they are like the conclusion for the stages of the Total Context of the Holy Qur'anic Meaning. "Al-Biqa'i" says in the opening of his interpretation of the Qur'anic Statement in Surah (Luqman):
foot_note: 1. (1) - It is famous among scholars that Al-Mufassal starts with Surah (Qaf). It is good to mention here Al-Biqa'i's explanation for naming this portion of the Holy Qur'an Al-Mufassal and what is before it Al-Mathani. That is from two aspects: "First: That Al-Mufassal is the first comprehensive title for Surahs regarding reading, and above it are Al-Mathani then Al-Mi'un then Al-Tiwl. So Al-Mathani are second to it in reality, and they are only second to the Mi'un because we found the beginning with the Tiwl from the other end. Second: When they exceeded the Mufassal, the division of the Surah from them was in two Rak'ahs of prayer like reading two Surahs from the Mufassal, so they were Mathani (Repeated/Doubled), for their doubling in the total prayer regarding reading part of them in each of the two Rak'ahs." (Nazm al-Durar: Vol 8 p 357 - 358)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Its objective is proving Wisdom for the Book, necessitating the Wisdom of its Revealer, Glory be to Him, in His sayings and actions. The story of Luqman, by which the Surah is named, is clear evidence for that. As if He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, when He completed what He wanted from the beginning of the Qur'an to the end of 'Bara'ah' which is the Surah of the Roman invasion, and He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, had started the Qur'an after 'Mother of the Qur'an' by negating Doubt from this Book and that it is guidance for the pious and provided evidence for that in the Surahs following it, then He started Surah 'Yunus' after the Surah of the Roman invasion by proving His Wisdom, and followed that with its evidence until He concluded Surah Ar-Rum, He started a new cycle in a more massive way than the first. He described it at the beginning of this one following Ar-Rum with what He described it in 'Yunus' following the Roman invasion, and that description is Wisdom, and added that it is guidance and mercy for the doers of good (Muhsinin), for these are people of Endings, and the pious (Muttaqin) are people of Beginnings. And when He proved in 'Al-Imran' [following Al-Baqarah which is the first of the First Stage] that it was sent down with Truth, He proved in 'As-Sajdah' [following Luqman which is the first of the Third Stage] its revelation and negation of doubt that it is from Him Almighty and proved that it is the Truth. He continued after this in the Surahs analogous mostly to what passed, as known by deepening in remembrance, contemplation, and reflection" (1). And He says at the opening of interpreting Surah (Al-Hujurat): "The sum of its objective is observing the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in etiquette with him; because it is the first of the Mufassal which is the summary of the Holy Qur'an, just as the objective of (Al-Fatihah) which is the first of the Qur'an was observing Allah Almighty. And the second of the Mufassal began with a letter from the disjointed letters, just as the second of what is other than it [Mi'un and Mathani] began with disjointed letters" (2). Likewise, Al-Biqa'i's care for looking into the escalation of the Qur'anic meaning and the escalation of universal objectives becomes clear to you.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The saying of the escalation of objectives of Surahs and their generation from each other is based on the saying that behind the arrangement of the Surahs of the Holy Qur'an is a meaning of the meanings of the rhetorical miraculousness of the Holy Qur'an. This becomes increasingly founded and established in the two features coming after. The Third Feature. Relationship of the opening of every Surah with the conclusion of the one before it. Every Surah has a beginning of recitation and an end of chanting. The station of the beginning in indicating its objective and content, and the station of the end in dedicating its meanings and condensing its contents will become clear to us. "Al-Biqa'i" pays attention to interpreting the relationship of the opening of the Surah to the conclusion of the one before it, just as he paid attention to interpreting the relationship of the objectives of Surahs to each other, so that the Proportion between Surahs has numerous causes and manifests in many appearances. Our saying "opening" of the Surah, or its Fatihah, and "conclusion" of the Surah or its Khatimah does not mean that its opening is disconnected from the one preceding it. The term here does not look at the relationships of the meanings of Surahs, but looks at the matter of recitation and chanting. The important thing is that "Al-Biqa'i" does not restrict his method to linking the first verse of the Surah with the last verse of the one before it only. Rather, the beginning of the Surah for him is its key and the treasure of its objective. Linking its beginning to the end of the one before it, which represents the good conclusion returning to its beginning, is in reality linking an objective to an objective. So his action here is not linking particulars with particulars but linking a universal content of a Surah to a universal content of another preceding it. This is a type of methodological conduct by Al-Biqa'i in establishing the truth he arrived at. He says regarding Surah "Al-Ma'idah" following Surah "An-Nisa": "When He Almighty informed at the end of Surah 'An-Nisa' that the Jews, when they broke the covenants He took from them, He forbade them good things permitted to them from much of the livestock animals indicated by His saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {And to those who are Jews We have prohibited every animal of uncloven hoof; and of the cattle and the sheep We have prohibited to them their fat, except what adheres to their backs or the entrails or what is joined with bone. [By] that We repaid them for their injustice. And indeed, We are truthful} (Al-An'am: 146) (1). And He Almighty continued tearing their veils and exposing their flaws until He concluded with a verse on Inheritance, which He opened its verses by willing (commanding) and concluded them by saying He is All-Encompassing in Knowledge. It suited the opening of this one with the command to the Believers - whom He severely warned against them - to fulfill (contracts) whose basis is the heart which is Unseen. So He said, indicating that the people addressed in the beginning of that one were qualified for the first ages of Faith (2) and described with what they needed. Singling them out indicates that those above them in ages (3) have firmness that suffices them from being loaded with the command, and that is more inciting for him to contemplate and comply (O you who have believed) (Al-Ma'idah: 1) meaning they claimed that with their tongues (fulfill) meaning verify that by fulfilling (the contracts) (4). This is a look at the head of the meaning in Surah "An-Nisa" and how it is like a cradle for what is the origin of the meaning in Surah "Al-Ma'idah". In Surah "An-Nisa" there is preparation by addressing those who were in a degree where they were not qualified for the call by "O you who have believed", as was the opening of "Al-Ma'idah", rather the call to them was "O Mankind", and this is the lowest degree of address, and the most general.
foot_note:
1. (1) - It is higher to mention here the saying of Allah Almighty in Surah An-Nisa: {So for injustice from the Jews, We prohibited for them good things which had been permitted to them...} (160). Perhaps he overlooked it or it was from the copyist. 
2. - He means: Those who believed, for they are the lowest ages of obedience and closeness. 
3. - He means: The Believers, the Pious, and the Doers of Good, for these are ages higher than the age of those who believed. 
4. - Nazm al-Durar: Vol 6 p 2

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And when you look at the call in Surah "An-Nisa", you find it opened with "O Mankind" (v:1), and concluded with it (v:170, 174) and it appeared in its middle (v: 133). The call "O you who have believed" in it was surrounded by this and did not exceed ten times despite the length of Surah "An-Nisa". And Surah "Al-Ma'idah", the call "O Mankind" did not appear in it at all, but the call "O you who have believed" was sixteen times despite being less in number of verses and words than Surah "An-Nisa". He says regarding the suitability of the beginning of "Al-Anfal" to the end of "Al-A'raf": ... "As for the suitability of its beginning to the end of that one, it became clear that the end of 'Al-A'raf' is the end of the story of Moses, peace be upon him, concluding with the story of 'Balaam', and that what is after that are but completions for what preceded indispensable, and completions for completions until the end of that was the praise of those who are qualified for presence with Him Almighty with submission and complete submission. So when they were attributed to that High Presence, that required a question about the condition of those who are with the one addressed [the Prophet], may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace. So it was answered by His saying (They ask you) meaning those with your Lord are the ones who defeated the disbelievers in reality as you knew that... so they are the ones deserving of the spoils, yet they have no attention towards them, but their concern is worship. While those with you, I made them only an apparent instrument, yet they ask (about the spoils) which I entrusted you with by the hands of my soldiers, a question of dispute which one should seek refuge in Allah from - as warned against by the end of Al-A'raf - because that leads to the division of the word and weakness in resisting enemies" (1). You see him not stopping in the link at the last verse of the previous Surah but looking at the concluding passage, so the consideration is not by the last sentence of the Surah but by the sentence which is the mother of the seal, even if numerous sentences came after it.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: You also see him observing the relationship of the subject pronoun in (They ask you) while no reference preceded it by a subject (relative noun) in the last sentence of Surah Al-A'raf (Indeed, those who are near your Lord), and what is between the conditions of those talked about in both regarding contrast, disparity, and difference. And he might extend his contemplation of the relationship of the Surah's opening to a Surah before it, not restricting it to the one immediately preceding it, as you see him acting in Surah "Yunus", saying: "When He presented in the beginning of Al-A'raf the incitement to convey advice via this Book and finished what the context required of warning against the likes of the events of the ancients and the demises of the past peoples, and what followed that of connecting the speech regarding the biography of this Noble Prophet, peace be upon him, with his people in his commands, during it, and its end in Surahs 'Al-Anfal' and 'Bara'ah', and concluded that by stating that the Surahs of the Book increase everyone in what is suitable for him making him ready to accept it and distance him from what is repugnant to him far from accepting its suitability, and that the Messenger, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, by that has contained descriptions, ornaments, and high morals necessitating turning to him and hastening to him, and informing that turning away from him does not harm him at all; because his Lord Almighty suffices him; and because there is nothing like Him, and He is the Owner of the Great Throne. When that was so, He Almighty repeated the speech regarding the matter of the Book with which He opened 'Al-A'raf' and concluded Surah At-Tawbah, and added to it the description of Wisdom, and pointed with the tool of distance to the fact that its rank in it is far to reach, wondrous in example, saying: 'These'... 'are the verses of the Book'... And this is what appeared to me in its joining with what is before it" (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is clear that the care for contemplating and interpreting the relationship of the opening of the Surah to the conclusion of the one before it is like the care for contemplating and interpreting the relationship of the objectives of consecutive Surahs to each other, and like the care for opening the Great Qur'an with Surah "Al-Fatihah".
