1. (1) - Muqaddimatan fi 'Ulum al-Qur'an (Introduction to Kitab al-Mabani) Ed: Arthur Jeffery: p. 40 - Maktabat Al-Khanji. 
2. - Ibid: 41-42.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of the Holy Qur'anic rhetoric is based on the premise that the parts of the Holy Qur'an are proportional in their rhetoric, whether a word, a Surah, or what is between them. Every part stands in its station based on the requirements of the context (Maqam), and that which is advanced is not advanced over the other while its meaning is separated from the meaning of what it was advanced over. Rather, the meanings of guidance in the Holy Qur'an reproduce from one another. You cannot say that such-and-such meaning is a beginning not preceded by meanings upon which it is built; rather, in the proportion and reproduction of its meanings, it is like a continuous ring whose ends are unknown. Therefore, in the introduction to his Tafsir, he declares that "there is no complete stop in the Book of Allah Almighty, nor at the end of Surah {Say, I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind} (Al-Nas); rather, it is connected—despite being the last of the Qur'an—to Al-Fatihah, which is its beginning, like its connection to what is before it, or even stronger" (1). The purpose of detailing the Qur'an into verses and Surahs exists for "Al-Biqa'i" in "that a thing, if it is a genus and types are made for it, and its types contain categories, it is better, more magnificent for its status, and nobler. Especially if the forms follow one another with wondrous organization, and analogues respond to one another with good cohesion, and likenesses embrace in similarity with perfect precision and beauty of rulings. That is also more invigorating for the reader, and greater for him when he takes from it a named portion of numbered verses, or known Surahs, and so on" (2). This detailing into Surahs does not mean, as you heard, that Surah "Al-Nas" is its end where meanings of guidance in it do not fuse with meanings of guidance in the beginning of the Holy Qur'an. This primacy and finality in the arrangement of Surahs is primacy in the order of recitation, not primacy in the separation of meaning. It possesses a circular context that has no beginning that does not fuse with something, nor an end where it cuts off. Hence, the Prophetic incitement for the reciter of the Holy Qur'an was to be the "Hal Al-Murtahil" (The one who alights and departs).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "The Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, was asked: 'Which deed is best?' He said: 'The Hal Al-Murtahil (The one who alights and departs).' It was said: 'What is the Hal Al-Murtahil?' He said: 'The companion of the Qur'an who travels from the beginning of the Qur'an to its end, and from its end to its beginning; whenever he alights (finishes), he departs (starts again)'" (Sunan Al-Darimi: Virtues of the Quran). Thus, "Al-Biqa'i" sought to return (link) nine surahs from the end of the Holy Qur'an to nine surahs from its beginning. By this, he exceeds with the style of "returning the end to the beginning" (Radd al-'ajuz 'ala al-sadr) what rhetoricians hold, making it encompass the structure of the Surah, nay, the structure of the entire Holy Qur'an. At the conclusion of Surah "Quraysh", he begins looking at returning nine surahs from the end of the Holy Qur'an in recitation to nine surahs from its beginning in order, saying: ((Just as the end of every Surah met its beginning, so too the end of the Great Qur'an met its beginning regarding nine surahs; this is the first of them if you count from the end towards it. For its summary is the favor upon "Quraysh" by aiding in trade, harmonizing them for travel in it, and striking in the earth because of it, and specifying Him with the command to worship the One who favored them with the Sacred House and brought them provisions and security through it. Among the greatest objectives of [Surah] At-Tawbah, which corresponds to it as the ninth from the beginning, is the disavowal (Bara'ah) of every renegade, and that doing so is a cause for unity after it was thought to be a cause for division, and mentioning the virtues of the House and who is fit to serve it, and winning its security and blessing, and the glad tidings of wealth in a manner greater than acquiring it through trade—more splendid, dazzling, fulfilling, abundant, radiant, blooming, majestic, and proud—by His saying Almighty: {It is not for the polytheists to maintain the mosques of Allah [while] witnessing against themselves with disbelief. For those, their deeds have become worthless, and in the Fire they will abide eternally} (At-Tawbah: 17) and His saying Almighty: {And if you fear poverty, Allah will enrich you from His bounty if He wills. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Wise} (At-Tawbah: from Verse 28).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Thus it is known with clear knowledge that He, Glory be to Him and Exalted, initiated the return of the segment (Maqta') to the opening (Matla') starting from Surah Quraysh, whom Allah, Glory be to Him and Exalted, honored by revealing the Qur'an in their tongue, and sending the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, with it, just as He honored them by building the House for their sake, and by magnifying it, He enriched and secured them. Among the greatest correlations in that is that the beginning of the Surah in which He started returning the segment to the opening is strongly similar to the Surah corresponding to it, such that each of them with the one before it is like a single Surah. For Bara'ah with Al-Anfal is like that, to the extent that "Uthman", may Allah be pleased with him, said: "The Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, passed away without clarifying its matter, so it was not established for him that it was independent from it; therefore, he did not write the line {In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful} between them." Whereas this one from the end [Quraysh] is decisively independent, along with what was reported of it being with the one before it [Al-Fil] as a single Surah in the Mushaf of "Ubayy", may Allah be pleased with him, and the recitation of "Umar", may Allah be pleased with him, of them in a way that suggests that, as passed, indicating that the latter is clearer than the former. Among the strangest of that is that the two Surahs preceding the two corresponding Surahs have an antithesis (Tibaq) between their matters. The first in the end, which is "Al-Fil", Allah, Glory be to Him and Exalted, honored Quraysh in it by destroying the People of the "Gospel" [Abrahah's army]. The first in the beginning, which is "Al-Anfal", Allah, Majestic is His Glory, honored them [the Believers] in it by giving victory to the People of the Qur'an over them [Quraysh] by destroying their tyrants. That was a cause for breaking their power and the fall of their pride leading to their happiness. And it was known that the Disavowal (Bara'ah) and others were only done to honor them; because they are intended essentially and by primary intent in the Message, and people are followers to them, just as all Messengers are followers to the Opening and Sealing Messenger...)) (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Thus, Al-Biqa'i seeks to interpret the coordination of the Qur'anic Surahs in a way that makes the rhetorical order of the Holy Qur'an, in its relationships with one another, like the relationship of parts of a continuous circle where the two ends are unknown. He continues clarifying the connection of each of the nine surahs at the end of the Holy Qur'an in recitation with the corresponding one of the nine at its beginning in reading. Among what is clear and undeniable, showing no taint of forced interpretation, is what you see of the close relationship between Surah "Al-Masad" [111], the fourth from the end of its recitation, and Surah "An-Nisa" [4], the fourth from the beginning of its recitation. He says in the conclusion of interpreting Surah "Al-Masad": "The summary of this Surah is that Abu Lahab severed his kinship ties, deviated from the intended path, strove after his misguidance to misguide others, and wronged the One advising him and compassionate towards him, who spared no effort in advising him despite what you see of him sparing no effort in harming him. He relied on his wealth and earnings, so he perished and destroyed his wife with him, and whoever followed him of his children. Among the greatest objectives of Surah 'An-Nisa', corresponding to it in returning the segment to the opening, is connection, closeness, and benevolence, especially to kin, and justice in all sayings and deeds. Thus, the explanation of the state of the Advisor who does not speak from desire, and the state of the misguided one who only speaks from desire, was His saying Almighty: {Allah wants to make clear to you and guide you to the [good] practices of those before you} (An-Nisa: 26). He concluded it pointing to the warning against a state like his [Abu Lahab's]. As if it was said: Allah clarifies to you lest you go astray and become like Abu Lahab in ruin and roasting in the Fire, as He clarified to you. So be cautious of everything resembling his state, even if the contrary appears to you, for I am more knowledgeable than you, and Allah is Knowing of all things. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds)) (1). This which "Al-Biqa'i" showed regarding the embrace of Surahs "Al-Masad" and "An-Nisa" shows no taint of artificiality; once he draws your insight to it, you find repose in what he drew you to.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Here he offers us guidance to extend the field of rhetorical study of styles, so we do not restrict them to the construction of a sentence or verse, but extend beyond that to the construction of a passage (Ma'qid) or Surah, or even the entire Holy Qur'an. Antithesis (Tibaq) extends from the opposition between two words in the structure of a sentence, or two sentences in the structure of a verse or line of poetry, to making it a contrast between a story and a story, similar to what exegetes and rhetoricians knew of conjoining a story to a story, and we extend it to make it a contrast between a Surah and a Surah. Thus, we have singular Tibaq, multiple Tibaq, and complex universal Tibaq. Rhetoricians had a similar view regarding Simile (Tashbih), but they did not do so regarding Tibaq, though it is worthy of it. Likewise, "Exportation" (Tasdir - Epanadiplosis): we extend it from returning the end to the beginning in the structure of a poetic line to the structure of a section in a poem and returning the end of the poem to its opening. In the Qur'anic statement, we extend it to returning the end of the Surah to its opening, and returning the final segment of the Holy Qur'an in recitation to its opening. Similar things can be done in styles of advancing and delaying, omission, disjunction, and conjunction. In summary, this action of "Al-Biqa'i" indicates that he holds that the arrangement of the Surahs of the Great Qur'an contains secrets of rhetorical miraculousness, and that it is not [only] miraculous in the order of its sentence or verse structures, but in the arrangement of its verses and Surahs. If a group of modern rhetoricians directed their attention to fulfilling some of the rights of this chapter through contemplation, pondering, and deriving the principles of its rhetoric in the Holy Qur'an, we would be able to establish, alongside what the predecessors established, what satisfies Allah Almighty from us as being part of giving advice (Nasihah) to His Noble Book.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: We would be able to add to the rhetorical and critical thinking of the human word—poetry and artistic prose—what confirms that we are not in need of begging for principles of critical thinking from people who do not speak our tongue and do not carry in their chests a concern like ours. It is indeed a disgrace/shame (Ma'arrah) for the grandchildren to beg for what is buried in the treasures of their ancestors available between their hands, yet they do not burden themselves with the honor of deriving from it. They see their honor in feeding on the crumbs of the tables of others, and in digging up graves to extract what the other has buried of critical thought which the people forgot and turned away from. Indeed, not a little of what you read of critical thinking begged from the Other on the Western shore, you can find its roots—which can be developed if the resolve is true—in the heritage of our ancestors, and in the work of "Al-Biqa'i" specifically, there is much nobility from those roots.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Chapter Two: His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Holy Qur'an in the Construction of the Surah. First Feature... Realizing the Objective of Each Surah and the Escalation of its Meanings. The previous features were related to "Al-Biqa'i's" methodology in interpreting the proportion of the arrangement of Qur'anic Surahs. The features coming to you are established to clarify his methodology in interpreting the proportion of Compositional Order (Nazm Tarkibi) and Ordinal Order (Nazm Tartibi) in the construction of the Qur'anic Surah. The basis of his methodology in this is his care for verifying and liberating the Greatest Objective of the Qur'anic Surah which he is interpreting and demonstrating the rhetorical miraculousness in its order, compositionally and ordinally. The Greatest Objective is what the meanings of the statement in this Surah revolve around, and it is what controls everything in it. He states in the introduction of his Tafsir (Nazm al-Durar) that the science of Appropriateness (Munasabat) of the Holy Qur'an is a science by which the reasons for the arrangement of its parts (i.e., parts of the Qur'an: its sentences, verses, passages, and Surahs) are known, and it is the secret of rhetoric; because it leads to achieving the conformity of meanings to what the context requires. This means he does not see that the secret of Qur'anic rhetoric lies only in the Compositional Order realized from the relationships of words to each other in the construction of a sentence isolated from its indicators in its context, even if extended. Rather, it lies in the Ordinal Order. The high miraculous rhetoric is not in defining this word to convey such meaning, or advancing it to convey such, or deleting the subject or object to convey such meaning; for you can find something of that in the construction of a sentence isolated from its indicators in its context in other than the Qur'anic statement. But the high miraculous rhetoric that silences all worlds lies in the relationships of sentences to each other in the context of the verse, relationships of verses to each other in the context of the passage, relationships of passages to each other in the context of the Surah, and relationships of Surahs to each other in the total context of the Holy Qur'anic meaning. Al-Biqa'i also explains in the introduction of his Tafsir what mastering understanding this and perfecting the interpretation of miraculous Qur'anic rhetoric depends on, saying: ((And proficiency in it [i.e., in the science of understanding the appropriateness of the Holy Qur'an] depends on knowing the objective of the Surah in which that is sought. And that benefits knowing the objective of all its sentences)) (1). As you see, he makes knowledge of the Surah's objective the basis of proficiency in understanding the proportion of the Holy Qur'an regarding knowing the reasons for the arrangement of parts of the Qur'anic statement starting from the word in the sentence ending with the Surah. At the same time, this returns with great benefit on knowing the objective of the Surah's sentences by understanding their Compositional Order. This places the interpreter of the Holy Qur'anic statement in a position of reciprocating movement between contemplating and tasting the part, and contemplating and tasting the whole. The more you increase looking into the Qur'anic statement in a part of it, the more it increases your ability to know the Greatest Objective; and the more you increase looking into the Greatest Objective, the more it increases you in understanding the statement of the Compositional Order of the sentence.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: That is what you see of "Al-Biqa'i's" explanation of the status of knowing the objectives of Surahs in perfecting the interpretation of the Glorious Qur'anic statement. When you look at the location of his explanation of the Surah's objective, you see that predominantly he opens the discussion by mentioning the objective of the Surah before mentioning its name, as you see in his interpretation of Surah "Al-Baqarah", Surah "An-Nisa", "Al-Ma'idah", "Al-An'am", "Al-A'raf", "At-Tawbah", and "Yunus". He may open the speech by interpreting the "Basmalah" before mentioning the objective of the Surah, as in Surah "Al-Imran" and "Ibrahim". And he may open it by mentioning the name of the Surah and interpreting the Basmalah, as in Surah "Al-Anfal", "Al-Mulk", "Al-Qalam", and "Al-Ma'arij". It remains to look into his methodology in clarifying that objective, to see that he adopts a methodology based on striving to liberate the Universal Meaning that flows through the passages of the Surah forming its Universal Meanings which consist of Partial Meanings portrayed by the statement of the Order of sentence and verse.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In his book "Masa'id al-Nazar", he states that ((every Surah has a single objective around which its beginning and end revolve, and it is evidenced within it. Thus, the premises indicating it are arranged in the most precise manner and most creative way. If there is something in it needing proof, it is proven, and so on in the proof of the proof, and so forth. When the matter reaches its limit (end), it concludes with what the beginning was from, then the speech bends back to it, and the view returns to it, on a wondrous path and an ascent impregnable unlike the first. Thus, the Surah becomes like a verdant, tall tree and a magnificent, elegant garden adorned with types of ornaments arranged after elegant leaves with branches of pearls. Its branches bend back to those sections like circles; every circle of them has a branch connected to what is before it, and a branch fused with what is after it. The end of the Surah has connected with its beginning just as its termination adhered to what is after it, and its commencement embraced what is before it. So every Surah became like a great circle containing circles of radiant verses, wondrous in order, amazing in joining, with the softness of the sympathy of its branches and the beauty of the continuity of its fruits and boughs" (1). He proceeds in this from the Universal Rule which his Sheikh "Abu al-Fadl al-Mashdali al-Maghribi" guided him to, and which he stated in the opening of his interpretation of Surah "Al-Fatihah" saying: "The Universal Matter useful for knowing the appropriateness of verses in the entire Qur'an is that you look at the ranks of those premises in proximity and distance from the Desired [Meaning], and look, when speech is dragged into the premises, at what it entails of the listener's soul anticipating (Istishraf) the rulings and implications following it, for which rhetoric requires healing the sick by removing the pain of anticipation through informing about them. This is the Universal Matter dominating the rule of linking between all parts of the Qur'an. If you do this, the face of the Order will become clear to you in detail between every verse and verse in every Surah and Surah, God willing, and Allah is the Guide" (2).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: If he, in his Tafsir (Nazm al-Durar), opens the speech in interpreting Surah "Al-Baqarah" by saying: "Its Greatest Objective: Establishing the evidence that the Book is guidance to be followed in everything it says, and the greatest thing it guides to is Belief in the Unseen, and its gathering point is Belief in the Hereafter, so the pivot is Belief in the Resurrection which the story of the Cow expressed, whose pivot is Belief in the Unseen..." (1), you find him, after finishing the interpretation of the statement and its proportion in the saying of Allah Almighty: {And those who disbelieve and deny Our signs - those will be companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally} (Al-Baqarah: 39), pausing for a long time to look into the proportion of the Surah's verses from its beginning to the beginning of this passage (Ma'qid). He presents two faces of establishing appropriateness between the verses of this passage, saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "When He Almighty established the proofs of Tawhid, Prophethood, and the Hereafter first, and followed it by mentioning general favors, calling people generally [meaning the saying of Allah Almighty: O Mankind worship your Lord... Verse 21], especially the Children of Ismail: the Arabs who are the people of the Caller, peace be upon him. And the most rightful to be called after relatives, and the most worthy of priority, were the People of Knowledge who were upon truth but deviated from it, especially if they had kinship; because they are worthy of rushing to answer with the slightest explanation and easiest reminder. If they return, the ignorant will follow them, so his matter becomes easy and his evil is cut off. If they do not return, their argument is prolonged, so their misguidance becomes clear to the ignorant, who then becomes worthy of returning and refraining from his error and abstaining. From the prolongation of speech with them, rulings became known and Halal and Haram became clear. Therefore, when He finished the call to the Arabs which included others briefly, and concluded by promising for following guidance and threatening [for opposing], He Almighty began specifically mentioning the scholars among the Hypocrites, who were those who showed Islam from the People of the Book in a way entailing the generality of those among them explicitly declaring disbelief, since they were among the greatest of those singled out to receive what He pointed to of guidance and statement containing healing. Their Book containing guidance was among the greatest, most famous, and most comprehensive of Books. So He narrated to them what softens iron and humbles rocks, saying Almighty reminding them of His specific favors upon them (O Children of Israel)" (1). After finishing explaining the sequence of meanings in the first passage of the Surah's passages and how the speech in the second passage beginning with the saying of Allah Almighty: {O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you and fulfill My covenant upon you that I will fulfill your covenant with Me, and be afraid of [only] Me} (Al-Baqarah: 40) was generated from it, he decides another face of proportion and generation, saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "And it is permissible to establish the appropriateness from the beginning of the Surah in another way, so it is said: Since the disbelievers were of two types: a type whose disbelief was pure (Mahd), and a type who mixed it with hypocrisy and deception. And the Pure was of two types: a type having no knowledge from a previous scripture, who are the polytheists of the Arabs, and a type having a scripture from which they know the truth. He Almighty mentioned the Pure type with what encompasses its two parts: the Knowledgeable and the Ignorant, saying Almighty: {Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe} (Al-Baqarah: 6). Then He followed it with the type of Hypocrites; because they are more important due to their intense mixing with the believers and showing that they are of them, so that they [believers] may be wary of their deception. So He Almighty said: {And of the people are some who say, 'We believe in Allah and the Last Day,' but they are not believers} (Al-Baqarah: 8). When He finished that, and what it entailed of commanding Oneness, establishing its proofs and pouring out its virtues, and expressing wonder at one who disbelieves despite the establishment of proofs, warning of those calamities, and soliciting affection by mentioning blessings, He began mentioning a type of the Pure who is like the Hypocrite in that he knows the truth and hides it. For the Hypocrite accustomed himself to disbelief, then desisted from it [outwardly], and showed putting on Islam while continuing on disbelief inwardly. This type [Jews] was upon belief in this Prophet, peace be upon him, before his call. When he called them, they erased the faith they were wearing and showed disbelief, and their state continued on showing disbelief and hiding the Knowledge which is the beginning of Faith. So their state, as you see, is most similar to the state of Hypocrites; that is why you see them paired with them in much of the Qur'an. He delayed them due to the length of their story and what it contains of proofs of Prophethood and signs of Message by revealing what they hid of the details of their knowledge. For debating the Scholar sends the horses of thoughts into the fields of knowledge, so they speed into the regions of desires until they become like birds and bring wondrous secrets.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He Almighty spread in the folds of their debate and the folds of their dialogue and speech comprehensive sentences regarding the laws of religion which contain the desire of the guided, establishing the proof that it is guidance for the worlds. This is the summary of the matter. In its details, as you will see of wondrous description, are matters too majestic for description, tasted by good instruction, and curing the stuttering of the one ignorant of it by subtle speech. Allah is the Guardian of success and the Guide to the straightest path" (1). You see in the second face a detail not present in the first, facilitating for you the vision of the movement of the Qur'anic meaning in the verses of that passage of the Surah's passages. In his reference to the multiplicity of faces of proportion and generation is guidance to the firmness of the attachment between parts of the Qur'anic Surah. This is the nature of the High Statement; it does not grant you a single face of meanings or giving, but rather treasures for you in its statement types of meanings of guidance, and leaves you to strive in extracting what aligns with your capacity as an incitement to continue striving in deduction. At the same time, it wards off the calamity of boredom if you were to take in every attempt of Ijtihad what you took in the previous one. But if you encounter in every time from the overflow of giving other than what you encountered in the one before it, you approach with the approach of the aspiring, yearning hopeful. In it is [the fact] that degrees of giving multiply and vary with the multiplicity of those striving in contemplation and vary with the variation of their capacities. Al-Biqa'i, after presenting to you what stood in his chest regarding the two faces of proportion and generation in the verses of this passage paving the way for the verses of the following passage, proceeds to establish before you what stood in the chest of "Abu al-Hasan al-Haralli" regarding that, saying: "And 'Al-Haralli' said: 'Then the address turned to the Children of Israel, organized by the beginning of the address to the Arabs from His saying (O Mankind). Likewise, the organization of the Qur'an organizes the head of an address with the head of another address suitable to it in the totality of its meaning, and organizes its detail with its detail. So the first and most worthy to be addressed after the Arabs - who are a Seal - were the Children of Israel - who are a Beginning, being the first upon whom was revealed the First Book

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: of the Torah with which Allah Almighty opened His books following His scrolls and tablets. Then he said: When the turning of the address to the Arabs, who had no prior guidance, was organized by what preceded it of address to the Prophet, peace be upon him, the address to the Children of Israel was organized by the address to the Arabs, due to what preceded for them of guidance in their time {Indeed, We sent down the Torah, in which was guidance and light. The prophets who submitted [to Allah] judged by it for the Jews, as did the rabbis and scholars by that with which they were entrusted of the Scripture of Allah, and they were witnesses thereto. So do not fear the people but fear Me, and do not exchange My verses for a small price. And whoever does not judge by what Allah has revealed - then it is those who are the disbelievers} (Al-Ma'idah: 44). And due to what was covenanted to them of doubling the guidance by what preceded for them in their ascension from the perfection of guidance through Muhammad, peace be upon him, and through this Qur'an. Therefore, the priority was their rushing to it so the Arabs would be guided by them, to be the first believer due to what they have of His previous knowledge.' End quote" (1). What "Al-Haralli" explained contains what guides to the rhetorical Sunnah of the Holy Qur'an in coordinating meanings and presenting some over others due to the succession of the second upon the first and its generation from it. It is not hidden from you that what Al-Biqa'i explained, especially the second face, has a bond of lineage to the saying of "Al-Haralli". "Al-Biqa'i" still summarizes for you the movement of meaning in its context during the Surahs. You see him, when interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty {These are the verses of Allah which We recite to you in truth. And indeed, you are of the messengers} (Al-Baqarah: 252), saying: "Perhaps the conclusion of the stories of the Children of Israel with this story is because it contains for the Prophet, peace be upon him, clear indication of the validity of his claim to Messengerhood; because it is of what none knows except the few of the skilled scholars of the Children of Israel.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Then He followed it with Ayat al-Kursi (Verse of the Throne) which is the greatest of the proofs of Tawhid. So that was in the utmost appropriateness to what is in the beginnings of the Surah in the saying of Allah Almighty: {O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous} (Al-Baqarah: 21) to the end of those verses of proofs of Tawhid containing proofs of Prophethood with which the stories of the Children of Israel opened. Thus, proofs of Tawhid bracketed their story, its beginning and its end, along with what is in its midst, proceeding on the Wise Style in struggling against scholars and debating the virtuous. So the summary of that is as if it was said (Alif, Lam, Mim) alerting the souls with what the All-Knowing, Glory be to Him and Exalted, kept exclusive to His knowledge. When hearing was cast and understandings were present, it was said: 'O Mankind'. When anticipation became great, He said: 'Worship your Lord'. Then He specified Him after describing Him with what clarified Him by His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence. Neither drowsiness overtakes Him nor sleep. To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. Who is it that can intercede with Him except by His permission? He knows what is [presently] before them and what will be after them, and they encompass not a thing of His knowledge except for what He wills. His Kursi extends over the heavens and the earth, and their preservation tires Him not. And He is the Most High, the Most Great} (Al-Baqarah: 255). Just as the beginning of Surah 'At-Tawhid': 'Al-Imran', revealed in debating the People of the Book from Christians and others, will gather that without separation. And their stories conclude with His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {Our Lord, indeed we have heard a caller calling to faith, [saying], "Believe in your Lord," and we have believed. Our Lord, so forgive us our sins and remove from us our misdeeds and cause us to die with the righteous} (Al-Imran: 193).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He means by the Caller - and Allah Almighty knows best - the one saying: 'O Mankind, worship your Lord' (Al-Baqarah: 21) to its end)) (1). When you look at his stance on the escalation of the Qur'anic meaning in Surah Al-Baqarah and the generation of those meanings when he interprets the verse which he holds to be the conclusion of Surah Al-Baqarah despite being followed by thirty other verses: "Ayat al-Kursi" (2), you hear him saying: ... "When He Almighty began 'Al-Fatihah' as passed by mentioning the Essence (Dhat), then made Himself known by Actions; because they are witnessed, then elevated the address to making known by Attributes, then elevated it returning to the Essence for qualification for Gnosis (Ma'rifah), He began this Surah [Surah Al-Baqarah] with the Attribute of Speech [meaning His saying: That is the Book...]; because it is the greatest of miracles, the clearest of them, the most indicative of the Unseen of the Essence, and the most effective in souls especially among Arabs. Then He made Himself known by Actions, and multiplied them. When no ambiguity remained, He established Oneness with His preceding verses, interspersing that with arts of wisdom and beauties of rulings and types of encouragement and intimidation in precise description and arrangement. When the commands were complete, and those deterrents struck terror, and souls looked forward to that Day—since the familiar from kings of the world is that they are hardly capable of a matter of matters with true capability due to the multitude of intercessors and willing friends, for the king among them his council is never free of a group each of whom is fit to stand in his place, and if he abandoned him or directed his plot against him, he would weaken his command and enfeeble his arm; so he needs to observe them, please them, and humor them—He Almighty clarified the attribute of the Commander with what He is upon of Majesty, Greatness, effectiveness of command, loftiness above prevention, and transcendence above ungratefulness (Kufr) and peer (Nidd) and uniqueness in all perfections and the preventing awe after its revelation there with the most complete revelation; lest intentions turn to other than Him, or one speaks without His permission, or it be other than what He wants; for that to be more conducive to accepting His command and stopping at His prohibition

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: and His rebuke. For the sake of these purposes, He drove the speech in the course of answering the question. As if it was said: This is what is not known from the conditions of kings, so who is the King on that Day? So He mentioned Ayat al-Kursi, the Mistress of Quranic verses, the like of which no book contained, opening it with the Proper Name, the Unique, the Comprehensive, with which no other was named" (1). He also comes in the introduction of his interpretation of the position of the story of our master Abraham, peace be upon him, and his request to his Lord, Mighty and Exalted, to show him how He revives the dead, drawing our attention to the Greatest Objective of the Surah, saying: "Since belief in the Resurrection, nay Certainty (Yaqin), is among the greatest objectives in this Surah, and it ended at this context which is for fixing the pillars of the Power to revive despite disparate methods and different ways—so He clarified first by refuting the disbeliever what necessitates Faith, and by making the wondering one witness what sealed Certainty—He rose from that clarification in the story of the 'Friend' (Al-Khalil) peace be upon him to what establishes Tranquility. He Almighty has established the matter of Resurrection in this Surah after 'Al-Fatihah' pointed to it with the Day of Judgment in the best establishment. He scattered its stars in it through the heavens of its verses, and distributed its traces in its corners between its proofs and evidences, the action of the Wise who casts what He wants gradually, neither hasty nor falling short. So He Almighty repeated its mention with the Hereafter at times, and Revival at others, sometimes in the World and sometimes in the Hereafter in the likes of His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {And of the Hereafter they are certain} (Al-Baqarah: from Verse 4), {How can you disbelieve in Allah when you were lifeless and He brought you to life} (Al-Baqarah: from Verse 28), {Then We revived you after your death that perhaps you would be grateful} (Al-Baqarah: 56), {Thus does Allah bring the dead to life} (Al-Baqarah: from Verse 73), {So Allah said to them, "Die"; then He revived them} (Al-Baqarah: from Verse 243).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And what was of its likes, analogues, and forms in those styles intended mostly essentially for other than it [Resurrection]. So the souls of those denying it became familiar with it, and had readiness to hear the deduction for it until He drove to them the matter of His Friend, peace be upon him and greeting and honor. It was as if it was said: O deniers of Resurrection and manifesters of wonder at it and imitators of fathers in its matter with reports most of which are false, hear the story of your father 'Abraham', peace be upon him, with which He met you with deduction for Resurrection, gathering the separated, and returning the spirit by the reporting of one who is not accused by the testimony of the Qur'an which incapacitated you from bringing the like of anything of it. So his testimony is the testimony of Allah; so that you become from that upon Knowledge of Certainty, nay Eye of Certainty..." (1). You see him striving to clarify the escalation of the Qur'anic Meaning and the dominance of the Greatest Objective over those escalating meanings, certain that the Qur'anic meaning in the context of the Surah is subject to the authority of a universal meaning, and that the partial meanings forming the meanings of passages from which the Surah consists are escalating meanings founding from one aspect what had no previous mention, and confirming from another what was previously founded. In every confirmation is a founding of what the Qur'anic statement stands upon of the methodology of distributing meanings. These two matters: escalation of meanings and their generation on one hand, and distribution of the statement about them on the other, are among the majestic characteristics of the Rhetorical Sunnah in the Holy Qur'an which you do not find in other than it in a manner even strictly distinct from it. I claim this is a feature of the features of the Rhetorical Miraculousness of the Holy Qur'an. And Al-Biqa'i, if his care for clarifying the facet of the organization of meanings in Surah Al-Baqarah and their escalation and subjection to the authority of a universal meaning which is its Greatest Objective became clear to you, implies he is keen at the end of his interpretation of the Qur'anic statement in Surah Al-Baqarah to summarize for us the speech on the arrangement of its meanings in the miraculous manner it came upon, saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "The secret of arranging the Surah of 'The Hump' (Al-Sanam) on this system is that when He Almighty opened it by classifying the people who are to Religion like legs carrying the possessor of the Hump, so it straightened and stood, He began the objective by mentioning the nearest of the Hump to the understandings of the people of standing. So He said addressing all the categories He presented: {O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous} (Al-Baqarah: 21). He continued until the matter became utmost clear, then He began mentioning His favors - Glory be to Him - upon the people commanded to worship by what He bestowed upon them of creating everything in existence for them by what He honored their father 'Adam', peace be upon him, with. Then He singled out the Arabs and those following them by clarifying the favor upon them in debating the Children of Israel and rebuking them. He Almighty emphasizes every little while the matter of Lordship and Tawhid in worship without mentioning any rulings except what the Children of Israel stripped themselves of, so He mentioned it by way of bestowing it upon the Arabs, and rebuking the Children of Israel for leaving it, not that it is intended essentially. When they were purified, and ascended, and became qualified for types of Gnosis (Ma'arif), He said elevating them from the ascents of Lordship (Rububiyyah) to the ladders of Divinity (Uluhiyyah): {And your god is one God. There is no deity except Him, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful} (Al-Baqarah: 163). When they mounted this honor, He taught them the purifying acts of worship, and cast to them their purifying spirits. So He mentioned the mothers of actions, fundamentals and branches, the five pillars and the Enclosure (Hazirah) and what followed that of limits (Hudud) in foods, drinks, marriages, and other interests. So they became prepared by them, and [knowing] that they are the noble arrivals from the Possessor of Majesty. So He said elevating them to the Unseen of His Lofty Presence mentioning the Named of all Names:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence. Neither drowsiness overtakes Him nor sleep. To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. Who is it that can intercede with Him except by His permission? He knows what is [presently] before them and what will be after them, and they encompass not a thing of His knowledge except for what He wills. His Kursi extends over the heavens and the earth, and their preservation tires Him not. And He is the Most High, the Most Great} (Al-Baqarah: 255). Since the one arriving at the highest station of Freedom must, according to the Folk [Sufis], return to the bond (noose) of Servitude, He mentioned to them some actions befitting them. So He urged towards things most of which are from the valley of Excellence (Ihsan) which is the station of people of Gnosis. He mentioned the like of Spending (Nafaqah) which is one of the buildings of the Surah following what He mentioned of the station of Tranquility, signaling that this is the affair of the Tranquil one. He encouraged it signaling that there is no hope in arrival except by stripping oneself of the entire world. He increased the urging for good food without which there is no survival in any condition. He forbade Usury (Riba) with severest prohibition, signaling contentment with minimum subsistence (Kifaf), and forbidding absolute increase for the Elite, and every haram for the Commoners. He guided to the etiquettes of Religion necessitating trust in what is with Allah Almighty, requiring true Reliance (Tawakkul) fruitful of aid from Allah Almighty. And the guidance to that, the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, passed away while adhering to it. He Almighty built each third of these thirds on an introduction establishing his matter and faced it with a conclusion warning against negligence of it. He increased the third, being the Conclusion, and by it is the blessing of completion, that He emphasized upon them after its conclusion belief in everything in the Surah.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He concluded by pointing out that the pillar of that is Jihad against those of error and stubbornness, and reliance in it upon the Owner of Sovereignty and King of Servants. That is the path of the people of righteousness, guidance, and correctness. And Allah Almighty is the Grantor of success to the right way)) (1). With this comprehensive summary of what are main pillars upon which Surah Al-Baqarah stands and rises, realizing for it its miraculousness in arranging the meanings of guidance within it in a manner making it the Hump of the Holy Qur'an, its Tent, and its Peak. Al-Biqa'i was aware of the good division and its wonder for the universal meanings from which Surah Al-Baqarah was established, and aware of the methodology of the Holy Qur'an in dividing the high rulings and etiquettes contained in the Hump of the Holy Qur'an and the methodology of the Surah in opening every section and concluding it. *** We look into another Surah from the "Hundreds" (Mi'un) after looking at a Surah from the "Long Ones" (Tiwl). We look at his explanation of the objective of Surah "An-Nahl". He says: "Its objective is indicating that He Almighty is Perfect in Power and Knowledge, Doer by Choice, Transcendent above impurities of deficiency" (2). Then he adds an explicit statement on proving Tawhid (Oneness) which he expressed generally by his saying (Transcendent above impurities of deficiency), for the first and greatest of impurities of deficiency is Shirk (Polytheism). Whoever has a partner is not transcendent above the head of impurities of deficiency. Perhaps Al-Biqa'i did not explicitly state Tawhid first in verifying the objective of the Surah—and he frequently reviews his interpretation—as an indication from him that Tawhid is the antecedent (Malzum) of what he explicitly stated of the perfection of His Knowledge, Power, Choice, and Transcendence above impurities of deficiency. Explicitly stating the consequents (Lawazim) necessitates knowledge of the antecedent. Whoever accepts the consequent must accept the antecedent inevitably: Whoever accepts for you that so-and-so moves must accept that he is alive, for life is the antecedent of movement. This is a methodology of the methodologies of binding to the truth.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: As if Al-Biqa'i points by that to the methodology of the Surah in providing evidence. It takes the mention of blessings as gratitude-inducing evidence for the Oneness of the Benefactor and the perfection of His Knowledge, Power, Choice, and Transcendence above impurities of deficiency. This is what the Surah is based on. So Al-Biqa'i made us feel by this action of his the reality of the methodology on which the statement in the Surah is based: stating explicitly the consequent to achieve and confirm the antecedent. However, the statement of the Surah establishes sentences explicitly stating Tawhid in specific locations of the area of statement within it: You find in the beginning of the first passage Him saying, Mighty and Majestic: {That you warn that there is no deity except Me, so fear Me} (An-Nahl: from Verse 2). And He says at the conclusion of enumerating a group of His blessings bestowed and used as evidence for His Oneness, Knowledge, Power, and Transcendence above impurities of deficiency (Verses: 2-21): {Your god is one God} (An-Nahl: from Verse 22). After mentioning what the disbelievers objected to the Call with and demolishing it (Verses: 24-50), He explicitly states Tawhid {And Allah has said, "Do not take for yourselves two deities. He is but one God, so fear only Me."} (An-Nahl: 51). When you follow the look into the verses of the Surah, you find they are descended from the meaning of proving the Oneness of Allah Almighty and the Beautiful Attributes necessitated by it: Perfection of Knowledge, Power, and Choice, by means of blessings, even if the indication of verses to this meaning varies. Thus, the Surah is based on the methodology of distributing the statement about the single meaning (The Greatest Objective) in different ways regarding clarity of indication to it. This is not specific to Surah "An-Nahl" but inclusive of every Surah of the Holy Qur'an.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: I almost never tire of confirming the statement that the Science of Bayan (Clarification/Imagery) in Qur'anic Rhetoric is not restricted to "Simile, Metaphor, Synecdoche, and Metonymy". Whoever wishes to study a Surah in the light of the methodology of the Science of Bayan, he must not limit his diligence in contemplation and interpretation to these styles in the Surah. Rather, it includes contemplating and pondering the indication of every sentence and verse to the Greatest Objective of the Surah (The Single Meaning) designated in it, and the degrees of difference in indication, and the relationship of this variation in ways of expression to the partial meaning and the universal meaning, relying on contemplating and pondering the Compositional and Ordinal Order of sentences, verses, and passages. *** If Al-Biqa'i is concerned with achieving the objective of the Surah whose methodology of statement he is contemplating, he is also keen on reviewing what he concludes of deducing the Greatest Objective of the Surah whose statement he is interpreting and whose great system proportion he is explaining. He shows us sometimes that he has re-examined the verification and liberation of the Surah's objective and something higher appeared to him than what he had indicated before. He says in the opening of Surah "Al-A'raf": "Its objective is warning those who turned away from what the Book called to in the past Surah of Tawhid, gathering on good, and fulfilling what evidence established as obligatory in Al-An'am, and cautioning him with the calamities of the two abodes. This is better than what appeared to me [before], and I mentioned it at: {And the weighing on that Day is the truth. So those whose scales are heavy - it is they who are the successful} (Al-A'raf: 8) (1). In his interpretation of that verse, he says after explaining the meaning of Weighing and that it is by a real scale for the scrolls of deeds or the deeds themselves after portraying them in the forms they deserve...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: So it became liberated that the objective of the Surah is urging to follow the Book, which implies urging to follow the Messenger, proving Tawhid and the Power of Resurrection by explaining the terrifying actions in the beginning of creation and destruction of the ancients, signaling that whoever does not follow him and declare the Oneness of the One who sent him down in this style that cannot be imitated and the methodology before which minds and natures stood still—due to the establishment of proofs of His Oneness that others are incapable of His sayings and actions—he is on the verge of being hastened before the Day of Resurrection with a punishment like the punishment of past nations and empty generations, along with what is stored for him on that Day of evil outcome and to show the effect of Anger" (1). You see him at the beginning of the Surah dedicating the objective to the meaning of Warning. This meaning is the axis around which the universal meanings of the Surah revolve, composed of partial meanings portrayed by the Surah's sentences and verses. In his interpretation of the eighth verse {And the weighing on that Day is the truth. So those whose scales are heavy - it is they who are the successful} (Al-A'raf: 8), he makes the objective more general than the meaning of Warning, even though Warning exists in that general objective, for in pointing to the Power of Resurrection is the meaning of Warning, because there is no meaning for Resurrection if it does not result in recompensing servants for what they did, whether good or evil. The summary of the matter is that Al-Biqa'i is keen on striving to verify the Universal Meaning dominating the Surah whose statement he is interpreting and whose system proportion he is explaining. He is keen that this meaning has existence in the passages of the Surah, even if its trace is subtle sometimes in understanding the partial meanings forming the meanings of the passages from which the Surah's system is composed. This methodology is among the most important things distinguishing Al-Biqa'i's Tafsir from other Tafsirs preceding it, or even succeeding it, for you hardly find a Tafsir like his in that keenness and tracking in every Surah of all the Holy Qur'an's Surahs.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: There is no doubt that turning to highlight some faces of proportion of some verses in their succession is not something innovated by "Al-Biqa'i"; it is something you find in quite a few books of Tafsir before him. However, you find this in them like nuggets/fragments. You do not find someone whose care turns to verifying the Universal Meaning for every Surah of the Holy Qur'an, and turns to the care of explaining the cohesion, rather the generation, of Universal Meanings existing in the Surah's passages, and the generation of Partial Meanings existing in the Surah's sentences and verses. But you find Al-Biqa'i doing that in every Surah of the Holy Qur'an. The Second Feature. Relationship of the Surah's Name to its Objective. Every Surah of the Holy Qur'an has a name or more by which it is known since it was revealed and until the Hour starts. Al-Biqa'i pays attention to interpreting the naming of Surahs. It is predominant for him to mention the name of the Surah or its names after explaining its Greatest Objective to clarify the face of its name's indication to its objective. That is one of his principles which he declared in the beginning of his interpretation of Surah Al-Fatihah after mentioning the Universal Rule he learned from his Sheikh "Al-Mashdali", saying: "It appeared to me by using this rule after reaching Surah 'Saba' in the tenth year of my starting to work on this book: That the name of every Surah translates its objective; because the name of everything, the appropriateness between it and its named appears [as] its title indicating generally the details of what is in it. That is what 'Adam', peace be upon him, informed of during the Presentation to the Angels - upon them be blessings and peace" (1). This is based on [the view] that the names of Surahs are traceable (Marfu') [to the Prophet] or Stopped (Mawquf) based on Ijtihad from the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. Al-Biqa'i did not explicitly state his school in that, although his methodology of interpreting the naming indicates that he is closer to Marfu' (Traceable) than to Mawquf (Stopped).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: When you look into his book "Masa'id al-Nazar", and he took care in it to mention Hadiths, reports, and traces related to the matter of Qur'anic Surahs, you find him mentioning regarding every Surah a Hadith, report, or trace containing an explicit statement of the Surah's name. This indicates that those names he is interpreting and explaining their indication to the objective of the Surah named by them are closer to being Marfu' (Traceable to the Prophet). What is from the guidance of the Prophetic Sunnah is his care, peace be upon him, for naming things: humans and others. He used to guide to good naming, and change the name of one whose name he did not find good. What happened with the grandfather of "Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib bin Hazn", may Allah be pleased with him, when he named him Sahl (Easy) and he refused out of tribalism - is standing in our souls as a majestic lesson so that we do not desire other than what the Bringer of Glad Tidings and Warner, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, desired. If this was his guidance, peace be upon him, in things around him, how would his guidance be regarding the naming of Qur'anic Surahs? Authentic books of the Prophetic Sunnah contain Prophetic statements that confirm the naming of quite a few Qur'anic Surahs.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The important thing is that in Naming there is a temptation that there might be a bond of lineage between the meaning of the Name and the objective of the Surahs named by it. So it is worthy for us to look into it, especially since the naming of quite a few Surahs is not fit to be justified by saying they were named so because of its mention in them. Otherwise, what is the reason for naming the Surah following At-Tawbah as "Yunus" peace be upon him, while his story is mentioned in others more extensively than it is mentioned in it? And why was not a single Surah named after "Moses" peace be upon him, while he is the most mentioned of Prophets regarding his story with the Children of Israel? And why was Surah "Bani Isra'il: Al-Isra" not named "Musa"? Nay, why was Surah Al-Qasas not named "Musa" peace be upon him, while his story was elaborated in it and news of him was mentioned in it that was not mentioned in others, and no story of other Prophets was mentioned in it other than his story, and what came of the story of Qarun, for Qarun was from the people of Moses peace be upon him. This indicates clearly that the matter of Naming does not revert to the mere mention of the name in that Surah. The important thing is that Al-Biqa'i takes care to mention the name of the Surah or its names if multiple, and in their multiplicity is an indication of its great merit and the breadth of its objective. He mentions to us the names of Surah Al-Fatihah: "So Al-Fatihah, its name is 'Mother of the Book', 'The Foundation', 'The Mathani', 'The Treasure', 'The Healer', 'The Sufficient', 'The Fulfilling', 'The Ruqyah', 'The Praise', 'The Gratitude', 'The Dua', and 'The Prayer'. He explains the relationship of the objective of Al-Fatihah: 'Observation of servants of their Lord; to single Him out in worship', saying: 'The pivot of these names as you see is upon a hidden matter sufficient for every desire, which is Observation (Muraqabah) which I will say is its objective. For everything not opened by it has no consideration. It is a treasure for everything, healing for every worry, fulfilling every desire, protecting from every evil, a Ruqyah for every affliction. It is the establishment of Praise which is encompassing attributes of perfection, and Gratitude which is magnifying the Benefactor. It is the essence of Dua, for it is turning to the Called, and the greatest of its gatherings is Prayer'" (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: As you heard, he highlighted the meaning of every name of its names through its Greatest Objective which is in reality the Greatest Objective of the Holy Qur'an. Contemplating the meaning of the Name guides to seeing a feature of the features of the Surah's objective. If you gather those features, coordinate them, and visualize a universal meaning they revolve around, you are close to realizing the Greatest Objective of the Surah. He says in Surah "Yunus" peace be upon him, clarifying the reason for specializing this Surah with this name, and specializing the story of "Yunus" peace be upon him to be the title of the Surah although other stories were mentioned in it: "Noah" peace be upon him (Verses 71-74) and "Moses" peace be upon him (Verses 75-93), then one verse was mentioned regarding the story of the people of "Yunus" peace be upon him: {Then has there not been a [single] city that believed so its faith benefited it except the people of Jonah? When they believed, We removed from them the punishment of disgrace in the worldly life and gave them enjoyment for a time} (Yunus: 98). He says: "Its objective: Describing the Book as being from Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted, due to what it contains of Wisdom, and that it is only from Him Glory be to Him and Exalted because other than Him is incapable of anything of it. That indicates without doubt that He is One in His dominion, having no partner in anything of His affair. The completion of the proof for this is the story of the people of 'Yunus' peace be upon him, that when they believed at the signs of doom, He removed [punishment] from them. This proved decisively that the One bringing it is Allah in whom they believed. For if it were another, their belief in Him would have necessitated bringing [punishment] upon them. And if they were punished like others, it would have been said: This is the habit of time, just as they said 'Hardship and ease touched our fathers'. This indicated that the punishment of others among nations is only from Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted for their disbelief, due to the consistency of that directly with the conditions of all nations, that whenever persistence in denial is found, punishment is found, and inversely, whenever it is negated in a time accepting the acceptance of repentance, it is negated. And Allah is the Granter of success" (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This indicates that the exclusive attribution of "Yunus" peace be upon him to this Surah is a naming due to the news of lifting the punishment from his people because of their faith when witnessing the punishment, and their sincerity in their faith. It was from the overflow of the Self-Subsistence of the Truth (Al-Haqq) and that He is Doer of what He wills, and that He is the One who punishes whom He wills with what He wills and when He wills and for what He wills, for that is for a wisdom of which He is knowledgeable. He is the One who revealed this Wise Book which guides to that and narrates to us from those news what others did not narrate. So the One who brought Mercy from the punishment to the people of Yunus is the One who brought the Wise Book to His servant and Prophet Muhammad, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace. In the opening of Surah "Hud" peace be upon him, he explains the Greatest Objective saying: "Its objective is describing the Book with perfection and detailing in the two states of Good Tidings and Warning, necessitating for its Revealer, Glory be to Him and Exalted, placing everything in its most complete place and executing it whenever desired, necessitating the Power over everything." Then he explains the reason for naming it "Hud" peace be upon him, while many stories of Prophets were mentioned in it, and the story of "Hud" peace be upon him was mentioned in others and they were not named by it, saying: "The most suitable thing in it for this objective is what was mentioned in the context of the story of 'Hud' peace be upon him regarding the perfection of Good Tidings and Warning in the immediate and the future, and the declaration of decisiveness in handling by initiative looking towards the greatest pivots of the Surah {Then would you possibly leave [out] some of what is revealed to you, or is your breast constrained by it because they say, "Why has there not been sent down to him a treasure or come with him an angel?" But you are only a warner. And Allah is Disposer of all things} (Hud: 12) and the care for every creature and the Power over everything regarding Resurrection and other things necessitating Knowledge of every known thing necessitating Singularity in Dominion. And the reason for the exclusivity of each of them [Hud and Al-Ahqaf] with their names will come in 'Al-Ahqaf'" (1). In Surah Al-Ahqaf he says:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Its objective is warning the disbelievers by indicating the truth of the Promise regarding the establishment of the Hour, necessitating Might and Wisdom revealing them most completely by the occurrence of truth in the Promise of destroying the deniers with what contradicts the state of their lands [wind vs quiet dunes], and that nothing prevents anything of that; because the Doer of that has no partner, so He is deserving of being singled out for worship. Its naming as 'Al-Ahqaf' indicating calmness of wind and stillness of air indicated that, by what the story of the people of 'Hud' peace be upon him indicated of Tawhid and warning them of punishment in this world and the Hereafter and of their destruction and the lack of avail of what they worshipped for them. It is not correct to name it 'Hud' peace be upon him nor naming Surah 'Hud' peace be upon him 'Al-Ahqaf' due to what was mentioned of the objective of each of them" (1). *** In explaining the relationship of the name of Surah An-Nahl to its objective, he says after explaining that its Greatest Objective is: Providing evidence by blessings for the Oneness of Allah Almighty and the perfection of His Knowledge, Power, Choice, and Transcendence above impurities of deficiency: "The most indicative thing in it of this meaning is the matter of the Bee due to what was mentioned of its matter regarding accuracy of understanding in arranging its houses and feeding and its other affairs, the difference of colors of what comes out of it of its honeys and making it a healing, along with its eating from beneficial and harmful fruits and other matters. Its marking as 'The Blessings' is clear in that, and Allah knows best" (2). If you look at the verses speaking about the Bee in this Surah: {And your Lord inspired to the bee, "Take for yourself among the mountains, houses, and among the trees and [in] that which they construct. * Then eat from all the fruits and follow the ways of your Lord laid down [for you]." There emerges from their bellies a drink, varying in its colors, in which there is healing for people. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who give thought} (An-Nahl: 68-69),

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: You see that it began with the matter of Inspiration to the Bee. This in itself is a proof of perfection of Knowledge and perfection of Power to inspire what He wills and whom He wills. What was inspired to the Bee contains knowledge that achieves its security and happiness in its life, which is known and famous among humans, believer and disbeliever alike. If this is undoubted, then Inspiration to the Best of Creation must be greater in achieving the security of servants and their happiness in the Two Abodes. And no one does that except One God, Knowledgeable, Powerful, Choosing, Transcendent above impurities of deficiency. Contemplating the state of the Bee indicates clearly that the One who created it and inspired it is indeed the One, All-Knowing, All-Powerful, Chooser. So this verse and that blessing were among the strongest proofs for establishing the objective of the Surah, for you do not find anyone disputing the characteristics the Bee was specialized with, dazzling characteristics whose most apparent features are knowledge, order, and ability to achieve the desired. As for naming the Surah "An-Ni'am" (The Blessings), Al-Biqa'i suffices in its interpretation and justification by saying: "And its naming as The Blessings is clear in that." This clarity is like the clarity of naming it "An-Nahl" except that the direction of clarity is different: Clarity of indication in naming it An-Nahl is from what was known and famous among commoners and elite regarding the affair of the Bee which I pointed to before. And clarity of naming it "An-Ni'am" is from the abundance of mentioning blessings and favors in this Surah. It was from the Sunnah of the statement about these blessings to order it in a way indicating the exclusivity of the Truth, Mighty and Majestic, in doing that, like His saying Almighty: {It is He who sends down rain from the sky; from it is drink and from it is foliage in which you pasture [animals]} (An-Nahl: 10). Such a structure: defining both parties "He - Who" is useful for Exclusivity. As if it was said: No one sent down water from the sky except Him. This is a meaning of the meanings of "La ilaha illa Allah" (There is no deity but Allah) which is the title of Tawhid and Absolute Perfection.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: If we desired to enumerate the verses indicating Tawhid explicitly and implicitly in Surah An-Nahl, it would be possible to say that every verse in it is a rhetorical variation of the meaning of Tawhid, with no disparity in indication except in degrees of its clarity: overtness and concealment. *** It becomes clear to you from the above that Al-Biqa'i bases his interpretation on [the premise] that every Surah has a Universal Meaning dominating its partial meanings, which is to them like the mother to her children. And that this Universal Meaning is the distinguisher between Surahs. And that in the name of every Surah is an indication to its objective, an indication generated from the fact that that Name is linked firmly to that Universal Meaning dominating that Surah. Hence, the criterion for naming or its motive is not that the name was mentioned in that Surah as previously pointed out. The matter stems from and returns to the Universal Meaning dominating that Surah and what is hidden in that Name of indication to that dominating Universal Meaning. If literary critics in Al-Biqa'i's era and after him had invested this and searched for the Universal Meaning dominating the poem and chose for it a name indicating that dominating meaning, they would have opened for Literary Criticism a wide road and a wondrous path. --- The Third Feature. Interpreting the Basmalah according to the Surah's Objective. Among what the methodology of interpreting the Holy Qur'an according to Al-Biqa'i is based upon is that every word of the Holy Qur'an, if mentioned again with its letters in another context, what is repeated is only what the tongue pronounces. As for what the heart perceives of that uttered word repeated in another context, it is another matter whose perception has not occurred in the manner it is now. This is not specific to the word but [applies] to the sentence and verse. Therefore, he looks at the Basmalah as carrying in the opening of every Surah in which it came a meaning other than what it carried in the previous Surah. This means that the context in which the Basmalah stands has a great effect in words and structures carrying meanings that do not wear out with frequent repetition.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says: "And I interpret every Basmalah with what agrees with the objective of the Surah, and I do not depart from the meanings of its words" (1). In his interpretation of the Basmalah of every Surah, he turns to the three Beautiful Names: Allah, Al-Rahman, Al-Rahim, mentioning with every name what fits the content of the Surah of this Basmalah, provided he commits to pointing to the meaning of Gathering and Encompassment with the Name of Majesty (Allah), to the meaning of Generality and Breadth with His name "Al-Rahman", and to the meaning of Specification with His name "Al-Rahim". He says in the Basmalah of "Al-Imran": "(In the name of Allah) The One, Unique in Encompassing Perfection, (Al-Rahman) whose mercy of creating encompassed every creature and clarified for the legally responsible the path of salvation, (Al-Rahim) who chose the People of Tawhid for the place of His intimacy and the homeland of His gathering and holiness" (2). You notice here he pointed to the meaning of Oneness and Uniqueness in Encompassing Perfection in his interpretation of the Name of Majesty; because the objective of Surah "Al-Imran" is proving Oneness for Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted, and informing that worldly leadership is of no avail. He pointed in interpreting "Al-Rahman" to the meaning of the breadth of the mercy of creating for every creature, pointing to His Uniqueness, Majestic is His Glory. And he pointed in interpreting "Al-Rahim" to the meaning of choosing the People of Tawhid for closeness. In his interpretation of the Basmalah of Surah "An-Nisa", he says: "(In the name of Allah) The Gatherer of dispersed matters by perfecting the pairing in the subtleties of destiny, (Al-Rahman) who made wombs a general mercy, (Al-Rahim) who singled out whom He wanted for connection based on what His religion called to, which He made a complete blessing" (3). That is because the objective of Surah "An-Nisa": "Gathering on the Tawhid to which 'Al-Imran' guided and the Book to which Al-Baqarah urged for the sake of the Religion which Al-Fatihah gathered..." (4). The relationship between the Surah's objective and what "Al-Biqa'i" interpreted the Beautiful Names in its Basmalah with is not hidden. - - -

2. - Nazm al-Durar: 4/195

4. - Ibid: 5/ 169

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Let us look at his interpretation of the Basmalah of Surah "An-Nahl". I have previously explained that its Greatest Objective is: Providing evidence by blessings for the Oneness of Allah Almighty and the perfection of His Knowledge, Power, Choice. We see him say: "(In the name of Allah) Encompassing the Circle of Perfection, so whatever He wills He does, (Al-Rahman) whose blessing encompassed His great creation and His small creation, His little and His big, (Al-Rahim) who singled out whom He wills with the blessing of salvation from what angers Him to what pleases Him" (1). His saying (Encompassing the Circle of Perfection) instead of saying: (Encompassing Perfection) is an indication of the breadth of His encompassment of all types of perfection such that a circle surrounds them in which all types of perfection head towards the center of the circle, which is the Divine Essence. So you cannot define the first of the types of perfection nor their last, for everything contained in His verbal and active manifestation revolves in the circle of Divine Perfection. There is no doubt that this will not be unless the Center of Perfection is One. If He is One, He is Perfect in Knowledge and Power and Perfect in Choice, doing what He wills, transcendent above all impurities of deficiency. He explains the name (Al-Rahman) by his saying: (Whose blessing encompassed His great creation and His small creation, His little and His big) indicating that He is the One who bestowed upon Man and guided him to what stabilizes his livelihood and showed him the means of acquiring the necessities of his life and perfections, and He is the One who bestowed upon the most despicable creatures in size among beasts and insects that as well. Likewise, He is the Rahman who bestowed Revelation upon the most perfect of creation, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, containing the happiness of the Two Abodes, and He is the One who inspired the insect, the Bee, and inspired it with what contains its happiness and the happiness of others. No one can generalize that except One who is One, Perfect in Knowledge and Power, doing what He wills. And this is the objective of the Surah.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: You see him mentioning his saying (His great creation) first, and concluding with his saying (and His big [creation]). In this is a look from him at Circular Wrapping (Al-Laff Al-Da'iri). This is something Al-Biqa'i cared to look into, almost basing his view of Qur'anic Proportion on the basis of the theory of Circular Order of the statement, whether in the construction of the verse, passage, Surah, or the entire Holy Qur'an. He interprets the name (Al-Rahim) by his saying: "Who singled out whom He wills with the blessing of salvation from what angers Him to what pleases Him" indicating that He is the One who singled out the Prophet, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace, by revealing the Holy Qur'an to him (Verse 44) and by giving glad tidings of the Night Journey (Isra) (Verse 127), and singled out the Friend, the Father of Prophets Abraham peace be upon him, by making him a model for the Prophet Muhammad, may Allah bless him and his family and companions and grant them abundant peace (Verse 123), and singled out the Muslims with the Holy Qur'an as a methodology of life so He saved them from His wrath by the religion He was pleased with for them (Verse 89), and singled them out by permitting for them much of what He forbade for others (Verse 114), and singled them out by accepting Friday which others from the People of the Book before them rejected, so it was a blessing on the Muhammadan Ummah (Verse 124), and singled out the Bee with precision of understanding in engineering hives and caring for its affairs with a system from which humans derive much of their methodology (Verses 68-69). This can never be except from One, Perfect in Knowledge and Power, doing what He wills. Thus Al-Biqa'i's methodology in interpreting the meanings of the Basmalah in Surah An-Nahl becomes clear to you according to its Greatest Objective, which is the Universal Meaning that all its verses came to clarify in different ways regarding the clarity of their indication to it. *** When you look at this action of his, it becomes clear to you that what he interprets the Basmalah with is not deduced from the objective of the Surah, but rather he mentions meanings that align with that objective. His methodology in this specific topic is not a deductive methodology but a conciliatory one, mentioning what agrees with what became clear to him of that objective, all while adhering to the universal principles of the meanings of the three Names: "Allah", "Al-Rahman", and "Al-Rahim".

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Interpreting the Basmalah in every Surah differently from how it was interpreted in another Surah was not an innovation of "Al-Biqa'i". You encounter it in the Tafsir of "Imam Al-Qushayri: Abd al-Karim bin Hawazin bin Abd al-Malik" (d. 465) titled: "Lata'if al-Isharat", even if the interpretive methodology and its basis differ for each. "Al-Qushayri" says regarding the Basmalah of Surah "Al-Imran": "The People of Verification differed regarding the name 'Allah': Is it derived from a meaning or not?
