Many of them said it is not derived from a meaning, and it is for Him, Glory be to Him, by way of Exclusivity, functioning in its placement like proper nouns for the description of others. So if this word strikes the ears of the People of Gnosis, their understandings and knowledge do not go to a meaning other than His Existence, Glory be to Him and Exalted, and His Right. The right of this statement is to be accompanied by the witnessing of the heart. If he says with his tongue 'Allah' or hears with his ears, he witnesses with his heart 'Allah'. Just as this word does not indicate a meaning other than 'Allah', the witnessed of its speaker is none but 'Allah'. So he says with his tongue 'Allah', knows with his heart (Fu'ad) 'Allah', recognizes with his heart (Qalb) 'Allah', and loves with his spirit 'Allah'... So there is no share in him for other than 'Allah'. If he is on the verge of being annihilated (Mahw) in 'Allah' for 'Allah' by 'Allah', the Truth, Glory be to Him, overtakes him with His mercy, so He unveils to him His saying 'Al-Rahman Al-Rahim' to preserve their souls from perishing, and desiring for their hearts to be purified. Kindness is a Sunnah from Him, Glory be to Him and Exalted, lest His allies (Awliya) perish completely" (1). It is not hidden that "Al-Qushayri" focuses here on meanings of Unifying Allah, Majestic is His Glory, in remembrance, knowledge, worship, witnessing... etc., as if he observes the meaning of Tawhid in Surah "Al-Imran". As you see, he points out that mentioning His name "Al-Rahman Al-Rahim" comes as a mercy to the Allies from annihilation in the seas of the abstraction of Tawhid. This contradicts Al-Biqa'i's methodology in interpreting the Basmalah. "Al-Qushayri" says in interpreting the Basmalah of Surah "An-Nisa":
foot_note: 1. (1) - Lata'if al-Isharat by Al-Qushayri: Vol 1 pp 217-218 - Ibrahim Basyuni - Egyptian General Book Authority.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "They differed regarding the Name: from what was it derived? Some of them said it was derived from 'Sumuw', which is Elevation. Others said it is derived from 'Simah', which is the Brand/Mark. Both are in the allusion (Ishara): Whoever said it is derived from 'Sumuw', it is a name of One whom whoever remembers Him, his rank elevates; whoever knows Him, his state elevates; whoever accompanies Him, his ambition elevates. Elevation of rank necessitates abundance of rewards and kindnesses; elevation of state necessitates appearance of lights in the secrets; elevation of ambition necessitates guarding against the slavery of others. Whoever said its origin is from 'Simah', it is a name of One whom whoever seeks Him is marked with the mark of Worship; whoever accompanies Him is marked with the mark of Will (Murid); whoever loves Him is marked with the mark of the Elite; whoever knows Him is marked with the mark of Specialization. The mark of Worship necessitates the awe of Fire to throw its sparks at its owner. The mark of Will necessitates the modesty of Gardens to covet enslaving its owner despite its noble worth. The mark of the Elite necessitates the fall of self-admiration regarding entitlement to closeness for water and clay in general. The mark of Specialization necessitates the erasure of judgment upon the seizure of the authority of Reality. It is said: A name of One whom whoever connects with, His destiny, Glory be to Him, elevates in his view above illusions; and whoever disconnects from Him, his heart is marked with the brand of separation" (1). "Al-Qushayri", as you see, made the basis of interpretation in the Basmalah of "An-Nisa" the derivation of the word "Al-Ism" and the allusive indication of this derivation. It is as if I see him observing in this the meaning of the derivation of offspring from wombs and observing the meaning of the saying of Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted: {O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both of them many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer} (An-Nisa: 1). The generation of meanings from the root of derivation establishes between them a semantic womb (kinship) like the womb existing between the offspring of our father Adam, peace be upon him.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And when you look into his interpretation of the Basmalah of Surah "Al-Hijr", you hear him saying: "The Alif of connection (Wasl) fell from the writing of 'Bismillah', and there is no cause for its falling. And an increase was made in the length of the 'Ba' of 'Bismillah' and there is no cause for its increase; to make known that affirmation and dropping are without cause. He who was accepted was not accepted for deserving a cause, nor was he who was rejected rejected for necessitating a cause. If it is said: The cause for dropping the Alif from 'Bismillah' is frequent usage in its writing, it is problematic that the 'Ba' of 'Bismillah' was increased in its writing while frequent usage exists. If it is said: In increasing the length of the 'Ba' is the blessing of its favors, it is problematic due to the deletion of the Alif of connection; because connection is present through it. Thus, nothing remains except that Affirmation and Negation have no cause; He raises whom He wills and prevents whom He wills" (1). He made the basis of interpretation here the orthographic aspect of the Basmalah: dropping a letter and increasing the shape of another adjacent letter, noting the absence of a rational Arabic cause such that the effect is realized where the cause is realized. He explained that the matter belongs to absolute Divine Will, and that there are no causes by whose existence effects exist, but there are means where effects exist *at* them, not *by* them. There is a difference between a thing being *by* a thing and being *at* (in the presence of) a thing. As if in his choice to point to this meaning in interpreting the Basmalah of Surah Al-Hijr, he is looking at His saying, Mighty and Majestic, in it: {And there is not a thing but that with Us are its depositories, and We do not send it down except according to a known measure} (Al-Hijr: 21). As if this verse is the Mother Verse and the Axis Verse upon which the Holy Qur'anic meaning in Surah Al-Hijr revolves. The important thing is that interpreting the Basmalah of every Surah differently from how it was interpreted in another is a methodology that some people of knowledge brought before "Al-Biqa'i", and each has his way in interpretation. What is taken from all this is that those adopting that way in interpretation proceed from a matter of value in the Rhetorical Jurisprudence of speech:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: They proceed from the desire to avoid saying there is verbal and semantic repetition of words in different contexts, and that the word and what is above it only comes once and has only one position. If it is established in another station, it is not the one that was before. This means that the semantic existence of the word renews with the renewal of the locations of the word and what is above it, and that the claim of rhetorical repetition in high speech, let alone the miraculous High Speech, is a claim lacking scientific verification. Hence, the world of Rhetoric does not know copying (Tanasukh) between its components and contents. It is a world composed of renewing elements. As if the world of Rhetoric is from the world of Paradise, for example: its fruits resemble each other but do not become identical, rather they renew and multiply: {Every time they are fed with a fruit from it, they say, "This is what we were fed with before," and it is given to them in resemblance. And for them therein are purified spouses, and they will abide therein eternally} (Al-Baqarah: from Verse 25). Based on this, it is worthy for one who undertakes to sail in the dictionaries of Rhetorical Interpretation of the Holy Qur'an to be aware that the Qur'anic statement is void of emphatic repetition that does not add something new and praiseworthy to what was previously founded. And to be aware that the Qur'anic statement has two great characteristics: First: The characteristic of generation of Qur'anic meaning and its escalation. And the Other: The characteristic of Rhetorical Distribution (Tasrif). These two characteristics I see as among the most comprehensive characteristics of the Rhetorical Miraculousness of the Holy Qur'an after the characteristic of establishing the feeling of the majesty of the Speaker in the heart of the receiver who is healed from the disease of heedlessness. The Fourth Feature. The Brilliant Opening and its Relationship to the Surah's Objective. Every Surah of the Holy Qur'an, especially the Long Ones (Tiwl) and the Hundreds (Mi'un), has an opening from verses which is a brilliant exordium indicating the essence of the Universal Meaning existing in the Surah.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: If we have seen him interpreting the Basmalah in a way fitting the Surah's objective as an indication that there is a Brilliant Opening in the Basmalah, just as he sees in the Surah's name a brilliant opening of its Universal Meaning and Greatest Objective as previously indicated, then above this is the opening of the first verses of the Surah with its meaning. Thus, in every Surah, there is what points to its Universal Meaning: its Name, its Basmalah, and the first verse or verses of it. It is predominant for Al-Biqa'i not to specify the opening of the Surah and its exordium for us, but he alludes to that during his interpretation. Also, the specification might be understood from the place where he mentions what he quotes in the opening of every Surah from the speech of "Abu Ja'far bin al-Zubair" regarding the proportion of Surahs from his book "Al-Burhan". The matter becomes clearer at the conclusion of his interpretation of the Surah when he returns the Surah's segment (end) to its opening. In Surah "Al-Baqarah", its opening is from its beginning to His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {Those are on guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful} (Al-Baqarah: 5). What follows it of mentioning those who disbelieve and the hypocrites is a completion of the exordium, so that the subject of the Surah begins with His saying Glory be to Him {O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous} (Al-Baqarah: 21). This opening contains an exordium with the Surah's Greatest Objective: "Establishing the evidence that the Book is guidance to be followed in everything it says, and the greatest thing it guides to is Belief in the Unseen." This is what the Opening focused on as is not hidden, for it explicitly made the basis and origin of the attributes of the Pious—for whom the Book was guidance—Belief in the Unseen. It made the head of their attributes in the first verse of describing the Pious: "and out of what We have provided them, they spend," and made the head of their attributes in the second verse of describing the Pious that "and of the Hereafter they are certain."

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Spending in the cause of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, seeking reward is but the fruit of Belief in the Unseen. And belief in the Hereafter is but belief in the Unseen of which there is no way to know anything except from the reporting of the Book or the Sunnah. In the Exordium (Istihlal) are main sentences explicitly stating the Objective. If the contemplator is guided to visualize them, the path to understanding the Surah's Greatest Objective becomes paved. Therefore, you see him in Surah Al-Baqarah pointing out that the incitement to spending has appeared clearly in several places of the Surah. You see him pointing out, when interpreting the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic: {They ask you what they should spend. Say, "Whatever you spend of good is for parents and relatives and orphans and the needy and the traveler. And whatever you do of good - indeed, Allah is Knowing of it."} (Al-Baqarah: 215), that there is an indication to Spending in the beginning of the Surah, saying: ... "Since Spending is among the fundamentals upon which the Surah was built regarding the attributes of the believers [the pious] (and out of what We have provided them, they spend) (Al-Baqarah: 3), then He repeated encouraging it in the folds of verses until He commanded it in the first verses of Hajj passed recently, although it is among the pillars of the beginnings of Jihad, until the previous verse contained it along with fighting which is the end of Jihad. This was the place of asking about them, so He Almighty informed about that by way of 'Irregular Spreading' (Nashr Mushawwash)..." (1). It is clear that spending seeking reward for the sake of Allah, Mighty and Majestic, is only adopted by one who believes in the Unseen; otherwise, his spending would not be 'seeking reward' (Ihtisab), and thus void in the scale of Law. He confirms the like of what I quoted from him here in interpreting the saying of Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted: {Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan so He may multiply it for him many times over? And it is Allah who withholds and grants abundance, and to Him you will be returned} (Al-Baqarah: 245).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Saying: "Since Spending, which is one of the greatest objectives of the Surah, is the firmest pillar of Jihad, and the strongest verifier of Faith and realizer of the pledge to the King, the Judge, He repeated the incitement to it in a manner more eloquent in encouragement than what passed..." (1). And when interpreting the saying of Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted: {O you who have believed, spend from that which We have provided for you before there comes a Day in which there is no exchange and no friendship and no intercession. And the disbelievers - they are the wrongdoers} (Al-Baqarah: 254), he says: "Since differing over Prophets was a cause for Jihad which is the Enclosure of Religion, and the pillar of Jihad is Spending, He followed that by His saying—returning to the beginning of the Surah from here to its end, and to emphasizing with the word of Command regarding what He previously encouraged of the matter of Spending—(O you who have believed)" (2). *** In Surah "Al-Imran", we find the Opening of the Surah from its beginning to the end of the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic {And Allah is Exalted in Might, Owner of Retribution} (Al-Imran: from Verse 4). In this Opening is care for portraying and establishing the meaning of Oneness for Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted, and informing that worldly leadership is of no avail in this world or the Hereafter. That is the Greatest Objective of the Surah. As you see, it is apparent to you from the saying of Allah, Majestic is His Glory, in the Opening: {Alif, Lam, Mim * Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence} (Al-Imran: 1-2) and from the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic: {...Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah will have a severe punishment, and Allah is Exalted in Might, Owner of Retribution} (Al-Imran: 4). These two sentences signal the Greatest Objective of the Surah to one who has insight in understanding the statement of the Wise Reminder about its meanings. *** In Surah "An-Nisa", you find the Opening of the Surah from its beginning to the end of His saying Glory be to Him and Exalted:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer} (An-Nisa: from Verse 1). For in this Opening is what explicitly states the objective of the Surah, such as His saying, Majestic is His Glory: {created you from one soul} and His saying Glory be to Him and Exalted: {through whom you ask one another, and the wombs} and His saying, Majestic is His Glory: {Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer}. These sentences are like explicit declarations of the meaning of Gathering upon a great matter, and the greatest thing to gather upon is the Tawhid of Allah Glory be to Him and Exalted. It is a gathering that achieves the meaning of uterine connection by which human existence stands. This is the Greatest Objective of Surah An-Nisa, to begin the detailing of the statement about this objective by His saying: "And give the orphans... etc." (1). You see the Surah has established rulings and etiquettes that guide to realizing the firm, merciful, cohesive structure of the family and the nation, so it gathers upon what pleases its Lord, Mighty and Majestic. Al-Biqa'i compares the opening of this Surah with the saying of Allah Almighty: {O mankind, fear your Lord, who created you from one soul and created from it its mate and dispersed from both of them many men and women. And fear Allah, through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer} (An-Nisa: 1) with the opening of Surah "Al-Hajj" with the saying of Allah Almighty: {O mankind, fear your Lord. Indeed, the convulsion of the [final] Hour is a terrible thing} (Al-Hajj: 1). And how the objective of every Surah is what required that the description of the Lord commanded to be feared in the beginning of every Surah be different from what He was described with in the other. Rather, he looks at the position of every Surah in the extended Qur'anic context. He says in interpreting the opening of Surah "An-Nisa": "He, Glory be to Him, made the command of Taqwa (Fear/Piety) an opening for two Surahs: This one, which is the fourth of the first half, and Hajj, which is the fourth of the second half. He justified the command of Taqwa in this one with what indicated the perfection of His Power, comprehensiveness of His Knowledge, and perfection of His Wisdom regarding the matter of the Origin (Al-Mabda').

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And He justified that in Hajj with what portrayed the Return (Al-Ma'ad) in a depiction upon which there is no addition. Thus, He indicated in them the Origin and the Return, alerting that it is the focus of Wisdom; existence was created only for its sake; so that the Beautiful Names and Lofty Attributes appear with the most complete appearance humans can view. He arranged that in the most precise arrangement, so He advanced the Surah of Origin over the Surah of Return; so that the recited verses would be congruent with the seen verses" (1). *** Al-Biqa'i has good attention to the Brilliant Opening of the five Surahs with "Al-Hamdu lillah" (Praise be to Allah). They are the Surahs: Al-Fatihah, Al-An'am, Al-Kahf, Saba, and Fatir. And how the objective of every Surah required that it opens with other than what the other opens with, even if they share starting with 'Al-Hamdu lillah'. In this, he relies on a statement by "Al-Sa'd Al-Taftazani" in the introduction of his book "Al-Talwih 'ala Sharh Al-Tanqih" in Hanafi principles of jurisprudence by Sadr al-Shari'ah. Al-Biqa'i quoted it from him in his interpretation of Surah Al-Fatihah saying: "And it was indicated in 'The Mother of the Book' - as the scholar Sa'd al-Din Mas'ud bin Umar Al-Taftazani Al-Shafi'i said - to all blessings. For they return to Creation (Ijad) and Preservation (Ibqa') first, and to Creation and Preservation second in the Abode of Annihilation and the Abode of Survival. As for the First Creation, it is by His saying Glory be to Him and Exalted {Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds} (Al-Fatihah: 2), for bringing out from non-existence to existence is the greatest nurturing. As for the First Preservation, it is by His saying Mighty and Majestic: {The Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful} meaning the Bestower of major blessings and their subtleties by which survival is. As for the Second Creation, it is by His saying, Majestic is His Glory {Master of the Day of Judgment}, and it is apparent. As for the Second Preservation, it is by His saying: {It is You we worship} to its end, for the benefits of that return to the Hereafter. Then the exportation with Praise came after Al-Fatihah in four Surahs; in each Surah of them, one of these blessings was indicated according to their arrangement." (2).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: So Al-Fatihah "Mother of the Book" gathers the indication to everything for which Praise is due to Allah. Then the four universal causes of Praise are distributed, each cause in a Surah, and these Surahs are coordinated according to the arrangement of causes. So Surah Al-An'am opens with Praise to Allah for the blessing of the First Creation: {Praise be to Allah, who created the heavens and the earth and made the darkness and the light. Then those who disbelieve equate [others] with their Lord. * It is He who created you from clay, then He decreed a term and a specified time [known] to Him; then [still] you are in doubt} (Al-An'am: 1-2). And Surah "Al-Kahf" opens with Praise for the blessing of the First Preservation, the highest of which is the blessing of revealing the Book: {Praise be to Allah, who has sent down upon His Servant the Book and has not made therein any deviance. * [He has made it] straight, to warn of severe punishment from Him and to give good tidings to the believers who do righteous deeds that they will have a good reward * In which they will remain forever * And to warn those who say, "Allah has taken a son." * They have no knowledge of it, nor had their fathers. Grave is the word that comes out of their mouths; they speak not except a lie} (Al-Kahf: 1-5). And Surah "Saba" opens with Praise to Allah for the blessing of the Second Creation (Resurrection).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {[All] praise is [due] to Allah, to whom belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth, and to Him belongs [all] praise in the Hereafter. And He is the Wise, the Acquainted. * He knows what penetrates into the earth and what emerges from it and what descends from the heaven and what ascends therein. And He is the Merciful, the Forgiving. * But those who disbelieve say, "The Hour will not come to us." Say, "Yes, by my Lord, it will surely come to you. [Allah is] the Knower of the unseen." Not absent from Him is an atom's weight within the heavens or within the earth or [what is] smaller than that or greater, except that it is in a clear register - * That He may reward those who believe and do righteous deeds. Those will have forgiveness and noble provision. * But those who strive against Our verses [seeking] to cause failure - for them will be a painful punishment of foul nature. * And those who have been given knowledge see that what is revealed to you from your Lord is the truth, and it guides to the path of the Exalted in Might, the Praiseworthy. * But those who disbelieve say, "Shall we guide you to a man who will inform you that when you have disintegrated in complete disintegration, you will then be [recreated] in a new creation? * Has he invented about Allah a lie, or is there in him madness?" Rather, they who do not believe in the Hereafter will be in the punishment and [are in] extreme error. * Then, do they not look at what is before them and what is behind them of the heaven and earth? If We should will, We could cause the earth to swallow them or [could] let fall upon them fragments from the sky. Indeed in that is a sign for every servant turning back [to Allah].} (Saba: 1-9). And Surah "Fatir" opens with Praise to Allah for the blessing of the second origination (the Recompense).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {[All] praise is [due] to Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth, [who] made the angels messengers having wings, two or three or four. He increases in creation what He wills. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent. * Whatever Allah grants to people of mercy - none can withhold it; and whatever He withholds - none can release it thereafter. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.} (Fatir: 1-2). In every Surah, there is scattered evidence pointing to the cause of the Praise with which it begins, according to the arrangement. The context here does not allow for a detailed discussion of this, and I have detailed it in my doctoral dissertation: "Quranic Proportionality according to Al-Biqa'i". In the opening of each of the four Surahs starting with "Al-Hamd" (Praise be to Allah), there is an indication of the Surah's content and its objective, based on the order of the blessings for which Allah Almighty is praised, which are comprehensive, universal blessings. The attention to interpreting the opening of the Surah and its indication of its greatest objective stems from the belief that the Quranic Surah is based on a total meaning that dominates all components of the Surah, and that the opening of the Surah guides to the hidden meanings within it. This methodology in interpretation is one of the fundamentals of Arab theory in understanding rhetoric. The scholars of Arabic paid attention to this chapter; some critics advised writers: "Improve, O assembly of writers, the openings, for they are the indicators of the statement" (1). The Fifth Feature: Returning the End (Maqta') of the Surah to its Opening (Matla'). Al-Biqa'i establishes his methodology in interpreting Quranic rhetoric on the basis that the structure of the Quranic Surah is like the structure of a continuous circle whose ends are joined together in a fusion where no joint is visible between its beginning and its end. Nay, there is no beginning and no end, nor joining nor mending, but rather there is casting and molding.
foot_note: 1. (1) - Al-Sina'atayn by Abu Hilal Al-Askari: 489 - Ed: Mufid Qamihah - Beirut. See also: Introduction to Tafsir Ibn al-Naqib: pp. 286-287 - Ed: Zakariya Saeed, Al-Khanji Library, Cairo; Al-Mutawwal by Al-Saad Al-Taftazani: 478-480.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In his book "Masa'id al-Nazar lil-Ishraf 'ala Maqasid al-Suwar" (The Ascending Steps of View for Overseeing the Objectives of the Surahs), he states that "Every Surah has a single objective around which its beginning and end revolve, and evidence is provided for it within. The premises indicating it are arranged in the most precise manner and the most creative approach. If there is something in it that requires proof, it is proven, and so on for the proof of the proof, and so forth. When the matter reaches its conclusion, it concludes with what the beginning started from. Then the speech bends back to it, and the view returns to it, on a creative path and a formidable ascent different from the first. Thus, the Surah becomes like a verdant, tall tree and a delightful, elegant, adorned dome, decorated with types of ornaments organized after the elegance of leaves with branches of pearls. Its branches bend back to those cut-off points like circles. Each circle among them has a branch connected to what is before it, and a branch fused with what is after it. The end of the Surah has joined its beginning just as its termination has soldered to what follows it, and its commencement has embraced what preceded it. So every Surah became like a great circle comprising circles of verses, radiant in arrangement, wondrous in assembly, with the gentleness of the sympathy of its branches and the goodness of the connection of its fruits and boughs" (1). The statement of the circular structure of the Surah does not contradict the statement of the ascent of meaning in its construction on one hand, nor the ascent in the entire Holy Quranic context. This is because the ascent is not based on a cumulative pattern but on a generative methodology. This considers that meanings in the Quranic Surah procreate to circle around a single axis, which is the axis of the circle that Al-Biqa'i calls: The Greatest Objective. So every Surah is like a circle whose meanings generate and ascend to form a circle, and the other Surah is a circle whose generated, ascending meanings revolve around an axis (Greatest Objective) built upon an axis (Greatest Objective) around which the generated, ascending meanings in the preceding Surah revolved. And you hear him affirming that in what I quoted to you from his explanation in his book "Masa'id al-Nazar".

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He pays great attention to contemplating and interpreting the relationship of the Surah's recitation ending (Maqta' al-Tartil) with its reading opening (Matla' al-Tilawah), and revealing to you the landmarks of closeness between the two meanings existing in the Opening and the Ending. Our saying "two meanings" does not mean they differ by separation, but means they vary in degrees of clarification, depiction, and rhetorical derivation; otherwise, in every meaning, there is a single dominant universal. They are, in the world of Quranic rhetoric, like the relationship of the firstborn child in labor to his sibling who is last in birth. I have indicated before that by our saying (Matla') we mean the opening of the reading, and by our saying (Maqta') we mean the ending of the recitation/arrangement; they are two terms not intended to denote the relationship of meanings to each other per se, but rather looking at the matter of reading and recitation. Al-Biqa'i did not leave any Surah, even if its number of words and verses were few, without explaining the relationship of its ending in arrangement to its opening in reading. There is no difference for him in this between the shortest Surah (Al-Kawthar) and the longest Surah (Al-Baqarah). In his interpretation, he does not look at the general meaning of the Opening and the Ending, but looks at the essence of the meaning linked to the axis of the Surah (its Greatest Objective). For the general meanings of the verses of the Surah might not show the landmarks of their proportionality and generation from the Greatest Objective to the passing glance, but the essence of the meaning and its spirit is what the contemplator sees the landmarks of proportionality between them on one hand, and generation from the Greatest Objective on the other. In his interpretation of returning the ending of Surah "Al-Baqarah" to its "opening", he says when interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty {The Messenger has believed in what was revealed to him from his Lord, and the believers...} (Al-Baqarah: from verse 285): "As for its appropriateness to the beginning of the Surah by returning the ending to the opening, it is that when He began the Surah by describing the believers with the Book in which there is no doubt in the manner that preceded, He concluded it with that after detailing the spending with which He described them in its beginning, in a manner that connects to what preceded of commands and prohibitions and characterizing with attributes of perfection in the strongest connection.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And He made the Messenger (peace be upon him) their head to honor the praise and encourage that description. So He informed of their belief in what was revealed to him specifically and in all Books and all Messengers, and of their statement indicating complete desire and the utmost humility and submission. So He said, resuming as an answer to one who seemed to say: 'What did he do upon whom these commands and prohibitions and others were revealed?' (The Messenger believed)..." (1) Then he says after interpreting the last two verses in the arrangement: ... "And it has become clear by mentioning the Revelation, belief in it, and victory over the disbelievers after detailing the matter of expenditure and the wealth that is spent from, the return of its ending to its opening, and its last to its first" (2). The proportionality between what Surah Al-Baqarah opened with in reading—speaking about the Holy Quran, belief in it, spending, guidance, and success—and what it concluded with in arrangement—speaking about the belief of the Messenger (peace be upon him) and the belief of the believers in the Holy Quran, their conduct, and what they have—is evident. You do not see artificiality in stating it or pointing to it, nor ambiguity in explaining its landmarks. Everyone of insight whom you alert pays attention and finds rest, while people of deep insight are in no need of alerting and indication. And its relationship to the objective of the Surah, which is establishing belief in the Unseen—the highest of which is belief in Allah Almighty and belief in the Last Day and what is in it—is not hidden. For its end establishes belief in what was revealed, belief in Allah, the Angels, the Books they did not see, and belief in the Messengers they did not meet, making no distinction between any of them out of certainty in the truth of the news about them. All of this is belief in the Unseen. This supplication, invocation, and hope for salvation on the Day of Resurrection is from belief in the Unseen. Thus, the proportionality of the Surah's recitation ending with its reading opening becomes clear to you on one hand, and their generation from the Greatest Objective on the other. *** And in Surah "Al-A'raf", he does not suffice with returning the last verse or two to the opening of the Surah, but returns twenty-eight verses from its end to its beginning.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He begins returning its ending, which starts with the saying of Allah Almighty: {And We have certainly created for Hell many of the jinn and mankind. They have hearts with which they do not understand, they have eyes with which they do not see, and they have ears with which they do not hear. Those are like livestock; rather, they are more astray. It is they who are the heedless} (Al-A'raf: 179) to its opening, saying after explaining the relationship of the last four verses to the opening of the Surah: "...And the end of the Surah has returned to commanding the following of the Quran to its beginning in the best return, and to describing the closest ones [angels/believers] with lack of arrogance and persistence in the duties of submission, to describing Iblis with disobeying the command of Allah Almighty in prostrating to Adam (peace be upon him) by way of arrogance—what a turn of attention! Rather, he began returning the End to the Opening when he completed the stories of the Prophets. So His saying Almighty {And We have certainly created...} (Al-A'raf: 179) is [corresponds to] His saying: {And that which is bad - nothing emerges but sparsely} (Al-A'raf: from verse 58). This will become clear to you if you review what I presented regarding the intended meaning thereof. And {And to Allah belong the best names, so invoke Him by them. And leave [the company of] those who practice deviation concerning His names. They will be recompensed for what they have been doing} (Al-A'raf: 180) is His saying Almighty {Call upon your Lord in humility and privately; indeed, He does not like transgressors} (Al-A'raf: 55). And His saying Almighty {And among those We created is a community which guides by truth and thereby establishes justice} (Al-A'raf: 181) is His saying, Majestic is His Majesty: {But those who believed and did righteous deeds - We charge no soul except [within] its capacity. Those are the companions of Paradise; they will abide therein eternally} (Al-A'raf: 42).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And [{And those who denied Our signs - We will gradually lead them to punishment from where they do not know} (Al-A'raf: 182) is] {But those who deny Our verses and are arrogant toward them - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally} (Al-A'raf: 36). And His saying Almighty: {...and that perhaps their term has come close. So in what statement hereafter will they believe?} (Al-A'raf: from verse 185) is His saying Almighty: {...So when their time has come, they will not remain behind an hour, nor will they precede [it]} (Al-A'raf: from verse 34). And His saying - Almighty: {They ask you, [O Muhammad], about the Hour: when is its arrival? Say, "Its knowledge is only with my Lord. None will reveal its time except Him. It lays heavily upon the heavens and the earth. It will not come upon you except unexpectedly." They ask you as if you are familiar with it. Say, "Its knowledge is only with Allah, but most of the people do not know."} (Al-A'raf: 187) is His saying, Majestic is His Majesty: {...Just as He began you, you will return} (Al-A'raf: from verse 29). And His saying Almighty: {It is He who created you from one soul and created from it its mate that he might dwell in security with her. And when he covers her, she carries a light burden and continues therein. And when it becomes heavy, they both invoke Allah, their Lord, "If You should give us a good [child], we will surely be among the grateful."} (Al-A'raf: 189) is His saying Almighty: {And We have certainly created you, [O mankind], and given you [human] form. Then We said to the angels, "Prostrate to Adam"; so they prostrated, except for Iblis. He was not of those who prostrated.} (Al-A'raf: 11).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And His saying Almighty: {...Say, "I only follow what is revealed to me from my Lord. This [Qur'an] is enlightenment from your Lord and guidance and mercy for a people who believe."} (Al-A'raf: from verse 203) to its end, after warning against peers (idols), is His saying Almighty: {...[This is] a Book revealed to you, - so let there not be in your breast distress therefrom - that you may warn thereby and as a reminder to the believers.} (Al-A'raf: 2) to His saying, Majestic is His Majesty: {...and do not follow other than Him any allies. Little do you remember.} (Al-A'raf: from verse 3). So Glory be to Him whose speech this is, and exalted is His veil, and mighty is His desire, and upon whom it was revealed be His blessings, peace, greeting, and honor" (1). His essay on returning the recitation ending of Surah "Al-A'raf" to its opening is clear; a person of perception does not need [much] to discern the truth of his doctrine and method. Every verse from the Ending meets its counterpart from the Opening in its apparent meaning which is hardly hidden from a viewer or listener. And if this is his case with the two longest Surahs: Al-Baqarah and Al-A'raf, returning the recitation ending of each to its opening, then I look at his case in returning the recitation ending of the shortest Surah in the Holy Quran to its opening: Surah "Al-Kawthar". "Al-Biqa'i" explains in the opening of his interpretation of it that its objective is "The grant of every good that can be." Then he explains the initiation of "Al-Kawthar" with the saying of Allah Almighty: {Indeed, We have granted you, [O Muhammad], al-Kawthar} and its relationship to Surah "Al-Din: Al-Ma'un", saying: "Since Surah 'Al-Din', by its clear statement, was forbidding bad morals, it was by its implication calling to high character traits. So 'Al-Kawthar' came for that.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: [Meaning that the clear statement of Al-Kawthar is an affirmation of the implication of Al-Ma'un]. And 'Al-Din' had concluded with the stingiest of misers and the lowest of traits: Withholding, to alienate from stinginess and from the denial it brings. So 'Al-Kawthar' began with the most generous generosity and giving to the most noble of creatures to encourage it and call to it [Meaning that the clear statement of Al-Kawthar is opposite to the clear statement of Al-Ma'un]. So it was as if it was said: You, O best of creation, are not clothed in anything of what that [Surah] concluding with withholding assistance (Al-Ma'un) forbade (Indeed, We have granted you... Al-Kawthar) which is part of the generosity towards those who believe in the Day of Judgment." (1) The relationship of Al-Kawthar to Al-Din becomes clear to you, and that it is a relationship of contrast between the clear statements of the two Surahs on one hand, and correspondence between the clear statement of Al-Kawthar and the implication of "Al-Din" on the other. And it becomes clear to you that the initiation of "Al-Kawthar" with clear statement establishes the Divine Giving to the Prophet (peace be upon him). If you look at its conclusion {Indeed, your enemy is the one cut off}, you see in the structure of its arrangement an indication that cutting off and prevention from every sensory and moral good is specific to the enemy of the Honored, Revered One (peace be upon him). This implies that he (peace be upon him) is the one connected to the magnificent giving, granted every possible good. So what its recitation ending conveyed is what the clear statement of its reading opening indicated, thus the glorious proportionality between the Ending and the Opening was achieved. Al-Biqa'i says: "When He commanded him to occupy time in worshiping the Creator and doing good to the creatures with the highest character, He justified it with what implies that he has no distraction nor any need that befalls him at all. So He said: {Indeed, your enemy... is} i.e., specifically {the one cut off (Al-Abtar)} meaning cut off from his root, cut off from offspring, destitute, and cut off from good, blessing, and mention; no one succeeds him to take care of his affairs or mention him, even if he gathered wealth and emptied his body for every beauty. While you are of connected command, famous mention, and raised status. So do not pay attention to them in any way, for they are less than to be cared about by one who empties himself to attain standing in Our Noble Presence...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: So the last verse is the result; because part of Al-Kawthar (Abundance) is the elevation of his affair and the affair of those who love him and his followers in the kingdom of the heavens and earth and the river of Paradise, and the lowness of his enemy's status in them. Thus, as you see, its joint has wrapped around its connection, and its end is known from its beginning, and it is known that its middle is like the middle terms [in logic], embracing the first by being of its fruits, and connected to the other because it is of the goals of its track" (1). The concept of returning the Ending to the Opening, or the 'Ajuz (last foot) to the Sadr (first foot) as rhetoricians say, is something the creative eloquent ones in the world of high expression cared for in the past, and rhetorical critics drew attention to its value. "Ibn al-Mu'tazz" made it in his book: "Al-Badi'" the fourth pillar or chapter of the five chapters of Badi' upon which he established his book Al-Badi'. If the attention of rhetoricians in this style was towards the correspondence of a word in the end of the verse or paragraph with another that preceded it—a correspondence in pronunciation that might be combined with correspondence in concept (meaning) or might not—then the matter here with Al-Biqa'i goes beyond phonetic correspondence first to semantic correspondence. And the correspondence goes beyond the scope of the word to a wider scope that may reach several verses. In this, there is a transfer of the style of returning endings to beginnings from verbal embellishment among the Badi' scholars to the Arrangement Order (*Nazm Tartibi*) based on the relationships of meanings to each other according to "Al-Biqa'i", and that type of Order is the Exalted, the Praiseworthy. *** The Sixth Feature. Relationships of Verses in the Construction of the Node (*Ma'qid*). The Quranic Surah, in its circular structure whose parts are generated from a main axis: {Greatest Objective} around which it revolves and which dominates its components and contents, consists of nodes, and each node consists of proportionate, generated verses. I have indicated before that the Surah in Quranic expression is composed of nodes (*Ma'aqid*), and each node is composed of verses, and each verse of sentences, and each sentence of words. The status of the word to the sentence is the status of the organ to the individual, and the status of the sentence to the verse is the status of the individual to the family.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And the status of the verse to the Node is the status of the family to the clan (Batn), and the status of the Node to the Surah is the status of the clan to the tribe, and the status of the Surah to the Quran is the status of the tribe to the human race. And that the Holy Quranic expression has a Greatest Objective from which Quranic meanings generate and to which they belong. I said this is only an approximation, not a depiction, for how can what belongs to the World of Command be depicted by what belongs to the World of Creation? If we have looked at the construction of Quranic expression in terms of Surahs and the relationship of Surahs to each other: objectives, endings, and openings, and we have looked at the establishment of Quranic expression in Surahs upon a central axis around which the meanings of the Surah revolve, and we have explained "Al-Biqa'i's" methodology in interpreting the ascent of meaning in the Surah as you heard in his interpretation of the construction of expression in Surah "Al-Baqarah", then we shall look at the construction of the Node from verses and the interconnection or proportionality of these verses. Al-Biqa'i in his interpretation does not resort to satisfying himself with linking the verse to the one immediately following it in reading; rather, he may look and see the proportionality of a verse to a verse preceding it in reading with several verses between them. Rhetoricians and exegetes before had attention to what is known as conjoining story upon story. The statement of conjunction in the correlation of verses is not the unique methodology in this correlation, for the relationships of verses go beyond what can be termed as Attachment (*Ta'liq* / tying) where a linguistic factor is responsible for that tie or attachment, to Interlocking (*Ta'aluq* / mutual bond) where a moral, internal factor is responsible for that interlocking. In their naming of this type of attachment as "Conjunction" (*'Atf* - also meaning sympathy/affection) is a subtle meaning: as if meanings sympathize with each other, like the sympathy of a loving mother for her newborn or a lover for his beloved. Relationships exist between the conjoined and the conjoined-to, and there is nothing in life that sympathizes with something it has no connection with. So is the matter in the world of Expression, as it is the world of Man; methodologies, doctrines, and landmarks of beauty approximate in each.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Among relationships are those of symmetry, some of support, and some of sympathy. So relationships of meanings vary, and their tools vary. If we were to look into rhetorical and linguistic terminology in the field of meaning relationships to see the semantic differences between them, their variety, and what they converge upon, this would enrich the jurisprudence of relations of expression, choosing for each type of relationship between meanings the term most specific and appropriate to it. The important thing is that "Al-Biqa'i" quotes from "Al-Harralli": "That in every verse there is a meaning by which it is organized with what precedes it, and a meaning by which it is prepared to be organized with what follows it. Thereby, the organization of verses is included in the meaning of inimitability (I'jaz) which creation cannot produce the like of, even if they were assistants to one another" (1). Hence, we see Al-Biqa'i making the Order (*Nazm*) in Quranic expression into two orders: Compositional Order (*Nazm Tarkibi*) and Arrangement Order (*Nazm Tartibi*). He says: "Inimitability has two paths: One is the ordering of every sentence on its own according to composition. The second: Ordering it with its sister considering arrangement. The first is closer to grasp and easier to taste, for everyone who hears the Quran... is moved by its meanings, and upon hearing it, acquires an awe with vigor and fear with expansion that does not occur when hearing other than it. The more one scrutinizes the meaning, the greater the position of inimitability becomes to him. Then, if the astute one crosses from that to contemplating the link of every sentence to what followed it and what it followed, that becomes hidden to him, and he sees that sentences have distant purposes and remote objectives, so he thinks they are discordant. Thus, he acquires from contraction and distress multiples of what he acquired by hearing of vibration and expansion....

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: But if he seeks help from Allah Almighty and persists in knocking on the door of relief by refining contemplation, showing inability, and trusting that it is at the peak of precision in linking, just as it was at the apogee of goodness in meaning and wording—being the speech of the One exalted above impurities of deficiency and possessing attributes of perfection—believing in the Unseen, and verifying the Lord, saying what those firm in knowledge said: {Our Lord, let not our hearts deviate after You have guided us and grant us from Yourself mercy. Indeed, You are the Bestower} (Al-Imran: 8), then that door opens for him, and behind it flash the lights of those secrets. The thought dances from it in joy, and they thank Allah in astonishment and wonder, and his heart burns for the greatness of that, so his faith becomes firmly established without doubt" (1). If we look at Surah "An-Nahl" for example, we see it consists of an introduction, a conclusion, and four Nodes: The Introduction is the first [verse]. The First Node is from the second verse to the twenty-first (2-21). The Second is from the twenty-second to the sixty-fourth (22-64). The Third is from the sixty-fifth to the eighty-ninth (65-89). The Fourth is from verse ninety to verse one hundred and twenty-four (90-124). And the Conclusion is the last four verses (125-128). When we reflect, we find that "Al-Biqa'i" has made the Third Node conjoined by its opening to the ending of the First Node, i.e., Verse (65) to Verse (19). The reason is that the First Node of Surah An-Nahl is dedicated to providing evidence through Allah's blessings for His Oneness, Power, Knowledge, and Perfection. The Third Node is also dedicated to establishing a new type of evidence through blessings for His Oneness... evidence in which the meaning of gratitude/bounty appears, whereas in the verses of the First Node, the evidence [aspect] was more apparent than the gratitude. As for the verses of the Second Node, they are like a parenthetical sentence between the First and Third Nodes. The verses of this Third Node stand to explain and refute the objections of the polytheists. So there is a resemblance between the location of this Third Node and its content, which is a marvelous type of resemblance between location and content.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: We look at the proportionality of the verses of the First Node: The verses of the Node begin by establishing the Blessing of Blessings: sending down angels with revelation upon whom He wills of His servants, then the blessing of Allah creating the heavens and the earth and His uniqueness in that. All verses of the Node speak about blessings indicating the Oneness of Allah, His Knowledge, Power, and Choice. The first evidence is Unseen evidence whose effects are seen and heard, but senses do not perceive it: sending down angels with revelation and creating heavens and earth. The second, connected to it without a linguistic connector, is Witnessed evidence that can be observed, especially in our era: creating man from a sperm-drop. Conjoining upon it a Witnessed evidence that shares with man being created from a drop: the creation of cattle... (Verses: 5-9). Then comes an evidence from blessings spread out, sharing with the animal world in being a blessing subjected to man (10-16). This third evidence used for the Oneness of the Benefactor and the perfection of His Knowledge, Power, and Choice has had its verses arranged in a marvelous manner making them three worlds: First World: The Exposed World surrounded by air (Verses: 10-13). Second World: The Submerged Descending World (Seas) (Verse: 14). Third World: The Towering World (Mountains) (Verses: 15-16). Then comes the ending of the Node standing with rebuking denial for those who equate the One who creates that marvelous creation indicating His Oneness... with one who does not create anything. The verses of the Node interconnect and are arranged in a marvelous sequence that no one has the power to advance or delay. As you look at the types of linking, you find some are internal moral linking as in the first verses of this Node, and some are linking by a linguistic connector, as in the verses of the last evidence of the Node's verses. The context does not allow detailing the interconnection between verses of every Node in the Surah. Looking into Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of the proportionality of verses of this Node reveals to you many of the landmarks of his methodology in this" (1). *** He may present several faces in linking the verse to what preceded it, not satisfying himself with one face, as you see in explaining the placement of Allah Almighty's saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Indeed, those who believed and those who were Jews or Christians or Sabeans [before Prophet Muhammad] - those [among them] who believed in Allah and the Last Day and did righteousness - will have their reward with their Lord, and no fear will there be concerning them, nor will they grieve} (Al-Baqarah: 62) in the context of the stories of the Children of Israel: "When He Almighty explained that when they were obstinate against Moses (peace be upon him)... it bequeathed disbelief in their hearts, so they persisted in disobedience and daring to transgress limits, so humiliation and misery were struck upon them, and they drew upon themselves anger. And in that was a warning to those who sought to tread that Straight Path from their condition, and a notification that the pious who are answered in the supplication for guidance are not upon anything of that; rather they said: 'Guide us', out of certainty and sincerity, absolving themselves of claims and objection to Messengers. He alerted that whoever acted contrary to their action, and believed from among them or others from all denominations, was upon the contrary of their condition with their Lord. So He is not angry with them, but pays them their rewards in full, and bequeaths them security and joy implying the opposite of humiliation and misery. So He said: {Indeed, those who believed}. Or it is said: When He Almighty justified the humiliation of the Children of Israel by their disobedience and transgression, it was as if it was said: 'So what is for the one who obeyed?' So it was answered with a general answer for them and others. Or it is said: When He Almighty informed that they were made to wear disgrace like a dove's necklace, and that might have given the illusion that there is no escape for them from it even if they repented—and His custom Almighty was running that if He mentioned a promise or a threat He followed it with a ruling of its opposite so the speech would be complete—know that the door of repentance is open, and the Lord is Generous in a general manner."

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Then he quotes to us the saying of "Al-Harralli" in explaining the appropriateness of this verse to what preceded it: "Al-Harralli said: When the Truth Almighty finished the news of the conditions of the Children of Israel at its end, explaining the highest of their honoring in the first address—and they were the first People of Scripture—He indicated with this conclusion that all who come after them follow them regarding what befell them from all people of the four denominations. End quote. Then "Al-Biqa'i" concludes his speech on the verse saying: "And the beauty of placing this verse in the midst of their stories is that they were commanded to kill every male from other than them, and perhaps they were commanded to kill women too. So perhaps it was thought from that that whoever believed from other than them would not be accepted... And in its placement also in the midst of their stories is an indication of lying to them in their saying {There is no way [of blame] against us regarding the unlettered ones} (Al-Imran: 75), and that the pivot of the sanctity of blood and wealth is only Faith and Uprightness, and that is present in the text of the Torah in more than one place..." (1). These are several faces he mentioned regarding the connection of this verse to what preceded it, which a hasty person who does not contemplate might think has no intimate relationship with what preceded it. This which "Al-Biqa'i" said regarding the facet of interconnection of this verse to what preceded it, you see existing in what "Al-Tahir bin Ashour" went to in his interpretation saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "This verse mediated between verses mentioning the Children of Israel regarding what Allah bestowed upon them, and how they met those blessings with ingratitude and lack of concern. So it came interjected between them for a suitability perceived by every eloquent person. It is that what preceded of narrating their bad reception of Allah's blessings had brought upon them types of humiliation and misery and their return with Allah Almighty's anger. Since attacking them with that would likely make them panic to seek salvation from Allah Almighty's anger, Allah Almighty did not abandon His custom with His creation of mercy towards them and willing the rectification of their condition. So He clarified to them in this verse that Allah's door is open to them, and that resorting to Him is an easy matter for them, and that is by believing and doing righteous deeds." (1) You see the like of this in his explanation of the connection of Allah Almighty's saying: {Say, "Whoever is an enemy to Gabriel - it is [none but] he who has brought the Qur'an down upon your heart, [O Muhammad], by permission of Allah, confirming that which was before it and as guidance and good tidings for the believers."} (Al-Baqarah: 97) to what preceded it, as he mentions two faces of proportionality and generation, saying:
foot_note: 1. (1) - Al-Tahrir wa al-Tanwir: by Al-Tahir bin Ashour: 1/531 - Ed: Tunis

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "When He mentioned their enmity to the most specific of humans and their daring against him with denial and killing, and concluded that with their enmity to the most perfect of creation and the most specific of them, out of envy for the descent of this Reminder upon him explicitly, then implicitly by what He symbolized regarding their setting up to kill him, and finished that with the inescapable punishment for them—because He is Seer of their deeds necessitating it—He mentioned what is precise of their deeds regarding their deep-rootedness in disbelief by their enmity to the elite of Angels who are pure good with no motive at all for hating them except disbelief. It started with mentioning the Revealer of the Quran [meaning the one commanded to carry the revelation and send it down: Gabriel peace be upon him]; because their enmity to the one it was revealed to for the sake of what was revealed to him is enmity to its Revealer; because he is the cause of what the enmity was for. So He said commanding him (peace be upon him) informing of what He saw of their hidden plotting that necessitates their harm (Say). Or it is said - which is better, clearer, and stronger - When He commanded him (peace be upon him) with what indicated their lying in their claim of the Hereafter being exclusively for them, and informed that they must be punished, He commanded him with another proof for both matters. So on the estimation of it being a proof for the first, it is coordinated upon the first (Say) without a conjunction to indicate that each of the two proofs is sufficient for what it was driven for. [And] on the estimation of it being a proof for the second which He singled out, it is an answer to one who seemed to say: Why does He not remove them from being granted long life to [avoid] the punishment?" (1) This is Al-Biqa'i turning over aspects of view and striving to trace the sources of relationship between verses due to what the Holy Quranic expression is characterized by of multiplicity of facets of expression, whether realized from its Compositional Order or Arrangement Order; rather the Arrangement [Order] is more abundant and subtler. He says in explaining the relationship of Allah Almighty's saying: {Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah will have a severe punishment, and Allah is Exalted in Might, the Owner of Retribution} (Al-Imran: from verse 4)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "When the Sustainer Almighty's command of Truth and Faith was known by that, it was known that for the opposers of His command among the opposites of the described believers—who are the disbelievers for whose defeat the Criterion (Furqan) was sent down to erase their religions—there is woe and destruction. So it connected to that with His saying Almighty {Indeed, those who disbelieve}... And the verse is on the estimation of a question from one who seemed to say: What is done with one who turns away from the described Books? Or it is said: When He said: {And He revealed the Criterion}, meaning the separator between Truth and Falsehood of verses and rulings upon you and upon others of the Prophets, no doubt remained for anyone. So He said: 'And the best of all that is that when Allah Almighty revealed Surah "Al-Baqarah" in its length explaining that the Book is guidance for the pious, and explained at the beginning of this [Surah] His Oneness, Life, and Sustainment indicating complete Knowledge and comprehensive Power, producing the truthfulness of what He Almighty informed of, He supported that by informing that that Book, while being a guide to Him, is Truth, and indicated that by its confirmation of what was before it of Books'" (1). We see him mentioning more than one face in conjoining the verse to another, indicating the multiplicity of facets of attachment and that it is fit for meeting and generating from more than one verse preceding it, whether close to it in location or distant. You see that in explaining the conjoined-to in Allah Almighty's saying: {And We have certainly revealed to you verses [that are] clear proofs, and no one would deny them except the defiantly disobedient.} (Al-Baqarah: 99)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "When He finished encouraging them regarding the Quran that it is from Allah Almighty, and that it confirms their Book, and regarding Gabriel (peace be upon him) that he is the one coming with it by Allah's permission Almighty, and intimidating them regarding the one whose enmity... He followed it by praising this Quran, and that it is a clear matter for the one desiring truth. If one disbelieves in it among them or others, he is Fasiq (defiantly disobedient), meaning exiting what is known of the truth, for it is such that it is not hidden from anyone. So He said Almighty conjoining to His saying {for he has brought it down upon your heart by permission of Allah} (v: 97), or His saying Almighty: {And Moses had certainly brought you clear proofs} (v: 92), or to what is estimated as: So it has become clear by this which Gabriel (peace be upon him) brought down that the Hereafter is not exclusively for them, and that they are among those whom their sin has encompassed due to their disbelief {And We have certainly revealed...}." (1) The reader of Al-Biqa'i's interpretation notices his predominance in going to conjunction on an implied [sentence]. As if he indicates by this that the Holy Quran strengthens the bond of necessary meanings—by virtue of being necessary to it—with the stated meanings, so it suffices with the indication of this bond instead of explicitly mentioning these necessary meanings to which what follows the declared is conjoined. So he brings what follows the conjunction returned to an implied [meaning] which is in severe necessity of expression for it, like the explicitly mentioned. Thus, the rhetorical fabric of Quranic meanings is based on a method of weaving where some silk threads hide in the brocade fabric, hardly appearing to the casual eye but appearing to the penetrating insight. Hence, you see the predominance of going to Brevity by Omission in Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of the pattern of Quranic expression, especially omitting the conjoined-to estimated from the womb of meaning in the previous explicitly mentioned sentence. Al-Biqa'i may go to conjoining a verse to another preceding it by more than forty verses as you see in conjoining Allah Almighty's saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {And Allah has sent down rain from the sky and given life thereby to the earth after its lifelessness. Indeed in that is a sign for a people who listen.} (An-Nahl: 65) to the saying of Allah Almighty {And Allah knows what you conceal and what you declare} (An-Nahl: 19). He says: "When the evidence that their hearts are denying out of arrogance and what relates to it ended, and He concluded it with what He gives life to hearts with—Faith and Knowledge after their death by Disbelief and Ignorance—and the Greatest Objective of the Quran was establishing four principles: Divinities (Theology), Prophecies, the Hereafter, and establishing Decree and Destiny and Action by Choice; and the greatest of these objectives was Divinities, He began with proofs of Oneness, Power, and Action by Choice necessitating the ability to Resurrect in a manner different from the preceding. This is so it is known that the proofs for that are more than the leaves of trees, and clearer than the light of day. So He conjoined to His saying Almighty {And Allah knows what you conceal and what you declare} a comprehensive saying in evidence between the Upper World and the Lower World {And Allah has sent down rain from the sky...}" (1). This is based on what is known among rhetoricians as conjoining story upon story, which is a method of meaning relationships. Al-Biqa'i himself emphasizes that the method of relationships between meanings in the Quranic Surah is like the method of relationships of branches, twigs, and boughs of a tree. The discussion on the relationship of verses to each other is vast and hardly encompassed. It is built upon what scholars agreed upon that the arrangement of verses is *Tawqifi* (divinely ordained) brought by Revelation. No one among the worlds—angel or prophet—had an intervention in it. You hardly find anyone attributed to knowledge claiming that the arrangement of verses in the Surah is an Ijtihad (reasoning) from a Companion, Prophet, or Angel.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: If the matter is *Tawqifi* (divinely ordained), there must be behind that a wisdom holding a position over it in the locus of Quranic Inimitability: Rhetorical Inimitability. Thus, it was necessary that there is a relationship of proportionality and generation between the verses of a single Surah, and that every verse is not cut off from its predecessor and successor. The Seventh Feature. Interpreting the Order (*Nazm*) in Quranic Stories. The Quranic expression about Allah Almighty's will for His servants came mixing two contexts: A legislative context whose pillar is Command and Prohibition with their differing paths and forms, and an educational context whose pillar is Encouragement and Intimidation. Hardly does one context strip itself of the company of the other; they exist together, even if the degrees of appearance of one and subtlety of the other vary. The Holy Quranic Stories are a type of psychological and spiritual education through encouragement and intimidation. Insights penetrating its depth perceive a flux of degrees of assignment with Ehsan-based meanings for a group that ascended in their march to their Lord from the lower degree of obedience to Allah Almighty to a higher degree: ascended from the age of "Those who believed" to the age of "The Believers" and above them to the honor of the age of "The Doers of Good (Muhsinin)" who worship Allah Almighty as if they see Him with the eye of insight. The Holy Quran establishes the status of Stories and their majestic message in several noble verses: {Indeed, this is the true narration. And there is no deity except Allah. And indeed, Allah is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.} (Al-Imran: 62) {So relate the stories that perhaps they will give thought.} (Al-A'raf: 176) {We relate to you, [O Muhammad], the best of stories in what We have revealed to you of this Qur'an although you were, before it, among the unaware.} (Yusuf: 3)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {There was certainly in their stories a lesson for those of understanding. Never was the Qur'an a narration invented, but a confirmation of what was before it and a detailed explanation of all things and guidance and mercy for a people who believe.} (Yusuf: 111). A careful look at the statement of this last verse which concludes Surah "Yusuf"—existing as a complete story where no scene was repeated contrary to the rhetorical Sunnah in the Holy Quran regarding Quranic stories—tempts you to contemplate His saying Almighty: {A lesson (*Ibrah*) for those of understanding}. As if in this is an indication that the crossing (*'Ubur*) from busying oneself with the apparent event narrated in those stories and what the narrative scene established therein, to what is the erected goal for which this story was driven, is only for those of understanding (Ulul-Albab). The Holy Quran attaches *Tadhakkur* (Remembrance)—which is summoning what one had previous knowledge of—to them. So the Holy Quranic Stories are only for taking lessons. And by contemplating His saying Almighty: {Never was the Qur'an a narration invented, but a confirmation of what was before it, and a detailed explanation of all things...}, this reveals the reality of these stories which no other stories can approach, and which nothing that times throw up will ever be able to belie a majestic or minute matter of. And by contemplating His saying Almighty: {and guidance and mercy for a people who believe}, this is a clear indication that these stories guide in a manner befitting their worth only those who uphold the belief that what they hear of these stories is not fabrication nor the product of imagination and wandering in every valley, but a confirmation of what is before it of the True Books which Allah Almighty revealed to His messengers, peace be upon them. As if the end of the verse looks at its beginning; it is of the type of semantic Returning the Ending to the Opening "The 'Ajuz to the Sadr". In this, from the Holy Quran, is a bright, dazzling guidance separating between two realities:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The reality of the Holy Quranic Stories, standing from the Truth and subsisting by it, which no slightest doubt approaches that there is a distance between what is narrated and what was or is in the World of Witness. And the reality of what is called stories in the world of literary creativity, whose metal is imagination and illusion, distancing from the Truth by any distance, even if some of it or its likeness was snatched from the roaring movement of life. Above this, they are divergent in message and goal. This necessitates a divergence between them in the methodology of clarification and depiction. Hence, it is not from the objectivity of interpretation as Quranic rhetoric, nor the objectivity of criticism as literary creativity, to take from the methodology of literary criticism—Arabic or foreign—for artistic stories what the Muslim reads the landmarks of rhetorical inimitability of the Holy Quranic Stories with. *** Al-Biqa'i contemplates the chapters of stories and their events, highlighting the proportionality of that with the context and the intent of the Surah. He may draw a comparison between the locations of a single story in multiple Surahs, highlighting the similarity of Compositional and Arrangement Order in the story. Al-Biqa'i's essay regarding Quranic Stories is a vast essay that papers like these cannot accommodate. It is worthy of having a scientific research dedicated to it, encompassing the gold nuggets scattered in the context of his interpretation of the Holy Quranic expression according to the principles of the science of Quranic Proportionality he has. We are only pointing to some of what incites undertaking the examination of what Al-Biqa'i's essay was in this. He says about "The Science of Proportions": "By it, the secrets of repeated stories become clear to you, and that every Surah in which a story was repeated, it was for a meaning more called for in that Surah, evidenced by that story, other than the meaning for which it was driven in the previous Surah. From here, wordings differed according to those purposes, and orders changed by delaying, advancing, brevity, and elaboration, while nothing of that contradicts the original meaning by which the story was formed" (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This, from "Al-Biqa'i", is a great principle of Rhetorical Interpretation of the Holy Quran, looking at the status of the Context and the Purpose for which speech is established in understanding the meaning and tasting the rhetoric. It indicates that Quranic expression does not contain sterile repetition, but is towards rhetorical derivation in depicting meanings, which grants the recipient a flood of semantic giving that repels the calamity of boredom and weariness. It is the Expression that does not wear out with much repetition, and its wonders do not end. Among what he said in interpreting the stories in Surah "Al-A'raf": "Know that there is no repetition in these stories, for every context of them is for a matter whose like has not preceded. The purpose of the story of 'Moses' (peace be upon him) and 'Pharaoh' (upon him be curse and blame) is this existential evidence for His saying: 'And We found most of them to be defiantly disobedient'. From here you know that the context of the story of the Children of Israel after salvation from their enemy is to explain their haste into disbelief and breaking of covenants. He Almighty continued in this evidence until the end of the Surah. And how appropriate His saying Almighty: {And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying to them], "Am I not your Lord?" They said, "Yes, we have testified." [This] - lest you should say on the day of Resurrection, "Indeed, we were of this unaware."} (Al-A'raf: 172) is to His saying Almighty: {And We did not find for most of them any covenant; but indeed, We found most of them defiantly disobedient.} (Al-A'raf: 102). And He mentioned in the beginning of the one following it [Surah Al-Anfal] their dispute over spoils to warn them against being among the blameworthy majority in this one. This is contrary to the purpose of the context of the Children of Israel stories in 'Al-Baqarah', for there it is to solicit faith by reminding of blessings; because that is in the context of His address—Almighty—to all people by His saying: {O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous} (Al-Baqarah: 21).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {How can you disbelieve in Allah when you were lifeless and He brought you to life; then He will cause you to die, then He will bring you [back] to life, and then to Him you will be returned.} (Al-Baqarah: 28) and what resembles it of seeking affection by enumerating blessings and repelling punishments. And Allah knows best" (1). This indicates clearly that he sees a special context for every story and for every aspect/scene of its aspects, which dictates that this story be here and this aspect of it be [here], and its order be in this manner. *** Among what he is concerned with explaining is the arrangement of events in Quranic stories, and showing that the criterion for its arrangement is not the chronological succession of events in reality, but the Context and the General Purpose of the expression is what dictates presenting the news of an event ahead of the news of an event that preceded it in occurrence. You see something of this in the first story mentioned in the Arrangement Context of the Holy Quran: The story of our father Adam (peace be upon him) in Surah "Al-Baqarah": The news of commanding the angels to prostrate to Adam (peace be upon him) came after the news of teaching him the names and informing the angels of what they did not know. The implication of the apparent [text] to him is that the prostration was first, and the command to the angels to inform of the names of things was after it in reality, but the narrative expression came otherwise. He says: "'Al-Baydawi' proceeded on [the view] that the command to prostrate was after informing of the names, and he did not mention a proof diverting from this apparent meaning (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: Vol 8, p 70 
2. - Al-Baydawi says in his Tafsir (Anwar al-Tanzil): "{And when We said to the angels, 'Prostrate to Adam'} When He informed them of the names and taught them what they did not know, He commanded them to prostrate to him as an acknowledgement of his virtue, fulfilling his right, and apologizing for what they said about him. It was said He commanded them before He fashioned his creation due to His saying Almighty {So when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My [created] soul, then fall down to him in prostration} to test them and show his virtue" (Anwar al-Tanzil - Vol 2, p 130).
