Al-Shihab Al-Khafaji comments in his footnote "Inayat al-Qadi" (2/130) on Al-Baydawi's saying (It was said...): "The author, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, indicated [by saying: It was said] his lack of approval, and did not point to the answer to his deduction from the verse [i.e., then fall down], which is that the 'Fa' (Then) of answer does not necessitate immediate sequence, as in His saying Almighty: {When the call is made for prayer on Friday, then proceed to the remembrance of Allah}, for proceeding is not obligatory immediately after it..."

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: However, proceeding upon it is better from the aspect of meaning; because the prostration of angels (peace be upon them) before [i.e., before manifesting the virtue of knowledge to Adam, peace be upon him] would be belief in the Unseen based on the rule of assignment. But after manifesting the virtue of knowledge, the cover was removed, and the facet of virtue became from the chapter of Certainty of Sight ('Ain al-Yaqin). As for the arrangement in mention here in this manner, placing prostration after informing, it is for a marvelous subtlety: It is that He Almighty, as He was in the explanation of blessings necessitating His thanks by singling Him out for worship for being a Benefactor, explained first His blessing upon every soul in its individuality by creating it and pouring provision upon it [referring to verses: 21-22]. Then He reminded all of a blessing encompassing them, which is His argumentation with the closest of His creation to Him at that time regarding our father Adam (peace be upon him) before creating him. The Wise Style required clarifying the proof of the virtue of this Caliph to them, so He mentioned what He gave him of knowledge. When He finished arguing with them with what necessitated their submission, He reminded his sons of the blessing of prostration to him. So presenting the manifestation of the virtue of knowledge was only to preserve the good context in arranging the proof on the most upright method and clearest path" (1). "Al-Biqa'i" highlights, as you see, the effect of Context and the Purpose for which speech is established on the Arrangement Order of the story's events, and how they might dictate presenting an event in mention over an event preceding in the occurrence of the story. So consideration is for what the Situation and Station require. ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: While looking into the rhetorical derivation of a single story and its depiction with diverse rhetorical images, he points out that "The intended purpose of recounting stories in the Holy Quran is only the meanings [i.e., meanings of guidance by which lesson-taking 'Ibrah' occurs]. So the difference in wording does not harm if it conveys the whole meaning or part of it, and there is no contradiction. For the story, when it occurred, was with the fullest of meanings mentioned. Then Allah Almighty expresses for us in every Surah wherein the story is mentioned with wordings suitable to that station regarding what is fitting of meanings, and leaves what that station does not require." (1) In this is an indication that the One who relates to us what was and what will be is only the All-Knowing, the Acquainted, Majestic is His Majesty. He is the Knower of the precise and subtle meanings hidden in the chests whose news He relates, and what was from them and what will be. And He is the Knower of what the Arabic tongue possesses of capabilities to express subtle, stray, and rare meanings. As if "Al-Biqa'i" here summons in his mind the saying of "Abu Sulayman: Hamad Al-Khattabi" (d. 388 AH) in which he says: "It was impossible for humans to produce the like of it for reasons, including: That their knowledge does not encompass all names of the Arabic language and its words which are vessels of meanings and carriers for them. Nor do their understandings perceive all meanings of things carried on those words. Nor is their knowledge complete to exhaust all modes of orders (Nazm) by which their harmony and connection to each other exist, so that they could reach by choosing the best over the good of its modes to produce speech like it..." (2)
foot_note:
1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: 1/284 
2. – Bayan I'jaz al-Qur'an al-Karim by Abu Sulayman Al-Khattabi: 26 – within the book Three Treatises on the Inimitability of the Quran – Ed: Muhammad Khalaf Allah and Zaghloul Salam – Pub: Dar Al-Ma'arif, Egypt

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i explains the goal of Quranic stories, which is explaining meanings. If they are conveyed, difference in wordings due to difference in stations does not harm. This is because events, when they occur, are complete in meaning, and Allah Almighty is knowledgeable of all of them, so He expresses them each time with what suits that station and the purpose for which the speech is set. In this is an indication that the One who relates to us what was and what will be is only the All-Knowing, the Acquainted, Majestic is His Majesty. He is the Knower of the precise and subtle meanings hidden in the chests whose news He relates, and what was from them and what will be. And He is the Knower of what the Arabic tongue possesses of capabilities to express subtle, stray, and rare meanings. So He selects in each instance from the Orders (Nuzum) what conveys to us a side of the meaning aspects such that what is conveyed to us is proportionate to the Context and the Purpose for which the speech is set, because that story has an educational, upbringing, refining goal which is the standard in selection of meaning and meaning-image. Most of what the Holy Quran related of stories, those informed about and whose news was told were not speakers of the Arabic tongue. But the Holy Quran depicted with the clear Arabic tongue their precise meanings existing in their foreign tongues and the meanings hidden in their chests which Allah Almighty created and knew their secrets. {And conceal your speech or publicize it; indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts. * Does He who created not know, while He is the Subtle, the Acquainted?} (Al-Mulk: 13-14). {He knows the traitor of the eyes, and what the chests conceal.} (Ghafir: 19). The expression of the Holy Quran with the clear Arabic tongue did not leave anything of the meanings of those whose news was told, but depicted them with an inimitable depiction. {Never was the Qur'an a narration invented, but a confirmation of what was before it and a detailed explanation of all things} (Yusuf: 111). It is the comprehensive, concluding verse establishing the reality of the Glorious Quranic Narration. ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: You see him in Surah Al-Baqarah and Surah Al-A'raf pausing at points revealing the Rhetorical Sunnah of the Holy Quran in ordering its stories, especially the Arrangement Order. In the story of "The Cow"—and the Surah was named after it, suggesting it expresses the landmarks of the Greatest Objective of the Surah with precise expression, even if subtle and fine—we find him looking at its Arrangement Order, especially its location in the context of the Surah, and in its Compositional Order. The story came in the context of the story of the Children of Israel and their affair, following the indication of their transgression in the Sabbath, and their command to be despised apes as an exemplary punishment for what came from them and an admonition for the pious against the like of their deed. As if in it is a great warning to this Ummah not to transgress in Allah's choice Almighty for it: Friday. In this context revealing the condition of the Children of Israel regarding their hardness against the Right of Allah Almighty generally and specifically, came the declaration of their hardness in their own interests through what came from them of killing a soul without right. Al-Biqa'i says, among what he says explaining the necessity of the Station for revealing the story of the Cow in the context of the Surah where it was revealed: ... "Since the Sabbath was only obligated upon them, and they were tested with strictness in it due to their proposing it and asking for it after refusing Friday... the most appropriate thing was to follow it with the story of the Cow, in which matter He was strict with them only due to their obstinacy in it, and their refusal to slaughter any cow that was easy. It may be said that since among what they slighted was the Sabbath by hastening to extinguish countless souls they were forbidden from (whales), and in the story of 'The Cow' was obstinacy and slowness regarding extinguishing one soul they were commanded to, He followed it with it" (1). This from "Al-Biqa'i" is an explanation of a face of revealing this story in this place of the Arrangement Context of the Surah.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In it is a revelation of a side of their bad conduct and choice and their turning away from Allah Almighty's choice for them, and how in what they go to with the requirement of their minds' choice, they are falling into evil consequence. So in joining the two news items is observation of symmetry (*Mura'at Nazir*), and in this is an admonition for the pious lest they adopt the methodology of those obstinate ones from the Children of Israel in their lives. *** And if Al-Biqa'i looked at the place of the story of "The Cow" in the Arrangement Context of Surah Al-Baqarah, he looks at the pattern of Arrangement Order of its events and sees that its Arrangement Order of events was not according to the pattern of arrangement of those events in existence at the time of their occurrence, and that is due to a requirement of the Purpose for which the speech is set. He says: "When the story was divided into two halves to alert to the two blessings: the blessing of pardon for pausing regarding the command, and the blessing of clarification for the killer by the supernatural command; and to alert that they have two rebukes thereby: one for bad manners in accusing of mockery and pausing from compliance, and the second for killing the soul and what followed it. Had it been arranged according to its arrangement in existence, that would not have been achieved. He presented the half more appropriate to the story of the Sabbath and followed it with the other" (1). The implication of the apparent was to begin the story with His saying Majestic is His Majesty: {And [mention] when you killed a soul...} (Al-Baqarah: 72) and that after it would be {And [mention] when Moses said to his people...} (Al-Baqarah: 67). But He presented the saying of their Prophet to them and what came from them due to what the Station and observation of analogues required, and presenting their rebuke for bad manners and pausing from compliance. He is looking at His saying Almighty: {and an admonition for the pious} so every Muslim protects himself against adopting their path in their lives, for there is nothing in imitating them except the shame of the world and the humiliation of the Hereafter. The discussion on Quranic Stories and what fits of Arrangement Order of events and locations of those stories in the context of the Surah is vast in scope; one like me can hardly encompass merely pointing to much of it, especially in this station.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And the speech on the Arrangement Order of Quranic Stories is one aspect of the Wise Quranic Stories, for its aspects are numerous. Among them is the derivation of expression regarding the story's scenes and events. Among them are the Quranic Meanings: General and Ehsan-based which came in Quranic Stories and the face of inimitability in them. Among them are the Singularities of Quranic Stories: Scenes that were not mentioned twice and expression was not derived from them, and words that did not come except once in it or in the entire Holy Quran. Among them is the Lexicon of Quranic Stories, and semantic nuances. And above this, the characteristics of Compositional Order and methodologies of depiction and embellishment in the Narrative Expression in the Holy Quran... etc. These are vast doors and dictionaries of rhetorical contemplation that cannot be encompassed, let alone their secrets counted, for they are of the most majestic Divine Blessings: {And if you should count the favors of Allah, you could not enumerate them. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.} (An-Nahl: 18). ***** The Eighth Feature. Explanation of the Arrangement Order of Sentences in the Construction of the Quranic Verse. It is clear that one of the methodologies of the Holy Quranic Expression is detailing its Surahs into verses. These verses—their detailing and designation of reading opening and ending—was not based on a linguistic rhetorical basis. Look at the saying of Allah Almighty: {Have you seen the one who forbids * A servant when he prays?} (Al-Alaq: 9-10). The Truth, Majestic is His Majesty, made the reading opening of the second verse the object of the verb He made the reading ending of the verse preceding it. This indicates that the matter is not returned to a linguistic criterion, even if such is not dominant in detailing the Surah into verses, especially verses that are extended, formed of several sentences which may have grammatical relationships or contextual relationships between them. Al-Biqa'i has glorious attention to interpreting the Arrangement Order of sentences in the construction of the verse, especially extended verses where the grammatical sentence holds the status of the word in the sentence.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He is also concerned with explaining the relationship of this Order's implications to the near and far context. This is due to him considering the Arrangement Order (*Nazm Tartibi*) higher in rank in contemplating the proportionality of the Holy Quran than the Compositional Order (*Nazm Tarkibi*). He considers standing upon it as something specific to the Imams of knowledge. As for the Compositional Order based on sentence construction, that is something many can easily stand upon and master understanding. He says while explaining the subject of the Science of Proportionality: "Its subject is the parts of the thing whose suitability is sought from the aspect of arrangement. Its fruit is viewing the rank the part deserves because of the connection and attachment it has to what is behind it and in front of it, which is like the bond of kinship" (1). And he says: "By this science—meaning the Science of Munasabat (Proportions)—faith becomes firmly established in the heart and settles in the intellect. That is because it reveals that Inimitability has two paths: One is ordering every sentence on its own according to Composition. The second: Ordering it with its sister considering Arrangement. The first is closer to grasp and easier to taste..." (2). Perhaps the ease of interpreting Compositional Order in sentence construction relative to interpreting Arrangement Order of compound sentences in verse construction is because Compositional Order has an objective reference in grammatical relationships between meanings of words. This is what Abdul Qahir called *Al-Nazm* (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: Vol: 1 p: 5 
2. Previous source: 1/10-11 
3. - If Abdul Qahir's attention to grammatical relationships in sentence construction was clear and great, this does not mean he stopped at that without transcending it, or claimed that there is no level beyond this level of attachment between speech components. Rather, if you look at his book: (Dala'il al-I'jaz), you see a stance from him regarding a statement by Al-Jahiz in the introduction of Kitab al-Hayawan saying: ((May Allah keep you from doubt and protect you from confusion... etc.)) which he did not consider of the Order by which virtue is mandatory (Dala'il: p 97-98). Despite every sentence being established from high Compositional Order wherein meanings of grammar were sought between meanings of its words, if it lacked Arrangement Order between sentences—whose pillar is Context and Purpose for which speech is set—you could advance a sentence over a sentence without the building demolishing.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: For the meanings of grammar sought between meanings of words in sentence construction is an objective, specific matter, even if faces multiply. What is such, its matter is easier relative to what is not returned to an objective criterion like Compositional Order; for its reference is contextual, intentional, i.e., referring to the context of speech in the wideness of its circles: the circle of verse construction, the circle of Node construction, the circle of Surah construction, and the circle of the entire Quranic Expression construction. Whenever the circle widens, the hearing and sight become subtler, so hearings and sights vary. The sentence looked at in its Arrangement Order in verse construction might be an extended sentence embracing within its womb numerous smaller sentences linked to it by compositional linkage based on grammatical relationships. What concerns us here is the relationships of grammatical sentences established from Compositional Order to form, by the Arrangement Order between them, a verse of the Surah's verses. That is where Arrangement Order exists. This [order] existing between sentences in verse construction is the narrowest field of Arrangement Order, whose fields may widen to ordering verses in constructing Nodes, ordering Nodes in constructing the Surah, then ordering Surahs and arranging them to achieve the Arrangement Context of the Holy Quran opening recitation with Surah Al-Fatihah and concluding recitation with Surah Al-Nas. I have previously looked at what is higher than the field of Arrangement Order between sentences for verse construction. The Quranic verse may be formed from a collection of grammatical sentences, each having its syntactic independence. However, despite that, the meaning of speech is not complete except with the sum of these grammatical sentences, nor can you stand upon the full rhetorical meaning of the speech except with the sum of these grammatical sentences. If you look at Ayat al-Kursi, you find it to be nine grammatical sentences, or ten sentences if we say the Name of Majesty is a sentence with one pillar deleted indicated by the estimated question: Whose is the Sovereignty today? Which is what Al-Biqa'i went to. The grammatical meaning in every sentence does not lack the preceding one according to grammarians, even if generated from it.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: These grammatical sentences are elements of a single Quranic (rhetorical) sentence. You do not stand upon the Holy Quranic meaning of this verse from a single grammatical sentence. For the Rhetorical Quranic meaning that made this verse the Mistress of Quranic verses, as the Sunnah guided to, is not established by the first grammatical sentence alone (Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of [all] existence) but one must encompass all sentences built upon it. The first grammatical sentence here is the Key Sentence and the Base Sentence upon which the rest of the sentences were built in constructing and forming the Quranic meaning of this Quranic sentence. Al-Biqa'i was concerned with interpreting the Mistress of Holy Quranic verses: Ayat al-Kursi in his interpretation, and dedicated a book to it: *Al-Fath al-Qudsi fi Tafsir Ayat al-Kursi*. Let us look at his interpretation of the Arrangement Order of this verse's sentences in his Tafsir. He says: "When He Almighty began Al-Fatihah, as passed, by mentioning the Essence, then made Himself known through actions because they are witnessed, then ascended the address to definition by Attributes, then elevated it back to the Essence to qualify for knowledge, He began this Surah with the attribute of Speech; because it is the greatest of miracles, the clearest and most indicative of the Unseen Essence, and the most impactful on souls, especially among the Arabs. Then He made Himself known through actions, increasing them. When no ambiguity remained, He established Oneness with its preceding verse, interspersing that with varieties of wisdom, beauties of rulings, and types of encouragement and intimidation in precise description and arrangement. When the commands were complete and those deterrents were terrifying, and souls yearned, and thoughts looked forward to knowing the cause of the severing of connection by the cutting of ties and the negation of intercession on that Day—since it was familiar from worldly kings that they are hardly enabled in any matter fully due to the abundance of intercessors and willing friends... He Almighty explained the attribute of the Commander regarding His Majesty, Greatness, effectiveness of command.....

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: For the sake of these purposes, He drove the speech as an answer to the question, as if it were said: 'This is what is unknown of the conditions of kings; so who is the King on that Day?' So He mentioned Ayat al-Kursi, the Mistress of Quranic verses, which no book contained the like of, opening it with the Unique Comprehensive Proper Name by which no other is named. That is when the listener qualified, after introduction by Speech and courtship by Actions, for the station of Knowledge, so he ascended to the apogee of Observation and the presence of Witnessing. So He said returning to the manifestation of Majesty gathering attributes of Majesty and Honor; because it is one of His greatest stations (Allah) i.e., He is the King on that Day. Then He established for Him attributes of perfection purified from impurities of deficiency, opening them with Exclusivity, so He said (There is no deity except Him)... And when He Almighty unified His Noble Self, He established His entitlement to that by His Life, and explained that the intended is Eternal Life by the description of Sustainment (*Qayyumiyyah*), so He said (The Ever-Living... The Sustainer). Then He explained His Sustainment and perfection of His Life by His saying Majestic is His Majesty (Neither drowsiness overtakes Him... nor sleep)... Then He explained this sentence by His saying Almighty (To Him belongs... whatever is in the heavens and whatever is in the earth)... Then He explained what this sentence included by His saying, denying upon whoever might imagine that something exits His command so it is not specific to Him (Who is it that can intercede... with Him except by His permission) i.e., by His enabling; for whoever no one can oppose, it is clear that everything is in His grasp. All that is evidence of His exclusivity in Divinity... Then He explained all that passed by His saying Almighty (He knows what is [presently] before them... and what will be after them)...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And when He explained His subduing them by His knowledge, He explained their inability regarding anything of His knowledge except what He poured upon them by His clemency, so He said Majestic is His Majesty: (And they encompass not a thing... of His knowledge except for what He wills)... Then He explained what is in this sentence of His comprehensive knowledge and complete power by His saying, depicting His Greatness, complete knowledge, pride, and power with what people are accustomed to in their kings (His Kursi extends... over the heavens and the earth)... Thus what preceded became clear by that; because whoever has this Greatness in this precise management and perfected making has this Knowledge and this Power that nothing burdens. Therefore He said Almighty (And their preservation tires Him not...) in His Sustainment as it burdens others... And since His Loftiness and Greatness by Subjugation, Authority, and encompassing Perfection were not confined to what preceded, He conjoined to it His saying Majestic is His Majesty (And He is... the Most High... the Most Great) as indicated by opening the verse with the Greatest Proper Name gathering all meanings of Beautiful Names in Height and Greatness that understandings fall short of due to illusions overcoming them... It is known from this establishment that every sentence started anew is a cause for what preceded it, and that the last one is explanatory of the necessary consequence of Comprehensive Knowledge, which is Complete Power... So whoever claims partnership, let him preserve this universe, even for one year of years, and let him know what is acting in that year for his saying to be valid. And how can he do that, and how!!! It became clear by what was established for Him Almighty of Highness and Greatness that the disbeliever in Him is the Wrongdoer (Zalim), and that the Day of His manifestation for judgment will have no intercession nor friendship. As for trade (bargaining), they are in the busiest occupation from it. Even if Ransom is meant by it, it is known that there is no way to it and no stopping at it. By these secrets, the saying of the Chosen Master (peace be upon him) became clear: 'Indeed this verse is the Mistress of Quranic verses' (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi in his Sahih: Virtues of the Quran: Hadith: 2878).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: That is because of what it included of Names of Essence, Attributes, and Actions, negation of deficiency and affirmation of perfection. It fulfilled proofs of Tawhid in the most complete manner in the wisest system and most creative style, being purely for that." (1) It became clear to us from Al-Biqa'i's interpretation the relationships of the ten sentences forming Ayat al-Kursi, and that its Arrangement Order is based on the methodology of Ascent and Generation. Al-Biqa'i stated in the conclusion of his interpretation that every sentence is a cause for its predecessor and clarifying what is hidden in what preceded it. In justification (Ta'lil) is the meaning of Generation, and in clarification is the meaning of Ascent; because clarification does not stop at explaining what preceded and clarifying it, but adds new [meaning] to it. The other comes and clarifies it, so the meaning ascends to its peak, and lights of clarification condense, so no ambiguity remains in a meaning of the meanings of the Mistress of Holy Quranic verses, which is in reality the conclusion of the Quranic Meaning in Surah Al-Baqarah. What came after it of verses is only clarification, as stated by "Al-Biqa'i" in the opening of Surah "Al-Imran" (2). *** If you look at the "Verse of Debt" (Ayat al-Dayn) also, you see that it is a single Quranic (rhetorical) sentence despite being the most extended verse in the Holy Quran. You see the Conditional Style with its two sentences as the base upon which the rest of the verse (The Rhetorical Sentence) was built. What was arranged upon the Conditional Style in debt transactions is very numerous. At the end of the verse is a Conditional Style in sales (And take witnesses when you conclude a contract). He did not attach numerous sentences to it as He attached in the Conditional Style in debt transactions due to the differences between the two financial dealings. His saying Almighty (Take witnesses) is in reality conjoined to the Conditional Style at the beginning of the verse. So the meaning is: O you who have believed, when you contract a debt for a specified term, write it down, and when you conclude a contract [of sale], take witnesses.)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This is one face of the "Waw" (And) about which we can say that it initiates a new sentence about Sale after finishing the talk about Debt, due to subtle relationships between the two dealings. It is from conjoining story upon story with a connected womb between them. Thus, the simplest context for the Quranic Meaning has five stages: Stage of talking about Charities (v: 261-274), Stage of talking about Usury (Riba) (v: 275-281), Stage of talking about Debt (v: 282), Stage of talking about Sale (v: 282), and Stage of talking about Pledge (Rahn) (v: 283). The talk about the last two stages was brief, and about the first three stages was expanded. He made the talk about Riba flanked by talk about two majestic financial dealings; no one cares for his share in them among servants except one with great belief in the Unseen: Belief in Resurrection and the Last Day. That is the head of the Universal Meaning and Greatest Objective of Surah "Al-Baqarah". He combined the talk about Sale with the talk about Debt in one verse because Debt, in one of its faces, is a type of Sale except it is with Allah Almighty, for He is the One who guaranteed the return. Hence, interest taken from the debtor was forbidden because the contract of debt is originally a contract with Allah Majestic is His Majesty and not with the debtor; for Allah Almighty bears on behalf of the debtor what is the counter-value of the debt. Hence, the reward of the Good Loan (Qard Hasan) was higher than the reward of Charity. There is another indication for people of Ehsan: In every legal sale disciplined by Prophetic manners is a debt. Al-Bukhari narrated with his chain from Jabir bin Abdullah that the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and salutations abundant) said: "May Allah have mercy on a man who is lenient when he sells, when he buys, and when he demands payment" (Al-Bukhari - Book of Sales - Chapter: Ease and Lenience in Selling and Buying). As if what he was lenient in during sale and purchase is looking towards its reward in the Hereafter.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The summary of the matter is that the Arrangement Order in verse construction based on contextual relationships between sentences requires its contemplator to have extra intelligence, sharpness of sense, penetration of taste, ability to visualize water sources, and that his knowledge be the knowledge of the skilled craftsman who knows every thread of silk in the brocade, every piece of carved wood in the paneled door, and every brick in the marvelous building, as Imam Abdul Qahir says. ... The Ninth Feature. Contemplating the Compositional Order (*Nazm Tarkibi*) of Sentence Construction. I indicated before that Order (*Nazm*) according to "Al-Biqa'i" is of two types: Arrangement Order (*Nazm Tartibi*), whose narrowest fields is to be between grammatical sentences as they form the Quranic Verse construction, and the relationships between these sentences are contextual relationships, not parsing relationships with grammatical standards. I have looked at Al-Biqa'i's stance on interpreting that pattern of Order, and its status in the Rhetorical Inimitability of the Holy Quran. And Compositional Order (*Nazm Tarkibi*) which exists between elements of grammatical sentence construction, its basis being grammatical relationships between components of the sentence. It is clear that the grammatical sentence, even if its elements extend, multiply, and vary—being words and being sentences with the force of a single word (having a parsing position)—the basis of relationships is only the Predication relationship existing between Predicate (*Musnad*) and Subject (*Musnad Ilayh*). Then, upon that mother Predication relationship, other relationships are built such as relationship of dependency, annexation, or attachment... Some Quranic verses, even if composed of several sentences, if you look at this verse, you see relationships between its sentences are grammatical relationships. Nay, some Surahs are nothing but a grammatical sentence embracing in its context smaller sentences attached to each other grammatically.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Look at Surah (Al-Asr) [The Time]. What do you see? You see nothing but a single grammatical sentence whose components are all attached to each other grammatically. Hence, the entire Surah is established from Compositional Order, not Arrangement Order. This is what you see also in Surah (Say, "He is Allah, [who is] One"). Despite that, it is a miracle for all creation. "Al-Biqa'i", in his interpretation of Compositional Order in sentence construction, links the signification of composition and stylistic features to the near and far context and to the main purpose of the Surah sometimes. Although his explanation of the link of the sentence's compositional signification to the extended context of the sentence might be faint, unseen by one in haste. It is not hidden that the wider the circle of context, the more the relationship of sentence construction characteristics to it enters into subtlety that requires its contemplator to have a flood of intellectual intelligence and tasteful purity. ***** There is no doubt that styles and patterns of Compositional Construction are very numerous styles and patterns that can hardly be encompassed, let alone counted. This places us in the position of one compelled to take and leave, to summarize and not exhaust detailing in what he takes. There are two defects I cannot purify myself from: the defect of taking some styles and leaving others, and the defect of summarization or satisfying with some forms of the style. This is a heinous defect in scientific research I detest greatly. How I wished not to be stained by either of them, but the goal set for this research leaves me no room for avoidance. *** Among the Compositional Order cared for by Al-Biqa'i, for example, is Specification (*Takhsis*) and its paths, which rhetoricians call (Restriction/Exclusivity - *Al-Qasr*). It is clear that paths of Specification in Arabic are very numerous, even if rhetoricians' attention was to a type with specificity in signifying Specification. In their study of methods of Restriction, they chose specific methods (Negation and Exception, *Innama*, Preposing, Conjunction with *Bal* and *Lakin* and *La*, Pronoun of Separation, and Defining both terms).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The criterion for selection was the method of indication of that meaning. Not everything indicating Specification according to non-rhetoricians is of the terminological Specification according to rhetoricians which they call (Restriction - *Al-Qasr*). Hence, the study of methods of Restriction according to rhetoricians is—in my view—from the Science of Bayan (Eloquence/Imagery) and not from the Science of Ma'ani (Meanings/Syntax). (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) The Science of Bayan is the science concerned with studying methods of indicating meanings, and is not concerned with studying meanings themselves nor studying how to compose and author the image indicating the meaning. We must differentiate between studying the meaning itself as it is, studying the image indicating it in terms of its composition method, and studying the image of meaning in terms of the face of its indication and the method of its indication of that meaning. Every study of the method of indication of image on meaning is from the Science of Bayan, whatever the image: simile, preposing, omission, command, prohibition, separation and connection, torus, matching, or punning... etc. Hence, the Science of Bayan is vast, not limited to Simile, Metaphor, and Metonymy as some students might imagine. These three: Simile, Metaphor, and Metonymy are only the most apparent and famous, but Science of Bayan is not confined to them. Science of Ma'ani is the science pursuing the view into meanings as they are, and into authoring images indicating them. So the method of authoring between components of the style of الاحتباك (Deletion for brevity/Implication), or Folding and Spreading, or Employment, or Enallage (Iltifat), or Restriction and Release, or Emphasis, or Matching, or Pairing, or Good Division, and others is from Science of Ma'ani. So the difference between the two sciences is a difference in the methodology by which the style is studied, not a difference in the styles themselves studied by each science. It is not said Preposing, Omission, and Separation are from Science of Ma'ani alone, just as it is not said Simile is from Science of Bayan or Punning and Returning Endings are from Science of Badi'. The matter returns to the methodology of handling and study, not to the style being studied. Every style is studied in the three sciences with three methodologies; each science has its methodology. Like what I said about Specification, we say about others.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In his interpretation of Specification which rhetoricians call (*Al-Qasr*), he is concerned with matters including its methods, its signification, and the relationship of that to context and the near or far intent. Sometimes you see him stating that the method of "Negation and Exception" is the most explicit type of Restriction. He says regarding the saying of Allah Almighty: {So I have warned you of a Fire which is blazing. * None will [enter to] burn therein except the most wretched one. * Who had denied and turned away.} (Al-Layl: 14-16): "Since it had preceded more than once the specification of each of the Doer of Good and the Doer of Evil with his abode by way of Restriction, rejecting that a doer of good be equated with a doer of evil in anything, and Restriction by (La - No) and (Illa - Except) is its most explicit type, He said (None will burn therein) i.e., suffer its heat and severity by way of necessity and immersion (except the most wretched) i.e., who is at the peak of wretchedness, and he is the Disbeliever" (1). Observe his saying "its most explicit type". This indicates he is looking at the method and degree of its indication of the meaning of Restriction. This is from the characteristics of the Science of Bayan "A science by which presenting a single meaning in different ways of clarity of indication is known" as "Al-Khatib" says in "Al-Idah". He explains to us the reason the Station required expression with the most explicit method of Specification: Negation and Exception. The Station dictates that there be no ambiguity at all in distinguishing between the destiny of the Doer of Good and the Doer of Evil and the abode of each in his Hereafter. So it was necessary that Restriction be by a tool whose indication of restriction is by *Wad'* (linguistic assignment), wherein no one hesitates, and which has no indication of anything else in any other context. Negation and Vacated Exception provides the meaning of Restriction by way of *Wad'* - and you do not find this method indicating other than specification in any case, unlike *Innama* or Preposing or Definition.... And Al-Biqa'i looks in another place at Restriction by Negation and Exception, and selecting it from among other methods of Restriction.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Allah Majestic is His Majesty says: {Indeed, they who conceal what Allah has sent down of the Book and exchange it for a small price - those consume not into their bellies except the Fire. And Allah will not speak to them on the Day of Resurrection, nor will He purify them. And they will have a painful punishment.} (Al-Baqarah: 174). If you look at this sentence, you see that the predicate of the Subject expressed by the demonstrative pronoun came as a sentence built from a style of Restriction whose method is Negation and Exception. The gaze stops at two words from the elements of this sentence located in the position of the predicate: "consume/eat" and "the Fire". One might calculate that in each is a semantic shift (metaphor). But Al-Biqa'i sees in selecting Negation and Exception as methods of Restriction in the verse a preventer preventing the assumption of metaphor. He says: "In mentioning it with the form of Restriction is a negation of the interpreter's interpretation of it being a cause [i.e., cause of fire], and diverting it to the face of reality which revelation attains but senses fall short of. They were in that like the numbed person whose hand is in the water but he does not feel it. This indicates the death of the senses of these people regarding the state of what they consumed" (1). The context of the verse speaks about those rabbis concealing what Allah Almighty revealed to buy a small price with it. That is the lowest a person busy with knowledge or affiliated with it can reach. So "Al-Biqa'i" explained that the explicit mention of His saying Almighty (into their bellies) fits with the giving of Restriction, as they lift the assumption of metaphor in eating or fire. Both are reality, not metaphor (2).

1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: 2 / 351 
2. - There is a significant matter in this related to the statement of metaphor in some words of the Holy Quran or its structures. It is thought that its indication of what was sensory of its meanings is a real indication, and what was abstract of them, its indication was metaphorical, like here, and like Blindness in Allah's saying: ((And whoever is blind in this [life] will be blind in the Hereafter...)) (Al-Isra: 73). The basis of this for those who say it is their calculation that the First Man did not use words except in sensory indication. When he rose culturally, he perceived abstracts, so he borrowed for them from words what resembles them in sensory things... This is a misleading calculation: The First Man in the guidance of the Book and Sunnah is Adam, father of humans. He is a Prophet whom Allah Almighty created with His hand and taught him all names and dwelled him in Paradise, the model of sensory and abstract beauty. So he was never oblivious to abstract significations of words. Words accommodate indicating many sensory and abstract significations without preference by priority or precedence of assignment or otherwise, even if degrees of clarity in indicating these significations vary. It is not a variation of assignment (*Wad'*). So the indication of the word "Blindness" on losing the eye of the heart (Sight) ability to perceive sensory things is not the real assigned indication, and its indication on losing the eye of the heart (Insight) to perceive abstracts is the metaphorical indication of similarity. Nay, the word Blindness indicates losing the ability to see things. Vision is two types: vision of the sensory aspect of things, this is for the head's eye (Sight), and vision of their abstract aspect, this is for the heart's eye (Insight). Whoever loses either is blind in reality, not metaphorically.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is a real fire burning the internal meanings by which a person is human. Lack of feeling this fire is due to the dullness of their sense, not its non-existence in them or their existence in it. Selecting Negation and Exception does not fit with stating metaphor in Fire or Eating, because metaphor has a claim, while in Restriction by this method is decisiveness and finality. The crime here is not committed except by one who reached a great extent in misguidance and severance. Whoever is among the scholars of the Revealed Divine Book then exchanges it for a worldly offer that does not weigh the wing of a mosquito with Allah Almighty, his deed is only from the burning of meanings of goodness in him, a severe burning. In this is a warning to the scholars of the Muhammadan Ummah not to conceal anything of what Allah Almighty revealed to please a person of authority or out of fear of him or looking forward to an enjoyment of the world. *** We look at another place of Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of the style of Specification in the saying of Allah Almighty: {Say, "I am only a warner, and there is not any deity except Allah, the One, the Prevailing.} (Sad: 65). Al-Biqa'i sees that the Restriction in (I am only a warner) is a Restriction of a Described to a Description (*Qasr Mawsuf 'ala Sifah*), a Restriction of Reversal (*Qasr Qalb*). And that in (And there is not any deity except Allah, the One, the Prevailing) is a Restriction of a Description to a Described (*Qasr Sifah 'ala Mawsuf*), a Restriction of Singularity (*Qasr Ifrad*). He says: "Since it was their custom when threatened to say: 'Hasten this for us if you are truthful in what you claimed', and it is cut (certain) that no one is capable of that except the Deity, they became as if they attributed to him that he claimed Divinity. He Almighty said alerting to that, commanding him to answer (Say) i.e., to the one who says that to you (I am only a warner) i.e., frightening to one who disobeyed. I did not claim I am a god so that might be asked of me, for no one is capable of the like of it except the Deity. So it is a Restriction of Reversal of the Described to the Description. And He singled out a restrictor of the Description in His saying (And there is not) and drowned in negation by His saying (any deity) i.e., worshiped by right, due to Him encompassing attributes of perfection.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And since the context was for Monotheism (Tawhid) which is the root of religion, He turned the speech from the manifestation of Greatness to One greater and clearer, so He said (Except Allah). For Encompassing, He expressed with the Proper Name gathering all Beautiful Names; if anything shared with Him, He would not be Encompassing. For Exclusivity, He said proving that (The One) i.e., in every consideration; so it is not possible that He has a part or has a like, thus being needy and equaled. (The Prevailing) i.e., who subdues others to what He wants. This is proof that He is the Deity alone, and that their deities are far from deserving divinity due to their multiplicity, equivalence by similarity, and neediness" (1). The Context and Intent guide that the Composition in (I am only a warner) indicates restricting the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and salutations abundant) to the attribute of Warning, and removing him from the suspicion that he claims Divinity. For their habit upon which they proceeded when he frightened them with evil consequence was to attribute to him the claim of what is only from Allah Almighty, and demand him to bring them what he frightens them with. So the Holy Quranic Expression comes turning their claim of attributing him to that against them, confirming that he does not exceed being a warner causing fear as revealed to him. Designating the Attribute negated in the Restriction by *Innama* here is linked closely to the context and the stance of the addressees. It looks at the near context existing in explaining the return of the pious and the return of the tyrants, and what it included of threatening the deniers, and at the condition of the deniers when they face that threat and explanation of their destination if they persist on it. If "Al-Biqa'i" holds that the Negated in (I am only a warner) is the claim of Divinity, he points out shortly after that in that is also a negation of the claim that he is a liar. As if the Composition in this context gazes at the beginning of the context and its end:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Its end guides that the description negated in (I am only a warner) is the claim of Divinity. And the beginning of the context {And the disbelievers say, "This is a magician, a liar."} (Sad: from verse 4) guides that the description negated in (I am only a warner) is Lying. Al-Biqa'i says afterwards: "When He restricted his noble self to Warning, and they were disputing him in it and attributing lying to him, He indicated his truthfulness and the greatness of this news by His saying Majestic is His Majesty: {I had no knowledge of the exalted assembly [angels] when they were disputing} (Sad: 69)." He glances in the saying of Allah Almighty (I had no knowledge...) an indication of his truthfulness in what he informs about his Lord, refuting their claim that he is a liar. And he glances in it a confirmation of the concept of Restriction in (I am only a warner) on the other face. As if the Restriction in (I am only a warner) was surrounded by what guides that he restricts himself to Warning and negates from it what some of them accuse him of claiming Divinity and ability to bring what he threatens them with, and negates from it what others accuse him of that he is a liar. So the Composition carries the indication of the negation of both descriptions with the aid of Context and surrounding clues. *** Let us look at another Compositional pattern, high in status, glorious in giving, generous: based on the positions of words in sentence construction, known among Bayan scholars as Preposing and Postposing (*Taqdim wa Ta'khir*). Standing upon the positions of words and fields of their movement in style construction is of glorious importance and at the same time of extreme difficulty. Perhaps for that reason, Abdul Qahir Al-Jurjani's attention to Preposing and Postposing and ranks of words and their orders in explaining the pillar of speech rhetoric (*Nazm*) was great. He frequently referred to Preposing, Postposing, and Arrangement. He dedicated a special chapter for Preposing in Dala'il al-I'jaz, opening it with a noble introduction in which he says:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "It is a chapter of many benefits, abundant beauties, wide disposal, far reaching. It continues to smile at you with a marvel and lead you to a subtlety. You continue to see poetry whose hearing pleases you and whose impact is gentle to you, then you look and find the reason it pleased you and was gentle to you is that something was preposed in it, and the wording was transferred from a place to a place" (1). An introduction of high order and phrasing. I see it was phrased in a way by which the Imam reveals something of the status of Preposing and Postposing in the order of Expression, and at the same time tempts us to linger at that rhetorical methodology to fulfill some of its due and harvest some of its fruit. He did the like of that with the chapter of (Omission) and the chapter of (Separation and Connection), which are chapters he almost exhausted speech on in their place. Al-Biqa'i has attention to the style of Preposing, Postposing, and Arrangement. Nay, he makes Preposing, Postposing, and Arrangement in sentence construction part of what he called Compositional Order (*Nazm Tarkibi*). There is no Preposing unless there is a diversion of the thing from its place which belongs to it originally. So everything established to be preceding is not of the Preposing based on diversion for indication of a desired meaning to be expressed. Preposing particles of interrogation or negation is not said to have behind it a meaning the speaker raced to by preposing, a race requiring artifice and choice. Rather, it is preposing from the origin of the language, existing as an obligation in every tongue speaking Arabic. So there is no merit for the speaker in this preposing; rather the merit—and it is existing and established—is for the nature of the clear Arabic tongue. Similar to this is preposing the semi-sentence predicate over the indefinite subject. There is no precedence behind it that the preposer aimed for contrary to the rhetorical nature of Arabic. Rather, you see in preposing that subject then a race to an effort to indicate a meaning that would not exist except by that precedence based on diversion from what is the origin of rhetorical nature.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Thus, Preposing looks at the diversion of the word or the preposed item from its place which belongs to it to a preceding place. This might be accompanied by diversion from the grammatical case that belonged to it or not. While later rhetoricians' attention was directed primarily to preposing one of the two pillars of the sentence over the other, then preposing attachments over what they attach to or what what-they-attach-to is attributed to, or preposing attachments over each other, Al-Biqa'i's view extends to preposing numerous elements, whether from the sentence pillars or its restrictions or attachments. ***** The Truth Majestic is His Majesty says: {[The time of] their account has approached for the people, while they are in heedlessness turning away.} (Al-Anbiya: 1). Al-Biqa'i looks at the order of the verse, seeing a preposing of the verb's attachment (for the people) and postposing of the subject (their account). He explains to us that "The expression came by delaying the 'Subject' and preposing the verb's attachment, because in this delay is 'Intimidation (*Tahwil*), so the soul may go every way in determining it'" (1). This fits the objective of the Surah and what it was driven for of "Deducing the realization of the Hour and its proximity even by death, and the occurrence of Account in it for the great and the small" (2). As if opening with the form *Ifti'al* (Iqtaraba - Approached) instead of the simple verb (Qaruba - came near) is an indication "to increased nearness; because there is no nation after this nation whose affair is awaited". So it is in the breath of the Hour. Thus, expression by the form *Ifti'al* and delaying the Subject met in indicating the severity of the Hour's proximity and the severity of the terror within it.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And his saying "so the soul may go every way in determining it" contains an indication that the vastness of the signified and its variety might not be expressed by a word uttered by the tongue, but might be by diverting a word's location to another location. As if the word giving up its place which belongs to it is only for a majestic matter that forms of expression speaking by word failed to fulfill its right, so diversion from locations of words was assigned to fulfill its right. In this is a discipline for the Ummah that every position-holder who sees that in delaying himself from it or advancing [another] over him is what grants this Ummah a flood of blessing, then it is of High Manners to adopt it descending to the requirement of its condition. How many a person advanced in life's setting, conditions dictate his delay and advancing one who is below him in rank of setting. So consideration is for what conditions dictate. *** Among instances where Diversion was of glorious giving is the saying of the Truth Almighty: {And He brought down those who supported them among the People of the Scripture from their fortresses and cast terror into their hearts - [so that] a party you killed, and you took captive a party.} (Al-Ahzab: 26). What surrounds the verses depicts the terror, panic, and exemplary punishment that befell the Jews supporting the Confederates. The expression about Bani Qurayzah by the relative pronoun and its clause (those who supported them) does not hide its giving, highlighting fame by the clause and correspondence of recompense to their crime. So bringing them down from their strongholds was the sign of recompense for this treachery. Merely starting with this in the context of terror and exemplary punishment is understood as bringing down for humiliation. But "Al-Biqa'i" sees that "Since bringing down from a place of immunity is a wonder, and was of various types, it was not explicit in humiliation. So the soul yearned for the clarification of its condition. He clarified that it is Humiliation, so He said conjoining with 'Waw' (And) to be fit for what is before and what is after {and cast terror into their hearts}..." (1). He directs the conjunction with "Waw" that His saying {cast terror into their hearts} was fit to point to two terrors: The terror that brought them down from their fortresses...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: And the terror that filled them while they were in the grip of the Muslims. One of them [the effects] was before the bringing down [from their fortresses], and the other was after it. He explicitly mentioned the second terror {and cast terror into their hearts} due to the horror of what resulted from it, which is His saying, Majesty be to Him: {A group you kill, and you take captive a group}, unlike what resulted from the first bringing down. He contemplates the preposing of the object in {A group you kill} and sees that "when He mentioned what He humiliated them with, He mentioned what resulted from it, dividing it, so He said (A group), mentioning it with the wording of a faction, and put it in the accusative case to indicate from the very beginning that it is subject to the hands of the doers (you kill), who are the men, and they were about seven hundred. And when He began with what indicated division, from which separation comes, and presented the greater of the two effects resulting from the terror, He followed it with the other effect; so that the two beloved effects would surround what indicates separation. So He said: (and you take captive a group), who are the offspring and women. Perhaps He delayed the group here to indicate choice in their matter, and presented the men due to the inevitability of killing regarding them" (1). Al-Biqa'i clarified the contribution of the root (Fariq - group/separation) and its placement as an object, without being raised to be a subject—such that it would be said: 'and a group you kill', meaning 'you kill it'—and the interaction of the two contributions: the root material and the position (objectivity) to depict the humiliation that encompassed them. This confirms and clarifies the richness of the Quranic word and the multiplicity of the tributaries of signification and benefit, and demonstrates the alertness of Al-Biqa'i in his penetrating contemplation. In the preposing, beyond what was mentioned, there is a building of suspense for the Muslim soul that lived moments of anxiety over the fate of Islam. So the verb comes after defining the object to determine the fate of the preposed group. If the indication of attributing the verb to the Muslims is added to it—while previous verbs were attributed to the Truth (Allah), Glory be to Him—then the two contributions harmonize in a way that contains healing for the souls that suffered the utmost moments of anxiety.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Al-Biqa'i, while clarifying the contribution of postposing the object in (you take captive a group), was generous and excellent. Observing the coordination of verbs and the two objects confirms the precision of Al-Biqa'i's observation of the Quranic sentence coordination, a coordination in which content and form interact. How sensitive Al-Biqa'i was when he glimpsed and pointed out the indication of preposing the object first as the inevitability of the fate for those presented, as if in the preposing there is an indication of confirming the occurrence of what was delayed upon them (killing). And in postposing the object after the verb (you take captive a group) is an indication that doing that to them is not inevitable; rather, they have the choice to do other than that to them if the matter requires. "Al-Biqa'i's" essay on the contribution of preposing (Taqdim) and its gift in the construction of Quranic expression is very extensive and marvelous. Let the context allow for a spread of speech, for it is but a signal enticing one to travel into his interpretation of the rhetoric of the Holy Quran in his exegesis "Nazm al-Durar" and its summary "Dalalat al-Burhan al-Qawim," which is still a manuscript. *** Among the compositional systems cared for by rhetoricians and exegetes in interpreting the Holy Quran is (Deletion/Omission - Al-Hadhf). Linguistically, it is: cutting, dropping, and throwing. In the terminology of rhetoricians: leaving out the mention of part of the speech due to a motive requiring that leaving, and due to a clue indicating the omitted part. In naming the unmentioned part "deleted" (Mahdhuf), there is an indication that this unmentioned part, since the origin (the dominant frequency) is to mention it due to the statement's dire need for it or otherwise, it is as if it was mentioned, even if by rhetorical force and not in actuality, then deleted for a matter that required that deletion: (Leaving). In this, there is further alert that leaving its mention despite its importance is only for a strong motive worthy of being counted. This is one aspect. Another aspect that can be noticed is that the unmentioned part does not exist except with a clue indicating it. So they made the indication of the clue regarding it as if it were mentioned, then there was the deletion of its wording and the remaining of its proof, thus realizing something of the meaning of "dropping" which is the linguistic meaning of deletion.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: In this aspect, there is an alert to the importance of the clue indicating it, whereas the first aspect contains an alert to the importance of the motive for leaving its mention. It is not hidden that the rhetorical view is arranged upon the grammatical view. Grammar is concerned with the matter of the clue, which is the validator of the deletion, and which had the second aspect. Rhetoric is concerned with the matter of the motive for leaving, which is the preponderant beautifier of the deletion, and which had the first aspect. I presented it in accordance with the science we are in the process of discussing. Among what is narrated from the people of knowledge is their saying: "Rhetoric is Brevity." It is a saying that understands the nature of eloquent expression in which the utterance of the tongue is meager, while the hidden content of the heart is abundant. This linguistic utterance carries in its womb a flood of meanings, precise and subtle, of which the tongue is incapable of projecting the phonetic equivalent. The virtue of brevity does not stop at this; rather, it is a path to establishing the listener and the recipient in a station where he goes to wide, vast doctrines to harvest the fruits of this brief expression. For the listener finds great pleasure in his endeavor to estimate what the weaving of the statement came to delete and fold the mention of. It is as if the listener and addressee, especially in the supreme miraculous expression of the Quran and Sunnah, finds in the speaker's opening of the door of estimating what was folded of mention an elevation of his status. It is as if he invites him to weave himself into this statement, to insert the silk thread that he supplies to complete the weaving of that marvelous brocade. It is the pleasure that no pleasure equals. It is strange that the more you increase in knowledge of the speech, and increase in closeness to the speaker and knowledge of him, high doors of estimation open to you that were not open to you while you were in the lower and further station. Likewise, you find yourself with the statements of deletion in elevation, refreshment of activity, and enjoyment of varieties of pleasure that do not end and are not restricted. Brevity is the hospitality of the speaker for the listener, and a notification from him to the recipient of brotherhood: Indeed, the eloquent speaker and the eloquent recipient in his reception are brothers...

It is strange that the more you increase in knowledge of the speech, and increase in closeness to the speaker and knowledge of him, high doors of estimation open to you that were not open to you while you were in the lower and further station. Likewise, you find yourself with the statements of deletion in elevation, refreshment of activity, and enjoyment of varieties of pleasure that do not end and are not restricted. Brevity is the hospitality of the speaker for the listener, and a notification from him to the recipient of brotherhood: Indeed, the eloquent speaker and the eloquent recipient in his reception are brothers...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: And brevity, in its indication of multiplied meanings, takes a path that is not exposed; rather, it gifts you its subtleties wrapped in silk curtains, and that is what the soul that tastes the beauty of expression adores. Deletion is a type of brevity characterized by what is above what I mentioned to you. "Imam Abd al-Qahir al-Jurjani" had words in his book: "Dalail al-I'jaz" (Proofs of Inimitability) at the beginning of his speech in the chapter of "Deletion," in which he pointed to something of the beauties of deletion, its virtues, and its gifts. He says in it: "It is a door of precise path, subtle source, wondrous matter, resembling magic. For you see by it that leaving mention is more eloquent than mention, and silence regarding benefit is an increase in benefit. You find yourself most expressive when you do not speak, and most complete in clarity when you do not clarify. This is a sentence you might deny until you experience it, and reject until you look into it" (1). This phrase of "Abd al-Qahir" is very rich in subtle indications and noble significations. He has enticed you and guided you to something of its subtleties by his expression in it, an expression he established on the method of resonant melodic signing. Contemplate his phrase played on the strings of rhyme (Saj'), balance, returning the ends to the beginnings on one hand, and contrast on the other hand. In this, there is an allusion to what "Deletion" contains of marvelous meanings and aesthetics (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) - Dalail al-I'jaz by Abd al-Qahir 164 - Ed: Shakir 
2. - And as you look into this word of "Abd al-Qahir" with which he introduces his speech on deletion, you find it enticing to look into the way deletion indicates meaning. That is, he entices you to look at deletion from the perspective of its indication of meanings, and this is the methodology upon which what rhetoricians call the Science of Bayan (Imagery) is based. He does not entice you to look at the composition and synthesis of the image of meaning based on the method of deletion as much as he entices you to look at the ways this image indicates meaning. It is as if he incites you to stand guard, struggling in a breach where guards are few: the breach of interpreting and contemplating the ways the image of meaning indicates it. The truth is that we are reckless in contemplating the ways of synthesizing and composing images of meanings, more than our care for contemplating and pondering the ways those images indicate their meanings. And as you look into Abd al-Qahir's explanation of the meaning of eloquence (Fasaha), rhetoric (Balagha), skill (Bara'a), clarity (Bayan), and the like, you find him making the origin of the characteristics of this reality the goodness of indication and its completeness. Looking into the goodness of indication is looking into the methodology of the Science of Bayan according to the later scholars. And as you look into the explanation of "Al-Rummani" before him regarding the meaning of rhetoric in his book (Al-Nukat), you find him making the origin of its reality from the goodness of its indication, as he says: Rhetoric is conveying the meaning to the heart in the best form of wording. Do you not see his saying (conveying the meaning to the heart)? Is this not a discussion on indication and not on the signifier or the signified? ... Is not the name of Rhetoric (Balagha) derived from conveying (Iblagh) which is delivery (Isal) which is indication (Dalala)?...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Behind the deletion of a word or a letter... there may be what pours into your heart a flood of meanings, and into your hearing a flood of aesthetics. The recipient who is eloquent in his reception, and creative in reading the expression, is enamored with the aesthetics of speech as much as he is enamored with its meanings, especially the expression of the miraculous noble Revelation, for among its aesthetics is a rain of its meanings. Space here does not allow for detailing images of Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of the style of deletion in the Holy Quran and the significations of that deletion and the mode of its indication of them. But what draws the attention of the reader of his exegesis is his care for a type of deletion that not many exegetes and rhetoricians care for, even if looking at it is as old as rhetorical thinking and contemplation of Arabic expression in general and Quranic expression in particular. It is what is called: "Reciprocal Deletion" (Al-Hadhf al-Taqabuli), or "Al-Ihtibak." Al-Biqa'i had extreme, eloquent care for interpreting this style. If we were to collect his essays on it in his exegesis, we would have from that a volume that would be a substitute for his book which he classified and authored on it and named (Al-Idrak li fann al-Ihtibak) [Realization of the Art of Reciprocal Omission]. (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) - Al-Suyuti says in his book: (Al-Tahbir fi 'Ilm al-Tafsir) "The Seventy-Third Type: Al-Ihtibak. This type is from my additions and it is a subtle type and we have not seen anyone from the people of Ma'ani, Bayan, and Badi' mention it. I had contemplated His saying, Exalted is He: (They will see therein neither sun nor freezing cold) (Al-Insan: 13) and the two opinions regarding freezing cold (Zamharir): it was said it is the moon in opposition to the sun, and it was said it is the cold. I said perhaps the intended meaning is the cold, and He indicated by the sun that there is no moon therein, and by the freezing cold that there is no heat therein, so He deleted from each side the opposite of the other. I said to myself: This is a subtle type of Badi' (Innovated Rhetoric) but I do not know its name nor do I know in the types of Badi' what suits it, until some virtuous Imams [meaning his Sheikh Al-Biqa'i] guided me that he heard some of his sheikhs establish the like of that for him in His saying, Exalted is He: (one fighting in the cause of Allah and another disbelieving) (Al-Imran: 13)... He said: This type is called Al-Ihtibak. The mentioned virtuous Imam said: I sought that in several books but did not find it, and I think it is in Sharh al-Hawi by Ibn al-Athir. Then the mentioned [Al-Biqa'i] authored a subtle composition on this type named (Al-Idrak fi fann al-Ihtibak)... Then I found this exact type mentioned in the explanation of the Badiyyah of Abu Abdullah ibn Jabir by his companion Ahmad ibn Yusuf al-Andalusi, known as the Blind and the Sighted. He said in his text: 'Among the types of Badi': "Al-Ihtibak", and it is a rare type, which is to delete from the first what its counterpart proves in the second, and from the second what its counterpart proves in the first, like His saying, Exalted is He: (The example of those who disbelieve is like that of one who shouts...) (Al-Baqarah: 171). The estimation: The example of the Prophets and the disbelievers is like the example of one who shouts and one who is shouted at. He deleted from the first: The Prophets, due to the indication of 'one who shouts' to it, and from the second: 'one who is shouted at' due to the indication of 'those who disbelieve' to it...'" (Al-Tahbir by Al-Suyuti: 128-129 - Ed: Dar al-Kutub al-Ilmiyyah: 1408 - Beirut. See with it: "Tiraz al-Hullah wa Shifa al-Ghillah by Abu Ja'far al-Ru'ayni al-Gharnati - p: 508 - Ed: Raja' al-Sayyid al-Jawhari - Mu'assasat al-Thaqafa al-Jami'iyyah - Alexandria. See also Al-Burhan by Al-Zarkashi: 3/129, Al-Itqan by Al-Suyuti: 3/182, Sharh 'Uqud al-Juman 133..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: The first thing that meets you of this in his exegesis interpreting this style is his interpretation of the saying of Allah, Mighty and Majestic: {It is He who created for you all of that which is on the earth. Then He directed Himself to the heaven, [and] fashioned them seven heavens, and He is Knowing of all things} (Al-Baqarah: 29). He says: "When He, Glory be to Him, summarized in the beginning of this verse (v: 28) the beginning of their affair, its middle, and its end in the manner previously mentioned, which alerts that disbelief should be among the impossible due to the dazzling proofs against it, He began detailing it in a manner inviting them to His side by bestowing types of beneficence with a matter higher in benefiting the objective than what was before it, according to the habit of the Quran in ascending from the high to the higher. So He, Glory be to Him, drove the beginning of creation, which is among the greatest proofs of His Oneness, in the course of bestowing favors upon His servants... So He said (He).. (who created for you.. what is in the earth) after He fashioned them seven... (all together)... And since the heaven was nobler in terms of the altitude that cannot be sought... He expressed its affair with 'Then' so He said (Then He directed Himself to the heaven)... (so He fashioned them seven heavens)... and created all that is in them for you. So the verse is of 'Ihtibak': He deleted firstly the fact that the earths are seven due to the indication of the second upon it, and secondly the fact that what is in the heaven is for us due to the indication of the first upon it. It is a rare, precious art, and I have collected a good book on it in which I mentioned its definition, its source from the language, and what examples of it were present to me from the Dear Book and the speech of jurists, and I named it: 'Al-Idrak li fann al-Ihtibak' [Realization of the Art of Reciprocal Omission]..." (1) Al-Biqa'i clarified for us what was deleted due to the indication of the textual clue upon it, and he did not clarify for us here the rhetorical aspect for deleting what was deleted and mentioning what was mentioned, just as he did not clarify for us here the definition of (Ihtibak), although he defined it in a place coming later.
