category_en: Quranic Sciences and Principles of Tafsir
book_title_en: Al-Biqai and His Method in Interpreting the Eloquence of the Quran
text_en: Perhaps the reason for what was omitted in the verse is that the omission, and the statement that the earth was made seven, while mentioning that the heavens were made seven, refers to the creation of the heavens as seven, which is part of the unseen and cannot be known except through revelation. It will not be within the scope of human knowledge at any stage until the Day of Judgment to fully perceive it through tools or methods. To this day, we have not seen even one of those heavens, and what our eyes perceive is not the heaven in its reality but a blue expanse between our vision. As for making the earth seven, this is something that human knowledge might be able to comprehend. In Surah At-Talaq, there is an indication of this: {It is Allah who created seven heavens and of the earth the like of them. His command descends among them so that you may know that Allah is over all things competent and that Allah has encompassed all things in knowledge} [At-Talaq: 12]. The Prophetic Sunnah also clarifies this. Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated: 'Whoever takes a portion of the earth unlawfully will have it sink beneath him on the Day of Resurrection to seven earths.'

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Perhaps the reason for deleting what was deleted in the verse is that the deleted part, which is making the earth seven—indicated by the mention of making the heavens seven—is that making the heavens seven is of the Unseen (Ghayb) which there is no way to know except by Revelation. It will not be in the possession of Science in any of its stages until the Hour rises to view it with its tools and methods. For we, until this day of ours, have not seen a single heaven of those heavens, and what our eyes perceive is not the heaven in its reality; rather, it is a blue barrier between our eyes and the heaven. As for making the earth seven, that is a matter for which science may have a way to its knowledge. Moreover, in Surah (At-Talaq) there is what indicates that {It is Allah who has created seven heavens and of the earth, the like of them. [His] command descends among them so that you may know that Allah is over all things competent and that Allah has encompassed all things in knowledge} (At-Talaq: 12). And in the Prophetic Sunnah, there is a clear statement of that. The two Sheikhs narrated: "Whoever takes a piece of land without right will be swallowed up with it on the Day of Resurrection to seven earths" (Al-Bukhari: Beginning of Creation, and the text is his, and Muslim: Musaqat).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: Likewise, the making of what is in the heavens for us, since it is not apparent to many servants unlike what is on the earth, He deleted it, and mentioned what is apparent in its matter to all servants. He folded what was not apparent to all of them to achieve complete communication of gratitude by mentioning the blessing. So He combined for us the blessing of informing us of what we have no way to know except by Revelation—which is a very high blessing not appreciated fully except by one who knows the value of the blessing of knowledge and science, and knows the danger of the calamity of ignorance and misguidance, and that knowledge is life and ignorance is death—and the blessing of gratitude that what is on earth is for us. So we must strive to invest it well for what contains a good return and destiny, and that whoever neglects the good comprehension of investing what is on earth has indeed lost a manifest loss. If we were to return with our insight to His saying, Majesty be to Him: {It is He who created for you all of that which is on the earth}, and contemplate this definition of the two parties (He) (who), and its indication of exclusivity signaling Monotheism (Tawhid), and that there is no maker of that except Allah, Glory be to Him. And taste the preposing of (for you), overflowing into the hearts of the people of knowledge floods of intimacy, love, and anticipation to know the beloved's gift to them. Look how much is the longing of the lover to know what his beloved gifts him when it is indicated to him that he has a gift from him?!!! So how if the gift is from the Lord of the Worlds?!! And taste the openness of the gift in His saying (what is in the earth) and what the phrase indicates of signs of preserving it and guarding it from the hands of those who do not deserve it. And that the gift, due to its preciousness to its giver, He did not place on the surface of the earth to be touched by hands not worthy of it, but rather He placed it (in the earth). This adverbiality indicates great preservation first for the majestic hidden [treasure], and the obligation of seriousness in seeking, believing in the great value of the hidden gift.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Quran
text: And contemplate His saying (all together), which has a broad indication: It can be a circumstantial adverb (Hal) from the pronoun in (for you), meaning there is no difference between you in this except by the amount of your striving to acquire your Lord's gift to you. This is descended from the meaning of His saying (Lord of the Worlds) and His saying (The Most Merciful) at the beginning of Surah Al-Fatiha, for they are two names indicating His vast grace and that He bestows upon all His creation floods of Merciful Lordship. And it can be a circumstantial adverb from the object of (created/made), meaning He made what is in the earth all of it, not withholding any of it from any of His creation if he is worthy to receive. I see no harm in combining both aspects together. That is what became clear to me. Although he addressed the style of Ihtibak in Surah Al-Baqarah in several places, he did not explain to us the concept of Ihtibak except in Surah (Al-Imran) when interpreting the saying of Allah, Glory be to Him: {Already there has been for you a sign in the two armies which met - one fighting in the cause of Allah and another of disbelievers. They saw them [to be] twice their [own] number by [actual] eyesight. But Allah supports with His victory whom He wills. Indeed in that is a lesson for those of vision} (Al-Imran: 13). He says: "The verse, as you see, is from the valley of Ihtibak, which is: to bring two statements from each of which something is deleted for brevity, what is mentioned indicating what is deleted from the other. In other words: it is to delete from every sentence something for brevity, and mention in the other sentence what indicates it" (1). The dominant feature of Al-Biqa'i's methodology is that he is concerned with clarifying what was deleted and what indicated it mentioned in the statement, and he may mention the rhetorical aspect for deleting what was deleted and mentioning what was mentioned. That is like what you see in his interpretation of the compositional system in the saying of Allah, Mighty and Majestic:

book_title: Imam al-Biqāʿī and His Method in Interpreting the Eloquence of the Qur’an
text:
{“So let those fight in the cause of Allah who sell the life of this world for the Hereafter. And whoever fights in the cause of Allah and is killed or achieves victory—We will grant him a great reward.”} (al-Nisāʾ: 74)

He says:

“(And whoever fights in the cause of Allah) meaning: his intention is to elevate the word of the Sovereign who encompasses all qualities of beauty and majesty.

(And is killed) meaning: in that path, while maintaining that intention, after divine decree and destiny take hold of him.

(Or achieves victory) meaning: he overcomes the disbelievers and is saved.

(We shall grant him) meaning: with a promise that has no failure…

The verse contains *iḥtibāk* (stylistic omission): mentioning *killing* first indicates safety second, and mentioning *prevailing* second indicates the possibility of being overcome first.

Perhaps the use of the particle *sawfa* (shall) hints at the usually long life of the mujāhid, contrary to what many people assume—informing us that the matter belongs to the action of the All‑Wise Doer, not to outward causes.

(A great reward)…

His limitation of the verse to these two states encourages steadfastness, even if the enemy is more than twice in number…"

(1) Al‑Biqāʿī points out that the Qur’anic expression mentioned *killing* in a form where the Muslim is grammatically the recipient of the action *(yuqtal – is killed)*, and mentioned *prevailing* in a form where he is the doer *(yaghlib – he overcomes)*. This illustrates the essence of Islam’s objective in jihad: the Muslim’s aim is not to slaughter the enemy nor to pursue worldly gains, but rather to seek victory for Islam and martyrdom in the path of Allah.

Victory is indicated by his saying *(yaghlib – he overcomes)*, and martyrdom is indicated by *(yuqtal – is killed)*.

This obligates every mujāhid to remain firm in battle even if his enemy possesses numbers and weapons.

And when this is the Muslim’s method, the result is nothing but honor and glory; in the honor of the Muslims lies the safety and security of the people of the world. For whenever the authority was in the hands of the Muslims in any time or place, people lived in peace and ease. ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Ihtibak" (reciprocal omission) and Compound Simile may intersect, such that the fabric of the simile is built upon reciprocal deletion. One of the most famous verses regarding this is the saying of Allah, Majestic is His Majesty: {The example of those who disbelieve is like that of one who shouts at what hears nothing but calls and cries cattle or sheep - deaf, dumb and blind, so they do not understand.} (Al-Baqarah: 171). This verse came in a context depicting the state of a group of people who take rivals besides Allah Almighty and follow the footsteps of Satan. When they are commanded to follow what Allah Almighty has revealed, they say, "Rather, we follow that upon which we found our fathers," even though their fathers understood nothing, nor were they guided. So, He depicted them in an image from which every rational soul flees; He depicted them, along with those calling them to guidance, in the image of a shepherd and his sheep at which he shouts to drive them away from danger, yet they hear nothing but his voice and do not comprehend what he shouts at them. Al-Biqa'i says: "Since the estimation was: 'Their example, then, is like one who follows a blind man on a rugged, hidden path in vast, dangerous deserts,' He conjoined to it what guides to its estimation from His saying Almighty - alerting that they have become by this like cattle, or even more astray; because even though [cattle] do not reason, they hear and see, thus finding their way to their benefits - (The example). And He explained the description that carried them to this ignorance by His saying (of those who disbelieve)... in that they do not hear from the call anything but the sound of the tone and the echo of the voice without applying their minds or having insight (is like that of one). Al-Harralli said: 'A mathal (parable) is what is obtained in the inner perception from the realities of sensory things, so it is subtler than the sensory thing. Therefore, it occurs clarifying a meaning like the intelligible meaning. The more apparent of the two serves as a parable for the more hidden. Thus, the clarification of a parable comes by a parable to refine the apparent sensory [image] and bring down the known absent [concept]. In this verse, the clarification occurs between the two parables, not between the two objects of the parable, due to the closeness of the two parables in meaning—which is the point of resemblance—and the distance between the two objects of the parable...'

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In mentioning these two parables, there is a contrast that allows the understanding of two other parables. This necessitated two representations within a single parable. It is as if the fulfillment of the wording understood by this brevity is: 'The example of those who disbelieve and the example of their shepherd [caller], is like the example of the shepherd and the example of what he herds of cattle.' This is of the highest speech of the eloquent Arabs. Whoever does not reach the understanding of combining the two parables limits himself to interpreting it as a single parable, estimating the speech as: 'And the example of the caller of those who disbelieve (is like that of one who shouts)' i.e., yells. This is because interpretation (Ta'wil) leads to ellipsis and estimation, while understanding prevents it and necessitates understanding the Quranic delivery according to its definition and face... It is known by this that the verse is of *Ihtibak*: The likeness of the 'Caller' was deleted from the first part due to the indication of the 'Shouter' to it [in the second], and the 'Shouted at' was deleted from the second due to the indication of the 'Called ones' to it..." (1). Interpreting the order of the verse according to this method (Reciprocal Deletion), in which he relied on "Al-Harralli", is the interpretation whose origin you see in the work of "Sibawayh" in "Al-Kitab" (2). This interpretation looks at the simulative representation and its composition from several elements; the context does not require mentioning all of them, but rather requires indicating some by others, folding from each side what is indicated by the mention in the other side. When we look at the first parable: 'The example of those who disbelieve', we see their representation as sheep at which their compassionate, kind shepherd shouts, driving them to their salvation, yet they hear nothing but a sound and do not understand what he shouts at them. So He mentioned what they are established in: their state of turning away from the Caller, to be evidence of what they know regarding the state of the sheep being shouted at while hearing nothing but calls and cries (And the example of those who disbelieve in their turning away from the call of the one who benefits them is like the example of sheep shouted at by their owner to save them).
foot_note:
1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: Vol 2, pp. 331-335 
2. - Al-Kitab by Sibawayh: Vol 1, p. 212 - Ed. Harun. See also "I'rab al-Qur'an attributed to Al-Zajjaj - Vol 1, p 47 - Ed. Ibrahim Al-Bayari - Dar Al-Kitab Al-Masri - 1982..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And in the second parable: 'The example of the caller of those who disbelieve', we see his representation by the state of the shepherd of sheep in his eagerness for them and driving them away from what harms them to what benefits them. The Arabs were people of grazing who understood the state of the shepherd with his flock, his compassion for them, his eagerness for what benefits them, and his patience with them. This summons in the heart of the one among them who reasons the reality of the state of the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation) with them. Therefore, what was mentioned of this parable was something they could not overlook because it existed among them morning and evening. So He mentioned the shepherd of the sheep and folded the mention of the state of their shepherd and driver to their salvation (And the example of their caller to guidance is like the one who shouts...). The phrasing of the verse in this manner is something that alerts the recipient when he hears or reads that there is something in the matter, and that it cannot be at all - based on the evidence of the context accompanying numerous previous verses - a representation of the state of those who disbelieve (while it was summarized and the point of the represented was not clarified) by the state of 'the one who shouts at what hears nothing but calls', if what is meant by 'what hears not' is the sheep, indicated by 'shouts'. If it is said the meaning is: 'The example of those who disbelieve in their supplication to their idols when a need befalls them is like the one who shouts (calls) to what hears nothing but calls and cries', then this interpretation, even if its perception is close, the context indicates that His saying (deaf, dumb, blind, so they do not understand) refers to those who disbelieve, not the idols. The entire context is not a discussion about idols but a discussion about those who disbelieve and their stance on being invited to follow what Allah Almighty has revealed, claiming they follow what they found their fathers upon; so they are like sheep following the ram leading them, not understanding what they are led to. ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Among the Compositional Order (*Nazm Tarkibi*) which Al-Biqa'i was concerned with interpreting—and it is a form of the boldness of Arabic like preposing, postposing, and deletion—is what is known as *Iltifat* (Enallage/Shift). It involves manipulating pronouns that have a single referent, so it appears once as a third-person pronoun and another as a first-person pronoun, while the referent is one. However, if the pronouns vary and their referents vary with them, it is not of the *Iltifat* which is of the boldness of Arabic at all. I am not here to look into the critique among rhetoricians regarding clarifying what is shifted from (*al-multafat 'anhu*) in that style, but rather what was from "Al-Biqa'i" regarding this. He holds the view that what is shifted from is what the apparent context required it to be—which is known as the school of Al-Zamakhshari and Al-Sakkaki—not what the expression started with, which is known as the school of Al-Khatib and the majority. You see this in Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of the expression at the beginning of Surah 'Abasa: {He frowned and turned away * Because there came to him the blind man * But what would make you perceive, [O Muhammad], that perhaps he might be purified} (Abasa: 1-3). He says in explaining its greatest objective: "Its objective: explaining {You are only a warner to him who fears it} (An-Nazi'at: 45), that the greatest intent is purifying the one capable of fear by warning of the Resurrection..." Then he proceeds to interpret the opening of the Surah's recitation, saying:..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "When He Almighty restricted him to warning those who fear, and Abdullah bin Umm Maktum the blind (may Allah be pleased with him), who was among the predecessors, had come to him (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation), and the Prophet (peace be upon him...) was at the time of his arrival occupied with inviting people from the leaders of Quraysh to Allah Almighty, having found some softness in them, 'Abdullah' (may Allah be pleased with him) began asking him, not knowing the preoccupation he was in... He (peace be upon him) disliked interrupting his speech with those [leaders] fearing he would miss what he hoped of their Islam... So he (peace be upon him) turned away from him and turned towards them, and dislike appeared on his face. He Almighty gently reproached him for occupying himself with those people by addressing the one whose nature is not to fear... So He said, clarifying the honor of poverty and the high rank of its status, and the virtue of the people of religion even if they are lowly, and the baseness of the people of the world even if they are adorned, honoring him (peace be upon him...) by the context of the third person... (He frowned), meaning: The one who is the greatest of Our creation, and whom We hold too high to confront with such reproach to his face, performed the action of one who dislikes a thing... And He signaled praise of him (peace be upon him...) that this was contrary to his natural disposition of mercy for the poor... by His saying Almighty: (and turned away) i.e., he (peace be upon him) burdened himself to turn away from him hoping that those nobles would submit [to Islam]... (because there came to him the blind man)... And when He made known by the context of the third person what was intended of reverence, and since prolonged turning away necessitates contraction, He turned to him (peace be upon him...) saying: (But what would make you perceive... that perhaps he might... be purified)..." (1)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In this method of addressing the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation) is an elevation of his status firstly, and a clarification of his rank with his Lord Almighty secondly, and a teaching to his Ummah on how their address should be with their Prophet (peace be upon him...). It is also a clarification that his action (peace be upon him) was merely out of consideration for the welfare of the whole Ummah, prioritizing the benefit of the Ummah over the benefit of one individual within it. For if those leaders, or some of them, entered Islam, their entry would be a benefit to the Ummah on one hand, and to Abdullah bin Umm Maktum himself (may Allah be pleased with him) secondly, in that he would be safe from their harm. Al-Biqa'i indicated the symmetry of the *Iltifat* (shift) from the direct address required by the apparent situation to the third person, then from the third person to the direct address. Along with that is the *Iltifat* from the simple verb form in (*'abasa* - he frowned) to the derived form (*tafa''ul*) in (*tawalla* - he turned away/took it upon himself to turn). All of that stands to clarify the great status of the Prophet (peace be upon him...). It is not hidden that the shift from the simple form in the verb (*'abasa*) to the increased form (*taf'il*) in (*tawalla*) is not of the terminological *Iltifat* according to later rhetoricians, but it is from the chapter of shifting from one thing to another for a meaning and a requirement. *** Among the Compositional Order known to the Badi' scholars is *Laff wa Nashr* (Involution and Evolution / Folding and Spreading). If you scrutinize the styles of Badi' embellishment, you see many of them return to Compositional or Arrangement Order, even if the perspective differs, leading to different methodologies of interpretation. Al-Biqa'i is concerned with a type of *Laff wa Nashr* which is the Reversed *Laff wa Nashr*, where the fourth corresponds to the first and the third to the second. He calls it "Chaotic/Disordered *Laff wa Nashr*" (*Mushawwash*), which is an imprecise terminology. In Quranic expression, there are only two types of *Nashr* (Spreading): Ordered according to the *Laff* (Folding): the first in *Nashr* for the first in *Laff*, and the last in *Nashr* for the last in *Laff* in order...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And the one ordered in reverse of it; there is no mixed *Nashr* which could be called chaotic. The important point is that *Laff wa Nashr*, even if considered among Badi' embellishments by later scholars—and it is something the ancients noticed since Al-Mubarrad (1)—falls within Compositional Order. In interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty: {Or do you think that you will enter Paradise while such [trial] has not yet come to you as came to those who passed on before you? They were touched by poverty and hardship (*al-ba'sa' wa al-darra'*) and were shaken until the messenger and those who believed with him said, "When is the help of Allah?" Unquestionably, the help of Allah is near. * They ask you what they should spend. Say, "Whatever you spend of good is for parents and relatives and orphans and the needy and the traveler. And whatever you do of good - indeed, Allah is Knowing of it." * Fighting has been enjoined upon you while it is hateful to you. But perhaps you hate a thing and it is good for you; and perhaps you love a thing and it is bad for you. And Allah Knows, while you know not.} [Al-Baqarah: 214-216], Al-Biqa'i holds that the verse contains a "Chaotic" (reversed) *Laff wa Nashr*: In the first verse, *Al-Ba'sa'* (adversity) and *Al-Darra'* (hardship) were mentioned in this order. In the second, spending was mentioned, which suits *Al-Darra'*. In the third, fighting was mentioned, which suits *Al-Ba'sa'*. He says:
foot_note: 1. (1) - Al-Mubarrad says: "The Arabs fold two different news items then cast their explanation in a sentence, trusting that the listener will return each to its news" (Al-Kamil: 1/75). And he says: (The eloquent, astute, quick-witted Arab casts speech as understood, and views repetition after that as a speech defect/stutter. Allah, Majestic is His Majesty, said—and to Him belongs the highest example: "And out of His mercy He made for you the night and the day that you may rest therein and that you may seek of His bounty" (Al-Qasas: 73), knowing that the addressees know the time of rest and the time of earning) (Al-Kitab: 2/36 - Al-Maktaba Al-Tijariya Al-Kubra - Cairo, 1355 AH)..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Since spending is one of the fundamentals upon which the Surah was built regarding the attributes of believers {and out of what We have provided for them they spend}, then encouragement for it was repeated within the folds of the verses until it was commanded in the beginning of the verses of Hajj mentioned recently [v: 195-197], alongside being the pillars of the beginnings of Jihad until the preceding verse contained it [v: 214] along with killing which is the ultimate Jihad, this was the place for asking about both. So He Almighty informed about that by way of Disordered (Reversed) Spreading (*Nashr Mushawwash*), and that supports what I understood regarding *Al-Ba'sa'* and *Al-Darra'*, for its usage [i.e., the disordered] in the Quran is more frequent than the ordered. So He said, teaching the one who asked: Did the addressees ask about both of them with that? (They ask you what... they should spend..." (1). Al-Biqa'i holds that *Al-Ba'sa'* is used more for war and *Al-Darra'* is used more for wealth. This is an indication from him to the statistical interpretative method which gathers evidences of the rhetorical phenomenon in the entire pondered discourse so the contemplator stands upon what is dominant in the discourse regarding its rhetorical sunnah (norm), to adopt that as his methodology in interpretation based on what is dominant in that expression. If you look at the signification of the material of *Al-Ba'sa'* in the Quranic expression, you find it for what afflicts the body (An-Nisa: 84, An-Nahl: 81, Al-Isra: 5, Al-Anbiya: 80, An-Naml: 23, Al-Hadid: 25). And if you look at the material of *Al-Darra'*, you find it for what afflicts wealth (Al-Baqarah: 233, Al-Imran: 134, Yusuf: 88, At-Talaq: 6). So what Al-Biqa'i went to is higher and more fitting to the Quranic expression. And if you look at the context of the verses in which Al-Biqa'i claimed Disordered Spreading, you find that Surah "Al-Baqarah" abounds in talk about spending, making it a fundamental attribute of the Muttaqin (pious). Affliction in wealth preceded affliction in self in the Surah (v: 155), and it spoke about spending (v: 177, 261, 262, 265, 274).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Above this, the story of the Cow contained in the Surah and by which it is named included strictness in spending upon the Children of Israel. Since the context was for spending, He prioritized it over fighting, saying first (They ask you what they should spend) then saying (Fighting has been enjoined upon you). Thus, it was a disordered (reversed) Folding and Spreading. Al-Biqa'i did not point to the reason for the expression using this Compositional approach in this verse. Perhaps it is because when Allah Almighty said in the beginning of the Surah (Guidance for the righteous * Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and out of what We have provided for them, they spend) (Al-Baqarah: 2-3), and since the statement about Islam's stance on wealth has such a significant status in the Surah, it was of care to make the statement about it in the middle of the meaning. It is as if there is an indication that Jihad with wealth is the pillar of Jihad with the sword, and that victory of the religion is not by the sword alone but by other matters wherein wealth is primary. *** Looking into the interpretation of Compositional Order in the construction of the sentence or verse in Al-Biqa'i's Tafsir cannot be fulfilled in all its aspects in this space. I did not aim for detail, but to dedicate the explanation of the landmarks of the methodology in a general statement joined by some guiding models. This makes me unafraid to desire moving on from expanding on this feature based on looking at Compositional Order. The Tenth Feature. Interpreting Rhetorical Derivation/Variation (Similar Order / *Mutashabih al-Nazm*). Among what the Truth, Majestic is His Majesty, established in His statement about the Holy Quran is His saying Almighty: {Allah has sent down the best statement: a consistent Book wherein is reiteration. The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah. That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whom He wills. And he whom Allah sends astray - for him there is no guide.} (Az-Zumar: 23) ..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: His saying: (*Mutashabihan Mathaniya* / Consistent, Re-iterated) gathers a great principle of the Wise Quranic Expression necessitated by the Greatest Objective of revealing the Holy Quran, and exalted by the method of Divine Education poured from the mine of Mercy for the worlds. The universal objectives of the Holy Quran are not expressed in a single place in the Holy Quran; rather, you see Him varying the expression about them in numerous places and diversifying the ways of indicating them, a diversification that penetrating and vast contemplation can hardly encompass. Al-Biqa'i says in interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty: (*Mutashabihan Mathaniya*): "(Mutashabihan/Consistent) meaning in miraculous eloquence and good admonition; there is no disparity in it at all in wording or meaning, despite it being revealed disjointedly over twenty-some years... He did not say 'Mushtabihan' (ambiguous/confusing) lest it be thought that it is all unclear in indication, for that is not praise. Since it is detailed into Surahs, verses, and sentences, He described it with the plural in His saying (*Mathaniya*), plural of *Mathna* from *Tathniya* meaning repetition. Meaning: stories, admonitions, rulings, and wisdoms are repeated/doubled in it, differing in expression in aspects of wisdom, varying in methods in clarity of indications, without any difference at all in the original meaning. One does not tire of its repetition, nor of repeating its reading, contemplation, and consideration. Additionally, everything in it is pairs of a thing and its opposite... No reward is arranged for anything therein except that it is doubled (followed) by understanding what is for its opposite by allusion, so it is mentioned twice, and encouraged or warned against twice... The benefit of repetition is that souls are most averse to the talk of preaching and advice. Unless it is repeated to them, returning to the beginning, it does not become firmly established with them, nor does it do its work. Hence, the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation) used to repeat his saying three times or more..." (1). The Quranic Expression is based on two great principles I indicated before, and I second the indication to them for confirmation and consolidation: Ascent of Meanings in the Quranic Context.

book_title: الإمام البقاعي ومنهاجه في تأويل بلاغة القرآن
text: Rhetorical Derivation/Variation (*Tasrif Bayani*) for the fundamentals of meanings of Guidance in the Holy Quran. These two principles are present in the Quranic Expression, a presence whose dazzling, conquering evidences do not disappear or cloud over. The second principle (Rhetorical Derivation) has received some of its due from many scholars, and books have been written on it. It has been known among scholars as "Mutashabih al-Nazm" (Similarities in Order). The truth is that "Rhetorical Derivation" to me is wider in scope than "Mutashabih al-Nazm": I hold that "Mutashabih al-Nazm" should be a term for what is similar in expression regarding its order-based relationships such as preposing, postposing, separation, connection, mention, and deletion in the construction of the sentence, verse, node (Ma'qid), or Surah. Meaning, the similarity whose pivot is the Order features which are grammatical relationships between meanings of words in sentence construction (Grammatical/Compositional Order), and that whose pivot is the Order features which are contextual relationships between meanings of sentences in verse construction, or between meanings of verses in node construction, or meanings of nodes in Surah construction... (Contextual/Arrangement Order). And "Rhetorical Derivation" includes this joined with the similarity whose source is choosing one word in place of another (exploded/gushed), (decreed/wrote), (swore/oath), (feared/dreaded), (year/season), (spouse/woman), (sent down/revealed), (saved/delivered)... etc., which is known among scholars as Derivation (*Tasrif*) in choosing words and their forms. Al-Biqa'i has extreme, eloquent care for contemplating this type of Rhetorical Derivation (*Mutashabih al-Nazm*), adhering to the method of looking into what the Context and Intent require. In this, he is worthy of having a special study dedicated to him, and balancing his method in this with the method of "Abu Ja'far bin Al-Zubayr" in (*Milak al-Ta'wil*), or "Al-Kirmani" in (*Al-Burhan*), or "Al-Iskafi" in (*Durrat al-Tanzil*). From this chapter is what came from Al-Biqa'i in interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty: {Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment.} (Al-Baqarah: 7) and the saying of Allah Almighty:..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Have you seen he who has taken as his god his [own] desire, and Allah has sent him astray due to knowledge and has set a seal upon his hearing and his heart and put over his vision a veil? So who will guide him after Allah? Then will you not be reminded?} (Al-Jathiyah: 23). He says regarding the verse of Al-Baqarah: "Since He equated warning them with the lack thereof, starting with hearts was more appropriate to equate them with cattle. Since the stupid person might hear or see, thus finding guidance, and [the need] for hearing is more harmful due to its generality, while vision is specific to conditions of light, He negated hearing then vision to lower them below the state of cattle. Contrary to what is in 'Al-Jathiyah', for when He informed therein of misguidance, and the misguided one is most in need of hearing the Guide, He negated it. And since the deaf one might possess understanding or sight, making his guidance possible, and understanding was more noble, He negated them in that order" (1). And he says in interpreting the verse of 'Al-Jathiyah': "Since the misguided is in greater need of hearing the Guide's voice than anything else, and one who does not benefit from what he has is judged as lacking it, He said: (And has set a seal) i.e., in addition to the present misguidance (upon his hearing) so he has no understanding of the heard verses. And since the deaf might understand by gesture, He said (and his heart) i.e., so he does not retain what is rightful to retain. And since the deaf insane person might see his harms and benefits, engaging them like cattle, He said (and put over his vision a veil) so he became unable to see the visible signs. Its order is thus; because it is in the context of misguidance as preceded in 'Al-Baqarah'." (2). It is clear that Al-Biqa'i did not stop in interpreting the similar order in the two verses except at the similarity in the arrangement between the heart, hearing, and sight, as He prioritized hearing over the heart in Al-Jathiyah after prioritizing the heart [in Al-Baqarah].
foot_note:
1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: Vol 1/96 
2. - Previous Source: Vol 8/96-97..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He did not stop at the repetition of the preposition in Al-Baqarah with hearing and heart (*'ala* qulubihim wa *'ala* sam'ihim) and leaving it in "Al-Jathiyah" (*'ala* sam'ihi wa qalbihi). Nor did he stop at bringing the nominal sentence in "Al-Baqarah" (wa *'ala* absarihim ghishawatun) with the nominative case, and the verbal sentence in "Al-Jathiyah" (wa *ja'ala* 'ala basarihi ghishawatan). From this is what you see of his clarification to us of the facet of expression in the saying of Allah Almighty in Surah Al-Baqarah: {And We said, "O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise and eat therefrom in [ease and] abundance from wherever you will. But do not approach this tree, lest you be among the wrongdoers."} (Al-Baqarah: 35) and His saying Almighty in Surah "Al-A'raf": {And "O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise and eat from wherever you will but do not approach this tree, lest you be among the wrongdoers."} (Al-A'raf: 19). The story of our father "Adam", peace be upon him, came in several Surahs, but the command to eat from Paradise wherever they willed did not come except in two Surahs: Al-Baqarah and Al-A'raf. In Surah "Al-Baqarah": The expression came conjoined with 'Waw' (And), and in Al-A'raf with 'Fa' (Then). In Al-Baqarah, the expression came saying (therefrom), and in Al-A'raf (from wherever you will). In Al-Baqarah, His saying (plentifully/raghadan) came driving His saying (wherever you will), and that did not come in Al-A'raf, despite the Divine Expression regarding their command being about one thing. So for which of them was the Divine Expression commanding them? If we come to the similar order in this sentence depicting the Divine Command to Adam (peace be upon him) and his wife to eat from Paradise, we find that when the context therein was "merely to explain the blessings as an appeal for familiarity, conjoining eating with 'Waw' in His saying Majestic is His Majesty (And eat therefrom) was sufficient for that. Explicitly mentioning 'Raghad' (plenty/ease), which is the greatest of blessings, had a great position, so He Almighty said (plentifully)... (wherever... you will)..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Unlike the context of Al-A'raf, for it was intended therein, along with reminding of blessings, to define the increase in empowerment (*Tamkin*), and that it did not prevent expulsion, as a warning to those established in the earth, expanded in livelihoods, against the descending of punishments..." (1). In Surah "Al-A'raf" he says: "Since the context here is for defining that He empowered our father, peace be upon him, in Paradise greater than His empowering us in the earth by bestowing upon him therein the abundance of life accompanying his existence, then it was good in His saying (So eat) to conjoin with 'Fa' (Then) indicating that the eaten thing was with the dwelling, not delayed from it. There is no contradiction between it and expressing with 'Waw' in 'Al-Baqarah'; because the concept of 'Fa' is a type included under the concept of 'Waw', and there is no contradiction between Type and Genus. And His saying (from wherever you will) means 'plentifully', i.e., widely, for it indicates the permissibility of eating from everything in it except what is forbidden. As for the verse of Al-Baqarah, it indicates the permissibility of eating from it in any place. This context to its end indicates that whoever disobeys His command Almighty, his throne is demolished and his glory destroyed, even if he has the utmost ability and end of strength, just as He expelled the one for whom He maximized ability by making His angels prostrate, dwelling him in His Paradise, and permitting everything therein except one tree..." (2). *** Among the similar order that Al-Biqa'i lingers at is what came of delaying (Purification/*Tazkiyah*) after Teaching in the supplication of the Father of Prophets Abraham, peace be upon him, and presenting it before it in others. Allah Almighty said: {Our Lord, and send among them a messenger from themselves who will recite to them Your verses and teach them the Book and wisdom and purify them. Indeed, You are the Exalted in Might, the Wise.} (Al-Baqarah: 129)

2. - Previous Source: Vol 7 / 371..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Certainly did Allah confer [great] favor upon the believers when He sent among them a Messenger from themselves, reciting to them His verses and purifying them and teaching them the Book and wisdom, although they had been before in manifest error.} (Al-Imran: 164) {It is He who has sent among the unlettered a Messenger from themselves reciting to them His verses and purifying them and teaching them the Book and wisdom - although they were before in clear error.} (Al-Jumu'ah: 2). These are three verses; Purification (*Tazkiyah*) was presented over Teaching in the first of them, and Teaching was presented over Purification in the other two. What is the facet of expression in that? Al-Biqa'i looks, in interpreting the systemic similarity of preposing and postposing, at the meaning of the preposed word, the context in which it appeared, and who the speech was about. He looked and saw that the verse of Surah "Al-Baqarah", narrating the supplication of the Father of Prophets: Abraham peace be upon him, is regarding the supplication for the Muslim Ummah (my descendants), and it is not such unless it has acquired Purification from Polytheism (*Shirk*) by the origin of Islam characterizing it. So the Purification required here is not purification from Shirk, but rather a purification founded upon prior knowledge of the Book and Wisdom, i.e., it is a purification of ascending in stations of obedience and proximity. And the Purification in Surah Al-Jumu'ah is purification from Shirk by which the origin of Faith is established; because the context is to talk about the Unlettered (*Al-Ummiyyin*), the Nation of Invitation (*Ummah al-Da'wah*), who have Shirk within them. So it is as if the Purification here is not the one requested by our master Abraham peace be upon him for his people in the verse of Surah "Al-Baqarah". Purification here needs to precede teaching the Book and Wisdom, because teaching them does not bear fruit for one whose heart is not purified from Shirk. Hence, Purification from Shirk was presented over teaching the Book and Wisdom...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: There remains what is in the verse of "Al-Imran", where the context is speaking about the Believers, who are purified from Shirk. So the requirement of the apparent was to delay Purification after Teaching as was in the supplication of our master Abraham peace be upon him. But Al-Biqa'i notices an important matter, which is that the verse of "Al-Imran" came in the context of admonishing the Believers regarding the spoils of war on the Day of Uhud. This was a grave matter from them; they were in need of purification from it first, then the teaching of the Book and Wisdom comes as an elevation for them and a cleansing from what does not befit them, even if they were purified from Shirk. The difference in the signification of Purification and who the speech was about is what necessitated the preposing and postposing. "Al-Biqa'i" says regarding the verse of "Al-Baqarah": "When he requested what belongs to him in the office of Prophethood—Allah Almighty teaching him the rituals without an intermediary—he requested the like of that for his descendants through the intermediary of one whom custom established for their likes. So he said (Our Lord, and send among them) i.e., the Muslim Ummah which is from my descendants and the descendants of my son Ishmael (a messenger from themselves)... and that Messenger is Muhammad, peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation, for no one else was sent from their descendants with the Book... (reciting... to them Your verses... and teaching them the Book... and wisdom... Since the appearance of his call, peace be upon him, was that the Sending in the Muslim Ummah meant they were in greater need of teaching what was mentioned than of Purification—for its origin exists through Islam—he delayed his saying (and purify them) i.e., cleanse their hearts with what he was given of precise wisdom, so they ascend by its purity and subtlety from the peak of Religion to a place where they are safe from turning back on their heels and distorting their Book as those before them did... And when He Almighty mentioned in Surah 'Al-Jumu'ah' His sending him among the Unlettered generally, the station required presenting Purification, the head of which is innocence from Major Shirk; so that they accept the knowledge that comes to them..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: As for presenting it in 'Al-Imran' with the mention of Sending to the Believers, it is because the situation required admonishment for turning towards spoils, which was the cause of defeat, as it was a turning towards the World, which is the mother of defilements." (1) - - - Similar Order (*Mutashabih al-Nazm*) and its interpretation by "Al-Biqa'i" in the company of Context and Intent is a vast door worthy of being the subject of an independent study to fulfill a small amount of its due. What I have pointed to guides to that feature among the features of "Al-Biqa'i's" methodology in interpreting the Wise Quranic Expression. The Eleventh Feature. Rhetorical Direction of Quranic Readings (*Qira'at*). It was from the grace of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, upon His servants that He did not reveal His Book in a single mode of recitation from which meanings of guidance are deduced; rather, the Revelation came in several modes, as the Purified Sunnah guided to: "This Quran was revealed in seven letters (modes), so read what is easy of it" (The Two Sheikhs: Al-Bukhari, Book: Virtues of the Quran, and "Muslim", Book: The Travelers - and the text belongs to him, Hadith No. 270/818). In the same chapter, Muslim narrated from Ubayy bin Ka'b that the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation, was at the pool of Bani Ghifar. He said: Gabriel peace be upon him came to him and said "...Indeed Allah commands you that your Ummah read the Quran on seven letters; whichever letter they read upon, they have done right" (Hadith: 274/821). In the multiplicity of these readings is a flood of mercy of alleviation for this Ummah. It is an alleviation not limited to performance and recitation, though this is the most apparent, but it is an alleviation in the assignment (*Taklif*) arising from the meanings of guidance deduced from those readings. Whoever reads with a letter and deduces from it meanings of guidance—a correct deduction according to the scientific principles of deduction—has done right. All of it is sufficient and healing, and praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The multiplicity of forms of performance is not a sterile multiplicity regarding the objectives for which the Quran was revealed: informing servants of the meanings of guidance desired by the Truth Almighty. Rather, every form of the Mutawatir (consecutive) performance possesses a giving from types of these abundant meanings which do not wear out with much repetition. Hence, listening to the Holy Quran was an act of worship {So when the Qur'an is recited, then listen to it and pay attention that you may receive mercy.} (Al-A'raf 204). He conditioned the realization of mercy on two conditions: Listening (*Istima'*) and Silence (*Insat*) together. Listening by casting the hearing and striving not to be distracted by a distraction, as alluded to by the form *Ifti'al* (Istami'u); and Silence (*Insat*), which is leaving speech entirely so that there is not in the slightest forms of speech what distracts from receiving the subtle meanings in listening to it, which one might not be able to perceive if occupied by a distraction of speech even if he listened along with it. If the forms of performance are *Tawqifi* (divinely ordained), then in every form established in its place and context is what makes it proportionate, interwoven, brotherly, and harmonious with the context in which it was established. This is what makes readings multiply in the performance of a Quranic word in a context, while the same word in another context has only one reading. This indicates that Context and Intent have a strong relationship with the multiplicity or unity of forms of performance. This is what urged me to look into Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of such faces. ***** Among the forms of performance are Idgham (merging) and Fak (separation) of a certain word among the words of the Glorious Quran. Idgham has an apparent phonetic face in entering the sound of a letter into the sound of another letter, and Fak is its opposite. It is strange that in the form and performance of the word "Fak" itself is Idgham [the double Kaf]. This paradox is like an allusion that even if Fak is the origin, consideration of what phonetic proportionality requires in this is a great basis of the bases of Holy Quranic proportionality...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Scholars of Arabic rhetoric had majestic attention to phonetic proportionality in their rhetorical books, especially the later ones who made that phonetic proportionality the introduction to the eloquence of discourse which is the basis of its rhetoric. This phonetic face: Idgham and Fak has a semantic face in the Quranic expression; Al-Biqa'i contemplates some of its images. The word (*yartadda*) came in Surah Al-Baqarah and in Surah Al-Ma'idah. The Almighty said in Surah "Al-Baqarah": {They ask you about the sacred month - about fighting therein. Say, "Fighting therein is great [sin], but averting [people] from the way of Allah and disbelief in Him and [preventing access to] al-Masjid al-Haram and the expulsion of its people therefrom are greater [evil] in the sight of Allah. And fitnah is greater than killing." And they will continue to fight you until they turn you back from your religion if they are able. And whoever of you reverts (*yartadid*) from his religion [to disbelief] and dies while he is a disbeliever - for those, their deeds have become worthless in this world and the Hereafter, and those are the companions of the Fire, they will abide therein eternally.} (Al-Baqarah: 217). And in Surah "Al-Ma'idah": {O you who have believed, whoever of you should revert (*yartadda*) from his religion - Allah will bring forth [in place of them] a people He will love and who will love Him [who are] humble toward the believers, powerful against the disbelievers; they strive in the cause of Allah and do not fear the blame of a critic. That is the favor of Allah; He bestows it upon whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.} (Al-Ma'idah: 54). In Surah Al-Baqarah (v: 217), the narrators agreed on reading with the separation of Idgham in it (*yartadid*). They did not agree on that in Surah Al-Ma'idah (v: 54). In Al-Ma'idah, "Nafi', Abu Ja'far, and Ibn Amir read (*man yartadid*) with separation of Idgham, and the rest of the Ten read (*yartadda*) with one stressed Dal" (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) – Al-Mabsut fi al-Qira'at al-Ashr by Ibn Mahran: p 162 – Ed: Subai' Al-Hakimi, and Al-Nashr fi al-Qira'at al-Ashr: 2/250

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is not hidden that the agreement of narrators in the verse of Al-Baqarah is divinely ordained (*Tawqif*), not convention, and likewise the difference of narrations regarding separation and merging in Al-Ma'idah is *Tawqif*. Hence, it was incumbent to look into the requirement of the multiplicity of the performance form in Al-Ma'idah and its unity in Surah Al-Baqarah. Al-Biqa'i says in contemplating the verse of Al-Baqarah: "The consensus of the Reciters on Separation (*Fak*) here is to indicate that the nullification [of deeds] is conditioned upon disbelief outwardly by the tongue and inwardly by the heart. So it alludes to forgiveness for the pronunciation of the tongue while the heart is at rest [with faith]. The reading of Idgham in (Al-Ma'idah) indicated that patience is a higher degree than responding with the tongue even if the heart is at rest" (1). And he says regarding Surah Al-Ma'idah: "When He forbade taking them as allies and informed that the doer of such is one of them, He negated the metaphor, declaring the intent explicitly. So He said, manifesting the result of what preceded (O you who have believed) i.e., acknowledged faith, whoever allies with them among you - this was the original [meaning], but He stated explicitly that this is leaving the religion, so He said (*man yartadda*), even if in a hidden way as indicated by Idgham in the reading of those other than the Medinans and Ibn Amir (*minkum 'an dinihi*)..." (2). The verse of Al-Baqarah is in the context of judging the nullification of the work of the apostate from Islam in the world and the Hereafter. This does not happen except to one who apostatizes outwardly by tongue and inwardly by heart. The verse stated explicitly the internal apostasy by the heart in His saying: (and dies while he is a disbeliever). So the external apostasy remained; the Performance was the indicator of it. So Separation (*Fak*) is necessary here because in Separation is Manifestation (*Izhar*), which is a linguistic/tongue action, alluding to the precise proportionality in the indication. So the verse combined the two conditions of nullifying deeds by apostasy: Apostasy outwardly indicated here by separation of Idgham, and Apostasy inwardly indicated by the phrase (and dies while he is a disbeliever). It is strange that internal apostasy was indicated by the phrase, and external apostasy was indicated by the performance of the phrase (Separation of Idgham).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In conditioning internal apostasy for the nullification of deeds and indicating it by way of the phrase is an opening of the door of pardon for one who is compelled while his heart is content with faith; he is one compelled to external apostasy without combining it with internal apostasy. As for the verse of (Al-Ma'idah), it was in the context of prohibiting taking Jews and Christians as allies (Verse: 51) and lack of patience in tribulation (Verse: 52). So Verse (54) came indicating that Allah Almighty might punish for internal apostasy indicated by the narration of (Idgham) and external apostasy indicated by the narration of (Izhar/Separation) by bringing a people He loves and who love Him. In this is a great threat that tears out the hearts of those who understand. Had the narration come with a single mode of performance, this would have been a deficiency in the conditions of punishment: realizing apostasy by one of two ways. Punishment is not dependent on the gathering of both conditions together at one time; rather, realizing one of them might result in punishment: Bringing a people He loves and who love Him. There is another indication: Idgham here points out that patience, which the one discussed in Verse (52) did not strive for, is indeed a higher degree than external apostasy by the tongue. We must note the difference between the answer to the condition in (Al-Baqarah) and its answer in (Al-Ma'idah): In (Al-Baqarah) it is nullification of deeds, and that is a destructive killer. In (Al-Ma'idah) it is replacement and substituting a people in place of a people; although it is great to the people of Gnosis, it is less than nullification of deeds. So the indicator of the condition of the answer to the condition in (Al-Ma'idah) was by way of Performance, which is an indication containing some concealment not understood by many people. And the indicator of the main condition for realizing the answer [in Al-Baqarah] was by way of the explicit phrase. This contains types of proportionality. This was "Al-Biqa'i". Look in his company at what his Sheikh "Ibn al-Jazari" said in Al-Nashr justifying the separation of Idgham by agreement in Al-Baqarah with his saying:..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Because the length of Al-Baqarah necessitates verbosity (*Itnab*) and increasing the letter is part of that. Do you not see His saying Almighty (*wa man yushaqiqi Allaha wa rasulahu*) in Al-Anfal (v: 13) how separation of its Idgham was agreed upon, and His saying (*wa man yushaqq Allaha*) in (Al-Hashr: 4) how its Idgham was agreed upon? That is due to the closeness of the two stations to Verbosity and Brevity" (1). What "Ibn al-Jazari" said, if it stood, would imply that everything in Al-Baqarah must be on the method of expansion, and that there should be no brevity by deletion of a word or brevity of restriction in it. How can "Ibn al-Jazari" justify a rhetorical approach with a rhetorical approach that itself is in need of justification like it? Length of statement is not a requirement by which a rhetorical face is directed; rather, the requirement comes from the very meanings and objectives to which the Surah is driven, and the conditions surrounding the Revelation. ***** Among what the narration agreed on performing in one way in a Surah and differed on in another Surah is the verb (yara/tara - see) in the saying of Allah Almighty: {Do they not see (*alam yaraw*) the birds controlled in the atmosphere of the sky? None holds them except Allah. Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe.} (An-Nahl: 79) {Do they not see (*awalam yaraw*) the birds above them with wings outspread and [sometimes] folded in? None holds them except the Most Merciful. Indeed He is, of all things, Seeing.} (Al-Mulk: 19). They differed in reading (*yaraw*) in (An-Nahl) with the third person and the second person, and agreed on the third person in Al-Mulk: "Abu Ja'far, Nafi', Ibn Kathir, Abu Amr, Asim, and Al-Kisa'i read (*alam yaraw*) with Ya [they], and Ibn Amir, Hamza, Ya'qub, and Khalaf read (*alam taraw*) with Ta [you]" (2). Al-Biqa'i holds regarding the verse of An-Nahl that "The speech and its context admit the Acceptor and the Turner-away, unlike the context of Al-Mulk, for it is for the Turner-away (Adversary). Thus, the reciters differed here and agreed there" (3).

2. - Previous source: 2/304, and Al-Mabsut: 225 
3. - Nazm al-Durar Vol 11 / 222..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He said regarding Surah Al-Mulk: "The reciters agreed on reading here in the third person; because the context is for refuting the deniers, unlike what is in An-Nahl" (1). If we look at the context of the verse of An-Nahl, we see it came in the exposition of enumerating blessings as evidence and gratitude. Gratitude, at least, is for the Acceptor and the Turner-away, and verses (70-72, 78, 80-81) confirm this. Whoever read with the second person (address) noted the side of the Acceptor; because blessings were created in reality for him (Al-A'raf: 32), so he is prioritized for that. Let the performance of the verse observe that in some aspects. And whoever read with the third person noted the side of providing evidence which is primarily for the Turner-away so he may be convinced from this aspect; thus the third-person reading observed it. The context of the verse of An-Nahl, as you see, accommodates both faces together, the Acceptor and the Turner-away, so there were two narrations. The context of (Al-Mulk) is for exposition only and refuting the deniers (Verses: 15 and following), so it is a context that does not admit directing the address [to believers] in this verse. Also, because it did not come to threaten the Turner-aways like its predecessor and successor, but to explain that He who causes the earth to swallow the tyrants by the authority of Subjugation possesses the power to hold the weak bird by the flood of His Mercy so it does not fall. Hence, the expression in the verse of Al-Mulk was His saying (except the Most Merciful), while in the verse of An-Nahl (None holds them except Allah). **** We look at another verse in which Al-Biqa'i borrowed the interpretation of the performance form from Al-Harralli but did not add anything to it, although he had the ability to do so, which shows us an aspect of his methodology in this. The Almighty said: {And if someone is in hardship, then [let there be] postponement until [a time of] ease. But if you give [from your right as] charity, then it is better for you, if you only knew.} (Al-Baqarah: 280). In His saying (*'usrah*) there are two readings (with Damma on Sin and with Sukun). And in (*maysarah*) there is a reading with Damma on Sin, a reading with Fatha, and a reading with Damma on Sin and Kasra on Ha causing saturation (Ishba'). "Ibn Mahran" says: "Abu Ja'far alone read (*wa in kana dhu 'usurah*) with Damma on Sin, and the rest read (*'usrah*) with Sukun on Sin.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Nafi' read (*fanaziratun ila maysurah*) with Damma on Sin. "Zaid" narrated from Ya'qub (*ila maysurih*) with Damma on Sin and Kasra on Ha saturated. And the rest read (*ila maysarah*) with Fatha on Sin" (1). In the verse are modes of performance, and every mode has a flood of meaning proportionate to the extended context and the vast intent that gathers the Ummah, granting every degree a portion of its giving. Al-Biqa'i says, quoting from "Al-Harralli": "Since people are divided into solvent and insolvent, i.e., rich and poor, it was as if said: This is the ruling of the solvent. (And if there is) i.e., found among the debtors (one of hardship) unable to pay at this time (then a look/respite) i.e., upon you is a respite for him. 'Al-Harralli' said: It is the delay anticipating accomplishment (until ease) if you are not satisfied except with taking your wealth. Nafi' and Hamza read with Damma on Sin. 'Al-Harralli' said: An indication of the dominance of ease, which is the wider of the two respites. The rest with Fatha is an indication of its intermediacy, so ease is in two ranks. Whoever waits until the widest of the two eases, it was a better repentance. End quote" (2). Al-Biqa'i looked, following Al-Harralli, at the signification of the Damma of Sin in (*maysurah*), sensing from its strong sound an indication of the complete ease of the insolvent, thus being a call that his respite be until his ease is complete. And he looked at the signification of the Fatha of Sin in it, sensing from its sound an indication of the intermediacy of ease, since Fatha is weaker than Damma. In the conditions of the word's vowel sound is an indication of the conditions of the meaning itself and its relation to the one the statement belongs to. Either of the two respites for the insolvent is obedience, except that the lower of them is a necessary right upon every Muslim, and the higher of them is a virtue upheld by the people of Ihsan (Excellence). Whoever is towards the higher indicated by Damma, it was a better repentance from what came from him of lending with interest which is the very detested, obliterated Riba. So the reading of Fatha is for the people of the first ages of Faith (Those who believe), and the reading of Damma is for those above them in ages of Faith: The Believers... The Doers of Good (Muhsinin).
