book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Diversity of meanings through diversity of readings fulfills the stations and ranks of obedience. For the people of obedience are not equal in their stations within it. Some readings depict an Ihsani (Excellence-based) meaning transcending what another reading depicts of the general meanings which are guidance for mankind and those who believe. All are sufficient and healing for every possessor of a station and rank of the ascending ranks of proximity. In the verse are modes of performance in (*'usrah*) with Damma on Sin and with its Sukun. Behind every mode is a meaning existing in the context towards the intent aimed at by the noble verse. It was sensed in the reading of Damma on Sin of (*'usurah*) an observation of the state of one whose hardship is severe; his right is inevitably to be given respite according to the amount of his hardship. If it ceases, the creditor has the right to demand from him. And in the Sukun of Sin of (*'usrah*) is an observation of the state of one whose hardship is light; his right is to be given respite also according to it, and not be deprived of respite. Had the narration come with Damma on Sin alone, there would be in this a deprivation of the one whose hardship is slight from the mercy of respite. In giving respite to the one of slight hardship is education and training on adopting the character of mercy, benevolence, and grace. In His saying (*nazirah/respite*) are modes of performance, some of which are not from the Ten Readings: The majority read (*fanaziratun*) with Kasra on (*Za*), being a predicate of an omitted subject, i.e., the obligation is a respite. Al-Hasan, Mujahid, and Al-Dahhak read (*fanazratun*) with Sukun on (*Za*), which is a lightening of (*nazirah*), following a dialect in Tamim: they say in *kalimah*: *kalmah*. It is as if in this verse is a lightening for the owner of wealth from one aspect and an encouragement for him to give respite from another, and a suggestion to him that respite is indeed light, so let him not calculate that calling to it is a burden upon him. The reading of Kasra on (*Za*) has an allusion that the respite should be complete, strong, encompassing the state of the insolvent, and that the owner of wealth be enabled to fulfill this duty: Respite. In this is education on excellence, mastery, and relieving those of need and hardship..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In the Sukun of the *Za* is a meaning of permissibility that the respite be according to the insolvency without excess, and an allusion that its realization is not difficult for the owner of wealth. It is a reading looking at the state of the wealth owner from two aspects: an aspect that is his right, and an aspect containing benefit for him through education, enticement, and incitement not to find the respite heavy, for it is light even if its duration is long. So the people of high aspirations perceive in the Sukun of *Za* an enticement for them to endure and a depiction to them that this is not difficult for them, rather it is light in reality due to the lightening of the sound of the middle of the word. (That is best and most suitable for final determination) (An-Nisa: 59). And the people of lower aspiration look at the fact that in Sukun is an indication of their right that the respite does not have to reach the complete perfection of the removal of insolvency. Everyone reads in the mode of performance what suits him (And follow the best of what was revealed to you from your Lord) (Az-Zumar: 55). In the word is another reading: Ata' bin Abi Rabah read (*fanaziruhu*) with Alif: Active Participle (Subject Noun), and the Ha is a pronoun annexed to the Active Participle, i.e., whoever gives respite to the debtor is towards ease. In this reading is an indication of glad tidings that whoever gives respite to the insolvent debtor, his state and all his affair, because of his respite to him, will be towards ease. In this is a response to what the Prophetic statement brought: "...And whoever relieves a Muslim, Allah will relieve him of a distress from the distresses of the Day of Resurrection" (Agreed upon: Al-Bukhari: Al-Mazalim, and Muslim: Al-Birr). And a fourth reading in it: Ata' also read (*fanazirhu*) with Sukun on Ra on the basis that it is an Imperative Verb meaning: treat him with ease and forgive him until the time of respite. It is from *Munazarah* meaning forgiveness and closeness (*Mudanah*), not from *Munazarah* meaning argumentation and debate..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Thus it becomes clear to you that there are modes of performance in the verse, and that in these modes is proportionality with the context. For the verse is established to call the Muslim to be in the aid of his brother, and that his lending to him should not be for the sake of benefiting from what he takes from him, but benefiting from what he earns of Allah Almighty's reward, then from what he realizes for the Ummah of the feeling of harmony and mutual support. This, if spread in a nation, purifies it from many of the diseases that exhaust its powers, tear its structure, and throw it into the humiliation of division, fighting, negligence, and distraction from caring for the conditions of brothers. That is the disease from which the Ummah is attacked. ***** Indeed, every element of expression, especially the Quranic expression, has a profound, glorious effect on constructing the meaning, depicting it, and embellishing it. The features of that effect might be hidden from us, but this is not valid to be a cause for denying its existence. If one were to deny everything not seen, the matter would be very dangerous. The head of Faith in Islam is Belief in the Unseen. So one must stop at what he knows without denying the existence of what he does not know. *** Standing upon what came in these verses of readings is from the chapter of beneficial knowledge. Arabic study celebrates the like of this. For the abundance of readings in the verse contains floods of meanings that help servants to stand in the gardens of obedience, and open before them paths of proximity to their Creator. There is nothing like the facilitation ruled by principles of knowledge for servants so that no soul flees from the vastness of obedience. The Twelfth Feature. Clarifying the Signification and Indication of the Quranic Word: Material and Form. "Al-Biqa'i" has extreme care for clarifying the signification of the material of the Quranic word and its form in the construction of its sentence, and revealing its proportionality with its context and the intent of the Surah, and its relationship with its sisters in the construction of the sentence which forms for him the (Compositional Order) in the Surah and which he makes a brick in constructing the (Arrangement Order) therein..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He is concerned with the semantic shift occurring to the Quranic word from its etymological and compositional heritage to what it acquires from the context it stands upon in the Surah. This feature of his methodology in interpreting the rhetoric of the Holy Quran is a vast feature; a single research cannot encompass the abundance of what came from him regarding it. The material of the word is the original letters from which the word is formed and in which it shares with its peers and sisters. These original letters carry in themselves and in the method of their arrangement what they indicate of a meaning. Scholars of Arabic have extreme care for this. Linguistic theories in this field are extensive, deep, possessing subtleties and niceties. "Ibn Jinni", "Ibn Faris", and others had a merit in this field that does not hide. What is meant by the signification of the material is what the word inherits from its origins that formed it. It carries this inheritance with it in its locations, mixing some of the significations it acquires from other tributaries with it, like the significations of its form or the significations of its performance. The word in Arabic expression is like the individual in the human world; it carries from the origins of its lineage and germ a flood of traits and characteristics it does not abandon as long as life remains in its bond or it remains in its bond. Then its actions vary, and what it grants and prevents, and what it shows and hides, according to what it aims for and intends, and what it stands in or is established. So it is eloquent in its action, descending upon the requirement of its conditions and the contexts of its existence in their variety and multiplicity. Like it is the word in Arabic expression; eloquent by what it descends upon of requirements of conditions in their variety and multiplicity, and contexts in their extension, distance, and nearness. The world of Expression in the Arabic tongue is from the world of Man in the Arabian Peninsula when it was Arab. May Allah have mercy on a time whose drink was Glory, whose food was Protection and Succor for every caller for help, and whose clothing was the Deep-rooted, Protected, Elevated Glory. ***..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i's methodology is based on visualizing the landmarks of proportionality of the Holy Quran in its words, sentences, verses, nodes, and Surahs. This proportionality is based on the realization of a comprehensive meaning for the proportionate elements. Visualizing this meaning is the key that achieves for Al-Biqa'i what he aspires to. That is what appears to one who follows observing his work. There is no doubt that it will not be in my power to encompass a small amount of what "Al-Biqa'i" cared for regarding the proportionality of the word's material with the context in signification and indication. However, I am striving to stop at what outlines his methodology and reveals the landmarks of his movement and what he ended up with in this. - - - To Allah belong the Beautiful Names, and for every Name among them is its signification and indication, and for every one of them is its location to which it is most specific. Understanding the expression with one of His Beautiful Names and the appropriateness of selecting it in its context is of the High Understanding. Al-Biqa'i had care for that. Among His Beautiful Names whose mention was not repeated in the Holy Quran is (Al-Bari' / The Originator/Maker). It might be thought to be synonymous with His Name (Al-Khaliq / The Creator) or (Al-Fatir / The Originator/Cleaver) whose mention is repeated in the Holy Quran, while His Name (Al-Bari') came only in two verses: The first came in the place of enumerating some of His Names at the end of Surah (Al-Hashr), and the other in Surah (Al-Baqarah - v: 54) {And when Moses said to his people, "O my people, indeed you have wronged yourselves by your taking of the calf [for worship]. So repent to your Maker (*Bari'ikum*), and kill yourselves. That is best for [all of] you in the sight of your Maker."} It is not hidden that the root meaning in the word (*Khaliq*) is Decreeing/Measuring (*Taqdir*), while the root meaning in the word (*Bari'*) is Freedom (*Bara'ah*) from defect in invention and decreeing. More gratitude appears in the expression with (*Bari'*). So if the context is for reminding of extra favor to entice good approach, then the expression with His Name (*Al-Bari'*) is more proportionate to the context. "Al-Biqa'i" says:..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "(And when Moses said to his people) worshiping the calf and silent about it... (O my people) and he emphasized due to their deep-rootedness in ignorance of the enormity of what they committed and their taking it lightly because of the desire absorbed in their hearts, so he said: (indeed you have wronged yourselves) a wrong for which you deserve punishment (by your taking of the calf) i.e., a god besides Allah Almighty. So you made yourselves submissive to what possesses nothing for it and to what it [the self] is nobler than. So you brought it down from the rank of its glory by its submission to its Master who does not humiliate one who befriends Him nor honor one who opposes Him, to its humiliation by its submission to what is below you yourselves... (So repent to your Maker / *Bari'ikum*) who created you (*fatara*) before you took the calf, free (*bari'in*) from defect with the perfection of creation on different forms. 'Al-Harralli' said: 'Al-Bari' is a name based on the meaning of *Bar'*, which is rectifying materials for depiction, like one who cuts leather and cloth to make a boot and a shirt, and one who grinds wheat and kneads clay to make bread and pottery and the like. Its meaning is the refining of the thing according to the readiness for its image. End quote.' ... (and kill yourselves. That is best for you in the sight of your Maker) i.e., the One capable of executing you as He was capable of creating you. In expressing with *Al-Bari'* is an encouragement for them to obey Him by reminding of Ihsan (beneficence) and an intimidation by inflicting humiliation..." (1). In summoning the meaning of (*Bari'*) is what shakes the soul striving to defile what Allah Almighty originated free from the filth of associating partners with Him. This is a type of corruption, and there is no greater corruption than one who corrupts his own self, which is created upon Tawhid, free from Shirk. For such a person is not trusted with others; whoever betrays the self between his sides and does not preserve it, his betrayal of others is more deviant and severe. In this is alienation for this Muhammadan Ummah from following the paths of those who betray themselves, defiling them with Shirk.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And the head of those Jews is upon them from Allah Almighty what they deserve of curse, humiliation, and exemplary punishment in both abodes. (1) Understanding the locations of the Beautiful Names in the Quranic Expression is of the greatest understanding. For the location of the Name in it reveals its subtle meanings. Contemplating its context, location, and comparing it with what approaches it in its root meaning and the context of its locations is a key among the keys to understanding the meanings of the Beautiful Names. That understanding which I see as a face of the faces of Enumeration (*Ihsa'*) which the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family and companions, urged upon: (Indeed, Allah has ninety-nine names, one hundred minus one; whoever enumerates them enters Paradise) (Al-Bukhari: Tawhid - Fath: 13-332).
foot_note: 1. (1) - Among the fruitful digressions is "Al-Tibi's" differentiation between the three Names (Al-Khaliq, Al-Bari', Al-Musawwir). "Al-Tibi said: It was said the three words are synonymous, and this is an illusion. For *Al-Khaliq* is from *Khalq*, and its origin is straight measuring/decreeing. It applies to invention, which is bringing a thing into existence without a precedent, like His saying Almighty 'He created the heavens and earth', and to formation like His saying Almighty: 'He created man from a sperm-drop'. *Al-Bari'* is from *Bar'*, and its origin is the freedom of a thing from another, either by way of separation from it, hence their saying: So-and-so became free (*bari'a*) from his illness, and the debtor from his debt, and from it 'I absolved the slave-girl'; or by way of origination, and from it 'Allah originated (*bara'a*) the breath/soul'. It was said: Al-Bari' is the Creator free from disparity and dissonance that disturb the system. *Al-Musawwir* is the originator of the forms of inventions and their arranger according to the requirement of wisdom without disparity or defect, and He forms it in an image upon which its properties are arranged and its perfection is completed. The three are Attributes of Action, unless *Al-Khaliq* is intended as The Decreer (*Al-Muqaddir*), then it is from Attributes of Essence; because the reference of decreeing is to Will. Based on this, Decreeing occurs first, then Bringing into existence according to the decreed manner occurs second, then Formation by leveling occurs third)) Fath al-Bari: 13/333..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: If we intended to contemplate and interpret Allah's Beautiful Names in the Wise Remembrance: location, signification, and indication, we would have meanings that many scholars lack insight into and awareness of. Perhaps Allah Almighty will guide and help with some of that. From this also are the names of the Holy Quran; the expression came with the name (Al-Kitab), (Al-Quran), and (Al-Furqan)... etc. Each has a location, signification, and indication. Al-Biqa'i, following Al-Harralli, had a contemplation of the significations of those names, their indications, and their stations in the context of expression. That is something praiseworthy to look into in its places in his Tafsir. *** Among what I need to look into here is the education of a soul prone to evil (*Ammarah*) regarding what does not benefit, His saying Almighty in Surah (Al-Humazah: 1-4): {Woe to every scorner and mocker * Who collects wealth and [continuously] counts it. * He thinks that his wealth will make him immortal. * No! He will surely be thrown into the Crusher (*Al-Hutamah*).} The Wise Quranic Expression selected the verb of Throwing (*Nabdh*): "la-yunbadhanna", and selected for the Fire a name that did not come except in this Surah. Since the context here, after what came in Surah (Al-Asr), is a context of educating the soul prone to evil with great intimidation from those deeds crushing the structure of the Ummah and turning away from what saves it from loss—through good faith, righteous deeds, advising truth, and advising patience—"Al-Biqa'i" reveals the proportionality between the signification of the material of this verb and this name and their contexts, saying: "...(*la-yunbadhanna*): i.e., he will surely be thrown after his death, the throwing of what is light, very despicable to every thrower, as indicated by the expression with *Nabdh*, and in the passive voice (into *Al-Hutamah*) i.e., the layer of Fire whose nature is to crush (*tah-tim*), i.e., break and smash with severity and violence everything thrown into it. So he will be the greatest loser. He expressed with it in contrast to preparation with wealth which drives one to disdain creation. The Master 'Abu Al-Hasan Al-Harralli' said:..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: 'So for the meaning specific to the ruling, He Almighty names it with one of its names, like *Jahannam* (Hell) in what is confrontation, and like *Al-Hutamah* (The Crusher) in what is a recompense for a force of subjugation and preparation with numbers, and likewise in the rest of its names.' And He magnified its matter by His saying: (And what can make you know... what is the Crusher... It is the fire of Allah... Kindled). When He described the Scorner (*Hamaz*) and Mocker (*Lamaz*), He described the Crusher (*Hatim*), so He Almighty said (Which). And since the conditions of a thing are only viewed from its front through knowledge, He said (Mounts (*Tattali'u*)) a severe mounting (over the hearts (*Af'idah*)) plural of *Fu'ad*: which is the heart that almost burns from the intensity of its blaze/intelligence (*Dhakai'hi*). He should have used his intelligence in causes of salvation. And its mounting over it is by rising over its center and encompassing it with a profound encompassing. It was named so for the intensity of its burning. It was singled out for mention because it is the subtlest thing in the body and the most severely pained by the slightest harm, and because it is the origin of corrupt beliefs and the mine of the love of wealth which is the origin of corruption and misguidance, and from it issue ugly actions" (1). "Al-Biqa'i" glances a high proportionality between the signification of the material of the verb "Nabdh" (throw) and the crimes committed by those scorners and mockers reckless in gathering wealth. So their punishment was a great humiliation and extreme hatred balanced with what came from them. If we look at the places where words of this material came in the Holy Quran, we see that meaning dominating it, confirming that it is selected to highlight it in the context where it appears: (Al-Baqarah: 100, 101, Al-Imran: 187, Al-Anfal: 58, Al-Qasas: 40, Adh-Dhariyat: 40, Al-Qalam: 49). Likewise, the expression about the Fire with the name *Al-Hutamah*, declaring the signification of crushing and breaking with violence, has a high proportionality with the context in which the verse came.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is one of the singularities (*Fara'id*) of the Holy Quran which was not repeated in it (1). If we look into the signification of words of this material in the Holy Quran, we see that meaning also dominating it, confirming that it is selected to highlight it in the context where it appears (An-Naml: 18, Az-Zumar: 21, Al-Waqi'ah: 65, Al-Hadid: 20). The indication of "Al-Harralli" which "Al-Biqa'i" quoted from him regarding the names of "The Fire" and the locations of expression with every name in the Holy Quran was a glorious indication carrying much subtle meaning. This draws our attention to the importance of pausing at the expression with names of Recompense for obediences and sins and the relationship of that to what corresponds to it of servants' earning, whether good or evil. In this is a clarification from Allah Almighty to His servants that their recompense is of the type of their deeds, so the servant must choose the recompense he wants. This highlights the great responsibility of the servant for what his hands earned. Added to what preceded of proportionality of the material's signification to the context is what that selection produced of tonal proportionality between: "Humazah, Lumazah, Hutamah". This harmony has effectiveness in highlighting meanings and depicting them. Al-Biqa'i, as you saw, has the ability to perceive the status of selecting words for the signification of their material which summons in the recipient's heart the reality which the Holy Quran educates the human soul by casting into hearts. Thus, it flees from those hateful deeds escaping that humiliating recompense, and to know that every arrogant tyrant will meet in the Hereafter humiliation matching his arrogance and tyranny.
foot_note: 1. (1) - The Holy Quran has singularities that are not repeated: words (in material and form, location and signification), structures, images, story scenes, and legal rulings... worthy of contemplation and rhetorical interpretation. I am still in the phase of collecting these singularities from the Holy Quranic Expression in preparation for contemplating them and interpreting them rhetorically. Perhaps Allah will help, guide, and accept...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: If we placed the word "yutrahanna" (will be cast) in place of "yunbadhanna" (will be thrown) in other than the Holy Quran, and the word "Al-Nar" (The Fire) in place of "Al-Hutamah", the context would reject that, and the expression would lack much of what performs what it is driven to. *** The Holy Quran selects a word in a context by which it depicts what burns in the hidden recesses of a people whose speech it relates, so the word, by what it depicts in its context, becomes the exposer of them. Allah Almighty says relating the speech of the Hypocrites in Surah "Al-Ahzab": {And when a faction of them said, "O people of Yathrib, there is no stability for you [here], so return [home]." And a party of them asked permission of the Prophet, saying, "Indeed, our houses are exposed," while they were not exposed. They did not intend except to flee.} (Al-Ahzab: 13). The word (Yathrib) did not come in other than this verse. The word "Tathrib" (blame), which is from its material, came in Surah (Yusuf: 92) {He said, "No blame (*tathrib*) will there be upon you today. Allah will forgive you; and He is the most merciful of the merciful."}. "Al-Biqa'i" says: "They diverted from the name - with which the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation) marked it, like Al-Madinah and Taybah, despite its goodness - to the name it was called by of old, with the probability of its ugliness by derivation from 'Al-Tharb' which is blame and violent reproof, to show diversion from Islam. It says in 'Al-Jam' bayn Al-Ubab wa Al-Muhkam': 'Tharraba alayhi tharban wa athraban', meaning *tharaba tathriban* if he blamed him, shamed him for his sin, and reminded him of it" (1). This word carries by the signification of its material (Th - R - B) the meaning of rebuke and shaming with the defect of what those Hypocrites allude to of violently reproving those standing for the victory of Islam and His Messenger (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutation).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In this diversion of theirs from the word selected by the Prophet (peace be upon him) to that hateful word is an allusion to their call to divert from what he (peace be upon him) called to, back to what their ancestors were upon. This depicts what churns in their chests of hypocrisy. Allah Almighty spoke the truth: {...You would recognize them by their mark, and you will surely recognize them by the tone of [their] speech. And Allah knows your deeds.} (Muhammad: 30). So this word in the context of the Hypocrites discouraging the resolve of the Muslims is extremely familiar to its station. It is the word most specific to that meaning, most complete for it, and most revealing of it. It exposes what the Hypocrites strive to hide and cover. In "Al-Biqa'i's" observation of that Quranic indication is a refutation of what some modernists criticize our heritage for, that its owners in their rhetorical understanding do not observe the correspondence of expression to the internal states passing through the souls of speakers, thus picking up psychological secrets from within the folds of linguistic secrets. *** "Al-Biqa'i" glances in the selection of another word what reveals the reality of the Hypocrites' minds in the context of the same Surah in the saying of the Majestic, His Majesty: {They think (*yahsabuna*) the companies have not [yet] withdrawn. And if the companies should come [again], they would wish they were in the desert among the Bedouins, inquiring [from afar] about your news. And if they should be among you, they would not fight except for a little.} (Al-Ahzab: 20). The expression came with the verb (*yahsab*) rather than others like "yazunn" (conjecture/think) due to the semantic difference between the two verbs, and due to the very marvelous proportionality between the signification of the verb (*yahsab*) and its context here. In this, he says:..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "He Almighty informed, confirming His past saying regarding their cowardice [previous verse], that the preventer He mentioned did not leave their side due to their excessive cowardice. So He said confirming that and answering one who might say: Fear has gone, so why have they not come? (They think (*yahsabuna*)) i.e., they suppose due to the weakness of their minds in this state—while fear has gone—due to the intensity of their cowardice and the fear established in them, that (the companies) although you knew they have left (have not left) but absented themselves deceptively. He expressed with *Hisban* (thinking/calculating); because—as passed from 'Al-Harralli' in Al-Baqarah—it is what dominates in matters of the type a human is created upon and settled as a habit for him. While *Zann* (conjecture) is in what is of known things taken by evidence and knowledge. He said: So the weakness of the scholar's knowledge is *Zann*, and the weakness of the rational person's mind is *Hisban*" (1). If we return to the locations of the Holy Quran's expression using the material of "Hasiba" and "Zanna", we find it establishing words of "Hasiba" in the context of blame, forbidding ugliness, denial and rebuke, or what indicates that what occurred is error or misguidance, pointing to the reality of the signification of words of this material revealed by "Al-Biqa'i" influenced by "Al-Harralli". As for the verb (*Zanna*), it may come in the Quranic expression in the context of indicating that what occurred is truth and correct, and it may stand in the place of Certainty... - - - He stands before the expression with the word "Mu'tafikat" (The Overturned Cities) in the saying of Allah Almighty: {Has there not reached them the news of those before them - the people of Noah and 'Ad and Thamud and the people of Abraham and the companions of Madyan and the towns overturned (*Al-Mu'tafikat*)? Their messengers came to them with clear proofs. And Allah would never have wronged them, but they were wronging themselves.} {At-Tawbah: 70}

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says, revealing the landmarks of the marvelous proportionality between the expression with the word "Al-Mu'tafikat" and the nature of the deed of the disbelievers from the nation of our master "Lot" peace be upon him—where the signification of the word "Mu'tafikat" was a fitting recompense for their heinous deed—and the nature of the Hypocrites whom the context of speech addresses. The verses follow successively from verse forty-two to the end of the Surah speaking about the Hypocrites. "Al-Biqa'i" says: {When He Almighty established by this verse their resemblance in enjoying the immediate [world] and concluded it with this conclusion signaling vengeance, He followed that by frightening them with their resemblance in what befell the groups of them, shifting to the station of the third person; because it is more impactful in awe. So He said establishing their loss: (Has there not reached them) i.e., these filthiest of the people of hypocrisy (the news of those before them) i.e., their great news worthy of being researched; to act according to what it implies when they disobeyed Our messengers. Then He substituted from it His saying (the people of Noah... and 'Ad... and Thamud... and the people of Abraham... and the companions of Madyan)... (and the Overturned Cities) i.e., in their turning away from preserving their honor in following the pleasures of their desires, so their deed bore fruit for them, after the swallowing by earth, of general extinction... He expressed them as 'Al-Mu'tafikat'; because the stories are for the Hypocrites whose affair is built on lying, diverting matters from their appearances, and turning them from their faces. The meaning is that since those people turned the act of marriage from its [proper] face, they were punished by the turning/overturning of their cities. So these [Hypocrites] are worthy of such punishment for turning speech from its face. The material 'Ifk' in every arrangement revolves around turning/inversion. If you *kafa'ta* (turn over) the man, it is as if you turned his action, returned it to him, and diverted it from you. The *Ikaf* of the beast resembles the twisted vessel. Lying is turning speech from its face, so it is *Ifk* for that reason. And Allah knows best" (1)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Al-Biqa'i" sees the ties between the semantic heritage of the word "Mu'tafikat" and the nature of the specific and general context of the Surah. He pointed to the specificity of this word in its indication of the reality of the state of the Hypocrites whom the context is about. It also casts into the heart of the recipient a realization of the extent of ugliness hypocrisy reaches, from which the sound soul flees. If the innate nature flees from the deed of the disbelievers from the nation of our master Lot, upon him be blessings and peace, then Hypocrisy is from the chapter of this deed, so the sound nature and the healthy heart are more averse to it. *** If the Holy Quranic Expression is based on (Rhetorical Derivation), this derivation includes what is known as Similar Order (*Mutashabih al-Nazm*), and I have pointed to some of it. It may also include a derivation in choosing the word in terms of its material in one context, and choosing another in another context. This is not of Similar Order because the derivation does not return to the order of the word but to choosing it itself in terms of its material or form. From that is what you see in the saying of Allah Almighty in Surah "Al-Baqarah" (v: 60): {And [recall] when Moses prayed for water for his people, so We said, "Strike with your staff the stone." And there gushed forth (*fanjafarat*) from it twelve springs. Every people knew their watering place. "Eat and drink from the provision of Allah, and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption."} (Al-Baqarah: 60). And in Surah "Al-A'raf" (v: 160) {And We divided them into twelve descendant tribes as nations. And We inspired to Moses when his people implored him for water, "Strike with your staff the stone," and there gushed forth (*fanbajasat*) from it twelve springs. Every people knew their watering place. And We shaded them with clouds and sent down upon them manna and quails, "Eat from the good things with which We have provided you." And they did not wrong Us, but they were wronging themselves.} ..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The expression came, as you see, in Surah Al-Baqarah with His saying (infajarat - gushed forth) and in Surah Al-A'raf (inbajasat - flowed out), and it is not hidden that they are not equal in their signification, for *infijar* (explosion/gushing) is greater than *inbijas* (flowing/oozing). So what is the effect of the context in selecting each word in its respective place? "Al-Biqa'i" says: "And how appropriate is the mention of *infijar* here after concluding what came before with *fisq* (transgression), due to their sharing the meaning of exiting from a boundary: this is an exit that gives life, and that is an exit that causes death. 'Al-Harralli' said: *Infijar* is the emission of something from a contained object, or as if it is a container whose vessel split and burst open from it; from it comes the *Fajr* (dawn) and the splitting of the night from it. End quote. And because this is a context of gratitude and reminding of favors, He expressed it with *infijar*, whose meaning revolves around splitting involving flowing and emission with spreading, expansion, and abundance. And since the context of 'Al-A'raf' was not for gratitude, He expressed it with *inbijas*, whose meaning revolves around mere appearance and welling up" (1). So the context is what necessitated selecting *infijar* in Surah "Al-Baqarah" and *inbijas* in Surah "Al-A'raf". If you look at the immediate circle of context in Surah "Al-Baqarah", you find it started from verse forty: {O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you and fulfill My covenant upon you that I will fulfill your covenant with Me, and be afraid of [only] Me} with reminding the Children of Israel of the favors bestowed upon them, yet nothing came from them except persistence in misguidance, to alienate the Nation of Muhammad from following their methodology and law. As for the immediate context in Surah "Al-A'raf", it is apparent in depicting the Israelites' haste into misguidance; you see it starting with His saying Almighty: {Then We sent after them Moses with Our signs to Pharaoh and his establishment, but they were unjust toward them. So see how was the end of the corrupters} (Al-A'raf: 103). Thus, it was more fitting and appropriate for the context of the verse in Surah "Al-Baqarah" to select the word more indicative of the strength of the event (infajarat), unlike the context of the verse in Surah "Al-A'raf". ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: We pause with him in interpreting the saying of Allah Almighty in Surah Al-Kahf (v: 77) {So they set out, until when they came to the people of a town (*Qaryah*), they asked its people for food, but they refused to offer them hospitality. And they found therein a wall about to collapse, so he restored it. [Moses] said, "If you wished, you could have taken for it a payment."} and His saying in it (v: 82) {And as for the wall, it belonged to two orphan boys in the city (*Madinah*), and there was beneath it a treasure for them, and their father had been righteous. So your Lord intended that they reach their maturity and extract their treasure, as a mercy from your Lord. And I did it not of my own accord. That is the interpretation of that about which you could not have patience.} In the first, He said (*Qaryah* - town/village) and in the other He said (*Madinah* - city), and the intended place is one and the same. There is no doubt that behind selecting *Qaryah* first is a requirement different from the requirement that selected the word (*Madinah*) in the other. Al-Biqa'i casts his insight towards the context and the purpose for which the speech is established, and to the signification of the root of each of these two words. He says regarding the first (v: 77): "He expressed it - here - as *Qaryah* rather than *Madinah* because it is more indicative of blame; for the root material 'Qara'a' revolves around gathering (*jam'*), which necessitates withholding (*imsak*)... Then He described it to show that it had a part in the meanness of its people by His saying Almighty 'they asked for food'. He made the noun explicit and did not use a pronoun in His saying 'its people' because the asking for food was to some of those they came to, or [alternatively] the coming and the asking for food were to some, but it is not unified [meaning not everyone they came to was asked], and this is the apparent meaning; because it is what agrees with custom" (1). Then he says regarding the other verse (v: 82):

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Since *Qaryah* does not contradict naming it *Madinah*, and expressing it as *Qaryah* first was more appropriate because it is derived from the meaning of gathering, it was more fitting for blame regarding the refusal of hospitality; to indicate their stinginess while in a state of gathering, and their love for accumulating and withholding. And *Madinah* implies residence (*Iqamah*), so expressing with it was more appropriate [in the second verse] to indicate that the people are residing in it, so the wall would collapse while they are residing, and they would take the treasure" (1). "Al-Biqa'i" intended to look at what the root of each of the two words "Qaryah" and "Madinah" is based on and what is intended from the verse of each. He perceived a proportionality between the material of each and its context and objective: The word "Qaryah" is based on the meaning of gathering; the Qaf, Ra, and the third letter contain the meaning of gathering. This summons in the heart of the recipient the meaning of the gathering of its people. The verse came in the context of highlighting that the people of that spot are characterized by the vice of stinginess and turning away from honoring guests, and that they are united upon the like of this. This is the most extreme stinginess; because one who is stingy while the people are in a gathering, his stinginess as an individual is greater. And in it is a blame that there is no one among them to forbid them from that vice, as if it became among them a recognized norm (*Ma'ruf*) not denounced, and this is transforming evil into good; if a nation reaches that, it is void of all virtue. In selecting this root material, there is proportionality with the context of exaggeration in blaming them. This explanation is supported by His saying: "they asked its people for food" and His saying "but they refused to offer them hospitality". The word "Madinah" highlights another meaning which is more appropriate for justifying the rebuilding of the wall: the roots of this word revolve around the meaning of residence (*Iqamah*). The verse came in the context of explaining the reason for what he did, and that had the righteous servant not rebuilt the wall, it would have collapsed, and the residence of those people around it would have helped hasten its collapse, making it prone to being looted. So the meaning of "Residence", which is the center of the signification of the material "Madana", is what is proportionate to the reason for building that wall.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: All of that highlights an aspect of the general meaning of the story: that behind this acquired knowledge is a knowledge more penetrating into the interior of truths, and that every possessor of knowledge must know that above his knowledge, however great and abundant, is a higher and greater knowledge. This fits with the general meaning of Surah "Al-Kahf" and what it opened with of praise for the blessing of knowledge by which the upright and beneficial survival in this life stands. *** Among what Al-Biqa'i was concerned with looking into regarding its interpretation and contemplating its appropriateness to its context and the intent of the expression are the words (*Sanah*), (*'Aam*), (*Hijjah*), and (*Hawl*) - all meaning year. They are words thought to be equal in their signification, but they came in the Quranic expression in diverse contexts and objectives. The word (*Sanah*) came seven times in singular form, and eleven times in plural form (*Sinin*): (Al-Baqarah: 96 - Al-Ma'idah: 26 - Yunus: 5 – Yusuf: 42, 47 – Al-Isra: 12 – Al-Kahf: 11, 25 – Taha: 40 – Al-Hajj: 47 – Al-Mu'minun: 112 - Ash-Shu'ara: 18, 205 – Al-Ankabut: 14 – Ar-Rum: 4 - As-Sajdah: 5 – Al-Ahqaf: 15 – Al-Ma'arij: 4). The word (*'Aam*) came nine times (Al-Baqarah: 259, 259 - At-Tawbah: 28, 37, 37, 126 - Yusuf: 49 - Al-Ankabut: 14 - Luqman: 14). The word (*Hawl*) came in two verses of Surah Al-Baqarah (v: 233, 240). And the word (*Hijjah*) came in a verse of Al-Qasas (v: 27). The prevailing view among rhetoricians is that the word "Sanah" is mostly used for a year containing drought and hardship, and "'Aam" for one containing prosperity and fertility. It is said "The people suffered *Sanah*" meaning drought struck them, as Al-Raghib says in "Al-Mufradat". Al-Biqa'i points out in some places these differences. Among that is what you see in his interpretation of the saying of Allah Almighty: {And you will surely find them the most greedy of people for life - [even] more than those who associate others with Allah. One of them wishes that he could be granted life a thousand years (*Sanah*), but it would not remove him from the punishment that he should be granted life. And Allah is Seeing of what they do.} (Al-Baqarah: 96)

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He says: "...And *Al-Sanah*: The duration of a complete cycle of the sun and the completion of twelve cycles of the moon - said Al-Harralli. This meaning, although present in *Al-Hawl*, *Al-'Aam*, and *Al-Hijjah*, yet the source of derivation is noted in the sentence. The rhetoric of the Holy Quran does not use any of these terms except where it suits the context from the origin of the derivation of these terms. This context, since the intent is to blame them for their desperation to remain in the world in any condition, knowing that it—even if it were the worst of conditions—is better for them than what is after death due to the realization of their misery, He expressed it with that from which *Al-Isnat* (drought) comes, which is famine and bad times. Or [it is] from that which involves rotation containing toil and fatigue, if its origin is from *Sana Yasnu* meaning when the beast turns around the well. Al-Suhayli said in 'Al-Rawd': A *Sanah* may be called a *Dar* (abode/cycle) in the report: 'Between Adam, peace be upon him, and Noah, peace be upon him, are a thousand *Dar*', meaning *Sanah*. Then he said: So contemplate this, for knowledge of the placement of speech and putting words in their appropriate places opens a door of knowledge regarding the inimitability of the Quran, and Allah is the One sought for help)) (1). And in the saying of Allah Almighty: {And We certainly sent Noah to his people, and he remained among them a thousand years (*Sanah*) minus fifty years (*'Aam*), and the flood seized them while they were wrongdoers} (Al-Ankabut: 14), he looks at the reason for expressing first with *Sanah* and lastly with *'Aam*. He says: "...He expressed with the word 'Sanah' to condemn the days of disbelief, and said 'minus fifty... 'Aam' to indicate that the time of his life, peace be upon him, after their drowning was comfortable, spacious, and good due to the faith of the believers and the fertility of the land" (2). So the days of struggle were days of suffering for him, so the word (*Sanah*) is most appropriate for them. And they were days of blame regarding their actions—disbelief—so the word "Sanah" also suits them, due to what it carries of its root material which I explained before. As for what was after the flood, with the drowning of the disbelievers and the salvation of the believers, they were days of spiritual spaciousness through faith and sensory spaciousness through the fertility of the land and abundance of blessings.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It implies that Al-Biqa'i holds the view that the fifty years (*'Aam*) are what Noah, peace be upon him, lived after the flood. *** The expression came with the word "Hawl" in the saying of Allah Majestic is His Majesty: {Mothers may breastfeed their children two complete years (*Hawlayn*) for whoever wishes to complete the nursing...} (Al-Baqarah: 233). The word (*Hawl*) contains the meaning of separation and change from one attribute to another; hence the changing state is called *Hal* (condition), meaning it does not remain as it is but transforms (*Yahul*) and changes. Al-Biqa'i contemplates the meaning of transformation in this verse saying: "When He mentioned breastfeeding, He mentioned its duration. Since the intent was merely the turning (*Tahawwul*) of time with its four seasons and the sun returning after traversing the twelve zodiac signs to the sign it was in at birth, and the intent is not to imply praise of the time nor blame, nor describing it with tightness or expanse, He expressed it with what indicates absolute transformation, so He said (*Hawlayn* - two turns/years)... as if it is taken from what has the power of transformation" (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i proceeds to explain firstly what is intended by the verse and secondly what is not intended. It becomes clear to him that the intent points to the meaning of transformation and change that occurs to the newborn due to breastfeeding. These two years are among the years in which the change of the newborn's state appears most in all its sensory and moral fields. If you looked at his state at birth and his state at the completion of his weaning, you would see a transformation and change the like of which you cannot see in any two years passing over the newborn afterwards. So this period is the most deserving of his life's periods of the meaning of transformation. Furthermore, it is not intended to point to an attribute related to the time in which breastfeeding occurs, whether of abundance of blessing or its scarcity, so that it is not understood that the ruling relates to that attribute of abundance or scarcity. This is from the perfection of protecting the listener of the Quranic expression from understanding from the statement other than what is intended. Such is considered by scholars of rhetoric as one of the fundamentals of eloquence: That the listener should not be misled by the speaker's poor explanation (1). *** The expression also came with the word (*Hawl*) in the same Surah (v: 240) {And those who are taken in death among you and leave wives behind - for their wives is a bequest: maintenance for one year (*Hawl*) without turning [them] out...} (Al-Baqarah: 240). Al-Biqa'i did not mention anything of his own in this verse, sufficing with quoting "Al-Harralli" explaining an aspect of the wisdom of making the waiting period (*Iddah*) of the widow four months and ten days completed to a year (*Hawl*), and that the verse does not contain abrogation, and the wisdom of making its interval {And Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise} (2). *** And the expression came with the word "Hijjah" in a verse from Surah Al-Qasas:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {He said, "Indeed, I wish to wed you one of these, my two daughters, on [the condition] that you serve me for eight years (*Hijaj*); but if you complete ten, it will be [as a favor] from you. And I do not wish to put you in difficulty. You will find me, if Allah wills, from among the righteous."} (Al-Qasas: 27). Al-Biqa'i explains the facet of emphasis in (*Inni* - Indeed I), the facet of expression with the word (*Ankihuka* - wed you), the facet of pointing with (*Hatayn* - these two), and the facet of making it eight *Hijaj*. Then he looks into the selection of the word *Hijaj* over other similar words like *Sanah*, *'Aam*, or *Hawl*, saying: "And the expression with what is from *Hajj*, which is intent (*Qasd*), is out of optimism that they [the years] will be—due to their goodness through following Allah's command, the abundance of His provision, the pouring of blessing, and the repelling of vengeance—worthy of being intended (*Tuqsad*), or that Hajj to the Sacred House of Allah will happen in each one of them" (1). "Al-Biqa'i" summons from the material of the word (*Hajaj*) the meaning of intent (*Qasd*) which is the standing basis in its derivations, and what this meaning acquired from the legal status of the word (*Hajj*). It is an enticement that this should be something one strives to intend and care for, and that he should feel that in these eight [years] he is in the status of a pilgrim (*Hajj*) turning away from all his own affairs and desiring the lot of his master, not occupied from him by anything of his own affair or the affair of other than his master. And that his relationship with things around him should be the relationship of the pilgrim with what is around him in the Sanctuary: endless peace. He also summons what accompanied this legal meaning of connotations tossed in the soul regarding optimism for the blessing that correlates with Hajj from the supplication of the father of prophets Abraham, peace be upon him, and what occurs of negating poverty and affliction. He points to the probability that this contains a condition that he carries him to Hajj every year of these eight. Thus, "Al-Biqa'i's" methodology becomes clear to you in sensing the connotations of the word acquired from its context added to what is generated from its etymological root and linguistic origin from which it sprouted. ***

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i also looks at the appropriateness of selecting the word "Iblis" for its context and the word "Shaytan" for its context, and both refer to one thing. In Surah "Al-Baqarah", the expression came with the word "Iblis" in the context of refusing prostration (v: 34), and in "Al-A'raf" (v: 11), Al-Hijr (v: 31), Al-Isra (v: 61), and Taha (v: 116). In the context of misleading Adam and Eve, the expression about him came with the word "Shaytan"; it came in Al-Baqarah (v: 36), Al-A'raf (v: 20), and Taha (v: 120). These are two names for a single entity, except that the Holy Quran selects each name in a context different from the one where it selects the other, due to the proportionality of the signification of each word's root material to the context of its occurrence. "Al-Biqa'i" quotes regarding His saying Almighty: {And [mention] when We said to the angels, "Prostrate before Adam"; so they prostrated, except for Iblis. He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers.} (Al-Baqarah: 34) from "Abu Al-Hasan Al-Harralli" regarding this: "Iblis": "From *Al-Iblas*, which is the cutting off of the cause of hope, which comes from despair due to the cutting of that cause" (1). And he quotes from him regarding the saying of Allah Almighty: {But Satan caused them to slip out of it and removed them from that [condition] in which they had been. And We said, "Go down, [all of you], as enemies to one another, and you will have upon the earth a place of settlement and provision for a time."} (Al-Baqarah: 36) his saying: ((The Shaytan: It is taken from two roots: from *Al-Shatan* which is distance, from which the long rope is named, and from *Al-Shayt* which is acceleration in burning... so it is derived from the two meanings like the word "Insan" (human) and "Mala'ikah" (angels))) (2). The word Shaytan is derived from two roots, meaning carved from them. He approves of this approach in etymology; because he sees in it a combination of two significations in one word, the gathering of which achieves high proportionality with the context and intent. So he says:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: ((The Truth Almighty mentioned the slipping caused by him - i.e., the enemy of Allah - by the name Shaytan, not by his name [Iblis]; due to what is in the meaning of *Shaytanah* of distance and speed which accepts rectification, and due to what is in the meaning of *Iblas* of cutting off hope. So there was in that a glad tiding of Adam, peace be upon him, rectifying [the slip] through repentance)) (1). The expression using the word "Iblis" in the context of abandoning prostration indicates what gripped the enemy of Allah in this context of despair and cutting off hope of being among the people of preference and proximity. Selecting this word: "Iblis" in this context suggested the internal image of Iblis when commanded to prostrate upon his refusal of what he was commanded. This depicts to us the great torment in which the enemy of Allah was placed by this. Understanding this helps the servant know the motives driving the enemy of Allah to take a stance of raging hostility against the sons of Adam, peace be upon him, so the human does not trust him nor feel safe with what he tempts him with of the trials of worldly life. And the expression with the word "Shaytan" in the context of misleading our father Adam, peace be upon him, indicates what his struggle in misleading the people of obedience will end in: that his effect is finite, vanishing quickly. Every attempt of his with one characterized by understanding of his state and position is destined to burn. Every attempt of seduction is burned by sincere repentance if the human returns to it. There is no greater loser than one whose great struggle in seduction burns away with a truthful word the person says, depicting what churns in his chest of remorse and fear.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: You can utilize "Al-Harralli's" statement to see that the word "Iblis" in its indication of "despair and confusion" points out that the enemy of Allah, at the beginning of his affair when commanded to prostrate, was confused between the analogies of his mind and his weighings between clay and fire, and the calls of the heart to submit to the Divine Command to prostrate. He lived first in confusion, then inclined to the voice of reason and its analogy, declaring: "I am better than him", "Shall I prostrate to one You created from clay?". As for the angels, they submitted with absolute surrender to what Allah Almighty wanted from them, and did not stand in the position of confusion that "Iblis" stood in. Consequently, what the "enemy of Allah" inclined to resulted in his expulsion from the mercy of Allah Almighty, and he was burned by His anger upon him, so he became a defeated Shaytan burned by the curse of Allah Almighty (1). Perhaps what brings this closer is that the Holy Quran does not apply the word "Iblis" except to the first of devils in existence, the one commanded to prostrate. Had the word "Iblis" been used in the context of seduction and temptation, there would have been great despair for the sons of Adam in this. But the overflow of Mercy (*Rahmaniyyah* and *Rahimiyyah*) manifested in selecting the word "Shaytan" in this context. This is among the subtleties of the *Ihsani* (Ehsan-based) meanings of the Holy Quran which only the people of *Ihsan* in understanding the Quran's rhetoric pay attention to. ***
