Claiming that the Sharia descended for us, so it is for what we see as rectification of our condition, and we are not created for the Sharia to be confined to what came, even if we see it does not suit our condition in our age and place. Adherents to this philosophy have multiplied in our time and lands, calling themselves leaders of Enlightenment.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The summary here is that the word in its context does not derive its signification and the facet of its indication solely from its etymological material from which it was generated. Rather, it derives that from numerous tributaries, including the material, the form it is upon, the position it occupies, the method of its performance, and even the manner of its drawing and writing... etc. These tributaries do not contradict in their giving but support and interact. Some may be more apparent and abundant, but they do not negate the giving of the other. Therefore, if "Al-Biqa'i" was concerned with the proportionality and interweaving between the signification of the word's material and its context and the significance for which speech is established, he also has concern for the signification of the word's form and shape and its proportionality with the context and intent for which speech is set up. It is a vast and spacious door, as word forms and shapes in Arabic are many, indeed multiplying. Exhausting and comprehending that is beyond what the soul can bear and what the place allows, requiring satisfaction with a not insignificant portion in clarifying "Al-Biqa'i's" methodology in investigating and editing the speech on this, revealing some of the landmarks of the Rhetorical Inimitability of the Holy Quran. - - - Al-Biqa'i contemplates the "Present Tense" in the beginning of Surah Al-Baqarah: {Alif, Lam, Meem * This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah * Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them}. He says: Then He described them with comprehensive actions to define them, saying: "Who believe in the unseen" ... "and establish prayer" ... "and out of what We have provided for them... they spend"... The intended meaning of these verbs here is bringing their realities into existence continuously. "Abu Hayyan" and others said regarding His saying Almighty in Surah "Al-Hajj": {Indeed, those who have disbelieved and avert [people]} that the Present Tense may not imply a specific time of present or future, thus indicating continuity at that time. End quote...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This is unavoidable; otherwise, this [description] in this "Medinan" Surah would not include those who adopted this character before the Hijrah. His saying Almighty: {Say, "Then why did you kill the prophets of Allah before, if you are believers?"} (Al-Baqarah: from verse 91) is decisive in that." (1) The Present Tense in these verbs notes the meaning of occurrence after it was not. Therefore, it includes everyone from whom the action occurred before the revelation of the Medinan verse, and everyone from whom it occurs or will occur until the Hour. It was not brought as a description (The Believers - The Establishers - The Spenders) to intend the indication of renewal, which is one of the characteristics of verbs. The context is one of clarifying who the Holy Quran is beneficial for, and they are the ones guarding against the path of those who earned anger and the path of the astray. The existence of these pious ones is not restricted to a specific time. These actions occur in every time wherein the pious exist. So it was most appropriate for the Present Tense to come to indicate that continuity. The Past Tense did not come lest it be imagined that this is specific to those from whom those actions occurred [in the past], while others are not, or that they are lesser than them in guarding against the path of those earned anger and the path of the astray and lesser than them in guidance by the Holy Quran. That would not fit the intent aimed at by the verses in the opening of Surah "Al-Baqarah". *** As for the Present Tense in the saying of Allah Almighty: {And when it is said to them, "Believe in what Allah has revealed," they say, "We believe [only] in what was revealed to us." And they disbelieve in what came after it, while it is the truth confirming that which is with them. Say, "Then why do you kill the prophets of Allah before, if you are [indeed] believers?"} (Al-Baqarah: 91). It came contrary to the requirement of the apparent context, for the requirement of the apparent was to say: "Then why did you kill the prophets of Allah before", because His saying (before) indicates that the killing whose occurrence is denounced happened before the address. Al-Biqa'i contemplates this saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: ((Then He explained that their disbelief by this killing is by way of satisfaction with the killing by their ancestors, by His saying affirming the neighbor [connection], because that was from them in some past times (before). In the form of the "Present Tense" is a depiction of the heinousness of this killing in that atrocious state, and a symbol that had they the ability now, they would have done their deed. For the estimation is: And you persist in killing them afterwards. In it is an allusion to their eagerness to kill the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutations) as an important warning...)) (1). So Al-Biqa'i sees in the expression using the Present Tense here, accompanied by the clue indicating the occurrence of the event in the past time (before), an indication of the intent to depict the ugliness of what occurred from their ancestors, and that they are pleased with it, not denying it, and that they are thereby like one participating in causing it. And that if an opportunity arose for them, they would not hesitate to seize it; nothing prevents them from it except inability or fear. As if their action with the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutations) would not be less than the action of their ancestors with their prophets, peace be upon them. So the action of their ancestors is as if it stands in its essence, form, and degree within them. In this clarification of their state for the Muslims, there is what is not hidden from a sane person. However, those affiliated with Islam by inheritance among the great politicians, intellectuals, advocates of enlightenment, sons of the new era, and peace activists do not see this. They are - according to their selves prone to evil - sharper in sight, and more deserving that their word be heard than all that is deduced by ancient mechanisms of understanding from a statement revealed fifteen centuries ago to a people residing in the heart of the desert!!! *** If the Present Tense (You kill) in the verse of "Al-Baqarah" came accompanied by a clue indicating the occurrence of killing in the past time (before), the Present Tense may come conjoined to a Past Tense verb, then a Past Tense verb is conjoined to it, as in His saying Almighty:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {And it is Allah who sent the winds, so they stir up clouds, and We drove it to a dead land and gave life thereby to the earth after its lifelessness. Thus is the resurrection.} (Fatir: 9). The verse came in the beginning of Surah "Fatir" whose "objective is: Establishing the Perfect Power of Allah Almighty which necessitates complete Ability for Resurrection" (1). It came in the context of Allah Almighty confirming that what He promised of Resurrection and Recompense is Truth, in which there is no doubt, and His prohibition against falling into the deception of the world and Satan: {O mankind, indeed the promise of Allah is truth, so let not the worldly life delude you and be not deluded about Allah by the Deceiver.} (Fatir: 5). The verb (tuthiru - stir up) came in the Present Tense conjoined to the verb (arsala - sent) [Past]. The requirement of the apparent was to say: Allah who sent the winds so they stirred up [Past] clouds and We drove it. Or: Allah who sends [Present] the winds so they stir up clouds, as in Surah (Ar-Rum): {It is Allah who sends the winds, so they stir up clouds, and He spreads them in the sky how He wills and breaks them into fragments, and you see the rain emerge from within them. And when He causes it to fall upon whom He wills of His servants, immediately they rejoice} (Ar-Rum: 48). But the Quranic expression here diverted from that, placing the Present Tense conjoined to a Past (sent) and having a Past (We drove) conjoined to it. That returns to the nature of the event: (Stirring) and its position regarding the Intent aimed at by the verse (Thus is the resurrection). This Intent is not present in the verse of Ar-Rum (v: 48), although it is in what follows it (v: 50). Al-Biqa'i says, revealing the face of expression with the Present Tense:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "When He Almighty informed that the existence of what He promised of Resurrection and other things is inevitable, and warned with every warning against taking His command lightly, and denounced equating the believer in it with the denier; and the cause of the heart-killing misguidance was Desires which cover the sky of the intellect and top it with their dark cloud, preventing it from penetration; and the cause of the clouds covering the sky [and] watering the earth reviving the dead grains was the Wind; and the cause of bringing it at one time and not another indicated Power by Choice, He said conjoining to the sentence {Indeed, the promise of Allah is truth} based on looking/reasoning, which is bringing out of non-existence, clarifying His Power over what He promised: (And Allah)... (who). Since the intent is bringing into existence from non-existence, He expressed with the Past Tense attributed to Him, because He is the Real Doer, saying: (Sent the winds) i.e., created them from nothing turbulent in it [the atmosphere], fit for turbulence and movement so He directs them how He wills, not fixed like the earth, and settled them between the horizons for the benefit of the earth's place. Since their stirring renews whenever He wants to water a land, He said attributing it to the winds; because they are the cause, expressing with the Present Tense narrating the state, to summon that marvelous image indicating complete Power. This is how Arabs do in matters containing wonder for the listener, urging him to contemplate and imagine it (so they stir up) i.e., by His moving them if He wills (clouds) i.e., that He Almighty ran His Sunnah that His wisdom appears gradually. Since the intent is deducing the Ability for Resurrection, and expression with the Present Tense refutes obstinacy, He expressed with the Present Tense. Since driving clouds to one land and not another and watering a place and not another is of a status of greatness, He turned from the third person [singular] and put it in the manifestation of Greatness [plural/royal we], saying (and We drove it) i.e., the clouds, expressing with the Past Tense to alert that every driving was after their stirring in the past and future from Him alone or through the mediation of those of His soldiers of angels or others He established for that, not from anyone else. He indicated that there is no difference between far and near by the particle of destination, saying (to a dead land).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And since the cause of life is the clouds due to the water arising from them, He said: {and gave life thereby to the earth}. And since the intent is guiding them to the Ability for Resurrection which they deny, He said removing metaphor by every estimation and clarifying the depiction with every clarification: (after its lifelessness... thus is... the Resurrection)" (1). "Al-Biqa'i" noticed the signification of the Present Tense in depicting the event, and establishing it before the eyes of the addressee as if it is happening, so nothing blocks him from insight into it and taking a lesson except a barrier from his own self. The expression came with the Present Tense in the verb whose event in the universe is most indicative of the occurrence of the Resurrection for which the context is set, which is the event of Stirring (so they stir up). This Stirring is like the stirring of the dead from their graves. He who stirred clouds to revive a dead land with them is capable of stirring the dead from their graves in that land. So the Present Tense here was the one capable of achieving the Intent, and it was the most friendly to the context. That it was preceded by a past tense and followed by a past tense did not prevent establishing it in its station, for sterile formal consistency does not repel the care for establishing noble, generous semantic consistency. It is not important, then, to say that the Present Tense depicts the event and summons it before the eyes of the addressee, but the most important thing is realizing the consistency between the context, the intent, and the verb selected for the diversion from Past to Present to occur in it. Not every verb of the verse's verbs is fit for that diversion from Past to Present to occur in it; rather, the reference in this is to the nature of this verb's event and its relationship to the context and the purpose for which the speech is set.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: It is clear that some rhetoricians consider such Rhetorical Derivation based on diverting from "Past" in (sent the winds) to "Present" in (so they stir up clouds) as a type of *Iltifat* (Enallage/Shift), which is of the boldness of Arabic. They do not restrict "Iltifat" to changing types of "Pronouns" referring to the same referent, as holds the majority of rhetoricians. Among those who count such a verse as "Iltifat" is "Al-Diya ibn al-Athir" (d. 637 AH) in "Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir", and I have detailed the discussion on his methodology in my book {Reading in Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir}. *** "Al-Biqa'i" contemplates the position of the "Present Tense" between two Active Participles (Subject Nouns) in the saying of the Truth Almighty {Indeed, Allah is the cleaver (*Faliq*) of grain and date seeds. He brings out (*Yukhriju*) the living from the dead and brings out (*Mukhrij*) the dead from the living. That is Allah; so how are you deluded?} (Al-An'am: 95). He points out that the meaning of (*Faliq* of grain and date seeds) is its originator and splitter for crops and plants. He expressed it that way because the thing before its existence was non-existent, and the mind imagines and fancies from non-existence a continuous darkness. When it is brought out from pure non-existence and sheer annihilation, it is as if, according to imagination and fancy, it split that non-existence" (1). So splitting the grain and date seeds is a type of giving life, i.e., bringing out the living from the dead, because in plants there is growth. From here, "The Truth Almighty explained the meaning of splitting and clarified it, indicating care for it time after time, by His saying 'He brings out' (*Yukhriju*) by way of renewal and continuity, affirming the matter of Resurrection (the living... from the dead)... And when its meaning was revealed and its significance became clear by bringing out things from their opposites—lest it be imagined, if nothing came out of a thing except its like, that the doer is Nature and Property—He conjoined to *Faliq*, increasing in clarification, His saying expressing with the Active Participle indicating stability, because they have no dispute regarding it, so the need did not call for expressing with the verb indicating renewal (and brings out (*Mukhrij*) the dead... from the living) (2).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The Present Tense in: (He brings out the living) reveals the reality of His saying: (cleaver/*Faliq*). In the expression with the Present Tense here is proportionality with the specific context of the verse, which is Resurrection, as is not hidden, and with the general context, the Greatest Objective of Surah "Al-An'am", which is the First Creation, and Praise to Allah for it. So He combined the two Creations: The first explicitly, and the second implicitly. At the same time, expression with the Present Tense in "He brings out the living" fits the nature of movement, renewal, and variety of the event. When the meaning of (*Faliq*) was revealed by this, He diverted to the Active Participle (*Mukhrij*) and conjoined it to the Active Participle (*Faliq*). The expression with the Active Participle in (*Mukhrij* the dead) fits also the nature of the thing brought out: "the dead", for it is stable, not moving, and finished, not renewing. It also fits the state of the addressees, for they are not in need of summoning that event before their eyes with the Present Tense to penetrate their hearts if they take heed; because they do not deny it such that the expression with the Present Tense would come announcing that He who is capable of what your eyes see is capable of what you are informed of truthfully and rightfully. Hence, the expression was with the Active Participle (bringer out of the dead) and its conjunction to the Active Participle, its counterpart (*Faliq*), not to the Present Tense before it (He brings out the living). *** Previously, the "Present Tense" came in the company of an "Active Participle". The "Present Tense" may come in the company of a "Passive Participle" as in the saying of Allah Almighty: {Be patient over what they say and remember Our servant, David, the possessor of strength; indeed, he was one who repeatedly turned back [to Allah]. * Indeed, We subjected the mountains to praise with him (*Yusabbihna*), in the evening and sunrise. * And the birds gathered (*Mahshurah*), all of them repeating [praises] to Him. * And We strengthened his kingdom and gave him wisdom and discernment in speech.} (Sad: 17-20). He made the praising of the mountains in the form of "Present Tense" (*Yusabbihna*) and the gathering of birds in the form of Passive Participle (*Mahshurah*). In this is proportionality and brotherhood with the context and the intended meaning thereof, and the nature of the event in each, and its doer and object. Al-Biqa'i says:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Since the existence of praising from the mountains bit by bit is more wondrous, because they are inanimate, He expressed with the Present Tense verb. He said depicting that state, expressing with the feminine pronoun to indicate that after their hardness, they became in extreme softness and looseness, each mountain of them praising with a voice unlike the voice of the other, because that is closer to distinguishing and knowing the praising of each individually 'they praise (*yusabbihna*)'. He did not say 'praising (*musabbiha*)' or 'she praises (*tusabbihu*)'; lest it be thought that their praising is with one voice confusing the matter in some of them. It can be [grammatically] a new sentence (Ist'inaf), or a circumstantial phrase (Hal) meaning that they yield to him with praising in word and state, the yielding of a chosen one obeying him. Since it was in the context of Returning (*Awbah*), and the end of the day is the time of return for everyone accustomed to what he is accustomed to, while it is a time of lethargy and resting from troubles, He said: 'in the evening' i.e., strengthening the worker and reminding the heedless. And since it was in the context of Overflow and honoring with the Quran, He said: 'and sunrise (*Ishraq*)' i.e., the time of the sun's elevation when people spread out. *Ishraq* is not the rising of the sun (*Tulu'*), but its clarity and light; its rising is *Shuruq*... And when He Almighty informed of subjecting the heaviest and most stable things to him, He followed it with the lightest and most mobile of them. He expressed regarding them with the Noun indicating gathering all at once and stability, because it is more indicative of Power. He said expressing with the Collective Noun instead of the Plural to indicate that in the intensity of gathering, they are like one thing. He mentioned their state in a description suitable for the singular and made it feminine to indicate what preceded of looseness necessary for females, necessitating the utmost obedience and acceptance of the disposition of rulings 'and the birds' i.e., We subjected them to him while being 'gathered (*mahshurah*)' i.e., collected to him by compulsion from every side all at once, by what the expression with the Noun instead of the Verb indicated. It is more indicative of Power, while they are more flighty than your people and harder to control than them...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: 'All' i.e., every single one of the mountains and birds 'to him is returning (*awwab*)' i.e., constantly returning; for the sake of 'David' peace be upon him specifically, from its familiar habits, not in another meaning of what it is accustomed to. Whenever he returned from his ruling and what he was occupied with of creation to praising the Truth, the mountains and birds returned with him in that. He made the predicate singular [i.e., *awwab*] to indicate that in obedience in discipline, they reached the limit as if they were a single thing. He did not make it feminine to indicate the intensity of their clamor in discipline and its greatness. Singularity - also - implies ruling upon every individual; had it been pluralized, the possibility would arise that the judgment is on the aggregate with the restriction of being a group. As if David, peace be upon him, understands the praising of mountains and birds, and each of them submits to him if he commands it to praise. 'And whoever realizes his state, everything assists him' - said Al-Qushayri. In this is an indication to the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family and companions and abundant salutations) that: Whenever We wish, We make your people with you in subjection like this. So do not despair of them despite the severity of their aversion and the strength of their ugliness and conceit. For We made them so that you may discipline yourself with them and increase by patience over them in majesty, loftiness, elevation, and perfection, to other wisdoms that minds cannot encompass. And do not despair of their softening to you and their returning to you, for they do not exceed being like mountains in strength and hardness or birds in aversion, recklessness, and lightness. Whenever We wish, We make them for you like We made the mountains and birds with David, peace be upon him; rather their matter is easier and their affair is lighter" (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The context in which these verses descended is to provide evidence for the perfection of Power and Absolute Dominance of Allah Almighty over the universes: {How many a generation have We destroyed before them, and they called out when it was no time for escape} (Sad: 3) to the end of the verses. In conjoining His saying (Remember Our servant David...) to "Be patient" is an indication that in the story of "David", peace be upon him, is what confirms the absolute capability of Power and Dominance. Therefore, this story was selected in this location of the context, and these events from the stories of David, peace be upon him, were selected here for their great proportionality and interweaving with the context. This is of a high status in the science of Quranic Proportionality. The context, as I said, is for indicating the perfection of Power and Absolute Divine Dominance over all universes. What suits this context is highlighting the event of Praising from the mountains in the form of renewal and continuous occurrence. That is because its issuance from them once is a clear proof of Power and Dominance, so how about when it is renewing and continuous?! Is that not an elevation of the evidence for the perfection of Power and Dominance and its inimitability? What gave it that is indeed the Present Tense attributed to the mountains expressed by a feminine pronoun. It also fits the context as it suggests extreme softness and submission, while they are the most solid of solids and hardest of hard things, as "Al-Biqa'i" highlighted the appropriateness of the expression with Evening and Sunrise and the appropriateness of the order in *Yusabbihna* rather than *Tusabbihu* or *Musabbiha*. As for the event of Gathering, highlighting it in the form of Passive Participle is what responds to the context first, the nature of the event second, and the nature of birds third. The power of gathering is complete when the gathering is all at once {Your creation and your resurrection are not but as that of a single soul. Indeed, Allah is Hearing and Seeing} (Luqman: 28). It is elevated if the gathered is of a nature of lightness and aversion like birds.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And it is marvelous that highlighting the event was in the form of a derived noun, increased by being a Passive Participle whose verb is only built for the unnamed doer (passive voice), to be understood that the doer of that will be none other than Allah Almighty. And to understand that the birds, as if from the intensity of dominance over them, strive by themselves, so they are gathered. Hence the event was attributed to them. This indicated that whoever is capable of this is more capable of gathering those who are less aversive than birds. In this is evidence for the Resurrection and the Great Gathering, and the context of Resurrection in this Surah is a broad context and a paved path. The Context – then – and the nature of the event and its doer or object is what necessitates a specific form for every element, and every element in the expression is subject to the dominance of a unified principle and one spirit, which is the Context and the Greatest Objective. I have seen Al-Biqa'i lingering at many significations of the form of the Quranic word and contemplating the proportionality of the facets of this form with the Context and Intent. As if he is looking in this at the saying of Imam "Abdul Qahir": "It is not enough in the science of eloquence that you set up a measurement for it, and describe it with a general description, and say about it a general statement. Rather, you will not be of any knowledge of it until you detail the speech and acquire, and place your hand on the characteristics that appear in the order of words and count them one by one, and name them thing by thing. And your knowledge should be the knowledge of the skilled craftsman who knows the science of every thread of silk in the brocade, and every piece of carved wood in the paneled door, and every brick of the bricks in the marvelous building" (1). ***
foot_note: 1. (1) – Dala'il al-I'jaz by Abdul Qahir Al-Jurjani:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: What has passed was an examination of the abstract present and past verb forms, or those where the abstract form has no usage or predominant usage in its meaning. Thus, the statement using the abstract form was not a deviation from the augmented form for a specific purpose regarding abstractness or augmentation. I did not neglect examining the accompanying verb and noun forms, as proper contemplation requires giving them their due right of pondering proportionality in this context. This is not a form of detestable mixing, for the insight into it was not the primary driver, but rather one of the consequences of the examination. We need, after this, to attempt to contemplate the statement using the augmented present and past verbs, looking at the form of augmentation in it and the proportionality of its indication with the context and the intent for which the speech is driven. "Al-Biqa'i" pauses, contemplating the Holy Qur'anic statement using the abstract verb form (Fa'ala) regarding good deeds, and the form (Ifta'ala) regarding bad deeds in the saying of Allah Almighty: (Al-Baqarah: from Verse 286) {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity. It will have [the consequence of] what [good] it has gained, and it will bear [the consequence of] what [evil] it has earned} ... Al-Biqa'i says: "'Laha' (For it) meaning specifically for it 'ma kasabat' (what it gained); the verb is mentioned in the abstract form regarding good to imply that the mere occurrence of it is sufficient to be counted, even if done with laziness, or even the mere intention of it. 'Al-Haralli' said: The form 'Fa'ala' in the abstract expresses the minimum acquisition; therefore, whoever intends a good deed but does not do it, it is written for him as a good deed. End quote. 'Wa 'alayha' (And against it) meaning specifically against it 'ma iktasabat' (what it earned/acquired). So He conditioned the form of 'Ifti'al' regarding evil, which indicates exertion (I'timal), pointing to the fact that the nature of the self is to incline towards desire with its entirety, and that sin is not written except with determination and strong resolve. If an apparent action results from it, it is done with seriousness, energy, desire, and expansion. Therefore, whoever intends a bad deed but does not do it, it is not written against him. The expression may come contrary to that for a meaning in that context required by the situation" (1). *** And he says regarding the saying of Allah Almighty:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {Indeed, those who came with falsehood are a group among you. Do not think it bad for you; rather it is good for you. For every person among them is what [punishment] he has earned from the sin, and he who took upon himself the greater portion thereof - for him is a great punishment} (An-Nur: 11). "The form of 'Ifti'al' from 'Kasaba' is used for sin to indicate that the sin is arranged upon what involved determination and strong resolve, confirmed by action containing seriousness and energy. It was stripped [to the abstract form] regarding 'Good' to indicate that reward is written by the mere doing of good, or even the intention of it" (1). It remains to look at Al-Biqa'i's saying: "The expression may come contrary to that for a meaning in that context required by the situation." This is a high statement. The combination of "Kasaba" and "Iktasaba" did not occur in other than this noble verse. The predominant usage is the coming of the abstract verb: "Kasaba" singly, intended for good at times and intended for evil at other times. The root: "K - S - B" appeared sixty-seven times; the abstract verb appeared "sixty-two" times, and the augmented verb "Iktasaba" appeared "five" times. The abstract verb came speaking about what is a bad deed in places including His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {Yes, whoever earns [kasaba] evil and his sin has encompassed him - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally} (Al-Baqarah: 81), {Allah does not impose blame upon you for what is unintentional in your oaths, but He imposes blame upon you for what your hearts have earned [kasabat]...} (Al-Baqarah: 225), {Corruption has appeared throughout the land and sea by [reason of] what the hands of people have earned [kasabat]...} (Ar-Rum: 41), and many others. It is explicit in expressing the commission of evil with the abstract verb "Kasaba". The verb "Iktasaba" came singly with evil, as in His saying:

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {For every person among them is what [punishment] he has earned [iktasaba] from the sin...} (An-Nur: 11). As for the saying of Allah, Majestic is His Glory, in Surah An-Nisa (Verse 32): {And do not wish for that by which Allah has made some of you exceed others. For men is a share of what they have earned [iktasabu], and for women is a share of what they have earned [iktasabna]. And ask Allah of his bounty. Indeed Allah is ever, of all things, Knowing}, the augmented verb here is not restricted to good or evil, but combines them. Al-Biqa'i did not explain the appropriateness of the statement using the form "Ifta'ala" for the context and intent in Surah "An-Nisa", but he sufficed by saying: "When He forbade killing and consuming [wealth] falsely by action, which are acts of the limbs, so that the exterior becomes pure from grave sins, He forbade wishing, which is the introduction to consuming; so that it would be a prohibition of consuming by way of priority... And the prohibition here implies illicitness (Tahrim) according to most scholars. So He said: {And do not wish for that by which Allah has made some of you exceed others} meaning in inheritance and other than it from all psychological virtues related to theoretical power such as intelligence... or practical power such as chastity... or physical virtues such as health... or external virtues such as many righteous children...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: When He Almighty forbade that, He justified it with what alerts to striving in seeking provision and moderation in request... So He said, indicating that no one attains all he hopes for: (For men is a share) meaning it has been decreed, so it neither increases nor decreases. And He Almighty clarified that one should seek and work, as indicated by the Hadith, so He said: (of what they have earned [iktasabu]) meaning: they burdened themselves and tired themselves in earning it regarding the matters of the two abodes, of reward and its causes from acts of obedience, and of inheritance and striving in earnings and profits..." (1). He sufficed, as you see, with explaining the indication of this form to burden and exertion, without clarifying for us the appropriateness of the statement using the form "Ifta'ala" to the context and the intent for which the speech was formulated. *** "Al-Biqa'i" perceives in the form "Ifta'ala" when prohibition enters upon it what he does not perceive in others, as in His saying Almighty in Surah (Al-Ma'idah: 51): {O you who have believed, do not take [la tattakhidhu] the Jews and the Christians as allies. They are [in fact] allies of one another. And whoever is an ally to them among you - then indeed, he is [one] of them. Indeed, Allah guides not the wrongdoing people}. This noble verse came in the context of alienation from being involved in any loyalty to those who are upon other than what pleases the Truth, Mighty and Majestic. The verses preceding it exaggerated in that alienation which makes the hearts of those who understand tear apart in fear of being involved in any of it, even if the people of misguidance, whose vision is clouded, call out among us morning and evening with the fabrication of human brotherhood across different beliefs, and singling out the calf-worshippers and the people of the cross with extra care for that brotherhood, while they carry nothing in the darkness of their chests except hatred, rage, and malice against every Muslim.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i says: "When He clarified their stubbornness and that their enmity towards the people of this religion, which drove them to this great matter, has no enmity beyond it, He forbade those marked with Faith from allying with them; because no believer or rational person would do it after this clarification. So He said {O you who have believed}, meaning acknowledged Faith. And since a human does not ally with other than his own people except with diligence in preliminaries he performs and things he does to endear himself to those he wants to ally with, He indicated that with the form of 'Ifti'al', saying: {Do not take [la tattakhidhu]} meaning that even if that were easily attainable, you should not do it, so how about when it does not happen except by expending effort? {the Jews and the Christians as allies}, meaning relatives (close friends), doing with them what a relative does with his relative, and hoping from them the same, while they are the people who disdain and despise you the most..." (1). Al-Biqa'i looks here at the nature of the sound human being, that he is innately disposed to grant his loyalty to those of his people who stand to support him, whether wrong or wronged. And that when this comes from him towards others, it does not stem from the metal of his instinct and nature; rather, he is the one burdening himself, exerting himself for that, and carrying himself to do what he does not naturally approach without training and practice. When he performs that loyalty to those who harbor enmity towards his people, he deafens his ears and locks the doors of his heart against the call of instinct and the call of Noble Revelation, crossing numerous barriers by this deed. This is what the form of Ifti'al, in which the prohibited verb came, suggests, giving the prohibition strength and emphasis. It is increased - in my view - by the indication of strength in causing loyalty found in the root of the verb, for the root "Akhadha" (to take) comes to indicate the strength of the action and that its doer strives in causing it or that its effect is very great and profound. This is what you realize in the verbs of this root in the Holy Qur'an's statement. Thus, the significance of the form and the root combined to portray the prohibition in this verse greatly.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He pauses at a verse after it that confirms that meaning existing in that majestic prohibition. The Truth, Mighty and Majestic, says in Surah (Al-Ma'idah: 57): {O you who have believed, do not take [la tattakhidhu] those who have taken [ittakhadhu] your religion in ridicule and amusement among the ones who were given the Scripture before you and the disbelievers as allies. And fear Allah, if you should [truly] be believers}. This is from the distribution of meanings in the Holy Qur'anic statement to establish the main meaning in the hearts and direct [attention] to other meanings worthy of observation. Al-Biqa'i says: "When He Almighty alerted to the causes preventing the alliance with disbelievers and restricted alliance to Himself Almighty, that definitively produced His saying alerting to other causes directing towards disavowal of them: {O you who have believed}, meaning acknowledged Faith. He alerted with the form of Ifti'al that whoever allies with them fights his intellect to do so, following his desire, so He said {do not take [la tattakhidhu]} those who took {ittakhadhu} meaning with utmost seriousness and diligence from them "your religion... in ridicule and amusement..." (1). In the previous verse, the call contained His saying "some of them are allies of others," as if it contained an incitement for those who believed not to be less than them in this. So those who believe must be allies of one another, not allies of others. Therefore, He followed this incitement with intimidation and alienation by saying {And whoever is an ally to them among you - then indeed, he is [one] of them}. This cannot be borne by anyone with an atom of faith in his heart, because it contains a declaration of his negation from the group of those who believe and his relapse into the abyss of the Jews and Christians.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: In the second prohibition came His saying: {Those who took your religion in ridicule and amusement} to heat them up and carry them to take a stance of jealousy and dignity against having affection for one who treats Islam with ridicule and play. If you were to ask that from someone with an atom of intellect among those attributing themselves to Islam—to accept the friendship of one who mocks Islam—he would refrain and refuse that it be from him. How many of those deep in disobedience would not accept a polytheist touching his religion with mockery, even if he is drowning in deviating from its guidance and law. Defining the object with the relative noun: {Those who took your religion in ridicule and amusement} conveys significant alienation from the prohibited act. *** Among the forms that the verb frequently appears in within the Holy Qur'anic statement is the form (Tafa''ala) with the doubling of the 'Ayn' and (Tafa'ala). Al-Biqa'i turns to perceiving the proportionality of each with the context in which they stand and the intent to which the statement is driven by its expression. He contemplates the saying of Allah Almighty: {He frowned and turned away [tawalla] * Because there came to him the blind man}. He sees in this statement using the verb (tawalla) in that form an utmost honoring and kindness to our Master Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. He says: "...He signaled his praise, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that that [i.e., frowning and turning away] is contrary to what He Almighty created him upon of mercy for the poor, love for them, and joy in their proximity and companionship, by His saying (wa tawalla - and turned away). Meaning, the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, burdened himself to turn away from him hoping that those nobles he was addressing would submit [to Islam], so Islam would be strengthened by them, and their followers would submit by their submission, so the Word of Allah Almighty would rise; because (there came to him the blind man)" (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Al-Biqa'i" explained the indication of the form (Tawalla), and that even if (Abasa - Frowned) seemingly implies opposing the better option (Khilaf al-Awla), the form (Tawalla) signals praise revealing what the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was naturally disposed to. For the conjunction between the two verbs, each in a [specific] form, indicates the High Station upon which the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was. This turning away was not from him, peace be upon him, according to his natural disposition, but rather he compelled himself to do so out of concern for what serves the interest of Islam first, the interest of "Ibn Umm Maktum" may Allah be pleased with him second, and then the interest of those leaders third. What increases the meaning in exposure is the statement about the act of addressing/attending to those leaders by His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {But as for he who thinks himself without need * To him you give attention [tasadda]}. He says: "When He mentioned frowning and turning away from him, implying their opposites for the one who was approaching them, He clarified that, saying: {As for he who thinks himself without need} meaning sought wealth, which is money and riches, and found it, even if he did not fear or come to you {To him you give attention [tasadda]} meaning you expose yourself by turning to him and striving in admonishing him hoping for his submission and the submission of his followers by his submission... He indicated by deleting the 'Ta' of Tafa''ul in the reading of the majority and assimilating it in the reading of 'Nafi' and 'Ibn Kathir' that this was done in a light manner, as is the habit of wise people..." (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This selection of the verb root, then its form, then its performance in two ways: Deletion and Assimilation, contains an indication of great honoring of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and praise for him regarding his profound concern for the Call and its affair, advising his people, and his love of good for all people even if they were among those who strove to harm him. All of this is proportionate to the general context of the Surah which stands on meanings of honoring and great praise; it is praise in the form of admonishment. This is from Al-Biqa'i an utmost achievement in analyzing and interpreting the elements of the Qur'anic statement in a manner that makes his methodology worthy of being a beacon guiding the ways of rhetorical analysis of forms of literary creativity in poetry and prose, and before that the High Miraculous Statement in the Qur'an and Sunnah. He addresses the form of the verb (Tazakka) and its proportionality with the context, saying: "Since his action was the action of one who fears there might be blame upon him for their remaining in disbelief, He clarified to him that he is safe from that, saying Almighty: {And not upon you if he does not purify himself [yazzakka]} at all and from the start, even the slightest purification - indicated by the assimilation - for upon you is only the notification. It is possible that it is an interrogation (Istifham), meaning: And what thing is upon you in his lack of purification? In it is an indication that it is obligatory to strive in purifying the follower from whom acceptance is known" (1). In the form (Tazakka: Tafa''ala) is an indication that this purification will not come from that person addressed by the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, which prepares him to leave excess in addressing him, so he does not burden himself beyond what he is tasked with. Al-Biqa'i perceived the face of interrogation in this sentence and its harmony also with the indication of negation on this compassion for the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: "Al-Biqa'i" pauses at the statement using the verb (Talahha: Tafa''ala) and the wondrous rhetorical proportion between the meaning of its root and form and the deletion occurring in it, and the context and the Greatest Objective of the Surah. He says: "When He mentioned the self-sufficient one, He mentioned his opposite, so He Almighty said: {But as for he who came to you striving [for knowledge] * While he fears [Allah] * From him you are distracted [talahha]} meaning specifically in that gathering; being in reality (talahha) meaning you occupy yourself; for the sake of those nobles... a light occupation as indicated by deleting the 'Ta' from 'Laha 'anhu' (distracted from him) like 'Radiya' (was content): when he was consoled, heedless, and left it. In expressing it this way is an indication that occupying oneself with those [nobles] has no benefit based on what the conjugations of the root imply, and that he who seeks the human and steps over people's necks to reach him has a great right upon you" (1). Deleting the "Ta" from the form of "Tafa''ul" in the verb (Talahha) - He did not say (Tatalahha) - and advancing the prepositional phrase (from him - 'anhu') indicate dazzlingly that he, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did not do that except with the one regarding whom he was admonished, and that he would not have done so were it not for his concern for what contained the Highest Good according to human estimations. The deletion of the "Ta" is a sign that this action is neither firmly established in him nor is he reckless in committing it. It is wondrous that the deletion was of a letter of meaning having prominence in its form; this suggests the verb losing the specific semantic characteristic of this form. So there was a difference between the 'Talahha' of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the 'Talahha' of others.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: His turning to the face of selecting the root (Laha) instead of (Shaghala - busy) and that he - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - did not engage in any amusement (Lahw) accustomed to by others, but rather was upholding the interest of the Call. However, the Holy Qur'an portrayed this care for inviting those leaders in the image of amusement (Lahw) looking at its outcome, not looking at the state of its doer. This contains great dispraise and profound satire for those leaders, and a notification that any struggle with their likes in inviting them to Islam will not bear fruit and that its outcome is the outcome of amusement (Talahhi). When that word touched the hearing of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, his heart found rest from fear that he might be blamed for abandoning some struggle in his call. For a person to be admonished for excess in diligence and burdening the self beyond what it is commanded is more honorable than being admonished for negligence. The admonishment of the Holy Qur'an to the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, never came regarding anything except what was by way of excess in diligence in the Call and excess mercy and kindness {There has certainly come to you a Messenger from among yourselves. Grievous to him is what you suffer; [he is] concerned over you and to the believers is kind and merciful} (At-Tawbah: 128). *** Masculinity and Femininity in Arabic have principles necessitating their obligation, prohibition, or permissibility. Rhetorical study is not concerned with what is obligatory or prohibited of them, but aims at what involved choice, so that the taster can perceive the rhetoric of the selected face. The science of Rhetoric is the science of the philosophy and interpretation of the faces of choice between available alternatives in expressing meanings, because there is no virtue until you see in the matter a manufacture and until you find a way to selection.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Some scholars of rhetoric consider looking into masculinity and femininity as chapters of the 'Courage of Arabic' and a type of 'Iltifat' (Grammatical Shift), as is known to beginning students of knowledge from Ibn Jinni and after him Ibn al-Athir in 'Al-Mathal Al-Sa'ir'. If the later rhetoricians of the Miftah school did not care much for this, it is not a sign of rhetoricians neglecting masculinity and femininity. The selected Masculinity and Femininity in the Qur'anic statement is apparent to every reciter, calling upon him to contemplate it, for beneath it are treasures of subtle meanings. You see that in the saying of Allah Almighty: {Then, is one against whom the word of punishment has come true [haqqa - masc.] - can you save one who is in the Fire?} (Az-Zumar: 19) and His saying Almighty (Az-Zumar: 71): The verb (Haqqa) came masculine despite being attributed to (Kalimah - Word) which is metaphorically feminine; Arabic allows both matters in it, and the predominant in general speech is the feminization of the verb attributed to it. He deviated in the verse from that frequent predominance for a matter proportionate to the context and intent. That is because "when He Almighty singled out the glad tidings for the doers of good [from the beginning of His saying: For those who have done good... Those are the people of understanding (Verses 10-18)], it was known that others were judged with misery. And he, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, due to what he was naturally disposed to of great mercy and abundant compassion, was worthy of sorrow for those who turned away [{Then perhaps you would kill yourself through grief over them, [O Muhammad], if they do not believe in this message, [and] out of sorrow} (Al-Kahf: 6) and {Perhaps you would kill yourself through grief that they will not be believers} (Ash-Shu'ara: 3)...

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: {So do not let yourself go out in regrets for them. Indeed, Allah is Knowing of what they do} (Fatir: 8). He caused by his sorrow for them: (Then is one against whom has come true [haqqa]) and He dropped the 'Ta' of feminization indicating softness to emphasize the prohibition of sorrow for them (the word of punishment) by his refusal and turning away, so he was because of that immersed in the Fire which We decreed as the recompense of the wicked; he cannot be saved from it" (1). He points to the effect of the indication of feminization in portraying their lack of deserving sorrow for them, while the punishment has become true upon them, indeed they were in it. This portrayal fits the indication of Interrogation in (Afaman - Then is one who) and (Afa'anta - Can you), and advancing the pronoun (Anta - You) over the verbal predicate, and portraying them as being in the Fire even though they are alive (even if they are, in my view, in a moral fire eating their humanity and relationship with their Lord). All that is to emphasize His prohibition to him, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding sorrow for them, that sorrow issuing from the heart of the Compassionate Merciful Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. So it was imperative to bring out all elements of the statement in a profoundly effective image, to correspond with the great sorrow for them from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. In this is increased praise for him for his compassion for his nation, even those who stubbornly opposed. *** And the statement came with the verb masculine while the subject is feminine plural, and the predominant is feminizing the verb with this subject, in the saying of Allah Almighty: {And do not be like those who became divided and differed after the clear proofs had come to them [ja'ahum al-bayyinat]. And those will have a great punishment} (Al-Imran: 105). The verse came in the context of guiding the Ummah to hold fast to the Book of Allah Almighty, calling to good, enjoining right, and forbidding wrong so that success is realized for them.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: He affirms this by forbidding the opposite of what He commanded them, saying: {And do not be like those who became divided and differed...}. Al-Biqa'i clarifies for us the proportionality of the masculine verb (Ja'a) with the context and the good outcome the verses carry to the Ummah: "...When He commanded them with that, He confirmed it by forbidding what opposes it, alluding to those regarding whom these verses were revealed from the People of the Book, rebuking them for their misguidance and difference in their religion against their prophets. So He said {And do not be like those who became divided...} by what they innovated in the principles of their religion, and by what they committed of sins... And since division might be physical only while agreeing in opinions, He clarified that the matter is not so, saying: {and differed...} by what bore for them the hatred carrying them to accept the state of one who is thought to be united while their hearts are divided. And when He dispraised them with difference which reason indicates is blameworthy, He increased in declaring its ugliness by [stating] that they differed in it after the prohibition of reason and clear transmission (Naql), saying: {after the clear proofs had come to them [min ba'di ma ja'ahum]} and He magnified it by stripping it of feminization {al-bayyinat - the clear proofs}..." (1). In the masculinization of the verb (Ja'a) is great eloquence in portraying the People of the Book as unfit for anyone with an atom of reason and understanding to follow in their actions and opinions. For they opposed clear reason and authentic transmission. The coming of the statement to them was nothing but a strong, clear coming not obscured to anyone with eyes. Despite this, they differed and divided. So how can a Muslim take from these people an example in any matter of his religion, and leave what is in the guidance of the Book and Sunnah?

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Importing systems of governance, economic, and social life from outside our lands is - by what the masculinization of the verb "Ja'a" indicated - among the most astray matters and furthest from the guidance of Allah Almighty; a distance that might signal what is hidden in the chests of those importers of those systems of aversion to the guidance of the Book and Sunnah. Such people, after clarifying the matter to them in a way leaving no room for pause, are more deserving to be exiled from positions of guardianship and authority. *** This which Al-Biqa'i contemplated and perceived is most fitting for the rhetorical understanding of the verses of the Wise Reminder. He is, in such matters, superior to many of the predecessors, and those who came after him. The summary of speech in this is that Masculinity and Femininity in the Holy Qur'an contain an overflow of subtle meanings that draws insights to caring for contemplating it, and that scholars counting it among the chapters of the 'Courage of Arabic' is for one who understands what it contains of wondrous statement. *** Closely related to the Courage of Arabic in the Wise Reminder is singularizing what the apparent situation indicates should be plural, or pluralizing what the apparent situation indicates should be singular. That is deviating the statement from the apparent situation in coordination with the context and for the intent for which the speech is established. It is clear that Plural is what opposes Singular, so Dual enters into it because in Dual there is a gathering of two things, and the guidance of Prophethood is that two are a congregation (Jama'ah), and what we approve in prayer we approve in statement. An example is the saying of Allah Almighty: {And give good tidings to those who believe and do righteous deeds that they will have gardens in which rivers flow. Every time they are fed with a fruit from them as provision, they say, "This is what we were fed with before." And it is given to them in likeness. And they will have therein purified spouses [azwaj mutahharah], and they will abide therein eternally} (Al-Baqarah: 25).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The description of the plural (Azwaj - spouses/wives) came singular (Mutahharah - purified), while the apparent requirement implies saying (Mutahharat). But the statement deviated from it to the singular to indicate that although they are multiple in Paradise, they are on a uniform path in purity, and to repel the suspicion that in their multiplicity they are tainted with what wives of this world are tainted with when multiple for a husband of bad character. So it indicated that in their multiplicity, they are upon the heart of a single wife; no deficiency and no variance. That is the peak of enjoyment. As if He removed from the multiplicity of wives in Paradise the corruption like He removed from wine in Paradise. Al-Biqa'i says: "When He mentioned the dwelling which is the place of pleasure and followed it with food intended essentially, and the pleasure of the dwelling is not complete except with the intimacy of a neighbor, especially one enjoyed, He said (And they will have therein) meaning with that (spouses). And since they are of one character with no deficiency in it, He indicated it by unifying the adjective, and emphasized that by expressing with the form 'Taf'il' (Mutahharah) to inform that work was done on it, work of exaggeration such that there is no hope for increase, so He said (Mutahharah)..." (1). Al-Biqa'i's view in singularizing (Mutahharah) is higher than the view of those saying that singular and plural here are two eloquent dialects (2), for this does not suffice in the rhetorical understanding of what the Holy Qur'an selected. And higher than the view that Singular is lighter than Plural, so if they combine they avoid heaviness by shifting to Singular (3), for such a view is critiqued by His saying Almighty: (Ayat Bayyinat - Clear Verses), (Al-Muhsanat Al-Mu'minat - Believing Chaste Women), (Fatayatikum Al-Mu'minat - Your Believing Girls), where it was linguistically valid to say (Al-Ayat Al-Bayyinah, Al-Muhsanat Al-Mu'minah, and Al-Fatayat Al-Mu'minah). *** And the singular of (Dar - Abode/Home) comes in the saying of Allah Almighty: {So the earthquake seized them, and they became within their home [dar] fallen prone} (Al-A'raf: 78, 91), and its plural (Diyar) in His saying Almighty: (Hud: 67) {And the shriek seized those who had wronged, and they became within their homes [diyar] fallen prone}.

1. (1) - Nazm al-Durar: 1 /196 
2. - Ibid: Al-Kashshaf: 1/262, Anwar al-Tanzil by Al-Baydawi and footnote of Al-Shihab Al-Khafaji: 2 /45 
3. - Al-Tahrir wa al-Tanwir by Al-Tahir bin Ashur: 1 /357..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: And His saying Mighty and Majestic: {And the shriek seized those who had wronged, and they became within their homes [diyar] fallen prone} (Yunus: 94). Al-Biqa'i says: "Perhaps singularizing 'Ad-Dar' here - i.e., in Al-A'raf - with the Earthquake (Rajfah) in the story of Salih and Shu'ayb peace be upon them in His saying (and they became within their home) meaning their dwellings, and pluralizing it in the two stories in Surah Hud peace be upon him is to indicate the magnitude of the earthquake and the shriek in the two places. That is because the earthquake, if it is in a single thing, is more firmly established, so it is greater in the intended exemplary punishment. And the shriek, its nature is spreading; so if it encompasses distant places and remote abodes, destroying their people, tearing apart their group, and scattering their unity, it is of excessive strength and extreme severity such that souls are disturbed by contemplating its description and hearts palpitate for it. The summary is that where He expressed with 'Rajfah' (Earthquake), He unified 'Ad-Dar' to indicate the severity of punishment by the greatness of the shaking. And where He expressed with 'Sayhah' (Shriek/Cry), He pluralized to imply the generality of death by the intensity of the sound. There is no contradiction; because their punishment was by both, and perhaps one was the cause for the other. Perhaps the intended meaning of 'Rajfah' is the agitation of hearts, an agitation that cut them, or that the abode shook, so the hearts shook, which is closer. 'Al-A'raf' was singled out with what was mentioned in it; because its objective is warning those who turn away, and the 'Rajfah' causes greater panic due to lack of familiarity with it (1). And he says in Surah Hud: "The secret of expressing with 'Diyar' (plural) with the Shriek, and 'Dar' (singular) with the Earthquake in 'Al-A'raf' has preceded. 'Hud' was singled out with what was mentioned in it; because its objective is greater with regard to detailing, and both 'Diyar' and 'Sayhah' are closer to that" (2). Al-Biqa'i looks in his interpretation and contemplation at the relationship of the effect to the affected (the place) and to the objective of the Surah: In Al-A'raf, the effect is the Earthquake, and when it is in a proximate place (Dar), it is greater and more severe in effect. This fits the Surah dedicated to Warning, as explicitly stated in its opening.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The Cry is an effect the nature of which is spreading, and spreading is a cause for weakening. So if it spread and yet destroyed, this indicates its great power. So the Plural (Diyar) was more indicative of its power. This spreading indicating the greatness of the effect is more suitable to the objective of Surah "Hud" which is Detailing, explicitly stated in its opening. It becomes clear to you that what "Al-Biqa'i" went to in explaining the proportionality between singularizing (Dar) and the statement using 'Rajfah' with the context in Surah "Al-A'raf" and its objective; and explaining the proportionality between pluralizing (Dar) and the statement using 'Sayhah' with the context in Surah (Hud) and its objective. You hardly find this with many of his predecessors - and I fear to say his successors - which confirms what he went to that "due to the difference in objectives of Surahs, the orders of stories and their wordings change according to the style useful for indicating that objective" (1) and "that every Surah in which a story is repeated is for a meaning claimed in that Surah evidenced by that story other than the meaning for which it was driven in the previous Surah. From here the words differed according to those purposes, and the orders changed by delaying, advancing, brevity, and elongation, while nothing of that contradicts the original meaning by which the story was formed" (2). *** Then comes the plural of paucity in the saying of Allah Almighty: {Indeed, Abraham was a [comprehensive] leader, devoutly obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth, and he was not of those who associate others with Allah. * [He was] grateful for His favors [An'um]. He chose him and guided him to a straight path} (An-Nahl: 120-121).

1. (1) - Masa'id al-Nazar by Al-Biqa'i: 1 /152 
2. - Nazm al-Durar: 1 /14..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Al-Biqa'i contemplates the face of proportionality in pluralizing the blessing as (An'um - few blessings) despite the fact that the blessings of Allah Almighty upon the Father of Prophets, our master Abraham peace be upon him, are very many and uncountable, saying: ""When He called them to noble morals and forbade them from bad ones by His acceptance of whoever turns to Him, even if his crime is great, answering the call of their father (Abraham) peace be upon him in His saying Mighty and Majestic: {So whoever follows me - then he is of me; and whoever disobeys me - indeed, You are [yet] Forgiving and Merciful} (Ibrahim: from Verse 36), He followed that by mentioning him to encourage following him in Tawhid and inclining with the Command and Prohibition in proceeding and refraining if they were of those who follow the truth or imitate the fathers. So He said by way of reasoning for what preceded {Indeed, Abraham was a [comprehensive] leader, devoutly obedient to Allah, inclining toward truth}. And since the context is for establishing perfection for Abraham peace be upon him... AND HE WAS NOT OF THE POLYTHEISTS... GRATEFUL) and since Allah Mighty and Majestic has uncountable blessings upon one whom He made a leader (Ummah), He clarified that all of that is little beside His Bounty. So He said: indicating that with the plural of paucity, and that the thankful for the little gives thanks if the much comes to him by way of priority (for His favors [li-an'umihi]) (1).

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: The context of the verse - as Al-Biqa'i points out - is to urge the disbelievers to be truthful in correcting what they claimed of adopting a general rule they adhere to in their lives: their following the path of the fathers out of righteousness and obedience to them. So the Holy Qur'an clarified to them that the most rightful of fathers to be followed is the father of all Arabs and the highest of them: Abraham peace be upon him. And he was not of the polytheists in any face of polytheism, indicated by deleting the (Nun) from the present verb (Yaku - was). So what is wrong with them that they disobeyed him and opposed him by their polytheism and turning away from his law and method to the law and method of one who is lower than him and inferior? So the situation required reaching the limit in elevating the status of Abraham their father, peace be upon him, perhaps they would follow him in his Tawhid and gratitude to Allah Almighty. He is thankful for the few blessings, so how about him being thankful for the many? That is truly great as decreed by the indication of the concept of agreement (Mawafaqah) which is a way of expression in their clear Arabic tongue. In expressing his being thankful for His (few) favors over his being thankful for His (many) favors is a following of the path of alerting by the lower to the higher. ***** Al-Biqa'i, as you saw, is keen on looking into the indication of words and their significations upon it, whether hidden in them from their etymological family or existing in them from their form and compositional structure. The word for him has numerous tributaries in its indication of its rhetorical meaning. The summary is that although I elaborated on this feature more than others, I did not fulfill pointing, mere pointing, to a tenth of what enters into Al-Biqa'i's interpretation of the Holy Qur'anic statement. Interval..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: Those are some features of a methodology in interpreting the Holy Qur'anic statement. It is not hidden that I did not encompass all features related to his methodology in interpreting the Great Qur'anic statement directly, like his view on styles of simile, metaphor, metonymy, rhetorical embellishment, and other things. For I was not one to exhaust pointing to them, let alone exhaust explaining them. If I have left explaining what was of this nature, there are also other features of lower rank than what I mentioned. Of that is his care for some issues of Qur'anic Orthography (Rasm); he seeks to contemplate it in light of the context and intent, even if he does not do this frequently. Some forms of Qur'anic orthography are worthy of pausing at and contemplating, but he passes them. Among those features also is citing Prophetic Hadith while clarifying their sources, and pointing to what was weak among them sometimes. He cares for explaining Reasons for Revelation (Asbab al-Nuzul), and uses them to perceive the appropriateness of the verse to its context and the objective of its Surah, even in perceiving the understanding of the Compositional and Ordinal Order in the verse. Al-Biqa'i, in his referring to Reasons for Revelation, was not referring to them to take them as a cause for explaining the face of the verse's proportion in its location with its context, for this proportion has another face or faces. He says regarding the saying of Allah Almighty: {Allah does not impose blame upon you for what is unintentional in your oaths...} (Al-Ma'idah: from Verse 89) after interpreting the verse preceding it: "And eat of what Allah has provided for you." He said: "When - as Al-Baghawi and others reported from 'Ibn Abbas' may Allah be pleased with them - this verse was revealed, they said: O Messenger of Allah, how should we deal with our oaths that we swore? They had sworn on what they agreed upon (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) - He means what concerned the Companions who covenanted on a matter, some of them resolved to fast and not break it, and some resolved to pray at night and not sleep...] ..

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: As preceded, so Allah Almighty revealed: 'Allah does not impose blame upon you' meaning upon what belongs to Him of complete Majesty (for what is unintentional) which is what the tongue utters without intent (in your oaths). Note that I did not rely on the reason for revelation in the appropriateness except for its entry into the meaning, not for being a cause. For not every cause enters into appropriateness... The cause was here entering into the appropriateness of the Order; because prohibiting what is permitted is sometimes by vow and sometimes by oath. Vowing regarding the permissible - which is our issue - is not binding and its expiation is the expiation of an oath. Then, there was no need except to define oaths and their rulings. So He Almighty divided them into two parts: intended and unintended. As for the unintended, it has no consideration. As for the intended, it is two parts: swearing on a past, and swearing on a future. As for swearing on the past, it is the False Oath (Ghamus) which has no expiation according to some scholars... As for swearing on the future - which is where prohibition can occur - He mentioned its ruling here by His saying (But He imposes blame upon you) (1). *** Among the main features that "Al-Biqa'i" was keen on in his Tafsir is his quoting the essay of "Abu Ja'far bin al-Zubair" in his book "Al-Burhan fi Tartib Suwar al-Qur'an" (The Proof in the Arrangement of Quranic Surahs). He does this in all Surahs, and does not comment on what he quoted from him, as if he makes the speech of "Ibn al-Zubair" complementary to his speech or explaining another face of the faces of linking between Surahs. We are in need of someone to undertake a scientific study analyzing the methodology of "Ibn al-Zubair" in explaining the miraculousness of the rhetoric of Surah arrangement, and someone to undertake afterwards comparing his methodology in this with the methodology of "Al-Biqa'i", for that is something we are in dire need of. *** Likewise, Al-Biqa'i was keen on quoting chapters from the treatises of "Abu al-Hasan al-Haralli", almost including in his Tafsir those treatises which: "Al-Haralli" made regarding the principles of understanding the Holy Qur'an. These treatises are: Miftah al-Bab al-Muqfal fi Fahm al-Kitab al-Munazzal (Key to the Locked Door in Understanding the Revealed Book). 'Urwat Miftah al-Bab al-Muqfal (Handle of the Key to the Locked Door). At-Tawshiyah wa at-Tawfiyah.

book_title: Imam Al-Biqa'i and His Methodology in Interpreting the Rhetoric of the Qur'an
text: This makes Al-Biqa'i's Tafsir a source for verifying these valuable treatises, which are worthy of care. I had started this, but I have not yet been successful in finishing it. "Al-Haralli" has a distinct methodology worthy of being dedicated to by a specialist in the science of Philology (Fiqh al-Lughah). I guarantee that he will find in "Al-Haralli's" work in this what he will not find with many others. *** He was also extremely careful in quoting from the Torah, the Gospel, and the Psalms. He may compare between copies of the Torah or Gospel, specifying the copy from which he quotes, and he may digress in quoting, reaching numerous pages.
